title: Don't go by the HBO show
body: Don't go by the HBO show! This book is well worth reading. I love a great character study and this book ranks pretty high, the twists and turns of the love and hate within this town kept me wanting to know what was going to happen next.

author: Juan Fajardo
title: Two Stars
body: Did not lived for the hipe.

author: Teebyrd
title: A great read!
body: I thought this book was terific!  I loved the interaction of the characters and their gossipy nature.  I had read other reviews saying there were too many characters to keep up with but I disagree as they all play a role in the story.  This was excellent !

author: B. Nicolai
title: Two Stars
body: I loved her "Harry Potter"books but this was depressing with very little light at the end of the tunnel.

author: Jacquie
title: GOOD READ. NOT HP.
body: My second reading as I was following the series on tv. the author really knows her folks and the dynamics of the "small town". I definitely found myself liking and disliking various characters in the story. it is not possible to be remote from the drama or the people. j k rowling is a fine writer.

author: MamaDurk
title: I just couldn't.
body: I've tried for the past year to finish this book. I'm about a third of the way through, and just couldn't pick out a plot. Recently, my husband saw that hbo had it as a 3 episode mini series. We watched it, hoping it would get my interest up enough to get back into the book. After watching all three episodes, my husband suggested I just pitch the book. I have no plans to finish the book.

author: JC Shaw
title: Five Stars
body: Loved it.

author: Staci
title: She's a great writer, especially when she has likable characters
body: She's a great writer, especially when she has likable characters. The problem with this book is that you don't really like any of the characters.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Potterville grows up
body: Jk writes and you need to read it, that's all I have to say!

author: shirley debalsi
title: Five Stars
body: Thank you

author: Regina Hamilton
title: Soul crushing
body: There has been a lot of bad reviews on this book. So many, that I was hesitant to read it. I am so glad I finally did. Rowling's unequaled skill in building an immersive world full of detailed characters that she displayed in the Harry Potter series definitely comes through in this book. It is not, however, a feel good story. There is no clear cut good and evil. This book left me in tatters emotionally. It is a rare author that can elicit such strong emotion from their readers. I loved this book.

author: Pauline Hogan
title: quick read
body: It was an ok book .  Quick read.  Good summer read.  Drags in some parts.  Interesting characters with interesing personalities

author: Debs
title: Forget the fact that she wrote Harry Potter - this is well written but not fun
body: I purposely waited a while to review this book to allow my initial disappointment with it to subside and then read it again. I fully admit that I read The Casual Vacancy because I am a massive Harry Potter fan and was keen to get my hands on Rowling's next work. If you are like me in that regard and thinking of reading The Casual Vacancy, I strongly urge you to do your best to forget that this is the same author who created Harry Potter. Rowling's debut novel for an adult audience is tragically devoid of any of the wonder I experienced reading her HP series. Although I was not expecting The Casual Vacancy to be similar by any means, I was hoping to be dazzled by it as I was by her previous novels and their characters. I wasn't. And that was surely her point.

author: jan
title: Relentless Suspense
body: Just loved it.  Slowly, and carefully the reader got to know the characters.  Seemed like very true human emotions brought out.  The good and the bad.  When the closing part of the book began, it was very fast and covered every and all questions about characters.  Very good, and sorry to have it end.

author: Arbor Dell
title: An engrossing surprise
body: Clockwork Orange meets Lord of the Flies. Not what you would expect from this author, and not an easy book to get into. Uncomfortable and edgy, but worth the effort.

author: Kathleen R. Coates
title: Worth the wait
body: Although I enjoyed this book, the pace was rather slow.  I enjoyed the character development.  The last few chapters were worth the wait.  I an looking forward to the upcoming series.

author: Patricia Payne
title: I didn't like any of the characters and considered putting the book ...
body: The writing is the ONLY thing that kept me reading...I didn't like any of the characters and considered putting the book down several times, but due to the genius of J.K....I just kept reading...

author: NoOneYouKnow
title: Author Catharsis
body: Most of the one star reviews are from HP fans who were hoping for Harry Potter Goes to College or something like that.  This is the exact opposite.  Filled with poverty, abuse, sex and drugs and everything else only for mature audiences.  Very raw.  I understand Rowling needed to tell this story as an act of catharsis.  I think the subject may have been too close to home. Rowling is a good writer but  the narrative is jumbled and there are too many minor characters to keep track of.  A good, quick read.

author: Fiona Jeanne Purcell
title: Five Stars
body: fantastic book

author: Jean Stradling
title: Five Stars
body: love the fast service and the product was perfect

author: Greg S. Churilov
title: Excellent writing style
body: Excellent writing style, utterly depressing book. The story describes a sh*tty little town full of small-minded, petty people who live in quiet desperation. At the start of the book, something awful happens. A few hundred pages later, something awful happens.

author: jtingermany
title: the plot moves along nicely and though i disliked most of the narrators
body: Having seen the mixed reviews, I wasn't sure what to expect, though it's immediately clear that Rowling has an entirely different voice from her Harry Potter novels (which I enjoyed). However, her characters just aren't very likeable, which a few exceptions. The small town of Pagford is filled with bitter, little people who mostly try to use Fairbrother's death for their own gains. Having said that, the plot moves along nicely and though i disliked most of the narrators, I was driven to finish it.

author: Heather Guran
title: Slow moving but enjoyable
body: Enjoyed the story but it was a bit more slow moving of a narrative than what I wished it to have been. It wasn't until the last half that I really was able to feel akin to characters.

author: Carolyn Lopez
title: Brilliant!
body: Don't give up on this book as you try to untangle the characters. I'm sure all of us are in there somewhere. Hmmm. Why do I feel guilty?

author: Kerry J. Chinnick
title: ... and it didn't fulfil my basic requirement for a good read. It must make me want to turn ...
body: I only read half the book (no haven't read Harry Potter) and it didn't fulfil my basic requirement for a good read.  It must make me want to turn the page to find out what is next and this one doesn't do it for me.  I couldn't follow the number of characters, lost track of who was who.  And as another comment compared it to say 1984, well I read that and I was hooked on finding out how it turned out.  There is no hook in this one, it plods along from one unlikeable character to another.

author: Charles Guerriero
title: Not her best effort
body: Somewhat convoluted and too many characters that don't pay an integral role in the main plot... Bring back Cormoran Strike

author: Mirza Borogovac
title: To enjoy Casual Vacancy you need to lobotomize part of your brain where your memories of Harry Potter are stored
body: A lot of people gave this book bad review because they were expecting Harry Potter. This book is nothing like Harry Potter. It's not just that the story is different, but the style, the way it's narrated, characters,  are all radically different. Two books are so different that it is hard to believe that Casual Vacancy and Harry Potter are product of the same mind. If harry potter is kind of similar to Narnia, than Casual vacancy is kind of similar to movie Requiem for a Dream.

author: joyce l. cundy
title: with great insight into the psyche of the characters
body: Extremely well written, with great insight into the psyche of the characters, but also a little too realistic and sad in its outcome.

author: Sandy Hines
title: Three Stars
body: Somewhat disappointed in this.

author: Franklin the Mouse
title: Lives Of Quiet And Not So Quiet Desperation
body: Many initial reviews I read about Ms. Rowling's first work outside of the Harry Potter world were tepid at best. It's what caused me to shy away from reading 'The Casual Vacancy.' Fortunately, curiosity got the better of me and I finally read the darned thing. It's hard for me to believe many of the negative reviews she's received are not due to readers having difficulty separating Ms. Rowling from her juggernaut Harry Potter series. It is weird. If her name wasn't on the book, the number of readers would've been less, but my guess, the percentage of those readers giving it a positive response would have been much bigger.

title: casual vacancy
body: The story was a bit slow starting but got better. Unfortunately it wasn't as gripping or as hard to put down as her other books. But then we have been spoilt by how very very good her other books are.

title: good plot, well

author: Jan
title: I just couldn't find anything to like. The characters were despicable
body: I didn't care for this book. I don't fault the author's writing style, nor the violence,sexual content and language. I just couldn't find anything to like. The characters were despicable, self-centered and tragic. I wasn't looking for Harry Potter when I started this book but I wasn't looking for depression either.

author: Ms V Griffith
title: Great read!
body: Once one gets to grips with the host of charecters initially....its a page-turner. Most enjoyable.

author: Cincinnati, Ohio
title: Borrow from the library, don't spend $$
body: Soooo disappointed. After the Brilliant writing and character development of the Harry Potter series, I was anxious to read J. K. Rowlings next offering. This book was so bad that it was difficult to finish it, though I did because I kept thinking it had to get better. Hoping this is a one-off for her.

author: Sally Domingues
title: Worth reading, interesting story
body: I'll admit it took slogging through at first, because there are so many characters and I got confused. However, it was an interesting look at modern English village life and a fresh story, so that made it worth it to me. And I was glad I stuck with it, because it became very interesting. I hope JK will continue to produce -- I will certainly look for more!

author: Brenda S Retterer
title: Four Stars
body: Very good

author: Brenda
title: not worth my time
body: I couldn't finish this book. I expected better from J.K. Rowling.  Just because you add sex and cursing doesn't mean that you have an adult book.

author: Aarennaar Krishnan
title: As dour as any epic from yore, without the payoff
body: Try as you may, it's well nigh impossible to approach a book from a famous author without thinking of her earlier books. Good or bad, JK Rowling manages to make you forget about Harry Potter very quickly while reading this book. So much so, that very soon you are left yearning to get something from the world of wizardry to save this book of misery.

author: TrpDip7
title: AN EXCELLENT COMBINATION
body: THIS WELL WRITTEN NOVEL ABOUT A SMALL BRITISH VILLAGE WAS INTRIGUING, SAD AND FUNNY. IN A VERY REALISTIC WAY.  WELL DONE!

author: Jane
title: Five Stars
body: Great read, had me hooked from the start

author: technoguy
title: Risen like a Phoenix from the ashes of Harry Potter
body: Casual Vacancy, JK Rowling's 1st post Harry Potter novel is an epiphenomenon of the Harry Potter phenomenon. The two kinds of fiction, one realistic state-of -the -nation novel,the other children's fantasy of the boy wizard Harry Potter,together with other wizards,witches and spells,which went on to sell 450 million world-wide and spawn 8 Hollywood movies. However, she's kicked all that away,to explore the world of the 'muggles' .I'm sure,secretly, in the back of her mind was a desire to play by the laws of ordinary reality, and see if she could write a book,free of tricks, to write a good book,that stood alone, without any dependence of the success of Harry Potter. Could she even write well without all the gobbledegook,a strong and fearless novel?

title: Stick with this story for a rewarding, thought-provoking read
body: THE CASUAL VACANCY by J. K. Rowling is the story of a bitter class struggle between the smug, wealthy inhabitants of Pagford, and their much poor neighbors who inhabit the council flats called The Fields.

Rowling has made her fortune with Harry Potter and should leave it at that if this is an example of her adult work.

body: I wanted to like this book more than I did.  She's such a great writer, but this book didn't grab me like her others have.

author: JamieLynn
title: Very dark
body: I loved the Harry Potter books and so figured this one would also be a new favorite.  While I realize this was written for adults, it was much too dark for me.  Lots of F*** bombs, abuse, drugs, and general unhappiness.  It was well-written with an interesting storyline and well-developed characters, but just not what I enjoy reading.

author: Eric
title: JK Rowling shows that she is an excellent, mature writer
body: JK Rowling shows that she is an excellent, mature writer.  She has created characters with such detail that you believe you are reading a work of non-fiction.  I quickly became wrapped up in the story and lost all track of time.  It was a pleasure to read a book that was crafted so well (after dragging myself through so many second rate stories).  I don't know much about small English town life, but now feel like an expert.

author: Siofra
title: Good Read
body: Classic Rowling with vivid character description. A sometimes hilarious take on small-town politics. A good read albeit dark and sad in place. Would recommend it.

author: catherine street
title: Five Stars
body: A amusing take on the complications of rural living

author: Rachael D.
title: ... reading this book WITHOUT expecting it to be anything like the Harry Potter series
body: I started reading this book WITHOUT expecting it to be anything like the Harry Potter series. I wasn't disappointed. In THAT aspect. I was, however, disappointed in every other aspect. It was a stew of horrible people doing horrible things. I get it that she wanted to do something new and edgier than what she was known for. It turns out there is a thin line between edgy and awful and offensive, and she hurdled over that line and left it in the dust.

author: CBo
title: The Social Politics of a Small Town
body: Great book written in the usual clarity that you would expect from JK Rowling.  Although the storyline stems from the sudden death of a Parish Councillor, it is more about the gritty social politics that exists between the small-minded inhabitants of Pagford, than the political policies of it's council.  Rowling has a way of defining the exact thoughts that go on in the many characters heads that really hits home, exposing them for their insular attitudes and behaviours, in particular, the blood-thirsty need for gossip from some of the middle aged, middle class wormen that feature in the story.  The only disappointment for me was that the x-ray function of my Kindle was not available for this book and given the multitude of characters this would have been very helpful.

author: Maura Dolan
title: Five Stars
body: Great book, which touches on gender, generation and social class themes.

I would say that it is a book that isn't for everyone though some of the characters can be easily related to.

author: DEBRA D. JEAKINS
title: Not expecting to find Harry P and his friends in this book I really did enjoy reading about all the dirty little secrets that ca
body: As a huge Harry Potter fan I went into this book knowing its NOT about Harry Potter! There, that's done!  Casual Vacancy is about death,sex,life, sex, life and the living in a small town.  As I live in an American village of about 2500 I can definitely say I know the life in the book.  Everyone spends all their time either knowing of trying to find out everyone elses business.

author: Sandy
title: Riveting
body: Wow, I am shocked that this book has received such mixed reviews! I could not put this book down. I found the characters and plot fascinating, and I especially enjoyed the multiple points of view. This is a book I'll remember.

author: R. Schadt
title: enjoyed it, for a fully fictional account
body: The community of Pagford is filled with dysfunctional people.  It was a fairly quick read, enjoyed it, for a fully fictional account.

author: Veronica Wilkens
title: One Star
body: one of the most boring books i have ever read.

author: Isabella
title: It's obvious that Rowling wants to create somewhat of a ...
body: It's obvious that Rowling wants to create somewhat of a crass contrast to HP but her superb way of writing and the way she engages us with the characters is evident. Her focus lies on the children's stories in this book too so in a way familiar. It is a tragic but interesting book about social class, adolescence and politics in a picturesque British village where nothing is as it seems.

author: Sheila Karlson
title: Disappointed
body: I was disappointed.

author: Daryl
title: J. K. Rowling has created a dark, ...
body: J.K. Rowling has created a dark, creepy society full of vulgar people with no redeeming value. Why would anyone care? Yuck.

author: Marie Doud
title: I don't like to read books with so much profanity
body: I don't like to read books with so much profanity.  It isn't even realistic that every character in the story (professional adults as well as teenagers) used "gutter" language constantly.

There were too many characters to try to keep straight and the story line was rather boring,it just didn't go anywhere..  I read the whole book, but truly did not enjoy it.  Sorry, I really wanted to like it.

It was not as crazy exciting as the Potter series, and I was expecting so much more from this book. Sadly, I was disappointed and unimpressed by the topics she went over.

title: I enjoyed her other books much more than this one
body: I enjoyed her other books much more than this one.  This book had a disjointed feel to it and was hard to get into.

author: Nana S
title: interesting read
body: It took a while for me to get into the story but at some point I was hooked and wanted to see what happened to the characters in the book. The story was raw and the characters were not particularly likable but all so human. Though their personalities seemed exaggerated, I could see many real human frailties and characteristics in each. The contrasts the author drew between the haves and have-nots rang true. I would recommend this book.

author: Michele Feltman Strider
title: This book is a blessing.
body: The author's love and compassion for her characters shines though this sad tale like sunshine. It was the little touches that killed me, like when we learn that Krystal had never had a banana before. Did I cry? You bet your banana I did.

author: Connie P. Utt
title: Not an interesting book
body: Not my favorite book by any means.  A struggle to finish it but afterward when I thought about it, I could see what whe wass trying to say.

author: LYNN G KRUEGER
title: Three Stars
body: OK

author: Chazaam
title: Much Better Than Some Would Have You Believe
body: You'd be hard pressed to find such a modern study of human character, sometimes in its basest forms, that is both entertaining and thought-provoking.  Many will never enjoy the brilliance of this novel because they are put off by the rather slow start. I had even avoided it for years, but after reading and thoroughly enjoying the two Cormoran Strike installments, I couldn't put it off any longer.  Believe me when I say that your patience will be justly rewarded.  While reading, I was struck by how mean and narcissistic the characters were, and my ability to identify with them. It made me think of The Last Psychologist's proclamation that we are all just a bunch of narcissists . I know that I'm misquoting him, so just go and check out his posts for yourselves.  http://thelastpsychiatrist.com/narcissism/

author: lonegunwoman
title: The Casual Vacancy by J K Rowling...................
body: For me this was an enjoyable engaging read, with a story line  that features strong characters, some are not so nice that makes the pages turn faster!  With prose that flows smoothly  I found it difficult to put down  for any length of time.  Having read this novel some time ago I wanted to add my voice to all the reviews out there,  as always it is a personal choice when reading a novel, I found this a very entertaining read for a good few hours one that remains with you long after finishing the novel.

author: Loves To Read
title: There's a bit of a barrier to entry, but it's brilliantly written
body: This is a book that you have to commit to reading in its entirety.  The beginning is a bit overwhelming and I can completely understand why so many readers gave up on it in the first few chapters.  There are so many characters to try to learn and keep track of that it seems like an impossible mess.  However Rowling does just enough to make each character memorably unique that as long as you're paying attention, you'll be able to sort out who's who.

author: Glynnis Jones
title: Five Stars
body: The casual vacancy was poignant and powerful. I was truly moved.

author: C. Bronte
title: An engrossing enjoyable read
body: I admit I procrastinated in reading this book after hearing some negative reports about the crude language, the unpleasant characters, and the all around disappointment of many with this beloved author.  I should have known better.  J K Rowling just can't write a bad book.  This one is as carefully crafted as her magnificent Harry Potters, everything falls in place.  The language that some readers deplore fit the characters exactly.  I found the insight into human nature to be as finely accurate as that in the HP books, but the struggle between good and evil now takes place within the psyches of her people.  As others have stated, this book isn't for everyone.  But if you have lived in a small town like this one, it rings as clear and true as a bell.  The striving for position, for holding onto small amounts of power, the desperation of the big fish in a small pond mentality, is dead on.  J K Rowling is expert at dissecting the layers that hold such societies together, showing how fragile they are.  This is a book I am glad to have read.

author: Loren Krumwiede
title: One Star
body: Very dull

author: GAPLI
title: Made patrons of our library happy!
body: We have a strong J.K. Rowling following and they were thrilled to see a new book by her!

author: muffin lover
title: Good story line
body: The only reason I have this book 4 stars is that I found it difficult keeping the characters straight in my mind.  There are so many characters and sometimes their first name is used and sometimes their surnames.

author: Nancy from GA
title: One Star
body: Moves too slowly

author: Katie Strganac
title: Vulgar!!
body: This book was extremely vulgar. I didn't even get halfway through the book. It was awful!

author: A&P
title: This is like the dark side of Little Whinging
body: Since I haven't read anything by Rowling other than the Harry Potter series,  I didn't know what to expect.  The novel is pretty slow going and she lulls you into thinking, "Ok, this is English life in a small town written like a soap opera" but as you keep reading, you can sense that something is happening but you're not quite sure what it is. She builds the characters gradually, giving you time to become engrossed and care (or not care) about them. The momentum builds and then comes the avalanche at the end. This book is an adult book and reveals Rowling's diverse writing skills. 01-23-15

author: Erin O'Riordan
title: Kudos, Ms. Rowling
body: I recently finished The Casual Vacancy, the first novel J.K. Rowling wrote specifically for adults and her first post-Harry Potter release. If you have not read it, please look away now, as this post is not spoiler-free.

author: Italian Dreamer
title: Not sure I will really enjoy it. I've started reading it several times but ...
body: I've put this novel aside for later.  Not sure I will really enjoy it.  I've started reading it several times but never actually finished it.

author: Yolonda Smith
title: Two Stars
body: Very disappointed in the book very long and not good.

author: andreasarasota
title: somewhat Interesting.......very sad
body: It was interesting to view life in a small town in Europe. It is probably much akin to small-town USA. It was terribly sad to see in nearly every family such unhappiness and so much sadness. I chose to read this because I liked all of the Harry Potter books so much. What a let-down !

author: sksd49
title: Unequivocally not a children's book
body: The first 300 pages of this book seem to be a laundry list of everything that couldn't be put into a children's book. If I wasn't reading this for my book club, I would have given up after the first section. There were also far too many characters to keep track of; I saw a character map and there are around 35 characters...much too many.

author: Bill Grennan
title: best writer of our age
body: Rowling is without a doubt the best writer of our age!  Loved the book and all of her books, no matter under which name she writes

author: Danbob
title: Bought as a present.
body: Bought as a present.  My wife did enjoy reading it.

author: Debbie Dammeir
title: Two Stars
body: no Harry Potter.

author: Susan M. Peyton
title: Almost TOO Real but I Still Recommend It
body: It was a much quicker read for me than any of her Harry Potter books, but I can't say it was an enjoyable read because--unlike her fantasy novels--everything is almost too real to be enjoyed, and yet, that was probably her point. The characters' lives kept the pages turning even though their conflicts were mostly petty and often downright stupid, but it's those kinds of people who believe their issues supercede everyone else's. The lives of the downtrodden don't matter even though those people to whom the small-town and small-minded people turn up their noses have the most real problems. Like reality, their outcomes don't fare well at all. Also like reality, the harsh underbelly of racism and classism remain virtually unchanged and almost unnoticeable if it weren't for Rowling's omniscient glimpse into the ugliest minds of the most seemingly banal of characters.

author: Ask Peg
title: Hadn't yet hit her stride as an adult novelist with ...
body: Hadn't yet hit her stride as an adult novelist with "The Casual Vacancy".  By the time she wrote "The Silkworm", she'd perfected yet another genre.

author: KatieM
title: Five Stars
body: Excellent book! It's identifiable as JK Rowling's style

author: Amazon Customer
title: A Challenge to Read But an Opportunity to Broaden Perceptions
body: I picked this book up in a library to read during cruise down time. I selected the book because of the author, decided to read it because of the cover jacket description and continued reading to the end because I wanted to see how it ended and I wanted to get a picture of British village life. I was not making Harry Potter comparisons at any time. I am able to compartmentalize my expectations and took this book on its own merit. That being said, it was difficult for me to make it through the book. The numerous characters were hard to keep straight until almost half way through. Once I thought I had them sorted, the story became easier to follow and I did develop feelings, good and bad, for some of the characters. I would not recommend this book except as a look into the way villagers live from day to day as they struggle to find their place in the scheme of their world. I saw another review that mentioned Peyton Place and that was my first thought on completing the book as I reviewed my reaction. That characters have few redeeming qualities and the ones they do exhibit do not seem strong enough to be a permanent part of their substance. They have moments of ethical or moral behavior but can't seem to maintain it and fall back into old habits. Almost as if the reason they behave ethically is not because it is the right thing to do but because they have considered how others will perceive their action. Perhaps that is not far from the mark.

author: David B
title: Four Stars
body: I liked it

author: Zootie
title: Couldn't get into it
body: The characters in this novel were like characters in Tolstoy, in the sense that I needed a chart to keep track of them.  I tried and tried to like this book but I just could not get into it.  I couldn't get into Harry Potter, either.  I thought maybe a book for adults would suit me better.  It didn't.

author: Amazon Customer
title: All over the place
body: I found this book very confusing at first due to the large amount of characters introduced within a very short time period.  I also found that the vast majority of the characters were not redeemable.  The ending was so abrupt I had to check my Kindle a couple times to make sure I wasn't missing something.  Truly not the book I was expecting.

author: Patricia Myers
title: Liked it!
body: It was an interesting story of how one man effected so many lives. Barry's death effected teenagers and adults alike. He effected them directly and indirectly. It certainly made me think about the people in my life. My only complaint about the book was a lot of characters were thrown at you at once. It was hard to keep everyone straight.

author: Ed  Creede
title: One Star
body: Couldn't finish it. Thought it was trash.

author: Noemi
title: Great Book
body: This book was sad, funny and interesting to read.  I've had sleepless nights and mornings and found myself reading this book I fell asleep. It was sometimes sad, funny and interesting to put down at times and that's why I rated this book 5 stars. I would recommend this book not only to teenagers but to adults as well.

author: Kamila Stofirova
title: Distrubing topics, lovely prose
body: If you like easy reading with a highly moral character to identify with, don't even think about picking up this book. You'd be risking becoming one of those dissatisfied reviewers. But if you can appreciate expert writing even though it paints a rather disturbing picture, you're gonna love this book. It explores many present-day issues, such as physical abuse, substance abuse, bullying, child neglect, self-mutilation, domestic violence, adolescent revolt, or neurological disorders. Characters are motivated by anger, jealousy, selfishness, fear, provincial narrow-mindedness, and other negative sides of human nature. Ms. Rowling has woven an intricate web of characters and relationships, all tainted by some sort of frustration. Thanks to the third person omniscient point of view, all pieces of the mosaic fall nicely in place and psychological motivation of individual characters is revealed.

author: AllieMac
title: Too many characters, hard to keep my interest.
body: Too many characters, hard to keep my interest. Couldn't get into it and never finished the book after getting halfway through

author: M. Schlachter
title: Two Stars
body: Boring

author: Charlie
title: an adult reading
body: A very intense story about the classes in England.  This could apply to many towns in America.  Rowling shows a side of life that is very real and very sad.  The personalities of the characters are heart wrenching.

author: Catherine A. Latora
title: Two Stars
body: Couldn't get through the first couple of chapters.

author: Malcolm Ellis
title: disappointing
body: A disappointing read that seemed to go nowhere & left a number of issues up in the air & unfinished

author: G. Punto
title: Three Stars
body: An OK book, but was not as excited abut the book as anticipated.

author: michael chiedi
title: Great book
body: JK has done it again. loved every second. the story had me in a range of emotions from start to finish.

author: owlet
title: I was disappointed in Rowling's first sortie away from the fantasy world ...
body: I was disappointed in Rowling's first sortie away from the fantasy world of Harry Potter which I adored. Casual Vacancy is carefully void of any magic, even the "ordinary" human magic of compassion. The only character who seems to have decency and lovingkindness dies on page one. Everyone else seems greedy or venal or terribly limited. But I'm glad that Ms. Rowling is still writing because I know she has a remarkable gift and she will find her way to produce more excellent works.

author: Alissa
title: Don't Waste Your Time
body: My book club and I all hated this more than any other book we have read in the past 3 years. I had never read the Harry Potter series so I went in with an open mind but it was a waste of time. It was depressing without any resolution. The characters did not grow despite all of the devastating occurrences in their lives. It almost seems like Rowling just wanted to write a sob story and then gave up halfway through. I've read that it was a socialist manifesto in disguise but I wouldn't give it that much credit.

author: Frances Ballard
title: Couldn't finish
body: One of the few books I couldn't bring myself to finish reading.  I loved the Harry Potter series, so I was very disappointed with this one.

author: Joyce Strohman
title: Disappointed
body: This was quite different than the Harry Potter series. I had trouble following it and did not finish the book

author: Ardy Woolley
title: It did get a little better at the end in a morbid way
body: Kind of disturbing.  It did get a little better at the end in a morbid way.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Four Stars
body: Worth dragging through it at the end, but my goodness it was dark!

author: Jeffrey A. Simons
title: Not Harry Potter and that is a good thing
body: The Casual Vacancy is a complete departure from J.K. Rowling's previous books but is equally captivating and compelling.

author: A. Cohn
title: Huge disappointment for this Rowling fan
body: While I loved the Harry Potter series, and thought the Cuckoo's Calling was a brilliant start to a great series, I can't believe how much I disliked The Casual Vacancy. I read it through to the end, almost against my will - like looking at something gross despite the revulsion. Rowling may have been making a social statement - or something - but it was lost amidst the despair, unlikable characters, heavy-handed plotting, etc. Even her usual, impeccably precise writing couldn't rise above the mess and the complete lack of subtlety. Really disappointing and a complete waste of time. (I'm giving it two stars and not one, because I reserve one-star ratings for books I can't finish. This one, unfortunately, I did.)

author: anonymous
title: slow start, but interesting.
body: Interesting characters, but sometimes hard to keep all of them apart.  Had a hard time getting through it at first, but the plot picked up 1/2 way through.

author: Robyn Vrana
title: Five Stars
body: So well-written.

author: Paul Mallon
title: Gave as gift. Well protected in shipment.
body: Gave as gift.

author: Katie Williams
title: Slow start but draws you in.
body: It took me a while to get into this book but I am pleased that I persevered with it. The characters are very real - some I loved while some were cruel. I was heartbroken at times and certainly didn't pick the ending. Couldn't put it down towards the end.

author: alan stops
title: Five Stars
body: I found it  captivating.

author: IRV FRANKEL
title: Five Stars
body: She writes well.

author: Celia Stone
title: One Star
body: The first few chapters I read were trash.I did not read the rest.

author: Sue
title: She loved it. It came speedily
body: I bought this as a gift. She loved it. It came speedily. Thanks so much.

author: Julia Carroll, Ph.D.
title: BORING
body: BORING

author: JJD
title: Two Stars
body: Not up to her normal quality. Strange ending.

author: Kdelight
title: One Star
body: Just a depressing book.

author: Stan Snapp
title: Not a Harry Potter Story
body: Loved this book and I'm not a Harry Potter person but his is well written and a real page turner.

author: Patricia Rosario
title: Another side of JK...
body: Well written, but of course, a much different style than the HP books.  This book paints British small town life as the dreariest, fakest, most unhhapy thing on Earth. Not a single good thing happens throughout the book!  Interesting read, but boy, it brings you down...

author: Looking for a Fun Read
title: Unpleasant book with somewhat redeeming ending
body: I hated this book until the final section, and then I thought it redeemed itself enough to give it a marginally favorable review.  Rowling did a masterful job for the first nine-tenths of this book in creating a small community filled with loathsome people with few favorable characteristics.  Unfortunately, the reading experience was so miserable that I think I have actually been irritable with my family while I have been reading the book.

author: Ruth Marks
title: I hope this is the first of many books for adults by JK Rowling.
body: The character development in this book made it so fun to read. I keep thinking about the characters and I am glad I read it.

author: Cecilia
title: it was okay
body: Meh. It wasn't horrible. But it wasn't good. And the repeated reference to "under my umbrella" was extremely annoying. Why she chose to repeatedly use that song is beyond me. However, there is grit and realism, which I can appreciate. Some may say she should have stuck to HP. What those people don't realize is this shows her development and talent as a writer to go from children's fantasy to a novel of this sort. Well done Ms. Rowling

author: Peg
title: Five Stars
body: Great book

author: Sherry Shike
title: Brilliant story of teenage angst and often the hypocrisy in all of us, underneath the layers
body: It's rare to find a book that wakes you up so deeply while having you laughing and crying, in equal measure.

author: Amazon Customer
title: I would not recommend this to my worst enemy
body: Never in my life have I not completed a book. I read several different books whilst reading this one just to try and break up the complete and utter hideousness of a shockingly dreadful read. Alas, it was not so. I gave up. Sadly, I would not recommend this to my worst enemy. A total contrast in writing style to the HP novels we all know and adore.

author: Freezy
title: So good.
body: Loved this book. You feel like you know these people and this town long after finishing the book. J K Rowling is an amazing writer.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not a page turner
body: Really hard to get into. Seems disjointed with so many different story lines. I haven't finished it yet as it's not fully captured me and I purchased it several months ago.

author: Pat Barry
title: Five Stars
body: good story line

author: Faye Stephens
title: One Star
body: I did not complete.  Not my kind of reading

author: Kathryn M. Maguire
title: One Star
body: Difficult to get into expected better

author: Buddy Rogers
title: Disappointing
body: Having never read this author, but being aware of her great fame, i was disappointed by the lack of cleverness of the plot, and the characters being so trite and unbelievable.  A very long read for such little payoff.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Started out slow, but overall, a good read.
body: The story does start off slow and I had the urge to quit reading it; however, owing to my faith in Jo's writing, I decided to continue on. First of all, reviewers who didn't like this story either did not finish it or were just expecting another extraordinary Harry Potter story to come out. On the contrary, The Casual Vacancy is anything but extraordinary --- the novel focuses on one small little town and on the ordinary lives of its residents. I do admit that the premise of the story would have have grip me to read the book if it weren't written by Jo. It is not a gripping story that would keep you awake at night, wanting to know what's next, wanting to read more. I read this book over the course of six months (I usually read and finish books within a day or two) during my downtime at work, wanting to finish it and knowing what eventually happens. When it all ended, I did feel like I would miss reading about the characters because the characters, especially the teenagers of the story, was the most interesting part of the story.

author: Gerald W. Lankford
title: Good Writing a little slow
body: Enjoyed it for the most part but not one of my favorites. Very complex to get into 89 characters .  Drama in a small community in the UK.

author: Buffy Moon
title: Four Stars
body: Story of the intertwined lives in a small town voyueristic look behind the closed doors.  Deep character development.

author: Mara L. Marsh
title: Different feel, but still excellent writing
body: Overall, I liked this book.  I listened to the audio version and have not read the text.  I've read the reviews about too much fluff, but I would disagree.  While the subject matter and tone is drastically different than Harry Potter, I could still see each scene and character as I listened and to me that is the mark of a good writer.  I did not find my mind wandering while I listened.  There are two main reasons I did not give the book 5 stars.  The first is that there were a lot of characters that were introduced quickly.  I did find myself wondering who a character was shortly after the introduction.  This corrected itself as I got further in the book, but in the beginning it was slightly confusing.  The other point was I personally did not care for the ending.  I was waiting for the next chapter and the book was over.

author: Ann C Allard
title: I loved this book as well as the other two 'non-Harry ...
body: I loved this book as well as the other two 'non-Harry Potter' books by J. K. Rowling.  I found this one to be very dark and considered putting it down several times.  But the characters grabbed me and I couldn't stop thinking about them.  Had to finish the book to see how each was ultimately developed.  Once completed, it stayed on my mind for a long time.  I think this would be a great 'book club' selection.

author: susan hicksj
title: Five Stars
body: Love it.

author: Karen Lea Hansen
title: Riveting. It left me feeling emotionally wrecked.
body: Like most people I know, I jumped on the Harry Potter train. I read the series, saw about half of the movie adaptations and I'm eager to visit Universal Studio's The Wizarding World of Harry Potter. I enjoyed the stories, but I must confess that I didn't really think of J.K. Rowling as a writer beyond the Potter Series.

author: Colin MOORCRAFT
title: Marvellous character assassination of virtually everyone in a small town ...
body: Marvellous character assassination of virtually everyone in a small town community and their local politics, whilst involved with impending Parish Council Elections following the sudden death of a Councillor.

author: Eric A. Kugler
title: The Outsiders meets Anna Karenina
body: Pretry good book with a boring and trite ending.

author: Tree
title: Not really her best. Too much fluff about nothing in the book
body: Not really her best.  Too much fluff about nothing in the book.

author: David A. Lamb
title: J. K. Rowling is, undoubtedly a phenomenal ...
body: J.K. Rowling is, undoubtedly a phenomenal writer. This story centers on one small town and the lives it contains. I read all of the Harry Potter books and was struck at Rowling's ability to tailor her writing style to her aging audience. Here, Rowling once again knows her audience...unless somebody is expecting fantasy and magic. If you're looking for fantasy and magic, look elsewhere. This book is a real as you can get.

author: LadyHerbie
title: This can't possibly be the same author as HP. ...
body: This can't possibly be the same author as HP.  There is nothing redeeming about any of the characters or the story.

author: youstruckgold
title: Life under the stairs.
body: This is NOT Harry Potter! Nor is it the smile-inducing detective romps of her Galbraith musings. The only positive force in this novel, disappears in the first few pages. From there Rowling treats us to a world of petty parochial politics, emotional heart ache, and unhappy endings. Casual vacancy again demonstrates Rowling's fabulous character development and scene setting; while demonstrating the enormous challenges that face those challenged most of all by their circumstances and demographics. A good read  - this is a journey well and truly under the stairs.

author: Desert Rat
title: Didn't Even Finish It
body: I checked this book out at my local library and returned it a week later.

author: Gonzo
title: Four Stars
body: Quality book.

author: Russell S. Marshall
title: A Modest Work with Significant Profanity
body: A modest work with significant and gratuitous profanity.  The book contains a pot-load of characters that are never fully developed.  Yet, they act and respond quite surprisingly.  Teachers, teens, and young children use language like they are characters in an HBO prison life or swingers special.  I finished it, but it was not a pleasant or particularly informative piece of writing.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not quite Harry Potter!!
body: I was a bit disappointed in this book, especially with what I considered a quite unsatisfactory ending. I must admit that it held my attention throughout!

author: Loraine Mc Namee
title: I would not recommend this book to a friend and would be wary ...
body: I read the book completely, and found it to be depressing - I prefer a more uplifting book and something that is a bit lighter.  The story line was dark, and definately an adult book - graphic detailed descriptions in this book of various social situations/scenarios not suitable for children.  Surprised that J. K. Rowling could produce this type of book following her huge international success with the Harry Potter series.  I would not recommend this book to a friend and would be wary of purchasing another book by this author

author: Barbara Henzel
title: Two Stars
body: Hard to find anything to like in any of the characters until the very end.

author: Julian Satran
title: A beautifully written but heartbreaking story
body: A heartbreaking story that will spoil for you forever the picture perfect image of an English village/suburb. It starts with the sudden death of a councilman due to an aneurysm and its main-line is the competition for the seat that involves a school headmaster, a printing shop foreman and a local attorney (who happens to be the son of the head of the local council). The story evolves around the candidates' families/extended families and it touches the lives of a single-mother who is a drug addict and her two children - a teenage daughter and a three year old boy. The author manages to make you feel like you were living in Pagford (the name of the village) without filling pages of details - with the same "magic" she succeeded making you live with Hary Potter. And breaks your heart with the accidental death of the little boy of the single mother and the suicide of his sister. The language is perfect and concise, the storytelling is beautiful. I thoroughly enjoyed reading the book and you will probably too (but don't expect to be very happy after it).

author: Bonnie M Myers
title: It did not move or move me, as a ...
body: It did not move or move me, as a result, it took me much longer to finish this kindle book than others! The resolutions at the end tied up some things, but not all.

author: Lindsay Swanson
title: Dark humor people will love this!
body: Well I may be bias because I love jk Rowling. But this book is amazing. I also have a very dark sense of humor, and was laughing so hard at many points. I love how all the characters are intertwined and the stories with them.

author: D. Postma
title: There is everything to like in this story
body: There is everything to like in this story. Rowling proves she has more depth than children's fantasy. I am well read and if any would be offended I can only say try looking in the mirror a bit more. If you don't like what you see... start with yourself then your circle, then beyond.

author: VA Girl
title: I'd recommend it to anyone 13 years and up
body: I don't have the words to express the impact this story could have on readers.  Ms. Rowling is not a one time Harry Potter success!

author: Adrian I.
title: five stars
body: great item & book and in very good condition.

author: PKsweets
title: In need of good editing!
body: Tried to like it.....HAD to stop at chapter 40.....just don't care anymore, my time is more valuable.  Long, overdone, over-narrated and I am over it!

author: Milpitas
title: Four Stars
body: Story wasn't as good as I thought

author: Hunters
title: Two Stars
body: didn't care for it.  She should stick with Harry Potter

author: PegM
title: A Difficult Read
body: We in the U.S. have noticed a tendency on the part of some those who reside "across the pond" to be cruelly sarcastic without a trace of shame. There is a lot of that sort of spirit in this book and that made it a difficult read for this reader. If you like "gotcha" moments, if revenge is your cup of tea, you should enjoy the bulk of this book, however, you might find the softening of that stance toward the end a bit of a disappointment. If you, on the other hand want to believe in virtue and goodness you might want to know that although truly awful things happen, at the end there seems to be something of a vindication of worthwhile values, if you don't particularly mind having been dragged across a minefield of nastiness to get there.

author: Vernon Goodrich
title: One Star
body: Big let down from her Harry Potter books.

author: JLS
title: Not for the sensitive
body: I was, at first, overwhelmed by the number of characters introduced in the beginning of this story, however, Ms. Rowling has a talent for giving each character their own voice and qualities. The events that happen throughout the book are mostly connected to each other and equally interesting. You may find yourself sympathizing with one person while despising another and then reversing your feelings all together. In any case, it's a story that makes you open your eyes.

author: SJB
title: I expected more.
body: I really hoped for more from JK Rowling.  Harry Potter series was amazingly imaginative and I couldn't put it down.  This book was not her best.  Her new series under her pen name is much better than this book.  Start with the Cormoran Strike books instead.  This was the only book of J.K. Rowling that didn't suck me in

author: Moira Sheridan
title: Loved it.
body: What a surprise........  had read many negative reviews of this book but finally decided to dive in.  Loved it.

author: beatrice j seegers
title: Three Stars
body: just so so

author: manuela i.b.
title: Pushed aside
body: Hard to get into. I need to make another attempt in the future. I wasn't turned on at all.

author: Jimena Nieto
title: Four Stars
body: I had a great time with this book!

author: Mary D. Grace
title: A little hard to follow at first...
body: This book was a little hard to follow at first. There were numerous, seemingly disconnected characters with their lives and stories moving in different directions. Somewhere past the middle of the book, however, their lives started moving toward each other. And in the end, the loose ends were tied up, although not necessarily in a pretty package. The characters' difficult lives were exposed and sometimes overly heavy. The conclusion of the book, though, made the ride worthwhile. And the inspirational spark to do something to better our communities was an unexpected gift.

author: M. Ann
title: One Star
body: The opposite of Harry Potter - no character development, no interesting story line, no value.

author: Donna P. Katsaounis
title: Five Stars
body: Super book.

author: Wood
title: Five Stars
body: Perfect gift.

author: A.M.A.
title: Yesh! Could not get through it.
body: Yesh!  Could not get through it.

author: Lana23
title: Four Stars
body: Enjoy her stories.  So different from her Harry Potter series.  Will read more of this series.

author: AZ Flygirl
title: Gross profanity does not make a story edgy, only shows lack of imagination
body: I was astonished at the profane language in this book and I admit I couldn't get past the 2nd chapter.  I was listening to it and when the character used the most profane word in the middle of Diety's name I took my earbuds out and gave up. I know it is considered sophisticated now to use profanity, but some of us would rather not muddy up the language with words that do not describe, only show the inability to create a story with actual thoughtfulness. I also did not like any of the characters, and it's hard to stay with a story if I don't feel any sympathy or affection for them. After reading the other reviews I'm glad I did not buy this audiobook and can just return it to the library. I wish I had read the reviews before.

author: Amazon Customer
title: This book is not for the lighthearted.
body: "The Casual Vacancy" touches on a lot of heavy topics and Rowling isn't shy about painting a graphic picture for us. I personally loved this book, although I did have to put it down to catch my breath a few times.

author: Cathy Pentecost
title: Not a happy read
body: The characters really evolved well, but pretty sad.

author: Kres
title: Five Stars
body: Thank JKR! I'll keep buying all your stories!

author: Eric Conn
title: great storytelling, extremely graphic
body: Rawling tells a great story as always, and character development is second to none. This is hardly Harry Potter, however, as the story is full of incredibly graphic material. Likewise, the story seems to end without much resolution or point. Did Rawling get tired of writing and force an abrupt closing? It sure feels that way. English 101: every good story needs a resolution.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Three Stars
body: OK

author: Derrick Lyons
title: Great and intricate plot
body: Great and intricate plot. It sometimes is a bit difficult to keep up with all of the moving pieces in her puzzle but it's really a well written story. And the character development is awesome. You really get a good feel for all of the people.

author: RICHARD LA
title: Five Stars
body: Every bit as good as her Harry Potter series.  She is clearly a multifaceted person and writer.

author: alazala
title: proceeding through hate or rebellion and closing whith reconciliation
body: This choral plot is a passionate manifesto in defence of the less blessed and weak members of communities. It aims to show that they are worth of pity and protection as much as the self centered members of upper class, who generally feel as much miserable and unhappy  only due to ambiguous human relations.  The indifference and selfishiness of rich people is made laughable in comparison to disgraces and basic unmet needs of the very unlucky counterpart.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Fantastic characters
body: Such an amazing story full of real and captivating characters. Can the story get a little disturbing? Yes. This book is not for the faint of heart, but if you want a real, well-written look at small-town life - this book is a must-read! Loved it!

author: M. McDonough
title: when does the plot get interesting?
body: After reading twenty percent of this slow-moving tale of a small town, I gave up. Yes, the character development was excellent but no obvious plot.

author: Wendy Hutchinson
title: all hating their lives and going on to screw each other over in pathetic ways. JKR should stick to fantasy
body: Actually, I would give this book zero stars!  It was awful from beginning to end.  A total downer.  Many, many dreary characters, all hating their lives and going on to screw each other over in pathetic ways.  JKR should stick to fantasy.

author: Alin
title: Can think of no reason to recommend this to anyone except someone I don't like.
body: I am very appreciative that Rowling and the major media reviewers have cleared up for me the features needed to get a critically aclaimed novel. To wit - a boring story, all characters headed nowhere good, no single likeable character, no identifiable justification for writing the story. The main take-home is a description of the one place and population you absolutely don't want to be around. I refuse to accept that it's worth writing a depressing story just to be depressing - does this mean I'm not 'cultured' or 'intellectual' by reviewers standards?.

author: Lucy M.
title: Good book
body: I was surprised to see all the bad reviews at this site and an overall rating of 3 stars for Rowling's book, The Casual Vacancy. Were all these people expecting Harry Potter?  I get the feeling that if she had never written that phenomenal series, people might not be so critical of her stab at an adult novel. Reviewers complained that there were no redeemable characters in the cast and the book was a depressing mess.  Well, I thought it was a very good book, well written and hard to put down. I thought this was a fairly accurate picture of life in modern times. Teens hating their parents....teens being bullied...bored spouses who cheat...rich people turning their heads with no concern for the poor in their midst...innocent children being abused and neglected with tragic results....insincere people gossiping. It all happens in the real world we live in and Rowling just took a slice from that real world and portrayed it well in her novel. Everyone isn't rich, moral or happy. Problems exist.

author: Sheila Deeth
title: Thought-provoking and thoroughly authentic
body: If you watched Broadchurch, or the American version, Gracepoint, you probably already know the flavor of J. K. Rowlings The Casual Vacancy. A small English town and its even smaller suburb across the hill form the backcloth to the tale. A wealth of characters, rich and poor, young and old, all hide their sins and secrets, living seemingly normal lives with normal afflictions covering normal needs. But one man has died, leaving a casual vacancy on the council. The councils word just might decide the future of a teenage girl and her run-down neighborhood. But it all depends on who can win the most votes, sway the most opinions, or beat the system most efficiently.

author: Michael Harryman
title: Four Stars
body: good

author: Hils
title: An interesting read.
body: An interesting read, but rather prescriptive in that she seemed to want to 'tick the boxes' re.social problems. I didn't feel I empathised with many of the characters, except for the young girl, Krystal. There were parts of the book that I enjoyed, others that were heavy going. However, overall I enjoyed her descriptive writing, and felt that her small observations of characters were well done.

author: RGC Burns
title: Realistic, well-researched and well-written page-turner
body: I am puzzled by a lot of the negative reader reviews, unless they are from people who were expecting a Harry Potter-type story.  I thought this was an exceptional book, with a wide range of social issues interwoven with very realistic and, I thought, mostly well-drawn characters into a well-written story that kept my interest.  This is a much better book and a much more realistic one than I expected from a writer who has heretofore written fantasy.  It kept me up reading into the early hours several nights running.  One reviewer said the ending was predictable; I disagree completely.  This book is not "about" drug use, child abuse and other horrors of modern life that impact characters in the story; it is about the interconnectedness of lives, the unexpected consequences of actions both planned and spontaneous, the secrets we guard and the lies we tell, sometimes to ourselves, to guard them; and how readily we misjudge others' motives and characters, being willfulling ignorant of what they have actually experienced.  Images and characters from this book will stay with me for a long time.

author: Linda L.Clark
title: Well developed characters; but not particularly likeable.
body: Well developed characters;but not particularly likeable.

author: SCM
title: Great writing, but not enjoyable to read.
body: I think JK Rowling is a brilliant author.  Probably the best on earth.  However, I did not enjoy this book.  It's excellent writing, but the story, the subject matter, and the general tone of the book were unpleasant and I derived no pleasure from reading this.  Artistically it's perfectly executed, but it was just not enjoyable to read.

author: Brian A Stokes
title: Venality in small town England
body: This was listed under mystery, but I wouldn't categorize it as such. The story of life in a small town among a small circle of friends, acquaintances and enemies is well told and pulls you into its orbit. The characters are well drawn.

author: Aisling Peyton
title: Wow
body: A really wonderful read, you could never predict where this book would take you. I laughed out loud and I cried. The characters are rich and you'll end up loving the ones you thought you'd hate!

author: Kindle Customer
title: One Star
body: Left no impression

author: Horst Eisfelder
title: Five Stars
body: A very good story. However to fully understand it, I am now reading it again from the very beginning.

author: gammyraye
title: Not bad, but not really great either....
body: If this novel were by an unknown author, I doubt that it would have made much of a splash at all. Since it was written by the author of the Harry Potter series, of course it attracted all kinds of attention and undoubtedly sold very well, despite the fact that it's not earth-shaking, groundbreaking, spirit lifting, thought inspiring, or page-turning. It's not a bad novel by any means, but it's not an especially good one either. It's actually pretty depressing in its picture of the people in a small English village.

author: Adam J. Cooper
title: Big Disappointment!
body: Such a disappointment!  So far below the quality of Harry Potter.  The plot was boring and so were the characters.  Very flat and uninteresting.

author: S D McEachron
title: Two Stars
body: Boring money not well spent.  Well written though.

author: Jessica Donohue
title: purposefully so that I (as a huge Harry Potter fan) would not be too disappointed when I read it
body: I waited a long time to read this book, purposefully so that I (as a huge Harry Potter fan) would not be too disappointed when I read it. I had heard lots of bad things and was completely resigned to low expectations. However, it was wonderful. It got off to a little of a rocky start, and the large cast of characters lost me for a little while before I hit my stride. But this is one of the best depictions of human foibles, how we think we are versus how others perceive us, how we all have brutal flaws and soaring high points. The shifting perspectives allows an insight into different points of view, creating multifaceted, interesting characters. I hated and loved all of them. By about halfway through this book I was having trouble putting it down and upon finishing it was left with a powerful ache and a new perspective. This book is probably not for everyone, and I can see how many a HP fan would be disappointed and bewildered. This book is JK doing something very different. It's adult, it's serious, it's complex, and it's very heavy. The book this most reminds me of is The Goldfinch, which I recently finished. If that sort of thing isn't your cup of tea, this probably isn't either.

author: jms
title: Eye Opener
body: I wish many conservatives would read this book. It could be an eye opener. Politics, attitudes and the lives affected in a small English community seems to reflect what we see, but can't understand, on a larger scale (USA). I gave it an extra star for impact. Takes a while to get to know the characters, but worth it.

author: john martin
title: There's not one character to love in this book
body: There's not one character to love in this book.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Wonderful
body: Great book. well written with real characters and an interesting plot. Don't read if you are expecting another Harry Potter- this is a book for adults so yes it deals with things like death, rape, self mutilation, and abuse and includes some cursing, just like in real life. The beginning was a bit of a slow going since there are so many main characters but once you figure out who everyone is it reads much faster and it's well worth the effort.

author: Carol from Ohio
title: Got better towards the end
body: Characters hard to follow. Got better towards the end.

author: LPD
title: This is a work of genius.
body: I absentmindedly picked up this book out of curiosity and absolutely could not put it down. From the start I marveled at Rowling's storytelling and at her perfectly sketched characters; if you like dynamic, vulnerable, flawed characters (read: no perfect heroes or villains) this is the book for you. These initial feelings were only strengthened as the story unfolded and I became even more engulfed in the lives of Pagford's denizens.

author: Post It Note
title: well-written
body: I really wanted to love this book. It was exceptionally well-written, though the sheer number of characters was daunting in the first portion. The subject was one that should have been boring but became intriguing. However, few of the characters had any redeeming qualities. The ending was also infuriating. Without giving away too much, I found the emotions that Rowling tried to arouse too complex and the unraveling of events too quick.

author: London Lass
title: Teenagers steal the show
body: The untimely death of a local councillor (from natural causes!) results in ructions as the posher villagers gang up on the crumbling council estate on their doorstep. Although the adult characters are well drawn, it is the teenagers who steal the show. As in Harry Potter, it is absolutely clear who the heroes and villains are. A fun, escapist read.

author: M. Turner
title: The morphing of JK Rowling
body: A simple story but elevated by the beautiful use of language and descriptive phrasing. JKR has morphed magically from the world of Harry Potter into the more mundane arena of small-town politics and its players.

author: C. Taylor
title: Good but very sad
body: Definitely worth reading, but I probably won't be able to bring myself to read it again.

author: Derek
title: I am thrilled to see a different story from Ms ...
body: I am thrilled to see a different story from Ms. Rowling, although I am still waiting for a update on Harry.

author: Wombat the Bookworm
title: Strong characters & intense experiences; a meditation on middle age, and an exercise in cruelty; also not very good.
body: When Barry Fairbrother, town counsellor for a tiny English down, dies of an anurysm, the ensuing vicious squabble over the titular opening becomes both intricate, fraught, and nightmarish.  The leading lights of the town and their children are all tightly intertwined, and often at odds with one another.  Its a book of strong characters and intense experiences, a meditation on the malaise of middle age, and an exercise in cruelty.  Its also just not a great book.

author: Cynthia A.
title: Three Stars
body: I was waiting for something amazing to happen the entire book and it never really did.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Three Stars

author: Sam

author: Jacqui Whitney

body: You have to be patient with this story. It takes time to develop the characters and make the reader care enough about them to read on. Having said that, to me it was worth not giving up as the story headed towards its poignant conclusion.  I shed a tear and thought about it afterwards - to me, that makes it a success.

body: I was very impressed with Rowling's ability to shift her writing to a quite different style. The book's focus was obviously well

author: Donna Elsie Flink Linley
title: Fabulous
body: Thank you for writing this book.  I work with victims of domestic violence and at times those who self medicate because of life history or domestic violence.  I find myself frequently disturbed by socio-economic stereotypes & found the author's rich character development outstanding. I have not read any of the author's other books, but will now.  Again thank you.  This book may just change many people's understanding of the world beyond their comfort zone and convince them to get involved and to not be so very quick to judge and/or dismiss other human beings.  Fabulous, fabulous.  I will read again.

The plot, however was not executed very well and was put to a total waste I couldn't bear it, I'm sorry. I really tried to finish the book but I can't even go through it halfway. . . I'm stuck and I don't usually get stuck. I haven't finished it, yes, but I can say there were no development in the characters in the story, speaking for just as much as I have read. Like what others would say, she should have stopped at Harry Potter.

What a disappointment!

title: Rowling is a very talented writer and I enjoyed the way she wrote this story
body: J.K. Rowling is a very talented writer and I enjoyed the way she wrote this story. The characters were similarly unlikeable to the Dursley's in the Harry Potter series. I am very sensitive, so the ending of the book upset me greatly and I could barely finish it. It was depressing, the characters were depressing but probably true to life. Just because my personality has a hard time with tragedies doesn't mean she is less of a writer. I kind of wish I hadn't ever read it...good art always evokes strong feelings

author: Amazon Customer
title: I loved this book
body: I loved this book. J.K Rowling has a way of getting into the heads of her characters. The book looks at the dynamics of village life, and how the death of one person has an impact on more than the family. The characters are real and although their lives are interwoven they are unaware of the connection with each other that  effects the wider village community. Good read

author: William Paul Plumlee
title: and it seemed to my senses similar in scene setting to the many Brit Coms I enjoy, but it did not capture my full attention ...
body: Just finished Rowling's "Casual Vacancy". An amazingly interesting read. I read a few pages in July when I first downloaded it, and it seemed to my senses similar in scene setting to the many Brit Coms I enjoy, but it did not capture my full attention and I put it aside. Picked it back up yesterday, and realized that like a surgeon J.K. had started at the surface, but once she started pealing back layer after layer the novel took on an amazingly interesting light. I will have to digest it for a while to appreciate the entirety of the message encoded within. Definitely a book that has provoked thought in me. Enjoyable read.

This book points out the devastating effects drug addiction has on family members, resulting in complete waste and destruction of lives.  J. K. Rowling is an example how success is possible from sheer devotion and motivation, willpower.  I will read all of J. K. Rowling's works.  Knowledgeable and able to write on many subjects.

author: theprimate@aol.com
title: No game
body: I started reading this with no previous knowledge of the author or work, but as a student of writing. This book was like watching baseball practice, with Derek Jeter: the skill, the power, the accuracy, savvy, balance, all the things that make a great athlete. The writer is also extremely skilled. The main flaw, is there was no game, no drama to hold attention, edge of your seat anticipation. I didn't care about the main issue of the town council, and I have met enough jerks in my life, that I don't care to delve into their details during my spare time. Guys, I don't go to the Stadium to watch practice, but to go through a good nine innings. I am wondering what she could do in the next novel.

body: Yes, if you love HP then this book could be uncomfortable. Kind of like listening to your grandparents swear. But that doesn't make it a bad book.

author: Jeremy L. Smith
title: Brilliant, Moving, Humorous Novel; Loved It
body: Knowing the brilliant imagination required to write the Harry Potter series, I knew that Rowling would make a great writer of adult novels, and I was not disappointed-quite the opposite.  This is a brilliant book which illustrates Rowling's true empathy and understanding of human nature; it illustrates without cliche what makes us all different and what makes us all similar.  Some of the rough and disadvantaged characters in the novel are probably as complete polar opposites of Rowling as could be possible in behavior and social status, but she is able to create characters whom you are simultaneously sympathetic with and repelled by.  Rowling understands people, all kinds of them; and she is not a snob...that much is clear from the book.  I could not put this book down and I truly enjoyed getting to know these characters; they are beautifully well-drawn and the book contains a lot of humor in spots which balances out some of the tragic and negative aspects of the story.  Rowling has me now as a devoted fan and I will continue to read her novels...she is now writing a series of mysteries which began with 'The Cuckoo's Calling' and I truly hope she will write more novels akin to 'The Casual Vacancy'.

author: Joe Da Rold
title: A Rowling Disappointment
body: The heart-attack death of a village councilman opens up a window of opportunity for others.  After 100 pages I could not find any reason to continue.  The characters were flat and there was no plot in sight.  Rowling knows how to tell a story, but she fails to apply it here.  A major disappointment.

author: Judy Galloway
title: I liked the reader- he does a good job w/ the ...
body: I purchased the Kindle version for my iPad but never really got started on it. I ended up listening to the audio book version. I liked the reader- he does a good job w/ the voices and I enjoyed his read.  That said, I was not having the best of weeks and listening to this while driving to and from work didn't improve my mood. None of the characters were lovable - it was even hard to "root" for any of them really.  In retrospect, Krystal was the most "authentic" - that is, unlike Fats or Gaia, she "was what she was".  The end seemed to come soon and leave me hanging.  Not sure how I would really feel if this book was written by "Mrs. Smith" - I was interested in it mostly because of the author (as I am sure many other readers were).

author: P. Hayden
title: This is an interesting book. There were major/minor plot ...
body: This is an interesting book. There were major/minor plot twists. All characters remained viable throughout the story. The author is a writer and deserves to be recognized for her craft. This is not Harry Potter nor should it be.

author: The Book Wheel
title: A Victory for 'Vacancy'
body: The Casual Vacancyis a story about theintricacies of small town politics, relationships, and rivalries following the untimely death of parish councilman, Barry Fairbrother. Barrys death is important because, without him, an important decision regarding the poor side of town is suddenly open for debate again, so both sides are trying to fill the spot with one of their own. Everyone, from the deli owner to the social worker to the junkie, is brought into drama.

author: Glenda Lane
title: This book is not easy to get into like the Harry Potter books
body: This book is not easy to get into like the Harry Potter books. I am really disappointed with this book.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Sadly one of the worst books I have ever read
body: Sadly one of the worst books I have ever read.  J.K. is a brilliant author so I'll still be looking for what she will write in the future and hopefully find something worth reading.

author: judyh
title: FIVE STARS from me :)
body: I felt I really NEEDED to write a review to help redress the mediocre rating this book currently suffers from. I almost missed out on the pleasure of reading this book due to being put off by its 3*** rating . I enjoyed this book more than even The Cormoran Strike books which I also loved. Don't be put off...it's a super read :)

author: HODGEPODGESPV
title: One faulty step
body: I was so excited to get this book! As expected, her writing was beautiful. But I just could get into or stay into it. It just kept putting me to sleep. I finally gave up. Trust me, this is not normal. Maybe this is just a British book.

author: Wendy M Cash
title: Half way into the book my interest in the ending ...
body: Half way into the book my interest in the ending arose. Hard to keep the characters sorted out and much too wordy.

author: Alan Kilistoff
title: One Star
body: Couldn't even finish it,very disappointing.

author: Linda Werner
title: Five Stars
body: A great read from a master story teller.

author: Jack Darnell
title: Good Read
body: Very well written. Nothing like the Harry Potter series, but very enjoyable. Many, many characters. I recommend you google The Casual Vacancy and reference the info on Wikipedia. It lists the main characters ans helps keep track of who's who.

author: Jeff W. Nieder
title: Five Stars
body: I couldn't wait to get home from work to read this book

author: Adrianne C Edmunds
title: a must read
body: I loved this book and am once again left with that feeling of "I need more".  I love JK Rowling's writing. This book accurately represents the intricacies and tangled web that is woven through the lives of the members of a small town. She does a fantastic job of showing the good and the evil that exist within us all as humans. I highly recommend this read!

author: alan farmer

body: Confusing at first, but the pace picks up throughout. Ending came together with a surprising twist, while keeping the same tone.

body: It took a while to grab my interest, but I enjoy her style of writing. She is very descriptive. I have recommended it to others.
