title: It is depicts the drama in the live of the ...
body: It is depicts the drama in the live of the inhabitants of a small town in England, with a surprising and tragic ending.

author: Diane M. Laroche
title: Unhappiness in every family unit-- life isn't always like what is portrayed in this book
body: Tragic--well written tale--I didn't see what was coming, but it was not unanticipated.  Unhappiness in every family unit-- life isn't always like what is portrayed in this book.

author: pablo axelrad
title: Mediocre
body: I found this book to be mediocre t best. There was no point to the story, it just rambled on in a pretentious manner. I was disappointed.

author: Ivor Livingston
title: At first it seemed like a mediocre story in a mediocre town in England ...
body: At first it seemed like a mediocre story in a mediocre town in England populated with mediocre people but I was surprised that I got to know the characters so well and understood what to them was important but to me small minded issues.

author: Thomas J. Harvey
title: The Casual Vacancy is a long and winding Rd.
body: It's a very good story. Lots of interesting characters. The problem is there are two many of them and it gets hard to keep track of them all. All in all in spite of the times it boggs down it's an enjoyable read with an ending that packs a punch.

author: aac
title: I love JK Rowling
body: I love JK Rowling, but this is one of the worst books I've ever read.  The only reason my review has stars is bc the shipper/store worked well.  Don't waste your time on this book.

body: I wanted so much to like this book, but I couldn't even finish it, it was so boring.

author: Sandra Foster

author: Luz Valenzuela

body: I enjoyed it a lot Congratulation to Mrs.Rawlings

author: Linda L. Snyder

author: M. Childers
title: Stick With It
body: The story was hard to get into until I hit the middle of the book, then I couldn't put it down!

author: TDG
title: Read this one
body: an engaging and disturbing read all at the same time. J.K. Rowling never disappoints.

author: Susan
title: It's boring. I normally stick it out at this point ...
body: I have a 100 page rule with any book I am reading. If the story doesn't grab me by page 100, I decide if I am putting the book down and moving on or if I am going to finish the book.  At page 100 I decided to finish the book although the story line was slow to develop.  Now I am at page 200, roughly the half way mark, and the story line is still trying to develop.  It's boring.  I normally stick it out at this point but I I am so bored that I'm not sure it's worth it.  Ms Rowling develops characters well and is obviously making an attempt to show she can write to adults much not much is happening in the story.

author: Jill in Colorado
title: Well written but too much of a downer
body: First of all, I had no expectations of similarities to the Harry Potter books (which I loved) when I read this.  It was well written with interesting characters, but it was such a downer - all the characters seemed to fall backwards into their flaws rather than overcome any of them; all the situations went badly instead of well, the moral of the story seemed to be people are awful and life sucks.  I am not a Pollyanna - I like some depth and some flaws in my characters and some gray areas.  But this book was just a bit too negative for me.

author: Lynn
title: Not a book I would recommend at all
body: Read this for my bookclub.  Not a book I would recommend at all.

author: Kelly
title: Amazing story

body: HAVING TROUBLE GETTING INTO THIS STORY.

title: One Star

author: Maxine J. Hall
title: Four Stars
body: Very interesting, although rather difficult for a non-UK reader at times.

author: Geraldine N
title: A Disappointment!
body: I was very disappointed in this book.  It does not come up to the same standard as her detective novels written under the name of  R. Galbraith.  The author packs in so many characters, each with a problematic, intense and detailed profile that the main story-line - if there ever was one to begin with - gets completely lost.  The Casual Vacancy is formulaic and evokes the worst episodes of "Eastenders" and "Coronation Street" combined.  Do yourself a favour and give it a miss!

author: Dianne Shuker
title: Four Stars
body: I really enjoyed it

author: Pat
title: It just never caught me. The characters didn't endear ...
body: It just never caught me.  The characters didn't endear themselves to me and the story tended to chop from here to there.  It did eventually tie the loose ends up but by then I really didn't care much.  I kept hoping for some revelation to grab me but it was just a grim, seedy story with no real redeeming ending.

author: Vanna Fuqua
title: She didn't disappoint. She gives the readers an honest look at ...
body: I've read all the Harry Potter books several times over so as an avid fan, I was curious to see how JK Rowling would handle an adult themed book. She didn't disappoint. She gives the readers an honest look at the most private thoughts of her characters. With just a few pages, you get a feel for who they are as people and the face they present to the rest of the world. Some of them I couldn't stand and others I wanted to get to know better.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not for HP fans
body: Rowling's first seven novels displayed her big imagination. Her first book for adults shows her big heart. She does a wonderful job giving several points of view in the lives and events of a small town, which is no small feat.

author: Mrs. F. Wilson

author: Bronwyn Venus
title: Four Stars
body: Sucked me in so I had to keep reading. Fascinating characters! Recommended!

author: Rachel
title: It was boring. There was no point
body: It was boring. There was no point. I love Rowling. but there was no REAL plotline. there was no real action. it was a book that you trudge through hoping something happens, and it never does. there are some mildly interesting happenings, but nothing where you think to yourself "my i cannot go to sleep because this is so good." I did the audiobook, and it took me about half a year to muster the time to listen and finish. it is about a man dying, and people considering taking his place. how i friend's/family deal with the death. it is based on a small town, and the plot is pretty small to accomodate.

author: Rebecca Helm
title: Spent the last chapter crying in public because it was so good
body: Starts out slightly boring, but becomes incredibly engaging. Surprisingly so. Please, please, fight your way through the first 80 pages or so because hoooooly bejesus it is worth it.

author: judy mastin
title: One Star

author: spellavis
title: I adore JK Rowling and her writing but is one ...
body: I adore JK Rowling and her writing but is one just was not for me. Her 'Cormoran Strike' series is FAR more enjoyable. And of course dear old Harry. Maybe at a later date once I'm finished with my reading lists and all, I'll pick this one up again.

author: The Wiz
title: Well woven tale - but takes a bit of time to get into the flow.
body: I found this book very difficult to get in to.  The story set in fictional Pagford, a rural English village, is largely as life, intrigue with some tragic events that really increase the complexity of the novel.  After months of trying, I finally got in the book's rhythm, and actually quite enjoyed the second half of this book about life's twists and turns.  Having spent years of my career in England, I had no trouble with the rural language and the various hierarchy's of the English way of life.  The story is well woven and captivating, once you get in to the flow.  Worth the read.

author: Freya Gordon
title: Great Story
body: J K Rowling has proved herself as a skilled, complex author. The Casual Vacancy is worth reading - a real page-turner for adults.

author: Clare Russo
title: I loved this book
body: I loved this book.  Ms. Rowling is a master of character development, and by the end of the book, I felt like I knew each of the them.  My only negative is that I felt the story ended rather abruptly.  I would have liked some kind of an epilogue to bring closure.

body: Read from July 02 to 04, 2014

author: Deborah Nelson
title: Three Stars
body: Slow moving until the end.

author: Melodie
title: Five Stars
body: Always a joy to read her books. Good read

author: Traci Ellis
title: Loved the characters
body: Took a while to get into but once I made it through a few chapters I couldn't put it down. Loved the characters. Looking forward to her next book.

author: Victoria Leigh
title: Best book I ever read
body: I would'nt have believed that a book about a small town replacing a town official could possibly be this interesting, but because JK Rawlings wrote it I decided to give it a try (not like I had read any of the Harry Potter books).  I literally couldn't put it down.  Read it straight through (by and large) in 2 days, most unlike me.  It was the best book I have ever read.  Her characters are still with me, and after 2 weeks and another novel (Donna Tratt's Pulitzer Prizing-winning novel The Goldfinch (not 1/3 as good by the way), I am still wondering how and what those characters are doing.  Absolutely fascinating to read.  What a writer!

author: Puddle
title: Not a casual read
body: This is a hard slog of a read, like reading a TV soap that does not inspire, full of horrible characters with few redeeming features you do not really want to know the minutiae about because you would not want to bother with them in real life. Sorry JK battled to the end but did not enjoy.

author: Jesk
title: Exciting first adult book for Rowling
body: An exciting first step for Rowling into the world of adult literature. She creates a world with characters you can't help but love, hate, pity and root for. The ending is unexpected and challenging. Rowling lives up to her reputation as an enigmatic and engaging storyteller.

author: Heidi Schwalbe
title: Five Stars
body: Well written

author: Nikki
title: Suprisingly enjoyable!
body: I actually enjoyed this book a lot more than I thought I would. I hadn't heard that many amazing things about it, and to be honest, the boring-sounding summary and the surprisingly long length made me a bit worried.

author: Ka Riley
title: No Casual Writing Here!
body: Causal Vacancy incites all sorts of reactions, and my friends, like the public, are severely divided on the merits of J.K. Rowling's departure from the world of wizarding magic. Unlike the Potter series, Vacancy is written for adults and deals with the kind of political wrangling we so often see in the news. The characters are all flawed, as is humanity. Some are seriously ill, mentally or physically. Some are well off; others are poor, living in deplorable conditions. Rowling's cast is varied and large; it isn't always easy to keep track of them, and most aren't likable enough for readers to form sentimental attachments to them. However, they are all rounded and real. So real, in fact, that it's easy to see them in one's mind's eye, to know they are people who might be on any street in any neighborhood.

author: Emily
title: the characters read like real people who have real problems
body: An engrossing but difficult read.  Rowling can be heavy handed at times, but, overall, the characters read like real people who have real problems.  Some hide behind a thin veneer of respectability while others don't have that luxury.  Rowling deftly weaves the threads of all the personal narratives together, using the death of one man as a touchstone; by the end, all the characters collide through a series of heartbreaking events that bring out the best or worst in each.  The book is like life itself, moments of redemption and grace mingled with painful self-realization that can bring you to your knees.  Or worse, a life that is static, intractable to change; that's the real horror.

author: MJC
title: An Awful Tale
body: I must agree with others who have given this negative reviews.  There was not one character in this tale that brought any likability.  Every single person was damaged in some way.  Perhaps these characters will be sprinkled within a community...but not every single person is so stricken.  While it was touted to be a tale of the haves and have-nots, usually there are some good people in each.  She developed no one with any quailites of goodness.  Shame on her and to all the reviewers who wrote that this was a good story.  Simply not so!

author: ilze Truter
title: Five Stars
body: Excellent! Keep on writing J.K. Rowling! Loved it.

author: Mels books
title: Two Stars
body: Subject matter was boring and the Characters not very likeable.

author: Dana R. Stone
title: Good book for J K Rowling's next after Harry Potter
body: Good book for J K Rowling's next after Harry Potter.  I read it and enjoyed it and then my sister-in-law also read the book and said she enjoyed it as well.

author: Stephen R. Winham
title: Fabulous Departure from the Potter Books
body: I read all the Harry Potter books as they came out and began to tire of them toward the end, no doubt partially because they were written for people a generation or two younger than me.  This adult book, with a totally believable story line, is so different it could have been written by somebody else.  It captures the layers, nuances, complexities and inconsistencies of the human psyche more honestly than any book I've ever read.  It is a great literary work and a true page-turner as well.  I am anxious to move on to her other books to see what further depths Rowling can plumb.

author: Loves Cats
title: but I'm glad I did
body: It was hard to stick with this book, but I'm glad I did.  The first 3rd was a jumble of depressed and depressing characters whom I had difficulty keeping straight; and the main character was dead.  That said, once it got into the stories of the young adults, I was hooked.  I found their characters moving, real and poignant.  This book is no comedy.  It is a poignant look into the unpredictable ways we are shaped by our choices, random events and the lives of those around us.

The only kind of prediction that could be made was "Where is this going?"  Was going to read her recent book, but this cured me.  There was not a single instance of decency in life.

Will be buying her next one, too.  Reading the "Cuckoo's Calling" now, and that one is also very good.  It's a private detective story setting - hard to put down.

body: "If God made the country and man made the town, then the devil made the little country town."--Author unknown

author: happy customer
title: k Rowling did not like this at all
body: Ugh J.k Rowling did not like this at all. smh

author: Oliver Twist
title: Move over Harry Potter!
body: I never was a fan of Harry Potter. The first book was fun, but halfway through the second I realized they were all going to be the same so I stopped reading. When I found "The Casual Vacancy" in a bookstore remainder bin I picked it up in the hope this would be different, having no allegiance to the last seven books that brought J.K. Rowling fame and fortune.

author: Tyler Francke
title: This book was not for me
body: "The Casual Vacancy" was not for me. I finished it, and gave it three stars, out of respect for J.K. Rowling, an enormously gifted author, who has clearly proven that "Harry Potter" does not contain the sum of her talents. "Vacancy" is an extremely well-crafted book, and contains many beautifully written and even moving passages. Its commentary on society, through the tragic character of Krystal Weedon, is poignant and well-rendered. At the same time, the book ends at its most hopeless point, with several of its characters' story arcs  not to mention, the central conflict of the entire novel  basically unresolved.

author: Susan Hart
title: took a while to get into...
body: At 72% I finally got my attention into this story. There seemed to be too many characters and too many story lines going that weren't connecting for me. The story in the end finished strong which is why I gave it a 3 tar rating. I'm moving on to reading her next book, hopeful that it will better come together.

author: jocelyn
title: Slow. Dark. Good
body: this book is told from several different points of view and is extremely confusing in the beginning. the book didn't get extremely interesting until part 4. everything else felt like a lead up until those things. the ending was very very dark. very real. but very dark.

author: Texanwmn
title: Not great
body: I'm not sure what I expected, but this definitely wasn't it. A few parts of the story made me laugh, but some of the names and families were difficult to follow at times. Nicknames, pet names, etc, all used throughout also made it difficult to identify each character.

author: Emile
title: Wonderful narrative and cast of characters
body: Wonderful narrative and cast of characters. Yes, there are many different people to follow throughout the story, but so interesting and satisfying.

author: Joe
title: I loved this book
body: I loved this book. I think a lot of the negative reviews come from people that were expecting it to be more like Harry Potter. This is a character driven story and its target audience is adults. It is not fast paced and it is not for everyone. Overall I thought it was very well done. JK does a great job of making her characters interesting and you genuinely care about what will ultimately happen to them.

body: did not hold my attention for long... did not finish it

body: I bought this a long time ago and have yet to finish it. It doesn't quite live up to my expectations after loving the Harry Potter series so much.

author: alee
title: So disappointed with J.K.
body: We picked this book for book club and we were all disappointed in J.K. Rowling.  This book is hard to follow, and it just goes on and on....It was also a super depressing storyline, and I think that contributed to my book club not liking the book.  We were all disappointed in J.K. Rowling with this book - we had high hopes for it because she is typically an amazing writer.  Don't bother reading this.

author: Hank Rearden
title: This wasn't a horrible book. It wasn't even a bad book
body: You know I just don't understand all of the negative reviews here. This wasn't a horrible book. It wasn't even a bad book. Those hoping that this would be rooted in some fantasy land, instead of a modern countryside setting will be in for a let down. But once you get past the initial shock, you might actually come to like this little tale of social justice, or injustice, and who is it that really gets caught in the middle of power struggles.  Be forewarned, there are casualties.  No happy endings here, just victims.

author: Linda McEnaney
title: Great characters. I usually skip pages of a book ...
body: I never read any of the "Harry Potter" books but I can see their appeal if this book is any indication of her style. Great characters. I usually skip pages of a book if parts are boring--no skipped pages here. I can't remember the name of that book she wrote under a pseudonym but that was how I discovered her. Also, excellent.

author: QT 3.14
title: A compelling, complex book
body: I generally do not like stories where everything is tied into a neat little bow at the end - all the issues are resolved, the good guys "win" and the bad guys get their due - so this was just the kind of book I liked. The characters were complex - they all had good and bad qualities, even though they were sometimes subtle and the reader has to try and remember that the author is creating a realistic story. I initially found the ending to be jarring, but it was one I kept pondering and after some thought, I did "like" it.

author: Lra
title: Five Stars
body: Great book. Great character development. Very engrossing. Leaves you thinking .

author: Robyn Hotchin
title: Five Stars
body: Excellent story.

author: Luvs2Read
title: Casual Vacancy, Totally Vacated!
body: Normally I hate to do a review on any book that I didn't read a substantial part, at least.  This one, however, totally failed to get me even a third of the way through.  The depression portrayed in this writing, all the four-letter words with no real addition to the storyline, and in general, the lack of storyline that I could see, made it so I just deleted this book.  Anyone who really is interested in this book, please download a "sample" to get your own impressions before laying out good money for a bad book.

author: Grandmadoc
title: what was this
body: This book made no sense to me, ending abruptly. I am sorry I bought it and I probably won't bother to read the next one she wrote. Maybe you need to be British to understand it.

author: Clara Beard
title: Good, but not excellent
body: It is an interesting, engrossing read, but suffers, somewhat, from a lack of judicious editing. Rowling can definitely weave a tale.

author: meadhbh cahill
title: Loved this book
body: Loved this book! I don't think of JK as the Harry Potter author anymore, and have just bought the new book in the Striker series so can't wait. JK's capacity for telling an intelligent, well thought out, complex, and complete story is truly fantastic, especially as her writing style makes it seem like the book wrote itself! Not an easy thing to do, she is a gifted writer and long may she keep the stories coming!

author: RK
title: I thought CV was really good but not great
body: I thought CV was really good but not great.  If I had not known it was Rowling I would not have guessed it.  Clearly she can write and this book shows that she has some pretty great range beyond the Potterverse. I liked the butterfly effect concept that runs through it, the notion that one event triggers off a sequence that flows through the rest of the story. I thought the characters were pretty engaging for the most part although I thought a few didn't bring much to the table and some were a little one-dimensional (why did we need Maureen?  she isn't very relevant and only kind of becomes marginally significant at the end).  The whole Gavin character was a little baffling too other than she felt like we needed a character who pretty much always gets things wrong.  The one thing I did not expect from the book was that it, for me, was a gut punch throughout.  Some reviews thought this was black comedy or tragicomedy but I didn't feel like the humorous scenes balanced the drama and tragedy that runs from the first chapter on.  I did like the small town where everyone is out to ruin everyone angle.  That was an intriguing point and how all politics is local.  Some reviewer called this book 500 pages of socialist propaganda.  That just made me giggle.  I think you know what you're going to get with Rowling now that she has enough money to own the planet so didn't really get why they were so upset (assume this was all about the clinic and how the town was trying to turn its back on the Fields).

author: Charlotte B Calacci
title: Three Stars
body: Didn't move along and keep my interest.

author: leh
title: I expected so much more
body: Not impressed at all.

author: Kathleen DesHotel
title: One Star
body: JK should have stayed the Harry Potter path.

author: Rose Gjvik
title: Their story is not easily forgotten.
body: Rowling masters the art of making human nature brutally transparent. She turns us upside-down and shakes us until our heart, soul and pockets are empty of hidden truths, shames and weaknesses. The Casual Vacancy doesn't have characters, only flesh and blood people. Krystal, Robbie, Nana Cath, Kevin and Miles all come out of their pages to meet you halfway as if they were living in the backyard of your head. Not to mention what they in unison do to your heart. Their story is not easily forgotten.

author: David Allard
title: Dark Read
body: So much different from her other works but this novel still shows that J.K. Rowling has got it. Good plot and interesting characters who are relatable. While I enjoyed it, some may find this novel as a depressing read with an ending that leaves little hope for most characters. Overall, I enjoyed this novel, and I believe that those who can appreciate literature and books with "darker endings" will find reading this worthwhile.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not that great
body: I thought it quite difficult to follow the story in the beginning and could see the ending coming way before it actually happened.

author: joble
title: disappointing
body: Grammatically a very well written book. The author has managed to convey the sense of a British accent and a vocabulary to suit the locale of her plot.

author: Nancy Whitlock
title: Four Stars
body: Great shape, but I hated the book.

author: Connie Thorpe
title: Different, but the same. I liked it not being in the USA.
body: jK Rowling.

author: Alissa A. Wells
title: Snooze
body: This book is so boring I couldn't finish it. I'm nearly halfway through and I'm not entirely sure what it's about. Politics and education?

author: Virginia Cann
title: One Star
body: Not worthy

author: Katharine (ventureadlaxre)
title: bit hard to read for how real and depressing it is, but fantastic overall
body: The Casual Vacancy by J. K. Rowling is a contemporary piece of literature, seasoned with a dash of  well, people seem to be saying mystery, but I hesitantly dont agree. I simply see it as a harsh view on society that isnt exactly nice to read, but would have to agree that more spotlight probably needs to be shown on such areas. I have the feeling that the style of life shown within this book is more prevalent than many of us would like to think on.

author: connie
title: Real characters for once
body: J.K. Rowling is a genius at character and plot development. No matter what she writes becomes a page turner. And since when did it become necessary to write characters that people can commiserate with completely? Life is filled with such a variety of peoples, personalities and issues that it is refreshing to have it expressed in print.

author: Julie
title: Realistic Fiction
body: This book was okay.  It's a testament to her writing that I kept with it because I detested most of the characters (which I think was what she was going for), and the novel didn't seem like it was really going anywhere.  But I also think that was by design, as it was intended to be a snapshot of a time and of a place.  By that criteria, it's excellent.  The characters were believable, honest, and thoughtfully portrayed - especially the kids.  They behaved exactly as one would expect them to, and as such, the book was appropriately heartbreaking.

author: Christopher R. Wilson
title: Powerful tale of fearing what you don't understand
body: This book started slowly, a bit like life in sleepy Pagford. But it steadily gathers steam as the characters start to interact in expected, and unexpected, ways. The end is a blur of resolutions to individual and collective storylines. I can't say if this book reflects life in rural England or not, but it makes a whale of a story!

author: Amazon Customer
title: great characters good story line
body: Enjoyed following story but sometimes hard to keep characters straight.  Sympathetic characters for the most part but seems to end a little abruptly.

author: N Don Brown
title: Proof she can be boring
body: The dialect is great IF you want to hear/read lower income British. I am still not sure why she wrote the book. Certainly doesn't need the money. and if she does it for the love of writing she should stop now

author: Ann
title: Second reading was better
body: I started reading the book but would put it aside for a week or more between sessions.  I found it confusing as there were a lot of characters.  I finally left it alone for several months and then read it more or less continuously.  Once I did this it was easier and not at all confusing.  It's worth 4 stars.

author: JKG
title: I tried...
body: I read 25% of this.  I just couldn't get into it.  This might be the only book that I have ever read and not finished.  Her next one (the detective one) was a lot better in my opinion.

author: Shelly L. Snow
title: Not your casual book!
body: A Casual Vacancy, not your casual book, is a fictional story set in the small English town of Pagford. Like any small town it seems peaceful to the casual onlooker but once an outsider takes up residence they realize things aren't quite what they seem. Its her first book after the highly successful Harry Potter series and in no way should be compared to her earlier works.

author: Enrique
title: better than expected
body: really slow start, about 60% starts to get interesting, great ending. great reference to the way kids nowadays use cellphones and text messaging for communications.

author: Michael Gray
title: Bubbles of Isolation in a splintered world
body: In "The Casual Vacancy" J.K. Rowling has brought her unrivalled mastery of the adolescent psyche into the fictional, dysfunctional world of a small English community where individuals and families alike live in bubbles of hostile isolation.  Not only has the magic of Hogwarts gone, but most of that world's capacity for empathy and mutual caring.  Rowling uses Third Person Omniscient (the inner thoughts of characters can surface at any moment in any scene) in order to present the dynamic life of a community in which hidden resentments and insincerity abound.  Rowling personally devotes much of her wealth and heart (through her non-profit, "Lumos")to the plight of neglected children, and in "The Casual Vacancy" she combines her narrative talent with a deep concern for children in a heartless and splintered world, especially those who have no voice.  In giving the voiceless voice, she has also written a gripping tale with believable and entertaining characters.

author: Grannybunny
title: Simply Awesome!
body: If anyone was concerned that Rowling would not be able to transition into a successful writing career post Harry Potter, no problem.

author: A. Allen
title: I'm not sure what I can add, but here's my review for this Devastating Masterpiece
body: Ahh, I think I've been avoiding this review.

author: EUGENE J MOLINELLI
title: Fascinating look into small town personalities
body: Believable and flawed characters each contribute in a small way to a tragic end. Would have preferred one or two more likable characters in the mix other than the one who created the vacancy..

author: Amazon Customer
title: Book noir
body: There is no doubt in my mind that Rowling can write. Despite the unrelenting misery of everyone in the novel, I made it to the end.

author: Darragh V. Metzger
title: Don't bother
body: JK Rowling can write, no one doubts that.  But in all these pages, there is not one single character who is not a waste of air and food.  Makes me resent having to spend the time with any of them.  Real life is filled with people like this; they're in the papers every day, on TV, all around.  Sadly.  So why should I read about them?

author: Donna C. Short
title: Good Read
body: I had not read any of J K Rowling's other books but must say that I thoroughly enjoyed

author: Angela Michelle Jay
title: An amazing, true to life tale.
body: This book was as I expected, a masterpiece. Rowling has again proved to be a master of her craft. The story is wound tight from start to finish, woven with believable, (sometimes agitating) wonderful characters in their own right. You don't have  to be a previous reader of Rowling to enjoy this book; however, you might want several pots of tea on hand.

author: Brian Nallick
title: A jumbled mess.
body: Like many others Im a huge Potter fan so I was anxious to see how JK would fare with a non Potter book.

author: Burt
title: Worthless
body: Probably the most worthless use of time in my lifetime. Absolutely no redeeming value.  Much better to take a nap.

author: stephen keyte
title: Steve's
body: It takes a long time to get going. But it a very accurate account of lives in some UK housing estates. Very good characters

author: Jen D.
title: I'm so sad
body: I'm so sad about this book.  I tried so hard, but couldn't get past page 30.  It was just so dull and spent so much time introducing characters with very little happening.

author: Juli Gasque
title: unexpected disappointment
body: I found this a very difficult read.  Not at all what I expected.  I could find no redeeming characters  and had to make myself finish the book.

author: LeeAnn Bigley
title: The title is right!
body: Casually written by a vacant mind. If I hadn't read the Harry Potter series, there'd be no way I would ever pick up another J.K. Rowling book. Is this really the same author who wrote that series? If I were to picture the author of this book, I'd guess a middle-aged woman in a chronic state of funk, deserted by her husband and children and embittered against the world, living in a small community where she is able to pick up on all the scum floating around in her town. Surviving the book's pages is a superhuman effort only viable to convince one that this author MUST (please God) have a point in here somewhere! But no ... It is as actually as bad as it seems to be, all the way through. This is the type of book rendered offensive by the author's unloading such trash on her unsuspecting public, given that this author has encouraged readers in previous novels. Shame!

author: RenaudME
title: Expect something new
body: I had completely gone into this book first expecting the magic of Harry Potter and also a murder mystery.

author: Amazon Customer
title: A "grim" place
body: I didn't expect Hogwarts, but this novel was just too bleak.  Try "The Cukoo's Calling".  A good mystery with a sympathetic protagonist.

author: Joan Carlton
title: Cheap Shot
body: It was hard to care about any of the characters.  Their lives were all too fictions to develop any real interest in the overlaping events that were supposed to be connected.  Dissapointing!

author: Vera Regelbrugge
title: Jk Rowling
body: Had it difficult to start reading this but once I was in the story loved the book. Another great work.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Amazing
body: Depressing but utterly thought provoking and touching. Well written, witty and intriguing. The first half is a bit hard to plough through, I'll admit, but well worth it in the end. Well worth the read.

author: Gibbs
title: Not a bad experience, worth reading, but I can't say I liked it.
body: There is a lot of anger and pain in this book.  The people lead lonely, angry, and often desperate lives.  There is something to be said for the strength that keeps people moving forward, the "extraordinariness" of real kindness, the difficulty in doing good, or understanding one's own motives.  There is something about the danger of lives not examined and the illusions and delusions that keep us alive.  There is something about how inter-connected lives are, and how little we can appreciate that or are aware of it.  There is a lot to think about here.  But I did not find any satisfaction in it nor would I suggest it to anyone looking for something to read.

author: Jiri
title: Fascinating story, great language
body: I really enjoyed the book.

author: Kasper W
title: Well written and thrilling plot
body: That Ms Rowling has managed to put the HP universe well away in this book stands to her credit. It is an interesting plot that grows more and more interesting with each page, depicting what goes on behind the drawn curtains and closed doors of small town England. The only let down is the end which is perhaps a little unsurprising. Still it is very well written and a really great read. Well worth buying.

author: ipad reader
title: Nothing like Harry Potter!
body: This book is totally depressing yet I was compelled to finish it anyway. Each character has their own evil selfish thoughts exposed as their lives intermingle in a twisted tale revolving around the death of one man. Graphic descriptions, language and deviant sex descriptions don't usually bother me but there was absolutely NO redeeming goals or happiness to be found in any of the towns peoples' lives. This is the first book I have ever written a review on and I've read a lot over 60 years! I am just amazed at how the same person who wrote the magical Harry Potter books could have also written this. Sure there was some child abuse and evil going on in HP but there was also good triumphing over evil. In The Casual Vacancy, there's just the evil. I will delete this book from my ipad and do NOT recommend reading it.

author: Penny
title: Interesting character study
body: I found it fascinating that there were no outwardly focused characters except the dead one. I did enjoy the characters themselves and had full pictures of them in my head as I read the story.

author: Mary Mertz
title: Not Harry Potter
body: I found this book hard to read.  I kept getting the characters mixed up and finally made a list to keep track.  Depressing stuff mostly.

author: Mysontherobot
title: Well written, but not very exciting.....
body: This was just not my kind of book.  The book was well written, and you felt as if you really know the characters,  I just prefer mysteries.  It was more a book of day to day activities.

author: Art Flores
title: Not recommended reading - what a drool of a story
body: Is this Rowling's first attempt at writing fiction?  A very sad plot indeed.  There's really not much of a story unless you want to read about people's dull lives. Not developed well including plot, characters and development of story.

author: Bruce
title: All Politics is Local
body: J.K. Rowling is the most financially successful writer of this generation, having penned the Harry Potter series which morphed into various forms of lucrative licensed entertainment.  The Casual Vacancy is a stylistic departure for Rowling.

author: n. cunningham
title: Boring
body: It's a very boring book and was not interesting at all. I'm actually really sad I spent money on it.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Well written characters and story
body: If I was to tell you what this book is about your probably think it's boring. But the way the characters are created, I couldn't stop reading. Some if them are not mineable at all, in some of them you can find pieces of yourself. Very well written and thought provoking.

author: Corinne Hall
title: True life characters
body: Great human drama, wonderful characters, hard to put down.  Easy for the reader to associate with the characters.  Am hoping Ms. Rowling puts another page-turner out soon!

author: Unknown
title: disappointing
body: I expected something great from this author,though the concept of focusing on one subject was interesting it became tiring. I would have preferred it in a shorter version.

author: VA
title: psychological foray
body: Interesting fictional account into the minds of various community members responding the death of a town member. Perhaps a bit too long

author: Vincent J. Joyce
title: A good start
body: I think JK Rowling is off to a good start as her post Potter career begins to blossom. Look forward to reading her tomes far into the future.

author: Liz McLeod
title: Slow to start
body: J.K. Rowling has given us another group of interesting characters who's lives become intertwined by a lust for power and jealousy. These characters have real human flaws and desires. Much more grown up than Ron and Harry and get up to way more mischief. After a slow start getting to know each character it literally could not put this book down. I look forward to more of her writings.

author: Bobbe
title: An adult version of Harry Potter
body: This book was not fast easy reading, but intriguing enough to keep me reading.  It left me wanting to read  more about the lives involved, just as Harry Potter did.

author: SHELLY BURKO
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: This is Rowling's first major foray into adult literature.  I am a grandmother, but I loved the Harry Potter series.  They were well written and contained everything good fiction should have.  I thought this was just okay.  I saw a similar writting style as in the Potter series, but the book was just not as good.  There were too many characters, some with nicknames,which confused things  even more.  I thought she tried to include too manythings in the bookso it was too long as well.  We did have a great discussion at our monthly book club meeting.  We all agreed about the rating of the book, but the discussion was great. It was the best part of the book.  I read a sample of Cuckoo's Calling and really liked it.  Several of the women read it and said it was better than The Casual Vacancy.  ilook forward to reading it.

author: D. Benson
title: Not Harry Potter...
body: I had a really hard time engaging with this book initially...actually for about half the book.  After I reached the point where i was engaged, my overall perception changed for the positive.  Not for everyone, but a very well written book, complex with a dark social theme.

author: David D.
title: Definitely NOT Harry Potter!
body: I was prepared for something different, but I was not prepared for the unrelenting darkness and malevolence that permeates Rowling's newest world. Usually one can discern the protagonists and antagonists, but it was really hard to find anyone to cheer for, let alone care about. Even those seemingly worthy of some sort of sympathy are so flawed otherwise that they too dissolve into the waves of selfishness, deceit, paranoia, and pain that flood these pages. Now ... if the reader can handle page after page, chapter after chapter of such despair, rest assured the ride will be a worthy one, as the writing is brilliant and the many intertwined stories so compelling that it is hard to stop turning the pages even when the hint of absolute revulsion lies immediately beyond.This book is disturbing, depressing, vulgar (excessively, I thought, hence a loss of a star), and ultimately offers a less than fulfilling denouement (hence the loss of a second star), but it proves that J.K. Rowling can conjure quite a tale without the aid of witchcraft.

author: AMil
title: slow start, a great finish
body: I really wanted to love this book. While there were definitely parts of it that shined, a really tedious set-up and the lack of a central character (or even characters) to root for left it at 3 stars for me. If you can get through the tedious introduction and are good at plowing through that kind of stuff, I'd recommend this book. The writing and character development are excellent, and kind of make up for all the other boring stuff. If you're not good at reading books that don't grab you within the first few chapters, then maybe pass on this one.

author: dianora
title: Bah
body: I read only the first few pages. Didn't work its magic on me. I was expecting more from the next J.K. Rowling book.

author: carolyn turkington
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I thought this was a great look into small town politics. What seemed like a simple story really turned out to be an indepth look into human kind. It shows how people come to be the way they are as well as showing that there are two sides to every story. Highly recommend it whether you're a Potter fan or not. You might be disappointed if you're expecting a story about the wizarding world but you will be very pleased if you are looking for Rowling's inherently kind and wise voice.

author: Shirley Eyden
title: Not anything like the Harry Potter books!
body: I found this book disturbing and didn't fall in love with the characters which I did with the Harry Potter books.  This book was one dysfunctional character after another.  Would not recommend this book at all.

author: Lorraine
title: I wanted to love it....but.....
body: Rowling presents us with moments of brilliance, heartbreaking loss, and grime in the disparity-filled lives of the residents of Pagford Parish, however, they are sandwiched in between vast, unrewarding stretches of tedium and mundane character development.  Taken on whole, it's just enough to keep you reading to the end, but not enough to make you really care about any of the characters until the last few dozen pages.

author: R. McGee
title: Casual Vacancy begs for a sequel
body: Casual Vacancy reminds me a lot of James Joyce's Dubliners;interconnected allies and enemies,  sometimes within the family and in  the small town in which they languish in.  The most compelling character is Crystal Wheaton, an abused teen teetering on the edge of the civility in Pagford and the doom of drugs and poverty and a hollowed out mum.  The lyrics from Rihanna were a delight and a surprise and the ending begs for a sequel. Overall,  the sum of the parts are greater than the sketchy whole. It was good to find Rawlings in the real, messed up world, a universe away from Harry Potter.

author: NTM
title: A well written, deeply moving novel!
body: The Casual Vacancy takes an entertaining approach to a realistic problem. Poverty, drug abuse, and adolescent struggles are all explored through multidimensional characters living in a secretly corrupt British town. The reader is enveloped by a setting vividly described by J.K. Rowling and is taken along for a ride that includes dramatic parish council fights, eye opening exposure to poverty and addiction, and a devistating ending to a tragically comical book.

author: M Domaschenz
title: Well written but 'Oh so depressing'
body: I read this story out of interest as I had read all the HP books as my children grew up.  I wasn't expecting wizards and magic but what I got was a depressing look at British small town life, leaving out all the good bits.  I kept reading hoping that there might be a glimmer of light.  I won't be a 'spoiler' so I'll leave it up to the individual reader to see if they can find one.

author: Bill Simpson
title: Piece of Trash!
body: I had looked forward to reading a "non-Harry Potter" book by Ms Rowling because I had enjoyed that series very much, but was almost immediately disappointed in The Casual Vacancy from the first chapter. I was surprised by the vulgarity used and the pitiful cast of characters she'd created. While I was initially interested in the what was began to unfold in the book, I just could not overcome the foul language contained within the book and so this was one of the very few books I totally stopped reading and have no plans of ever reading it.

author: Stephanie E. Snider
title: like home
body: i love her style of writing! it feels like home. obviously, the subject is a far cry from Harry Potter, but her handling of characters is familiar. there is justice and there is injustice, much like in the Potter series. Rowling has a gift in presenting seemingly unsavory characters in a way that allows you to at least understand why they are the way they are. everyone has a story, and rowling is a master at telling. the actual story was not what was fascinating to me. it was the characters and their interwoven lives. well done!

author: Christine Smith
title: I liked it!
body: As others have said, it rambled around a bit and some of the characters seemed a bit contrived and sometimes vicious, but she is of course a great writer and it was enjoyable.  I stuck with it and was glad I did.  Interestingly, for someone who wrote the definitive young people's book, she gave the children, even the grown-up daughter, the power to affect their parents' lives.  Particularly in this case, when no one else seemed to call parents out on their poor behavior.  I will read her other books.

author: Patricia Breitzer
title: quite different from Harry Potter
body: Realistic, well-written, somewhat depressing. It also contains some comedy, mainly in the online postings of several anonymous townspeople, one calling himself "The ghost of Barry Fairbrother." Fairbrother has died at the beginning of the book, leaving a vacancy on the city council.

author: Robin O,
title: a bit difficult to get into but worth it!
body: The characters were well written but with so many of them, you got a bit confused. Otherwise, it was an excellent story with a good message.

author: K. Spangler
title: Bad language.
body: Unfortunately, the book has too many swear words. I'm just not a fan of reading literature with that many uses of the "f" word.  I'm aware that the British use this word more than we do, but I don't appreciate it.

author: Kenn Day
title: Well written but degrading
body: For Potter fans, imagine an entire novel written about the world of Harry's muggle relations, unrelieved by hogwarts or magic of any kind. This is the world as presented by Rowling in The Casual Vacancy.

author: D. Wright
title: Great book!
body: I have been reading books by J.K. Rowling for years now and I cannot get enough of them, I just can't put them down once I start reading them, this one was even harder. Would recommend 100%

author: V.P.Q.
title: Highly recommended
body: A very good read and the storylines wove very well. The characters were very believable and well made. Quite emotional.

author: MHD
title: better than the reviews
body: I read some of the reviews of this book on Amazon and almost didn't buy it.  I'm glad I followed my heart instead.  The book has richly developed characters and a cohesive story line.  I'll think about this book for some time to digest all of what I've read and may go back and read it again.  There are a lot of characters all introduced in a short number of pages, so I think I'll enjoy it more the second time around.  I would recommend the book to anyone who enjoys thinking about what makes people tick.

author: Mr Toad
title: I had difficulty staying interested
body: Remarkably tedious. I got to page 100 and there were still no characters I cared about or plot to interest me. I never put books aside and I finally put it aside. I started flipping ahead and it doesn't appear anything ever really happens- there is a large cast of characters and many of them seem kind of similar- had trouble distinguishing one middle age couple from another and what they wanted. There are some nice descriptive bits here and there, and racy bits to show it is for adults but the sexy stuff just feels awkward and self conscious. Mostly tedious. I read a lot of genres- from Jane Austen to Dickens to young adult to sci fi and fantasy to Mary Stewart- but this was just unreadable.

author: Alicia D. Finnerty
title: Well done, J.K.
body: Heartbreaking but addictive read. Will stay with me for a long time. Once you begin you won't want to stop reading.

author: Jill Clardy
title: Complex Characters in a Village Setting
body: My review is for the Audiobook, skillfully read by Tom Hollander. The audio book runs nearly 18 hours, so it occupied me for several weeks during my daily commute.

author: Catrina Van Horn
title: Horrible
body: I bought this book assuming it was going to be fantastic. Look at the author, It is the same one as the amazing Harry Potter books, but his couldn't hold a candle to those books. Much more of an adult book and it was not well written. Clearly, it just got past because of who the author is. She should stick to kids stories in my opinion.

author: NJtwinmom
title: insightful, thought-provoking
body: This is a far cry from Harry Potter, and I was a HUGE HP fan, but it is still very much worth reading. This story examines/illustrates a common, widespread social dilemma from multiple angles/points of view with keen insight. The character descriptions an interpersonal dynamics between characters were so good, so insightful, you wonder how Ms. Rowling does it. She puts herself in the position of the miserable housewife, the rebellious teenage boy, the junky mom, etc. and creates such rich and realistic internal dialogue for each character. She is truly brilliant.

author: David Antunes
title: Simply amazing!
body: Being a Harry Potter fan, when this new JK Rowlinkg book was available for sale I immediately bought it.

author: Gail Harden
title: A farce or not?
body: A bit over the top for me.  Every single character (and there were many, hard to keep up with them) was dysfunctional.  In the end, I figured it was a farce, but I didn't love it.

author: Eleonora Domenichini
title: A casual vacancy tantalizing the desire of residents in a British small town.
body: I do not understand the negative reviews of this book. The characters, dialogues, and events are so masterfully intertwined, that it would not room to boredom even if the story was boring. And it is not.

author: D. at LLRC
title: A adult book by J. K. Rowling
body: The book is about the politics of a small town in England.  I never finished the second disk, not because the story wasn't that good, because of the language used.  I know that the "F" word may not be as profane a word in England, but to hear it constantly used was something that I felt I did not need to listen to.

author: Diane Tabern
title: Read for book club choice
body: Having read all of Harry Potter books I was curious as to what Casual Vacancy would be like.  The book has some strong characters, most have very few redeeming qualities. The story of semi rural Englands local Parish councillors was full of secrets, lies and indescressions. Without giving away too much, it is unsurprising, given Rowlings previous subject matter, that it is the children who end up causing the whole village to unravel and turn on itself. Overall, an excellent read and recommened not just for HP fans.

author: L. Warren
title: I did not enjoy
body: This very dark story has well developed characters, but maybe too many for a clear focus.  It seems more like an exercise.  Of the 18 or so examined characters.  Only 3 youth and 3 adults seem to have a shred of hope or growth of experience by the end.  I dont need it to be black & white / good & evil, but in an entire village there was only one nice, hopeful, caring person (who often neglected his family for his causes) and he drops dead in the first chapter.  Everyone else is selfish, evil, abused, timid, intimidated, miserable, defeated, arrogant, judgmental, abusive or powerless. Some have described this as more realistic but I felt it to be unbalanced.  Like the negatives have been hand-picked and anything positive lasting for longer than a moment is ignored for the sake of exposing the dark parts.

author: Margaret Barnett
title: I did like it, but only Casually good
body: There were a lot of characters to keep track of and a lot of words that I had to look up.  Some of the English phrases were hard to understand.  Very good story line with lots of twists and turns.  I liked Cuckoo's Calling much better though.

author: Kristin  Gronemeyer
title: slow reading
body: I was expecting more, I don't know, action? Or at least a story that moved along a little faster.  Lots of characters to keep track of.

author: Steve Riley
title: Great story!
body: I very much enjoyed this book although I started reading it with some trepidation but I was pleasantly surprised.  I enjoyed knowing what each character was thinking as it was written in third-person omniscient point of view. It did take some effort in keeping everything in account but it was worth it.  I was especially impressed with the authors understanding of the issues in teenagers lives.

author: Amazon Customer
title: I liked it, but not as much as the Harry Potter series
body: It took me awhile to get into this book, I have to admit.  i found that there were so many characters that it was hard for me to remember who was who and also track who was married to who.  But I do have problems remembering names of people I know as well.  I also do not have large chunks of time in my life to read and there are large gaps in the time I spend with a book, so remembering all the characters might be easier if you sat for an hour or so to read instead of 10 minutes here and there.

author: Giles S.
title: the most boring book I have ever read:
body: Was this the book that Janet Rowling wrote under a pseudonym that received great reviews?

author: Carol
title: The Moral Vacancy
body: I may have expected too much from J.K. Rowling.  She has such an awesome imagination.  However, in The Casual Vacancy, she took a small village in England and made everyone in it a pervert of some sort.  Not a good person could be found!  Very disappointing to me.

author: Constance
title: Excellent story of real life not magical life
body: I did not expect to like this story but was drawn into the life and characters of this village.  They were all imperfect and tragic to some extent but the ending illustrated the strength and simplicity of the human spirit.

author: Dramatic Conclusions, Pam Boyd
title: A Book That Meddles
body: After reading this book, I cannot look at any photo of Rowling without seeing a face familiar with all manner of suffering, loneliness, and isolation. Although the casual vacancy is a political descriptor, the term seems to also describe the painful vacancy that exists casually in our relationships.

author: SMBP
title: Disappointing.
body: Of course, following a fabulously successful Potter series is difficult, but this lacks imagination and class. Would have been better to quit while you were ahead.

author: Kits
title: A decent read (plot spoilers in review)
body: I was rather excited to read Casual Vacancy by Rowling. I haven't read Cuckoo's Calling so I thought it would be interesting to see what she came up with after the Harry Potter series. The book didn't overwhelm me neither did it excite me that much. There was too much time spent on details of the characters. Fleshing out characters is one thing but over working them is quite another. I also reckon that the two deaths (plot spoiler) are unnecessary just to create a catalyst of sorts. A one time read only if you are a true Rowling fan.

author: Stephen
title: Meet the Dursley's neighbors
body: What I imagined the brown of little whinging could have been like if there was no Hogwarts and we delved deeper into the life of mugggles.

author: CLAIRE H.
title: not very interesting...the casual vacancy
body: I did not like the kindle version of the book...seemed like the subjects kept changing just about every other paragraph..not at all like the harry potter books which I thoroughly enjoyed...it took me a long time before I finished the book...I found it really boring..

author: Phil
title: Underwelmed
body: I got the senario but it was pointless. The only possible reason to write this book was to verify the state of the UK society.

author: Rosie
title: Mr. Perfect has died
body: The story revolves around how all the inhabitants of a Parish are connected to "Mr. Right" and how they are failing to "measure up".  For in this town "it's The secrets that will kill you".  While i could anticipate the denouement, it was not as predictable is i thought it would be if people jumped on their white steeds and galloped of into the sunset.

author: debsdeal
title: Different J. K. Rowling
body: Pretty good read for a first time book of a different genre.  I did not, however, like the ending.  I guess I am a sucker for a happy ending.

author: theweed
title: Disappointing
body: After the Harry Potter series, I looked forward to a good book.  I should have guessed that an author who changes genres often stumbles a bit, failing to meet the quality of the previous book.  Ms. Rowling din't only stumble, she tripped and fell.  During the entire read, I failed to see any plot.  The characters, all unlikeable and rife with myriad problems, underwent little change, either good or bad.  I failed to see the point of the entire story, if that's what you dare call it.  It seemed more like one very long, boring vignette.  I do hope she does better with her next one.

author: Francesca
title: Dull Characters
body: I liked the quality of the writing, but the story was rather uninteresting.  Believe it or not her characters were predictable and nearly all living men were caricatures and the woman just slightly more developed.  I didn't really care what happened to most of them.  Nevertheless, the ending wrapped most of the story lines up into a neatly presented package

author: Nancy H Miller
title: Better than expected
body: Fun,crazy and sad all in one. Although I bought it for the author I really enjoyed the style and the story.

author: Angela Chiang
title: Completed the book, was baffled and disappointed
body: I did give the book a chance.  You cannot compare this book with 1984 or other classics as a few other reviewers have done; it is honestly a straightforward observation of several families in town.  It is not a disturbing character study.  I found all of the characters caricatures of extreme personalities or extreme situations, and each of them a different extreme.  Their reactions of things that happen to them are immediate, surface reactions; it does not allow the reader to be sympathetic or to be empathetic to the characters.

author: Angela
title: Loved it
body: I know a lot of people who had a hard time getting into it. There are many characters, so I can see how that can happen, but you start to learn and care about all the characters and understand how they are all connected in a small town, so stick with it!

author: maureen c. ogden
title: On-the-mark commentary of today's world
body: Highlighted the cruelty and pettiness exhibited by so many in the world today.  J.K. Rowling, as in previous books, makes her characters come alive.

author: louise
title: Great  story
body: From the beginning this story was very enthralling.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Very much a downer
body: I am glad to see J.K. Rowling venture into other genres but, while this book may have been well written, it was not my cup of tea. The story started off depressing and never got better. I don't know how it ends because I got too depressed reading it to finish it. I very much enjoyed her mystery story and am looking forward to its sequel but I really didn't care for The Casual Vacancy.

author: Joan Plummer
title: Rowling did not achieve her goal.
body: This book is so boring, not up to J.K. Rowling's capabilities.  Small town lives as in any town anywhere.  Nothing exciting or even worth reading.

author: Sarah Atkinson
title: Power through the set up stage- it's worth the read.
body: What a book.  Of course, I picked it up

author: Robert Benfatto
title: Rowling turns her modern day Pagford into the equivalent of Trollope's Barsetshire and George Eliot's English Midlands.
body: A moving novel with multiple living, breathing characters moving seamlessly throughout the intertwined stories depicted in this brilliant work of craftmanship and art. I have never read a Harry Potter book and I gather those works  are the reason behind this allergy some readers have to to everyday language, drug use and human sexuality that are offered as the reason for their bad reviews.This work is not disappointing. It's a triumph. Rowling turns her modern day Pagford into the equivalent of Trollope's Barsetshire and George Eliot's English Midlands.  A very sad book that begins with a death and ends during a funeral, but with a life affirming memory.

author: Beckyloutx
title: Weak
body: Loved loved loved Harry potter series and was prepared to love this book too. But the characters seemed one dimensional,plot was thin...never  satisfactory. I just couldn't get into it. Also some aspects seemed very shallow...the treatment of characters lacks veracity--I just cannot believe people actually think/behave this way. It's funny because in some science fiction and fantasy stories outrageous things happen, but I still "believe" the characters. In this book, I wanted to believe...but I just couldn't.

author: L.Rose
title: twists and turns right up until the end
body: twists and turns right up until the end....didn't see the ending coming at all.

author: Randy norton
title: J.K. Rowling
body: I am having a difficult time getting interested in this book. I'm a grandmother who loved the Harry Potter series but her attempt at an adult book leaves me uninterested. Hopefully it will improve as I read on.

author: Ximena
title: Don't read if you are expecting something similar to Harry Potter
body: Casual Vacancy is a very good book. I enjoyed it because it shows some of the realities of the welfare system in the UK and the views of their different citizens. It also shows how even with this system some people fall through the cracks. If you are expecting something similar to HP do not read it as this is a book for adults. It has some strong language and some very visual stuff but i do believe is a very good book. I actually enjoyed reading some more serious literature from her although I do love the harry potter series.

author: genevany
title: Defining human nature
body: Rowling takes a massive amount of characters and defines each one by picking them apart for flaws. She manages to meld this into a story about life and death and human nature. The seamy undersides of each are exposed and dissected as though the reader were there in the room with each character. The story line is tightly wound around a small town environment where everyone plays at being important. Just like a small planet of ants, they go about their business with an agenda of their own.

author: Edward L. Keating
title: outstanding
body: I truly enjoyed this book.  It was such an amazing set of character studies.  Even when I was not reading, the story stayed in my mind.  I'm likely to start it again.

author: Patricia H. Bullock
title: She's here for us.
body: I couldn't put the book down; Rowling gets inside the heads of so many bewildered people, of all ages, that the story is automatically exciting and a bit sad from the first page. Anxiously awaiting more.

author: D. K. Ennis
title: New Avenue for Readers
body: I started this book and liked it but I prefer her mystical adventures of Harry Potter.  J.K. Rowling is an amazing writer!!!

author: Luke
title: not so casual
body: Her characters come off the page and are extremely believable though very flawed. It is a depressing read, but well written and haunting. If you work with young people, it is a valuable read. So often adults make judgments about kids that make situations worse rather than better.

author: carrie-ann ness
title: Most people in my book club hated the story as well
body: I have never read Harry Potter (yes yes i know) so I didn't come into this book with any particular expectations.  It wasn't an enjoyable storyline....quite brutal in places.  I also didn't find the writing to be anything of consequence.  Most people in my book club hated the story as well...although one woman really enjoyed the writing style.

author: penny
title: it takes a village to raise a child
body: Never has this quote been so true. A community can make or break an individual . Unfortunately tis is a breaking rather than making story.

author: Michael Self
title: I'm glad I stuck with it
body: Initially, I wondered if the author was being just a tad too clever. On passing that, I began to relax into the delightful character development that continued for the bulk of the rest of the novel. I'm glad I stuck with it. A satisfying read on multiple levels.

author: Ben
title: Well written, insightful peek into the dynamics of a small town
body: Full of well rounded characters, this story will keep you turning the pages while simultaneously feeling both empathy and disgust for each of the many characters. Ultimately, it leaves you walking away thoughtful and curious about where you fit in with the cast and questioning your own motivations for good or bad.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Disappointing!
body: JK, stick to Harry Potter books.  This was one of the most hard to read, depressing (and not just the subject matter), confusing books ever. Every possible scenario was stuffed into this book and. . .nothing!!  It was a huge disappointment from such a successful writer.  My best advice is don't read it!!

author: Barbara Wert
title: Very depressing
body: Skipped thru to the end hoping it would get better. The writer found little positive in the life of her characters.

author: Brian G.
title: I kept hoping for an actual plot...
body: ...but it never materialized. I love JK Rowling's Harry Potter books, but this one didn't do it for me. It reminded me of an episode of Seinfeld where they joked it was a "show about nothing." This is a book about nothing.

author: ozone
title: All gossip, no plot.
body: I listened to this book on CD's I got from the library.  I'd actually give this book 2.5 stars.  The reason I rounded up is because J.K. Rowling is a great writer.  She has a way with words that is to be admired.  So I just couldn't give it two stars.  I didn't dread listening to it or consider stopping, but the story just wasn't very good.  It was very much like a soap opera.  If you are old enough to remember the TV show Dallas, I think it was much like that, except without a plot.  If you like the idea of listening to a bunch of gossip, this book is for you.

author: T. Schlosser
title: Wanted to Disagree with the Bad Reviews
body: The negative reviews kept me from buying this book when it first came out.  However, when it showed up on the shelf in the lunchroom I decided to read it and form my own opinion.  Honestly, I can't add much to the other bad reviews except to agree with them. Want to read JK Rowling's work for adults try Cuckoos Calling.

author: E.G.
title: Not bad
body: Just a story about a town of people and their lives. After the success of Harry Potter, how do you go main stream? This was a decent story overall. But, not as engaging as the Potter series.

author: Regine Tollefsen
title: heart break
body: Don't read this book with Harry Potter in mind. It is a very real tale of social and psychological pressures in contemporary England. The social worker in me highly recommends it.

author: JDT75
title: Having problems sleeping?  Read this!
body: She did such a great job of keeping readers on the edge of their seats when reading Harry Potter.  Not a real fair comparison as this book was geared toward adults but her attempt at this was lacking.  Just couldn't get into it.  Just too slow and boring for me.  Found myself falling asleep while trying to struggle through.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Excellent read, left me thinking
body: Just finished this novel. I had a very difficult time putting it down from the very beginning. Rowling's writing is superb. Each of the characters were so well developed and brilliantly described. They are realistic in the sense that we all know people like these. It's a book that leaves you frustrated with human nature, people's poor choices and selfishness, but encouraged by the way that some people can make a difference with a little bit of effort. I guess it's not a book for everyone, but some of the one star reviews reveal that there are a lot of people out there who don't understand or appreciate the real purpose of great literature : to teach us more about human nature, even if what we learn is the ugly truth.

author: Jane Offutt
title: Teens expose parents' bad behavior
body: I found this story interesting because the bad behavior of the teens was sympathetic compared to the bad behavior of their parents.  The story is clever in how J.K. Rowling shows how teens use social media to turn their parents' lives upside down.

author: Isabel Luengo
title: Shut down the Fields!
body: The book is fun to read, but it is a little too Peyton Pacish. When I finished the book, I was completely for closing the detox clinic and letting the Fields go. What a story of failure! Rowling would have done better if she had chosen a character from the Fields with some hope of redemption. It was hard to feel much sympathy for any of the characters. What a mess!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Interesting character development wasted on a story without a purpose.
body: Honestly, I am the kind of person who just has to know how a story plays out, but I cant with this book, and I wont.  I got to page 105 and then read the last five or six pages and I am done, I wont be back to it.  Too many characters, too much description but no plot i could find in those first 105 pages and an ending that I just wasn't prepared to read up to.

author: Amazon Customer
title: A Fascinating Character Study in Abnormal Psychology
body: When Barry Fairbrother drops dead of an aneurism while celebrating his wedding anniversary with his wife at the local golf club in the small town of Pagford, it leaves a casual vacancy on the parish council.  Residents of the town react differently to Fairbrothers death, and the novels main focus is on the interaction of the different personalities, how they are affected by the death, and how they plot and scam to use the death to their advantage.

author: Ellen Peterson
title: Excellent read
body: Sad to see negative reviews of this book, probably because the readers were expecting more Harry Potter.  This book has many characters introduced quickly,  warts & all, but once you get it you are sucked into the unfolding story.  The individual characters (some not very sympathetic) may seem unattached in the beginning, but as you read on it becomes clear that each one's actions impact the final outcome.  Really good book and I hope to see more of these from Ms. Rowling.

author: leigh
title: thrilling from the start
body: Although I was expecting a mystery or an adventure like Harry Potter, this did not disappoint. Brilliantly crafted and entertaining, this book is a must read!

author: E. Tait
title: Wonderful read
body: Rowling creates Well developed characters, as well as wonderful descriptions of small town politics in England. A beautiful book. Recommended!

author: LeeAnn
title: Just keep reading...
body: The Casual Vacancy initially caught my attention because of the author.  Had I known what the book was about ahead of time, I may not have purchased or read it.  I am not particularly interested in politics at all and find small-town or local politics to be possibly one of the most boring subjects to discuss.  However, upon completing the book, I am glad that I took the time to read this story.

author: Joan
title: An entertaining read
body: I read somewhere (after I read it) that this is Jilly Cooper coupled with Joanna Trollope.  Couldnt agree more, how many times did I think of Jilly Cooper reading this. I'm not knocking Jilly Cooper, I read her voraciously when I was younger, and have read all the HP books, and I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Its not great literature, but it is an entertaining read

author: M. Hornsby
title: Didn't make it past page 22
body: I was looking forward to reading this book, especially since it takes place in Britain.  I love to read about their villages, towns, cultures etc.  However, I was sorely disappointed when I began running into curse words and adolescent sexual thoughts and actions.  I'm not a Puritan by any means, but come on now - in the span of 3 pages, the "F" word was used 7 times!  Then when "JFC" was used, that was it for me.  Sorry if I sound picky, but had I known about the language and other factors in this novel I would not have bought it.  Just a heads up for those folks who prefer not to read books with "colorful" language.

author: James Owen
title: It's not all bad
body: I am re-reading it now (my usual habit) so I reserve the right to change my mind, but I was not into the book until 65% (It's on my Kindle.) After that, I began to be involved with Krystal. That's a bit long.

author: Stargazer51
title: Boring
body: I was the only one in the household who actually finished this book.  I can't understand how JK Rowling could do such a superb job with the Harry Potter series but bomb on this book.

author: Oboe Mom
title: A well-written and unexpected story
body: Couldn't say why I liked this book until I read the other 4-5 star reviews, which excellently explained why I did. I think Rowling wrote an excellent book. I almost didn't read it because of the negative reviews, but I'm really glad I did. It is dark. It is real. I can see my community in Pagford. I'm glad that Rowling wrote a different type of book than her Potter series.

author: Lowell N. Schwankl
title: Absorbing cautionary tale.  Couldn't put it down.
body: A little like watching a slo-mo train wreck.  Fascinating look into where a free-stuff society can go over a few decades.  Should scare hell out of those Americans who think this kind of entitlement life is a good thing.

author: Flopsysmum
title: Anything but a Casual Vacancy
body: This is not a children's book so be warned people! This adult novel by JK Rowling showcases her fantastic use of language. Her descriptive and rhythmic style grabs the readers imagination from the beginning. For anyone who knows the West Country in England, the novel quickly transports the reader to many small rural town facing change from encroaching urban areas. The character of Howard, could very well be found in many villages: larger than life in size and in personality. I loved Fats and Andrew, typical cocky teenagers, even if their actions were appalling at times. However, these characters were so well developed, they could have walked through my door with own son of a weekend! This is a novel that showcases JK Rowling's sense of humour throughout. I loved this despite it not being a warm and fuzzy story. JK, you rock!

author: Virginia M. van Rookhuyzen
title: Look for the real story ...
body: When read with an understanding of J.K. Rowlings early life experience, with an awareness that she grew up in an environment much like The Fields, it helps one realize her desire to tell this story. The real story, is her desire to make others aware of such a life, for which I thank her.

author: m.hjiujnbvg
title: would love to see it a movie
body: Another great Rowling book.  Again, not anything like the Potter books.  The characters in this books are so wonderfully dysfunctional, politically crooked, drug addicted, hypocritical, self important and oblivious to anyone else's feelings or problems.  Every family in this small town has dark, ugly, and extremely disturbing problems and their children all suffer because of this.  The adults cannot see past their own wants and selfish problems to realize that their children are suffering.  Even after major tragic events, the children were the only ones who felt pain, grief and guilt.

author: lisa mccaul
title: Boring
body: i wasn't captured at the begging so kept putting it down and found it hard to get back into as there were to many caricatures. and then just as I was getting into it thinking now the story will start it was the last page. overall S***e.

author: Dika R.
title: only soso
body: Not surprisingly, the teen characters are better written than the adults.  The first half of the book is a real slog to get thru before it starts to get better.

author: Monique
title: amazing! compelling.
body: Great! Could not stop reading! Sensitive, beautiful language, loved the sayings in between. Longing to read more of her other books

author: El
title: Nothing Casual about the Craft of this Vacancy
body: You know those headlines you read that make you shake your head, cluck your tongue, and thank heavens it's not you? A heartbreaking story of cruelty against a child, or a rape, or an overdose? Rowling takes one of those heartbreaking headlines and completely and totally humanizes it, giving you the backstory of just how such a sad story came to pass.
