With her usual brilliance at world building and character development, she takes you deep into an emotional and cerebral battle against futility that took decades to build to its crescendo. But brace yourself; this is no Hogwart's.

author: Amanda
title: Amanda
body: It's ok a bit confusing jumping between character all the time and it did take a bit to get into it

author: Florence E. Staege
title: Bad book
body: I did not like this book at all and would not recommend it to anyone.  I only read it to see what her writing was like, because I have heard so much about her, but had never read any of her other books.

author: Marla Bagley
title: Lessons for us all
body: I do not believe that in writing this book J.K. Rowling created it for our enjoyment but rather an introduction to situations that many

author: MBSM
title: Wish I hadn't read it
body: While the book was an okay read;  I really wish I hadn't read it. I felt that the characters were developed properly, but I just didn't really like, the whole story line. I felt it could have been written better and that there was too much information on some characters as compared to others.

author: LJB
title: A hard read
body: The plot took forever to get going. The last 25%  finally pulled me in.

author: Siansonea
title: Loved itnever read any of the Harry Potter books
body: Honestly, it took a lot of guts to write a book like this, after pandering to a specific audience for so many years. The masses don't like books like this, because the masses like Heroes and Villains (note the capital H and capital V). Well, none of those here, though it could be argued that Obbo and Fats are villains (small v) and that Krystal Weedon is an antihero of sorts. But none of that clean and artificial character delineation we so often see in books. Some characters are thoroughly detestable (Shirley, I'm lookin' at you), and a lot of characters are deeply flawed (including the aforementioned Krystal), but what makes them interesting is that they ring true. The garden variety Good and Evil characters of other books are relentlessly artificial, and I find it difficult to engage with such characters. J. K. Rowling wasn't afraid to ditch that paradigm, even though she had perhaps been the biggest purveyor of them (thus my lack of interest in Harry Potter), and I applaud her for it. These characters may not be likable, but really, likability is overrated. Or rather, it should be.

author: Anon
title: You let me down, J.K. Rowling
body: I bought this book based on Rowling's previous works. Sorry I didn't read the reviews by others first. Dull. I can't even give it away.

author: Vicki Bland
title: Too many switches of characters
body: It took too long to get to know the characters and who was connected to who?  Felt very disjointed.  Hard to enjoy.

author: P. DeBarr
title: Terrible!
body: My book club read this book and very few people enjoyed it.  I was very interested in reading a J.K. Rowling book because I never read any of the Harry Potter series due to my dislike of fantasy.  I had high hopes for this book.  I did NOT like any of the adult characters in the book.  I found them confusing and distasteful.  The whole book was dark and depressing.

author: Carol D. Crotts
title: Hard to get into
body: Almost too many characters and a lot of character development. Not enough suspense or intrigue. Will try her other adult novel.

author: Derin Attwood
title: An excellent surprise.
body: I was pleasantly surprised at this book. I had no expectations, and it was different to any of my usual choices. It did take me a while to sort out all of the characters, but once they fell into place and I was able to enjoy the play of people and their situations.

author: Exor Cote
title: Not Harry Potter
body: Not Harry Potter, so it is different style and content.  Was a bit difficult to start for me, but a great read from J.K. Rowling.

author: JFox
title: Absolutely brilliant! 10 stars!
body: Brilliant writing, wonderful characters.  Stories that will grip your hearts.  This is NOT for kids or even young adults (12-13 years of age) although it does deal with a lot of teenage problems, big and small. The idea of how each life counts and how one person's (seemingly a not a powerful or significant person) can alter other people's lives forever. Truly brilliant read. IT should be required reading in junior and senior years in high school.  Seriously.

author: Doc C
title: Painfully true
body: The subject matter makes it difficult to say I "enjoyed" the book, so giving four stars doesn't mean I will read it again.  But I am glad that I've read it once.

author: M. Steelman
title: A British Peyton Place
body: J. K. Rowling's first adult book bears all the hallmarks of her Harry Potter books: interesting characters, tangible setting, building a story the reader wants to know. Her talent in creating a world that is familiar yet foreign shines here. Pagford is full of hidden lives and secret desires and Rowling unveils them while slowly building to the climax. As in life, there are no happy endings, just changes as the world keeps turning in the West Country.

author: J. Brown
title: Poor read
body: The storyline moved far too slow. Was bored throughout most of the book. Almost gave up reading to the end but persisted and managed to make it to the end. Would not recommend it to anyone else to read.

author: Ariesme
title: She should be a Agathe Christie.
body: I am currently up to chapter 6. It is slowly unfolding and gets better. The characters are so surprising. I know the ending will be a slam dunk.

author: Hannah Sandoval
title: Amazing
body: I couldn't put it down! The characterization was wonderful. Just as good as harry potter eventhough its an entirely different genre

author: Ralph W. McCann
title: Too Many People that are almost fatally flawed
body: It is hard to believe that no one involved leads an ordinary life and not be involved in the plot

author: Jessica Peveler
title: Definitely NOT Harry Potter
body: I'm amazed at how boldly Rowling shed her Harry Potter series to write this raw story about the dark secrets of a small English town. It's like a modern British Peyton Place. It reminded me a lot of Catcher in the Rye; some of the characters and ideas were so vulgar. And yet, they can seem to be forgiven by the fact that their vulgarity is so harshly truthful.

author: Frances
title: a struggle to get through
body: Like the boat race mentioned throughout, the story was a hard pull. A collection of prejudice and snobbery offset by prejudice and slobbery

author: Mahoney
title: Interpersonal relationships, cloaked in small town politics...
body: With compelling and interesting characters (always good character development from Ms. Rowling) this is a quick read. While she does not present new ideas about community and the politics of interpersonal relationships, she does insist that you re-examine your own assumptions.

author: Paula A. McMahon
title: Excellent Book!
body: This book had excellent character development, plot and ending.  I had a difficult time putting it down; one of the best books I've read in a while!

author: Eric Juneau
title: Too Much Setup - Only Appealing to BBC Lovers
body: I'd heard a lot of things about J.K.'s post-Potter experiment. Opinions seemed to be split. I heard critics panned it on release day, but at the end of the year, it was hitting a lot of "Best of" lists. I went into it giving a lot of benefit of the doubt. After all, this is an author who has her own theme park.

author: Eugenia C. Leal
title: JK Rowling latest book
body: It is a well written book.The start is good, like it could be a thriller but later it becomes a story about suburbia, a small town in England with all the gossip and speculation. It has a lot of characters but unfortunately, I couldn't identify with any of them. I finish reading it because I always finish what I start but the ending was just as disappointing as the rest of the story.

author: Diane C Roebuck
title: Mildly interesting
body: The story was okay, but the book was way too long and slow moving.  I prefer to read books that keep me from wanting to put it down.  This was not one of those.

author: Andrew Zaruski
title: Very engrossing!
body: It is a very dark vision of "human condition" beautifully written and well plotted.

author: happy reader
title: good read
body: Good book about people in a small town and what happens when city counsel type position is vacant. The characters  realistic and interesting.

author: Indigo
title: Great read!
body: This is a book that deals with "heavy" subjects though it is not crass or unnecessarily vulgar. I could not put the book down. I was fascinated by the characters and how their motivation and personalities were slowly revealed. I couldn't wait to see what happened next. It's definitely not a "happy go lucky" book, but it is fascinating in its brutal honesty and depiction of how everyday decisions can have resounding consequences. Loved it!

author: Kristin87645412543
title: Loved reading this book!
body: Definite departure from HP books, so dont read if thats what you are looking for.  However, same amazing writing that JK Rowling is known for.  At first there were so many characters it was hard for me to keep track of what was going on, but the story was so interesting to me, I found it impossible not become invested in each character.  Even the unlikable ones are brilliant and so...human.  The story is dark, and graphic at times (which wasnt what I expected from her as a huge HP fan) but its so funny and the characters are so realistic.  I just loved this book; I can not wait to read more from JK Rowling as an adult fiction author.

author: Kindle Customer
title: unexpectedly poignant read
body: Much depth of character

author: David Collins
title: British class culture.
body: Interesting insight into class culture on a small country village. Some things, unemployment, drugs and drinking ring true. Rowling's portrait of middle class Britain a bit scary.

author: B. Campbell
title: Dark but compelling
body: I admit that I didn't think JK Rowling was a very good writer when I read the first Harry Potter book - but the books were completely engaging and she did improve immensely with each book. The Casual Vacancy has nothing in common with those books - so don't look for that - but it is a gritty, real story that exposes the worst of people in a small town. I finished the book feeling uneasy - but knowing that I had read something masterful.

author: John
title: JK Rowling did herself proud
body: Interesting plot.  The switching back and forth from present to past makes you pay attention to the book at every turn.

author: Barbara Skilbeck
title: Great book well written
body: Kept interest from first to last page.  Well thought out story that was well written.

author: robert h cormier
title: Very different from Harry Potter
body: Very interesting about small town politics and how the lives of people intertwined with one another to create all sorts of problems.

author: Nancy W.
title: The Casual Vacancy not what I expected
body: I did finish the book.

author: J. Baker
title: Loved this book.
body: I cannot wait for her next one.  Hope this will be a series.  Character development was fun to watch. A good read.

author: Brian OConnor
title: dark, thoughtful, well-written, humorous
body: I loved "The Casual Vacancy." The narrative style is third-person but frequently switches perspective between the large cast of characters, and JK Rowling has such an amazing understanding of her characters/way of crafting and portraying her characters, who are each so distinct and realistic, that when she writes from each of their perspectives you really feel like you're experiencing the novel through the characters' experiences. Kind of hard to explain (there's probably a literary term for this - I just thought it was done extremely well here).

author: Margaret Taylor
title: A disappointing read
body: I must say that curiosity drove me to read this book. After enjoying the Harry Potter series, I wanted to see how well J.K. Rowling could engage adults in her first novel aimed at adult readership. I was disappointed. I probably would not even have finished it had it not been a book club selection. That being said, the book did realistically portray life on the dark side of both halves of the socio-economic divide. It was not an enjoyable book by any matter of means, but it did spark lively discussion at our book club meeting.

author: miltr
title: What was the point?
body: The novel appears to be about class warfare in a small English town.  She describes a number of people in very uncomplimentary terms.  None have any redeeming features.  It was frustrating for me because I could not tell the point of the story.

author: Jeanne Gehret
title: Not Worth Finishing
body: More than a hundred pages into the book, it doesn't have a single character that I like, and is very slow-moving. Why would I want to fill my head with a bunch of nasty, self-interested, foul-mouthed, violent, deluded people who are not going to do anything particularly interesting?

author: DIANE MINARCIK
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Story and characterizations were excellent, however.  It held my attention until the end, which was not satisfying.  It seemed to end abruptly giving most of the characters closure, but not the story..

author: Sydney1817
title: How to appreciate and actually enjoy The Casual Vacancy
body: First: at the beginning, jot down the character names in one of two columns: those who are pro-Fields and those who are anti-Fields. To get you started, the man who dies at the outset, Barry Fairbrother, is pro-Fields. Note their nicknames and spouses, and the parent/child relationships. There are many significant characters and your notes will help sort out the cast and get you through the first 100 pages.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Book was disappointing
body: After reading her latest book, "The Cuckoo's Calling," which was a suspenseful page-turner, I was disappointed with her first effort after the Harry Potter books. It was slow and hard to get into. It didn't really get interesting into about halfway through. The subject matter, dialects and setting were very British and had a limited appeal for me. I was tempted to give up part-way through the book but kept going. It did get more interesting as it went on. I would recommend this book to diehard fans of J.K. Rowling.

author: S. G. K.
title: Dressed up soap opera
body: Not much happens for a very long time. But Rowling has an easy style and a great eye for the little things that make us individuals.

author: Shelly King
title: It was OK
body: Not the greatest book I've ever read but still a good read.  We'll written and kept me wanting to read more but I didn't find many admirable qualities in the characters.  Not a happy and uplifting story.

author: Rusty
title: Good story.
body: I picked it to see if I would enjoy J.K. Rowling's work outside of "Harry Potter" and I did.  Should be a movie.

author: kathy haile
title: Casual Vacancy
body: In true Rowling form this work is intreguing from start to finish. The characters are well developed and interesting. This is a must read for fans of J. K. Rowling.

author: Rhett Parsons
title: A Very Different J.K.Rowling
body: Rowling's building of character and unashamedly highlighting flaws in nearly everyone draws you in and has you debating with yourself who's the goodie and who's the baddie.

author: Michael Kuhn
title: not  at all your Harry Potter
body: Well worth the read.  Very Brittish.  Much human suffering nod turmoil of the soul.  Rivalry, competition, defeat, loss, saving the traditions of the past, paving the way for perceived improvement."  Where is the redemption?  Where is the joy?

author: Kimberly Williams
title: very disapointing
body: I expected more from a children's author. The profanity and the sexual references are not what I expected.  Great authors can write well without this junk.  A vast majority would prefer clean books.

author: Sandy
title: thought it would. better
body: Too much description of characters and too many characters.  The last third of the book was the best. Took me a long time to get into it.

author: L. L. Lloyd
title: Had a hard time with this one
body: I knew this was no Harry Potter, but still had a hard time getting into it. It may be a culture difference. However, I would recommend it as a type of "coming of age" novel. Gritty at times, filled with the drama found in most small towns, "Vacancy" shows how difficult parenthood is whether you are upper middle class or a junky.

author: Julie Elizabeth Powell
title: An excellent read!
body: A very well written somewhat dark read which character lead. Each character has its flaws, weaknesses and dark side yet each also are real in an all too human way.

author: Gloria Matuska
title: A disappointment
body: Got bored with it but was determined to finish it!

author: Keiron Malkin
title: The Casual Vacancy - post Harry Potter
body: After Harry Potter, my expectations were too high, I found this book a little awkward / clumsy but it could just be that JK Rowling has been so adventurous in previous books, and this didn't have that "magic".

author: grizzlysmit
title: Great book
body: Loved it J. K. Rowling is a great author this is totally different from the "Harry Potter" series but this is still a  great work

author: G. Hunter
title: Character development?  Resloution?  Plot?  Dark and Depressing.
body: First off, please do not let anyone under the age of 18 read this book.  Of course it is a break from the Harry Potter series.  what a break.  Of course the Potter books were contagious and at times a guilty pleasure. This book had very little of the positives of her earlier work.

author: M. Woo
title: it got better
body: It took me forever to get through this book. I started in October and finally finished it. The book was so slow in the beginning, but it picked up towards the end.

author: Kindle Customer
title: An excellent read
body: I thought the characters were brilliantly drawn and very true to life, warts and all.

author: Missao13
title: It was great!
body: I expected not to like this book because of what I had been hearing about it but I'm glad that didn't happen.

author: BCB
title: Just not what I was looking for
body: I'm probably one of those people who was judging this book on the Harry Potter series, but I just couldn't get into it at all.

author: K Thomas
title: Dark and Depressing
body: Although well written, this book will not make you feel happy.  It is a sad, dark tale through and through...

author: mary
title: not what I expected
body: The Casual Vacancy is definitely not in the same vein as Harry Potter.  For the first third of the book, it was hard to follow--jumping from one person to the next and back again.  There is a lot of foul language and actions in the story.  It is depressing at times.  Very dis-functional people/families.  The only sane person seemed to be Barry (and he was dead before the story starts).

author: David Clark
title: Boring
body: Boring, Boring, Boring. I expected so much more from such an accomplished writer.  The views and tips say more words needed, so Boring, Boring, Boring.

author: barbik
title: Peyton Place in England
body: HAHA dating myself ... page Turner lots of twists ....older crowd....you really feel for all the characters. Hope she writes again!

author: Josh
title: Don't bother
body: This book didn't get good until page 400. Too many characters, too much back and forth. Not a fan of this one by Rowling.

author: M. Danielson
title: Rowling Made Me Eat Crow
body: As a rather crusty English teacher, I have always taken the liberty of looking down on J.K. Rowling and her little Harry Potter series. I read this book because of a challenge issued by one of my students, and I couldn't put it down. The sheer, genuine awfulness of Rowling's characters is delightful. There is absolutely no one to cheer for, but I found myself hoping for redemption for all. Anyone who has lived in a small community will recognize the ugliness that resides behind closed doors and smiling faces.

author: Becky
title: Fantastic
body: Life in a small British town. The author has transformed into adult fiction well. I loved the characters and their very human flaws. A very good read.

author: Cheryl Coneeny
title: To many. Characters
body: felt there were to many people involved in the story. took several chapters to remember who was who and how they intertwined

author: J. L. Harrison
title: Where's Harry?
body: As a lover of the Harry Potter series, I found myself looking for any sign of wizardry in this novel.  We HP fans watched J.K. Rowling develop from a YA author to a fully developed adult fiction writer.  In this book she blooms...leaving all the magical tricks behind; relying solely on her insight, rapier wit and honed writing skills.  A dear friend, who had just unexpectedly lost his wife, recommended the book.  As I read I marveled that he could get through such a dark and complicated tale and that he raved about it.  The ripple  effect of an unexpected death takes the reader into the lives of a disparate and vast cast of characters, many of whom do horrible things to the each other.  I never found Harry, but I certainly saw the colorful and quirky character development I'd grown to love in the HP saga.

author: Jillymc
title: Slow start but thought provoking
body: I seemed to get bogged down with the multiple names for every character.  Probably just me, but I had a hard time keeping them straight.  The book seemed to take a long time to develop, however, in the end, there were a number of things to ponder with regard to human nature and I find myself still reflecting on the story even though i finished it a week ago.

author: Ole Asbjrn Riis
title: Beautifully vitriolic commentary
body: J.K. Rowling gives a succinct and very amusing portrait of small town England - deliciously exposing the more ridiculous aspects of local politics, but doing it with love and sympathy. She writes in a flowing, easy to read manner and tells a jolly good story.

author: earth
title: No Harry Potter Here!
body: Starts out sort of slow....Picks up the pace and interest of the reader!  Well written and I did not want the end to come!

author: R. Bolden
title: Great book club selection!
body: Well written story.  The character's come to life.  What goes on behind closed doors, in the comfort of one's own home, in the quiet of one's own thoughts, can be frightening!

author: Molly Donnellan
title: No Harry Potter
body: ok, I didn't expect Harry Potter.  It was supposed to be a departure from that.  It was well written - but I just really disliked most of the characters.

author: The Hooker
title: Rubbish
body: this is definitely the worst adult fiction I have read very unbelievable characters and a absolutely stupid storyline Harry potter it isn't

author: Wneki
title: I am disappointed
body: As much as I loved the Harry Potter books I had to force myself to finish this one. Hopeless, depressing, not that well written. I think that J.K. Rowling was brilliant when she wrote Harry Potter but if this book was to shape her career as an author it would have been one of these books one may not even finish reading and forgets and wants to forget as soon as is done reading. It would never be a bestseller.

author: pj
title: Rowling more than disappoints
body: This novel verges on trashy and even though I "get" what her point is, I certainly expected more of J.K. If this is her best attempt at an adult novel she should stick with fantasy.

author: Carl Alves
title: Just awful
body: JK Rowlings displayed such an amazing ability as a storyteller, that it amazes me that she would do such a poor job in her post Harry Potter debut.  My biggest issue with The Casual Vacancy is that there isnt so much as a thin plot, but more like no plot.  The novel starts off with Barry Fairbrother dying in his small town in England, and the rest of the novel is people reacting to it.  It is full of people with petty concerns and unimportant things that they dwell on, but there is no actual story here.  Furthermore, there is not a single likeable character.  I have no idea who is supposed to be the protagonist or antagonist, but I didnt care in the least for any of them.  This novel was so painful to read that I had to stop midway through.  Normally, I stick with a novel to the end even if Im not enjoying it, but this was so dull and uninteresting that the thought of reading another 300 pages worth of it depressed me.  If youre a Harry Potter fan, avoid this one or you will be sorely disappointed.

author: Beth Mulbry
title: Long boring
body: We read this book in my book club.  Half the group did not even finish it.  J.K. Rowlings is great at detail and this book had too much detail on some things, it made the book drag.  Also, if you like happy ends do not read this book.

author: Frank Salucci
title: Hard to believe this was writen by JK Rowlings
body: The whole time I was reading I kept thinking it would get better, it's JK Rowling. I was even more disappointed once I finished. The ending was so unnecessary and only made a bad book more disappointing.

author: t -wizzle
title: painful to get through
body: I'm a Rowling fan, but I only finished this book because I felt that I owed her for the hours of enjoyment she has given me In her other books.  The tone of this book felt like Rowling was going through a Miley Cyrus-esque distancing of herself from her previous work.  It was unnecessarily crass, the plot had no driving or compelling tension (so the character development just seemed to languish on and on), and the end had no redeeming value.  I'm sure that some will say that she wrote it to build awareness of those less fortunate (the poor, the addicted, the mentally ill or psychologically disturbed) but if that is the case, she failed - because she never created a character that we could care about or identify with.  I read 1-2 books a week and this was easily the worst book I've read in a decade.

author: Jane
title: Not my favorite...
body: I had to work at getting through this.  I found the british english a little difficult to understand at times.  The book moved a little slow for me, but 'ok'.

author: S. Callaghan
title: One of two books in my life that I seriously considered not finishing.
body: I borrowed this book from the library (thank god I didn't spend money on it!!!) for the same reason thousands of others did.  I loved Harry Potter, and wanted to see what else the author could offer.  That said, I agree with other reviewers who said you can't compare this to Harry Potter because it is a completely different kind of narrative.  However, the real reason I think people compare it to Harry Potter is not to compare the content of this dark, depressing, and disturbing story (which is completely opposite from that series), but more because it is completely missing one of Rowling's greatest attributes as a writer... engaging characters and an interesting plot.

author: Jill S.
title: Greatly disappointed with this book.
body: J.K. Rowling keep me entranced from page one with every one of her "Harry Potter" books.  However, after patiently reading this one, hoping it would get better eventually, at 1/3 of the way through I finally gave up and could not finish it.

author: Beverly Beth Urban
title: The Casual Vacancy . . .
body: Harry Potter, this is NOT!!  I have read all the Harry Potter books by J. K. Rowling--and loved them.  However, "The Casual Vacancy" is an entirely different 'breed of cat'--and if you can get through the life-in-the-raw shock of Part One, you will appreciate what a truly gifted writer this woman is.  J. K. Rowling is truly brilliant and writes straight from the chill in her bones.  Beautiful work here while, at the same time, being sadly authentic.

author: Carol Siegel
title: Yes, This is How It Is for the Poor in a Bourgeois World
body: Everyone who has ever been desperately poor and struggled up to literacy and beyond should read this book.  At first the amount of rage against the middle-class characters shocked me.  I've never seen more cruel character portrayals or more vicious humor than Rowling directs against the Mollisons, for example.  But then I began to recall what it was like to feel as helpless as Krystal Weedon and as terrified of ending up like Terri Weedon, before  I found a teacher who cared enough to help me surmount my dyslexia (thanks, Mr. Miller!) and later professors from the lower classes  who spent the time with me I needed to learn to solve problem with words. Rowling is cruel to the cruel and speaks for those who can't write books.  She deeply explores what the loss of Barry Fairbrother, who thought everyone was at least as valuable as he was, does to a community of smug, selfish, judgmental, over-privileged creeps.  And it's balm for the soul of everyone who has ever had to contend with similar communities.  If you feel sick with anger when you see the top 10% pinching up their faces in distaste as they step over the homeless lying in the street on their way into boutiques and expensive cafes, then you'll enjoy this cathartic novel.  (And bonus points for the depiction of what it's like to live with a guy like Simon Price!)

author: Paul J. Austin
title: Interesting
body: the subject matter was not overly exhilarating. Long story that really was dreary. I was surprised by the outcome, I suppose I thought there would be a more uplifting ending. It just ended!

author: Anna Crowe
title: Strangely Unredeemable
body: I had hoped for Rowling's demanding pace and style that demands the reader to turn another page. I kept turning pages only with the hope that these people (who were terribly difficult to follow) had something -- anything redeemable in them.

author: James Beardsley
title: Stick with childrens books.
body: I got the impression that she was trying to write for adults but hadn't made the transition from children books.

author: Kindle Customer
title: From kids books to adults
body: I loved the characters and I hated some which is still a good thing.  she is very good at making her characters real and getting you to feel for them I was worried to read this because going from very successful kids books into adult fiction had to be hard not many authors could pull off a complete genre switch.  this is certainly not a book for kids.  I was sad to see it end but it came full circle before doing so

author: Ruth Angela
title: Great for a cruise when you have a lot of time
body: The story is convoluted, and well written .. of course... There are some superb descriptions that would equal any famous writer in the world.

author: Beth
title: Interesting...
body: I may be the only adult in the English-speaking world who had never read any of the Harry Potter books, so my expectations of The Casual Vacancy were minimal. It was a tad slow to get going, but I ripped through the last 20% or so very quickly. It did end kind of abruptly, as another poster mentioned. The other problem was that it seemed to have a few too many characters; I kept mixing a few of them up together. In retrospect, that may have been deliberate; the ones that confused me most were Shirley and Maureen, the wife and business partner respectively of Howard, the top guy in Pagford. As it turns out Maureen may have had an affair with Howard (or not, we never really know), it may be that I was meant to mix them up. It's a reasonably good book; I enjoyed it.

author: Michelle Boytim
title: A gritty tale of suburban English life
body: (3.5 stars) This a gritty tale of village and suburban life in England. Conflicts that have been simmering under the surface for years come to a head with the unexpected death of a councilman, leading to a "casual vacancy" on the council. The factions on the council are divided over the perceived drain on resources by the subsidized housing community (the Fields) just outside of the town. Whereas Barry, the deceased man, rose from poverty in the Fields to a comfortable middle class experience, others are convinced that is a blight on their community. At the center of the story is Krystal, a kind of anti-heroine, a teenager trying to take care of her toddler brother and her in and out of rehab for heroin mother. She had been taken under Barry's wing as a member of the rowing team. While far from an angel, Krystal has a tragic air of trying to do the right thing but failing despite her good intentions. As the politics become nastier, we see how the families are affected and how small things can erupt into terrible consequences. While I agree with some of the other reviewers that the dark and gritty nature of the novel can sometimes be over the top and is certainly a big departure from the Harry Potter series, it is a shot of reality, and you can see Rowling's depth of character development and storytelling in spite of the modern and "real" tone. While I didn't love the book, certain aspects stuck with me, particularly the characters of Krystal and Sukhvinder who were overlooked for their perceived inadequacies and yet had true hearts hidden beneath their pain.

author: Dragonfly
title: Diappointing
body: I didn't finish this book, it was depressing and unpleasant to read about a group of unhappy quarreling people.  The author must have been out of sorts when she wrote this, it isn't up to any standard expected of J.K. Rowling.

author: N. Warren
title: Snooze
body: I couldn't get through this novel. I really tried. I wanted to like it, but I just couldn't. I am such a huge fan of the Harry Potter series, and I really wanted to enjoy her first adult novel.

author: Roberta L Chalou
title: Skip this one.
body: Very boring read - Rowling doesn't get to the heart of the story until half way through the book. Too many characters, too many scenarios, and mediocre writing. Rowling should stick to children's books, where her imagination soars.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Disappointed
body: It started off really interesting but introduced too many characters and the relationships got confusing.  I'm not giving up on it and will try again.

author: Carole L. Martin
title: Oh dear
body: I LOVE JK Rowlings's stories. I couldn't wait to read this to see how she fared in "adult' material. Oh. No. The basic story is good, a counselman dies suddenly and leaves a vacancy that several people vie for. But there are so many characters I couldn't keep them straight (weird, I didn't have any problem with that in Harry Potter) and the characters are all vicious, angry and foul mouthed. The story began to drag and I was actually glad when I finished it, but I did not like the ending. I hear it will be made into a movie. Please don't.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Definitely a change from Harry Potter but I liked it
body: An interesting character driven story about a small town full of secrets and intrigue.  As you read the book you learn more and more about the different people in the town.  Overall I thought it was fun to read but wasnt my favorite. I still prefer the Harry Potter series but this is a completely different style.  And for that, I commend the author.

author: Jenny M. Bangerter
title: good book
body: First I have not read Harry Potter, ( yes some of us haven't) the book was recommended by a book club I belong to. Didn't mind it was very sad at last but that is life.

author: Mary Emma Middleton
title: Interesting look at  small town politics
body: I actually read all the HP books but that was not why I chose to read Casual Vacancy. Every character was flawed in some way (as are we all) and they wanted to be noticed more than anything. So much misunderstanding between husbands & wives, the teenagers and the other characters. No one confronting the truth except for Krystal and even then, she could not face up to her responsibilities as a sister - perhaps too much had been placed upon her shoulders too soon. We only have to look around us to see that this type of behaviour, the lies, the secrets, the push for power is in our midst. And even when disaster struck, there still was little compassion for the wounded and the hurting. So real; so true.

author: MW
title: What's with all the negativity?
body: No, this is not Harry Potter (which I loved).  This was written for adults and has an entirely different writing style.  Some have said this book is dystopian with evil characters.  SO not true! This is far from dystopian.  Yes, I guess almost all the characters are flawed in some fashion (some by choice and some by circumstance), but aren't we all?

author: Victoria Anderson
title: Gift
body: Not sure about this one.  It was a gift for my niece for Christmas; however, being she loves everything J K Rowling writes, I'm sure she loves it too.

author: Amazon Customer
title: well written. a slice of real life
body: Rowling wrote a gritty novel. Sad and moving . Insight into drug world. All characters very well developed . Didn't not like them personally but very. Real.

author: Jim gahring
title: Just ok
body: I wanted to like this book.  The writing is wonderful and the story is a good one.  My problem was with the characters.  Not one of them is likeable.  I couldn't find something to relate to in any of them.  That was my biggest problem with the book.  By the end I didn't care enough what happened to them.

author: Emma Peale
title: If it weren't by Rowling, it wouldn't have been published.
body: Admittedly, I haven't finished yet. I'm giving it 100 pages before I abandon it and I'm just a few pages short when Amazon emailed the urge to review. Okay. It's not that it isn't about magic; it's not that it's not Harry Potter; it's that is written as if it is purposely trying to not be lyrical, beautiful, or incisive in its style. I get it that it's a trend these days for authors to write each new book in a different style, but I must ask, Why? This might have made it as a short story. The writing is blocky, trudging, decidedly pedestrian. Every now and then there is a funny moment, a witty observation, an incisive scene, as when the social worker tries to interview the junkie mother with the hungry toddler running around in wet diapers, risking his life as he fights the already entrenched negligence. But there are so many characters, most of whom seem to be short and squat or tall and obese, it is difficult to keep them straight.

author: Anne Zirkle
title: Interesting story but lacking
body: As stated by many other reviewers, this is not Harry Potter, nor should it be compared in any way to the author's children's series. That being said, I was not expecting this book to be remotely like Harry Potter, but I still came away feeling disappointed. The story lines in the book were interesting and could have been meaningful, however the author failed to make me care about her characters. By the time I reached the denouement, which the author obviously intended to be very emotional and heart-rending, I was honestly just relieved that the book was over. I've tried to put my finger on what it was that left me feeling so ambivalent about this book and think that perhaps the problem was that there were too many characters that she tried to get us to care about, resulting in my ultimately caring about none of them?

author: Kay D. Kirby
title: Disappointed--Never read Harry Potter books because genre did not appeal--but thought she must be a good author.I was wrong!
body: I read it because someone gave me the book. Could be of interest to someone at a diffeent place in life

author: K. Bandy
title: A ponderous satire with a strong finish
body: I have just finished reading The Casual Vacancy, and was interested in reading some reviews, hoping to find some great interpretations and insight into Rowling's message.  Instead, it seems like everyone either expected Harry Potter or just missed the point.

author: SW
title: Surprisingly, this book about a small town was really.much bigger
body: Rowling has an amazing ability to make the people she writes about into.people you know. This could really.be about.my.small.town in.the US. The seemingly slow moving pace of.the beginning magically draws you.in so you will end up reading this all.night to find out what comes next from.the characters who become people you know

author: Calvin
title: Foul language
body: There are so many words in the English dictionary to use without using the"f" word.  I have no recommendation to give for this book!

author: Kortney
title: Too many character switches.
body: I got to about 180 pages and stopped. I figured if I didn't know which character was which by then it wasn't worth continuing. I hated how she switched between so many characters to try to tell a crappy story that was really depressing.

author: ThomasR
title: Thought I needed therapy after reading only half of the book
body: Morose; if small English society is this twisted and perverted I am indeed sorry for them.  I saw no socially redeeming quality in the narrative other than to appreciate where I live (and I already do).

author: skeeterbug
title: Certainly NOT Harry Potter
body: I wasn't sure what my expectations were regarding this book when I started reading it.  I was NOT expecting it to be anything like Harry Potter - phenomena of that sort come around once in a lifetime and I was curious to see how JK Rowling would be as a writer when she wasn't writing about HP.

author: BookLover
title: Terrible
body: I read a lot of books so I am used to bad language.  But I just couldn't stand all of it in this book.  Not all young people swear like this.  Plus, there weren't any characters that I liked.  Sorry that I wasted my money on it.

author: Debbie Stombaugh
title: Lengthy and Sad
body: Very long. The characters were shallow and self involved. I wouldn't recommend it. It was hard to finish.I kept wanting to go on to another book.

author: R. Camilleri
title: A divine comedy
body: A perceptive reviewer here noted with puzzlement "that Rowling has described this as a dark comedy."  JKR is of course right that The Casual Vacancy is comedy in the sense that Dante's epic was a "divine comedy."

author: R. Camilleri
title: A Comedy of Resurrection
body: A perceptive reviewer here noted with puzzlement "that Rowling has described this as a dark comedy."  JKR is of course right that The Casual Vacancy is comedy in the sense that Dante's epic was a "divine comedy."

author: antonio vega.jr
title: great book
body: it took a while to get into the book but once it got it it was a great read - way to change it up

author: Gina Arnone
title: Behind closed doors
body: This was a difficult book to read. If a book ever needed warnings for being a possible trigger this is it. It definitely wasn't a feel good story. That aside, once I got into this book I found it hard to set down. It definitely is a peek behind closed doors, and that can be a scary thing. I did have some problems with aspects of the characters, I am not sure if it was just not liking how things were going or if it was an actual character flaw. The nurse didn't seem to be very useful when it came to caring for injuries, no matter the circumstance that lead to the injuries.

author: Road Warrior
title: Well Written - Gritty, sad, true
body: It's not surprising that Harry Potter fans don't like this book. Rowling has used her fame and readers' expectations of escapist literature to lure comfortable people into thinking about uncomfortable things - things that need our concern, repentance, and action. This book is well written, drawing the reader in gently to the dynamics of a small community, eliciting chuckles and finally, tears.

author: Willow
title: A Depression Cast of Characters
body: JK Rowling can write.  No doubt about it.  But this was a dismal, dreary group of characters living in a dreary dismal town and there wasn't anything in it that didn't make me feel deflated.

author: ZC
title: Spectacular prose in a rambling story
body: Spectacular prose in a rambling story that seems to pleasantly go nowhere for some 400 pages before (spoiler alert) suddenly taking a very dark turn in action in the last 100 pages.

author: Ashleigh Lay
title: Run-of-the-mill omelet
body: This type of shadowy drama isn't really my jam and if Rowling hadn't written it, I doubt I would have even picked it up. In the throes of Potter passion, I was always so impressed with how big her scope can be as a writer, how imaginative. This book is the polar opposite of scope, taking cues from the Jane Austen school of thought that all you need for a good story is a few families in a small town and a spark. Unfortunately, the citizens of Pagford are never as interesting or sympathy-inducing as Austen's characters. Mostly, they are ordinary small town people who peck and gossip, desperately trying to hide their own flaws and secrets while exposing those of their neighbors. Some of them are better eggs than others, but they all make a rather run-of-the-mill omelet in the end.

author: Bianca Asher
title: Thumbs and toes up!
body: Being a die hard Harry Potter fan, I was very reluctant to read this more adult based book from J.K. Rowling. However, once it hit my Kindle I was absorbed into the storyline and characters that she so beautifully creates.

author: Jj
title: Fly on wall
body: Loved it. I love that feeling of being a fly on the wall. To see people when there is no audience. Not a light book by any means, but was pleasantly surprised at the characters and how much I enjoyed them all.

author: nikki feldman
title: the book was ok but not great.
body: Good story & suspense.

author: William Whipple III
title: Falling Dominos
body: I bought The Casual Vacancy out of curiosity as to what Ms. Rowling would choose to write about after the spectacularly successful Harry Potter series, and found it a good effort.  The book is a bit hard to follow, however, because of the large number of characters and frequent switches in perspective.

author: Nicole
title: A Realistic Book by a Fantastic Writer
body: Overall, this is a really good novel. It was a little slow going at first because she has to take time to introduce the many different characters, but once it started moving I couldn't put it down. This book is brilliant in it's depiction of human nature, including the ugly side of it. But for Harry Potter fans, I warn you, this is not at all a fantasy and is not the feel good novel that her Harry Potter series often was. Instead this book is a work of literary fiction that exposes the petty behavior and apathy of a small town, full of fairly affluent middle class people, towards a community of impoverished people on their border. Rowling has created a story that most people could see unfolding everyday outside their own doors, if only they would stop and really look. Her characters are totally believable, but not necessarily likable (though there are a few that I liked). These are flawed people, but they have their moments of revelation and introspection that lead a few to rethink their way of living. But at it's core, like Harry Potter, this is a novel about tolerance, understanding, courage, and love. It just isn't shown through rose colored glasses.

author: S. Robbins
title: What was the point of this
body: I think J. K. should stick to fantasy.  This was interesting but a real downer and at the end I wasn't sure why I was listening, other than I wanted to know what happened.  Expensive buy, and you probably can live without it.

author: Julia D. Kirwan
title: Slog at first but then it gets interesting
body: JK has taken on a new literary challenge with this story of a small town in England and its local politics, the relationships of parents and children, and classism, elitism of some town members contrasted by those in the "Fields".  While the author is developing the characters in the first 100 pages, it is a bit of a slog, but once you get into the story it gets interesting.  The characters (with all of their flaws and inadequacies) are developed and revealed. At the end, you are in consideration of right and wrong, good and evil, and human condition.

author: Kady Turner
title: The Casual Vacancy Review
body: "I dont know who this is for. I dont know who would like it. I feel like J.K Rowling might be beating me over the head with some social message, but I dont get it. Or perhaps J.K. Rowling..."

author: March Hare
title: Too casual by far
body: Not a great novel.  This is a novel in which nothing happens.  Everything is much the same at the end as it is in the beginning.  The people who were in power are still in power (with one very small addition).  The do-gooders are still trying their best to overcome evil.  Nothing gets resolved, there are no learnings for the reader.  The one good thing - JK Rowling really knows how to draw a character.

author: JoyceSi
title: Worst book ever
body: I was so excited to read this book when it came out because I loved the Harry Potter movies but had never read any of JK Rowling's books. What a disappointment, There are too many characters to keep track of and not enough plot to hold my interest. I kept waiting for the payoff and found myself getting more and more frustrated by the boring story and pointless trivia that the author chose to focus on. I even skipped over 100 pages in the middle and I doubt it made a difference at all. Skip this book and read "The Cuckoo's Calling" instead.

author: Janira Ramos
title: Thumbs up for Jo Rowling
body: I liked how the story kept going back and forth, a bit confusing but I liked it. I was disappointed with the ending but I still enjoyed the quality and content of it.

author: StrangePegs
title: The Protagonist Is DEAD
body: My first impression of the book remains my impression of the book now that I've finished it, that Rowling was trying too hard to be "adult." It's like the stereotypical starlet who goes out of her way to do as many nude and/or sex scenes in her movies as soon as she turns 18. Or, you know, like Lindsay Lohan or Britney Spears. Or, prior to them, Drew Barrymore (if any of you remember when she went through that stage and posed in Playboy and all of that). It's not that there is sex in the book, it's that any time there was anything sexual, she conveyed it in the most crude and vulgar way possible. Like the detailed description of a young girl's genital area in a quasi-sexual way. It just seemed to me like a cry of, "Look! I can write adult stuff! I can!"

author: Los Osos Girl
title: A boring town made interesting
body: When this book was assigned by my book club I was not overly excited to read it, however, Rowling's makes the daily pettiness and challenges of this community and its citizen quite memorable.  Like real life, its characters are hardly perfect and there is both melodrama and melancholy.  Who knew the parish council elections could lead to such insight into this community.  Los Osos Girl

author: Marti
title: Wonderful story!
body: When I first began reading this book, knowing nothing of the book,  I imagined it would be something like the HP series. I quickly discovered that I was wrong. This book is nothing at all like HP. This book is about real everyday life and the Pain, Hurt and pettiness of people. It deals with ignorance and foolishness, social stigma and taboo. I cant say I am surprised that I loved this book, J.K Rowling is an amazing author..

author: StrangePegs
title: The Protagonist Is DEAD
body: My first impression of the book remains my impression of the book now that I've finished it, that Rowling was trying too hard to be "adult." It's like the stereotypical starlet who goes out of her way to do as many nude and/or sex scenes in her movies as soon as she turns 18. Or, you know, like Lindsay Lohan or Britney Spears. Or, prior to them, Drew Barrymore (if any of you remember when she went through that stage and posed in Playboy and all of that). It's not that there is sex in the book, it's that any time there was anything sexual, she conveyed it in the most crude and vulgar way possible. Like the detailed description of a young girl's genital area in a quasi-sexual way. It just seemed to me like a cry of, "Look! I can write adult stuff! I can!"

author: Sheryl Sorrentino
title: Lively, Moving and Fast-Paced
body: Wow. The Casual Vacancy has got to be one of the best books I have ever read. I am rather pleasantly surprised to feel this way, because I didnt much care for J.K. Rowling when I read her early Harry Potter books to my then school-aged daughter. Id found her writing as dry and unmoving as her stories were imaginative.

author: diri
title: The casual vacancy
body: Awesome story,  characters come to life and leave you thinking about them long after you have turned the last page.  Raw, gritty realism.  Heart wrenching,  kept me immersed from the first page.  This book transports you, with vivid descriptions. I cannot praise this book enough. Thanks J. K. Crawling!

author: deborah kelly
title: depressing book!
body: The book moved way too slowly I did not like any of the characters I didn't care what happened to them,made it 1/2 way through and quit.Every time I read it I came away feeling sad and hopeless muchlike the books characters.

author: A. Johnston
title: Insightful and very well written
body: Very engaging book.  Some books have a slow start trying to set the stage for future action but this book grabs you right away. In her description of a characters' thoughts J.K. Rowling shows brilliant insight into their true nature and motivations.  This book describes life in a small town and how people are affected by an unexpected death. She helps us understand what it feels like to be in each character's position and sheds light on how each character came to have their current point of view.  She adeptly describes situations in brief but highly descriptive phrases so I was never inclined to skip ahead. Each part of this book was carefully and succinctly crafted to precisely convey an image to the reader.  There's much more going on here than just the straight story line. Lots to think about but never approaches being preachy.

author: Daniel Davidson
title: Boring
body: A novel without a single interesting character or insight. I wonder what percentage of those who started reading it made it to the end

author: J. Rudolph
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: This one took some reading over to understand what is going on in some places but it certainly was off the beaten path, but I did enjoy it.

author: Alexander
title: Intelligent read, reminiscent of George Eliot's Middlemarch
body: I loved it, couldn't put it down, and now can't find anything to replace it.  The Casual Vacancy is not at first an easy read, but contains humor amidst the realism.  I especially recommend it to teachers, who deal with real life on a daily basis.  The story itself centers around the death of a teacher in the opening scenes, and the lives of the people he left behind.  This story is about a village and the lives and thoughts of its people, similar to George Eliot's Middlemarch, another very intense look at humanity.  Yes, there are a lot of characters, and yes, there are no completely good people or completely evil people, but those are strengths in a novel.

author: Ryan
title: A Surprise
body: I didn't know how I would feel when I heard that J.K. Rowling came out with an adult novel, but of course I was going to read it. This novel was the perfect start for this fantastic author to break away from Harry Potter and start to write adult novels. This epic tale of a corrupt town may be confusing at first, but after a few chapters in the characters begin to all fit together and the story line is incredible. It was a fantastic book that I did a book report on last year and it gave me so much to talk about and think about what is wrong with our corrupt society and the government. I highly recommend everyone to read this novel.

author: Gail S.
title: Don't expect Harry!
body: Well written but a little depressing!  It was easy to connect with the characters.  A great insight into small town life and politics.

author: llindalu
title: Different
body: I enjoyed the book once I convinced myself I shouldn't be comparing the Harry Potters I so love.  It is if course an entirely different read.  I look forward to more.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Wow
body: Amazing insight into Brit local politics. Loved the rich characters, could hear their voices in my head for days. What a tale. Read it!

author: jobooks
title: Good read, but...
body: A very readable and well-managed book, that yet never takes off into that higher sphere of insight and understanding which real Literature requires,

author: P. Hjemboe
title: couldn't get into it
body: I had high hopes for this book, but it was seemed so disjointed from the get-go, some many characters intoduced and not really fleshed out enough to make me care about any of them...I just decided there too many other things I I'd rather be reading. I gave up after a couple chapters.

author: Alison Pheasant
title: AVERAGE READ
body: Not what I expected after Harry Potter series!  took a long time to get into and the characters were hard to follow.

author: Joy
title: Rowling hits a home run with this one!
body: This was a very interesting and easy book to read.  Characters were clearly defined and the story line kept you involved.  Definitely would recommend any of JK Rowling's books for adults.  Very entertaining and enjoyable.

author: Stefan.K
title: Success beyond Potter
body: Well written and simply enough for a very lay audience to grasp in terms of writing style.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Hard To Get Into
body: This book was "hard to get into"....but hang in there..it gets good...worth the wait!!!The plot definitely has some twists and turns.

author: Joanna
title: Extremely interesting!
body: Great study of human character! Highly readable - reads like the best whudunnit, yet highbrow! By highbrow I mean thought provoking, intellectually challenging and sophisticated!

author: Tracey Harty
title: Well-woven Tale
body: This started out slow for me, trying to stay focused on the varied character descriptions. In the end I came to truly enjoy the depth of the characters and how their relationships and situations were inter-related.  Very crafty!  Also enjoyed the glimpse of life in a current-day small town in England.

author: R. WAUGH
title: No Harry Potter Here
body: A very interesting book about British political life.  Great the way the characters are developed and the interplay amongst them.  Takes time to get into the story and to sort out the characters but by the end you want it to keep going.

author: Peg P
title: Read with caution!
body: Do not use this book for bedtime reading if you are looking for something relaxing.  This is a grim novel.  it opens with the sudden death of the one redeeming character.  Rowling's characters are vividly drawn.  Are they believable?  A few, perhaps.

author: John M. Vizcarra
title: Pleasantly adult small-town week-in-the-life-of book
body: I must admit, going into this book I didn't quite know what to expect. After enjoying her Young Adult Harry Potter series, I knew this was a more mature book, but really didn't know much about it. The jacket write-up wouldn't normally be enough to rope me in, but the strength of Rowling's other works was.

author: April
title: Too much bad language
body: The story might be interesting, if it wasn't so vulgar.  There was a lot of unnecessary swearing and sex.  I know it is a book for adults, but I felt it took away from the plot.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Disappointing
body: After the rich imaginative prose in her Harry Potter books I expected something more. i found her style stilted and the storyline unimaginative and dull.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Love Her Writing
body: Not so much this book. Could not get through it. Found the characters unlikeable and did not want to invest my time to see if that changed. I read for entertainment and did not find this book entertaining. J.K. Rowling is a wonderfully talented writer, this book failed to draw me in. That is my experience with the Casual Vacancy,

author: Alma Sessler
title: Uninteresting and dull
body: Dull, poor plot. Not at all up to her Harry Potter series. I would not recommend it to my friends.

author: Heather M
title: Better than the other reviews made it seem.
body: I'm a fan of the Harry Potter series (having read the entire series) so I thought I'd give her first shot at a book for adults a try.  While others complained about its gloominess and the lack of magic, fantasy and or how boring it is, I disagree. It isn't by any means a "happy" story, but just like in the HP series, I laughed, cried, got angry, and felt a kinship with many of the characters. HP was successful not only for its subject matter but also for the skillfulness in which JK Rowling breathes life into her characters. After reading A Casual Vacancy, I have to say that while the story may not be everyone's cup of tea (as another review said, "if you wanted something funny or magical then head to the another genre section")  I have to give JK Rowling some props for her first stab at writing for adults. I look forward to reading whatever she comes up with next!

author: R. Hartley
title: JK Rowlings' Casual Vacancy review
body: As normal, it takes awhile to get into a JK book... keep listening. Are there a lot of characters, yes. Will you get lost; yes. Is the story worth it; YES!

author: Shannon Elf
title: I wish I could give it 6 stars
body: I loved this book. I couldn't put it down and read it cover to cover in about a week. I got so attached to all the characters - they are written so beautifully and with such depth and I miss them now that I've finished the book. That's the best kind of fiction, in my opinion.

author: K. B. O.
title: Cant get through it
body: Big harry potter fan. Didn't expect this to be the same but the story has not grabbed me at all. I just don't care.

author: vcdeitrick
title: Not Harry Potter
body: A grown up book by JKRowling was just as satisfying as the Harry Potter Series. It was a little British, but I can't rate 1/2 a star off, so I'll leave it at 5 stars.

author: Judith A. Myers
title: Worth your time!
body: Great read. The characters are very well developed and you become involved in the plot almost immediately. I would buy again.

author: Mnj
title: WOW
body: This book was so unexpected! Rowling writes a compelling story that is realistic and heart breaking. Well done very well done

author: JMR
title: Casual Vacancy
body: Very interesting book. Not exactly what I expected. Think of small town politics and all of the dirt that sometimes comes out when an unexpected event occurs. In this situation it is the death of Barry Fairbrother. The parents, also involved in the small town politics, are so busy scheming that they have neglected one important thing -  their children who each in their own way secretly expose family dirt. This is truly a like it or hate it book but worth the read.

author: Joan Alexander
title: actually, I would give 1/2 a star.  It just was not up to her standards.
body: It was not up to her standards.  It was very hard to read and not a page-turner.  I would not recommend this book.

author: Brian Hetherington
title: Casual vacancy
body: To be honest I wish I hadn't bought this book.. I found it slow and dull..In fact quite disappointing. It seemed to me an

author: Maureen McAfee
title: Perfect
body: I got the book as soon as I expected and the book was undamaged.

author: JYM
title: Read it
body: Stunned. I'm only familiar with the HP books via nephews. I decided to buy one nephew her book for adults, read pages online. Decided to order one for college reader and one for me. Could not put it down. She has 20 or so characters fleshed out, and the interplay is funny, sad, astonishing. Her child characters will astonish you. If you love fiction, read this book.

author: Laci Nagy
title: A slow hard slog
body: Few of the characters are likable and until the last few chapters I only kept reading out of loyalty and a sense of having wasted my time if I didn't finish it.

author: Susanne Zels
title: A very honest and well written novel
body: I couldn't put the book down and was positively suprised by J.K Rowlings first adult novel. The story touches upon some real social issues in the UK.

author: Susan L. L.
title: Casual Vacancy Good read
body: There are so many dysfunctional families in one town.  I had a little trouble in the beginning keeping track of all the family members but once I got to know them I was able to keep track.  It is a very good read and I enjoyed it.  It was a tragic story from the beginning to the end.  Be ready because it will start and end with tragedy. The story and its characters are very dysfunctional.  My kind of book.

author: gaye blomfield
title: Poor read
body: Having read The Cuckoos Calling expectations of this book also being a good read we're high. Was let down and rating reflects my opinion of this read.

author: Pat Thomasson
title: Started twice. Glad I finished.
body: I've read all of the Harry Potter books. Ok, that's done.

author: July Moore
title: Too difficult to get into.
body: I read about 25 pages, but it didn't catch my interest.  since I have other choices, I can afford to be choosy.  Note, I own a bookstore.

author: annlelli
title: Very interesting
body: Could be any town or city...people with problems.  It's our society with the haves and have nots anywhere you go.

author: P. M.
title: too dark
body: I finished 2 chapters.  Too dark for me.  I read to relax.  This book is not relaxing.  This is my first book review.  Shows how much I disliked the book.

author: L. W. Schore
title: Lost her luster
body: I was astounded to see the drop in tone, liveliness and vibrancy that was so evident in J.K.'s wonderful Potter books. What's awful here is a desire to be serious and adult, with shocking displays helpings of  foul language. It's a shocking come down. I couldn't believe it's the same author that made a billion on something so good.

author: Stephanie
title: Brilliant. I was drawn in from the very first page...
body: I never read Harry  Potter, so I came to the book with no thoughts of comparing her past work. What I loved about Casual Vacancy is how she nailed the small, but very meaningful idiosyncrasies in all of her characters.

author: Sadaf Haroon
title: returned!!
body: what a disappointment after HP series!!!!...

author: Julie G Caldwell
title: Modern issues
body: Surprising different from the Harry Potter books, but covered a variety of issues pertinent to the current day reader.  Very interesting reading.

author: Armin Hanik
title: Tried it valiantly,,, just to give her a fair chance
body: I have to admit I gave up after 10% (kindle) in. What a load of boring cobbled together crappola.

author: Lorraine Cleary
title: Brilliant
body: it's funny, sad, horrific, brutally honest and very clever.  I am going to miss the characters.

author: M. Q. Bell
title: A Bunch of Muggles
body: I know it's not fair to compare this work to her Harry Potter series, but it's a natural thing to do.  Her "magic" isn't there in this one, though the 2nd half flew by after a sloggy first half.

author: Susan Ballard
title: No good
body: I read almost this entire book waiting for something to happen. I finally gave up. I'm certain she's just introducing characters for a series, but I found them rather flat, and I couldn't decide who the main character was.  This is an adult book, so language and situations are adult in nature, I knew that going in and was not offended or surprised. It was just incredibly boring..

author: Kindle Customer
title: Why did I waste the money??
body: Took the extremely talented writers credentials and said to myself, "myself, this should be good."  Fought my way through the first 75 pages and could not go on.  Reputation or not the writer could not hold my interest.  Seemed way to ordinary and mundane with way to many characters you have to try and keep up with.  I like to read for "pleasure" not pain.

author: Kindle Customer GINNY
title: OMG
body: I loved this mystery. I love the style of writing, the language usage, the character developement and the unraveling of clues. It kept me guessing. And it was fun. Not gorey.

author: Janet Franzen
title: What a Storyteller!!!
body: This is such a great read.  Once you get to know the characters you just can't wait to keep going to find out what happens to them.  It was a challenge to keep them straight, but it all worked out.  My book club had a great discussion as we related the events in the story to our society today.

author: C. Walton
title: Change of pace
body: I'm not the kind of person who can divine the allegory behind an author's story or printed sentence, but this book seemed to be a look into the lives of a small group of people and their motivations and how the life of one person can affect the lives of many in ways you wouldn't expect and regardless of the relationship between the people. Depending on the kind of life you've led and the people you've known, you may or may not find the characters to be "real" in that they seem to have more than their fair share of faults, idiosyncrasies, and secrets, but I found them to be very real on many levels. If you don't find them to be real or believable, just remember it's a novel, not a psychology text book.

author: Julia Larson
title: Poor ending
body: How to end a story when all is loss..kill them off.  Sad situations make poor reading. I expected more from a talented writer.

author: Cynthia M. Shaler
title: Greatly enjoyed it. Tightly written.
body: This is how one would want Rowling to write a murder mystery: with well-developed characters (sympathetic and otherwise), intense action, and just enough hints to keep you turning the pages and--at the end--wanting the next novel to come out really soon.

author: Patap
title: How one incident affects many
body: I found this book quite interesting in how a death in an English village affected many families.  The story did jump around from family to family a little too fast at first but then I became used to Rowlings type of writing.  She gives many insights to thoughts of her many characters and has some wonderful perceptions of life; i.e. "tiny ghosts of your living children haunted your heart;they could never know, and would hate it if they did, how their growing was a constant bereavement."  Enough said.

author: Mibby
title: Good and Quick Read
body: Not too good at reviewing books.  I bought it for my Kindle..  I enjoyed the book, and it was an easy quick read.

author: Laurie Mack
title: I've read half way through and as hard as I try, I'm not going to be able to finish it.
body: I love the way JK Rowling develops her characters, but it is all character development and outside of the beginning, no mystery.

author: Christina Rickman
title: Interesting and well written!
body: JK Rowling is a great author- her style of writing is unique and interesting. This book is all about characterization (as opposed to a particularly action packed plot-line) but JK Rowling keeps you interested and engaged with her witty insights on human nature. You finish feeling very unsettled because the characters and their emotions and intentions feel very real.

author: AnneP
title: Couldn't put it down
body: I know a lot of people have complained that Rowling head hops in this novel, but I really sort of liked it.  Her insights into human behavior and how the interactions and acts of the people around us effect how we behave are amazing and well worth keeping notes for the first three chapters until you know the characters well enough to put it down.  .

author: Z Hayes
title: Has its moments
body: I have to admit that I purchased this book because I am a great fan of the Harry Potter novels by J.K. Rowling. I knew that this was going to be a very different read just from all the synopses and reviews I read but I felt compelled to read it anyway. I wanted to experience for myself how well Ms. Rowling transitions into the mature, grown-up fiction genre after having written so successfully for the Young Adult fantasy market (though the HP novels are ageless in that they appeal to readers of all ages).

author: Amazon Customer
title: Mixed Feelings
body: In true JK Rowling fashion, the characters were well defined and she revealed the characters in an unvarnished fashion. For me, I like my reading to be more of an escape from life's harsh realities.

author: Peggy
title: excellent character development!
body: So well written.  Not being a follower of Harry Potter, wasn't sure about experiencing this departure. So glad I did!

author: Heather E. Poginy
title: Excellent Writing, Not for the Faint of Heart
body: If you are looking for an uplifting read, do not read this.  The Casual Vacancy starts off quite confusing, as there are many characters that you have to sort out before you get to know them.  Each has their own way of contributing to the tragedy of the story.  Yes, you heard it - this story is NOT uplifting.  It will tear you to pieces.  Given the length of the story, it gives you a long time to truly connect with the characters.

author: Peg Abt
title: fabulous read
body: Memorable characters who depict beautifully the different classes and why the Brits make it so hard to be successful without the right pedigree.  But the book also shows our universal desires, strengths , weaknesses, pettiness, compassion & lack of compassion. Amazing detail-- Pagford and the Fields come to life--& an impressive portrait of the fears, insecurities, & difficulties of being a teenager is the modern world & what lies beneath the seemingly idyllic life of a small town.

author: firewithin
title: kimee56@yahoo.com.au
body: Human nature written about in all rawness.  Very clever indeed.  You recognise all the characters.  The story is a brilliant study of people.  Bravo!

author: Lisa L.
title: Not Harry Potter, to be sure, but a strong piece of adult literature
body: Given the length of this book, the plot is minimalist, detailing the quotidian microdrama of a tiny hamlet in England and the adjacent, slightly larger town.  There is no backdrop of historical significance, there is no cataclysm, there are no dragons. I normally have little patience for endless descriptions without a lot of action, but Rowling is something of a wizard in her own right when it comes to the subtle magic of arranging words on a page.

author: Stephen A. Benner
title: A Decent Social Commentary, but Not Such a Good Novel
body: This story shows J.K. Rowling's usual gathering of several threads together in one story, but unlike her other books The Cuckoo's Calling (as Robert Galbraith) and if course the famous Harry Potter series, she doesn't bind all the threads together in a neat conclusion.  They are mostly left dangling at the anticlimactic ending that while it is considered a sad local tragedy is forgotten soon by everyone in the town.

author: monita
title: Not casual- Edgy, Thought provoking, Honest
body: I recently picked up  The Casual Vacancy by JK Rowling to read on a flight. I had not read the reviews but I remembered hearing that this was different from the  Magical Potter series.  This is a somber but well-written adult read. I would not recommend it for children because of graphic accounts of self-mutilation, suicide, pedophilia, mental illness and other ugly realities.  JK Rs narration is effortless; dry British humor emerges but is restrained. Rowling boldly strips her characters to their sullied souls and makes the reader acutely aware of her penetrating literary eye. I dont think she wrote this book on her train trips but I sense that this plot was brewing in her mind for sometime perhaps since childhood. She is a wizard at creating adolescent characters. They are painted with so much finesse that you can touch and feel their blemishes, insecurities; false sense of bravado, odd alliances and stark rebellion. There is probably a bully like Fats in any school and a silently suffering victim like Sukhvinder. There is no protagonist but one is left feeling deeply for the rough and tough, Krystal daughter of a drug-addict mother who tries hard to beat dire poverty and the odds stacked up against her but fails miserably. There is no redemption and the ending is bleak but there is a metaphor of hope in the yearning to excel at rowing!

author: Billie Settles
title: The Casual Vacancy - a chequered success.
body: "The Casual Vacancy" was, not surprisingly, beautifully written. J.K. Rowling's readers have come to expect this, and we were not disappointed. However, the story was convoluted and dense, reminding me of a Russian novel. The town, itself, finally emerged as the main character, with the many tormented townspeople playing the roles which defined it. If there was a rewrite, I would suggest focusing on one or two of the finely drawn characters with the others as subsidiaries.

author: Margarita
title: Couldn't put it down once I got hooked.
body: It took me a couple of chapters to get the characters straight, and then I was hooked. Krystal Weedon is one of those memorable characters who sticks with you for days after finishing the book. Rowling is truly gifted with the ability to create a world that a reader enters and lives in while reading. A dark world, but I was there.

author: G Andrews
title: Intriguing...
body: This was quite different from what I'd expected and it took a while to figure everything out, then it became nearly impossible to put down.

author: Amazon Customer
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: At first it was difficult to keep everybody straight and to understand this English town.  I liked the consequences of behavior throughout the book.  Sad ending but the only ending.  Very insightful about how people dwell on their own problems and can't see beyond it.

author: Wynter Jackson
title: I am a little dissapointed because I ADORE the Harry Potter series
body: I can not actually 100% rate this novel as I really was unable, rather, more uninterested in finishing it. I simply couldn't connect with any of the characters and therefore after numerous attempts at reading it-I sadly shelved it. Perhaps another time?

author: Grandma Bella
title: Novel "Casual Vacancy"
body: The plot was good, but the unnecessary use of so many "4 letter" words seem to be overused and abused.  The characters in this small village were well developed, and could be used in future books.

author: Peter Speers
title: good not great
body: Started very slow almost gave up several times. Characters as well developed, so much so that you know them almost personally by the end.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Intriguing Story
body: I liked the flow of the story and was somewhat surprised by the ending. It seemed somehow cutoff and unfinished.

author: Rebecca Jaxon
title: Brilliant writer - Different
body: I suspect that many people who bought this were expecting another Harry Potter-type book and were disappointed as a result. I loved all the HP books, but I am happy that Rowling is wishing to branch out into other genres and exercise her craft on other topics.

author: ReadsReviewsAlways
title: Lots of characters- confusing yet interesting!
