body: I was less than impressed with this book.  It has so many characters that I got tired before I finished reading the book and gave up.  I loved the Harry Potter books, but thought she had too many different story lines going at once in this one.

author: nancy brickner
title: The language was so bad, though I could have finished this if I tried.  It was better than the Cucoo's Calling.
body: Language too crude for my taste; otherwise I might have liked it. I stopped reading it as I did the Cucoo's Calling.

author: Diane V. Murrell
title: Crude content and depressing
body: I loved the Harry Potter series and purchased this solely on the strength of the former books excellence. I found the Casual Vacancy, however, to be crude in it's vocabulary, depressing and poorly written. None of the skill of story telling or descriptive writing or character development were evident.  I could not bring myself to finish the book. Regardless of this opinion of this book I remain a huge fan of Ms. Rowling's other works and consider her Potter series all time classics.

author: G. McMullen
title: Not quite Harry Potter but very good
body: Interesting, good characters, did leave you hanging a bit at the end, could have used some closer on some of the issues at the end of the book

author: Brian
title: Uninteresting characters
body: I read 250 pages and finally skipped ahead 50 pages at a time, then to the last few pages to see how it concluded. The ending was boring and too easily predictable. At almost 500 pages, this novel could have been half that, as there is little positive character development.

author: Jaclyn L. Wenner
title: Clarity weak
body: Characters were not developed enough to really feel involved in the plot or care what happened to whom.  I had a hard time finishing it.  I always try to finish and find a redeeming grace, but found none this time.

author: Daniel P
title: Poor story, good writing
body: Writing is good, story chopped up and very depressing.  I finished it only because the writing was good, was my first Kindle read

author: Patricia A. Goss
title: Bad Language!
body: The language was to raw for my reading pleasure. I started it and read only a few chapters and put it away. I wouldn't consider giving it as a gift!

author: Janice P. Baker
title: It's Okay
body: I liked it, although I felt it could have had more drama, rather than so much in-depth psychological aspects of the characters.

author: Glenys Rockell
title: I don't do reviews, but...
body: Easy read, and I enjoyed the multitude of characters and each of their stories. Good bit of escapism, and not too heavy.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Characters to care about
body: I am not normally a fan of the English novel but this drew me in with complex characters and a marvelous setting.  These people are flawed and muddling through their circumstances which makes them interesting.  I picked this up because it was written by J. K Rowling but after the first chapter, I forgot all about that and just enjoyed the story.

author: Sunny Day
title: Depressing
body: I did not like this book. There were too many characters, none of whom you would want to know. The chapters were too short, resulting in a choppy story. I kept wondering what was the point of the entire plot? The characters started out as unlikable people and ended that way, with maybe one or two exceptions. The story is about a horrible town with very flawed residents! Hopefully this small town only exists in Rowling's imagination. Don't waste your money on this book.

author: Sue W. Elliott
title: Better than I expected:
body: Haven't finished it but I find it well written and good character study of life in a small English village.  Interesting people with paths that cross in the geographic place they are planted.

author: Aaron House
title: The End Justifies the Beginning
body: First off, I admit that I had to start this book twice to get through it.  Rowling takes a long time (the first half of the book) setting the stage for the action that comes in the second half.  But, having now read the entire book, the first half is justified.  At its core, I think that The Casual Vacancy is a character study.  Rowling is delving deep into the human heart and the human condition.  She doesn't paint a rosy picture of humanity (she didn't in Harry Potter, either, by the way).  Instead, she is candid in revealing a portion of humanity as it is: fallen, flawed, often limited by circumstance, and self-centered.  Rowling takes the time necessary to explain and examine the human beings she portrays.  These character examinations make up much of the first half of the book.  I think the difficulty in starting this book and staying with it is the lack of focus on plot in the first half of the book.  In the end, that's a great thing.

author: Carole Valentine
title: I hated it
body: That was the worst book I have ever read! I kept reading in the hopes that it would improve. It did not!

author: Ellen Hamilton
title: An Amazing Author...not just for kids anymore
body: J.K. Rowling is a phenomenal writer.  However, "Casual Vacancy" was not one of her best.  Check out "Cuckoo's Calling" for a really great read.  You'll never guess 'whodunit!'

author: Kathleen C. Lehman
title: Characters and Plot are a downer
body: While the writing is lovely, the characters and the plot are not.  The village is full of mean spirited and bitter people doing mean spirited and bitter things.  I could not find anyone to root for as the story unfolded.  Too bad because the prose itself is nice.

author: Katie C.
title: Excellent read!
body: J.K. Rowling writes great characters, she demonstrates diversity, humor, education, and drama. I was very entertained throughout. She is a smart writer.

author: SS
title: The greatest mistake of J.K.Rowling
body: By having the 2nd ever sold book (HP series) in terms of quantity in the history of the humankind, Rowling created a brand for her name, possibly one of the strongest brands in the world and definitelly in the literature field. Million army of fans was ready to buy Hogwarts library books, the tales of beedle the bard, and the foresaken Harry Potter encyclopedia that will never appear, unfortunately. So what does she do? She destroys that brand by going in completely different niche. From childish, teen type of a book that actually suited perfectly even adults into some dirty and nasty book that made me vomit. It is like, if Maybach started to produce Smart type of cars from tomorrow. Totally illogical, nonsense. Who is she now? What can we expect from her? Another adult book that depicts the ugly parts of our lives? Instead of being number one in the teen niche of the book shops, she digged a grave for her name and her brand. It does not matter whether you liked or not the book so much. It matters that Rowling moved into another direction. It is up to you to like it or not. However, it is utterly disappointing that the possibility of seeing HP like books is vanishing year by year. And who else, if not Rowling, could give us those magical hours of reading and rereading the book?  Excuse me, but there are thousand of writers in the same adult genre and if I want something more realistic and criminalistic, I will 100% find a good book in the nearest book shop. But WILL YOU FIND A GOOD book for your children that will keep them away from computer? I doubt that.

author: TJM
title: Good read, well written.
body: Good read. She tells a story really so well. This being said, the story  did not go anywhere and it seemed to be just a 500 page book that could have been written as a kick ass 150 page one.  I love this author so it is hard to not like anything that she writes and of course I will buy her new one.  Instead of buying it, borrow from a friend is the way to go or library it for sure.

author: Dan Thompson, Author
title: Not Just a One Trick Pony
body: After being won over by the hype of The Casual Vacancy, her first adult novel, I decided to give this a go and thankfully I was proven wrong.

author: Dolores Christensen
title: Ironic Title
body: The title is ironic......the vacancy caused by the council member's sudden death is not unimportant as casual implies. His absence effects the Council and the entire town.Ms. Rowling knows psychology and the characters react in a realistic way.Also,as a retired Social Worker, her descrcriptions of problem families and how we TRY to help are real.Subtracted 1 star for a bit too much obscenity for my taste.

author: Nelda R. Wellard
title: Great
body: It is a good read!  JK Rowling has done it again!  Keep up the good work cause I love your books!

author: Roxanne Townsend
title: read the first 50 or so pages could not get into this story!
body: I am very disappointed! Finally set it aside for another book. Life is too short to waste on an uninteresting book. Disappointed

author: Amazon customer
title: Couldn't finish
body: Don't waste your $$'s on this one. I rarely put a book down, but this one was so bad I had to stop reading it. No redemptive value.

author: oweihyoiqsgI
title: very boring
body: Expected more action  and drama.  I had to make myself finish it.  Felt like I was wasting my time eavesdropping.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Excellent read!
body: What a good read!! The setting and characterisation of a small rural village and it's people are great. The story includes humour, drama and a wide variety of characters to make it more than interesting.

author: Joyce Easton
title: Not what I expected
body: Having never read any of the Harry Potter books, I was looking forward to reading this book.  Our book club, the Novelettes, selected this for our August read.  When we met to discuss the book, no one had anything good to say, and some of the members stopped reading after a few 100 pages.  I continued to read it, because I kept expecting it to get better.  Having been an elected official on a council, I was amused by some of the antics when trying to fill a vacancy.  But it was not worth the time it took to read 503 pages.

author: Karlynn Kern
title: Very Entertaining
body: I felt like a resident in the small town of Pagford, England. I

author: DEE P.
title: A domestic small town thriller in a different vein.
body: This book was a page turner and the details of everyday life, especially for the impoverished was so accurate.

author: Amazon Customer.  amott
title: J K hits  a fresh unexpected home run
body: Wonderful book filled with deep quirky characters who  repel the reader as well as mesmerize.  Exactly the well woven story we have come to expect from this author!

author: S. Hays
title: Long slow start, good finish - worth the effort
body: I gave up on this book twice before starting over and finally finishing it. In the first 300 pages or thereabouts, the characters seemed to me to be unrelievedly and unrealistically bleak, as though the author herself was mistaking poverty and meanness for authenticity, like her adolescent character Fats Wall. The omniscient framework that let the reader into every character's head showed only the worst of each person: fear, pettiness, and selfishness, with the only pleasures coming from sticking a pin in someone else. The offscreen Barry Fairbrother was apparently the only decent person in town, although even he was a bit of a jerk in the first couple of pages before he died and created the casual vacancy.

author: Rachel Jensby
title: I didn't care about any of the characters until the book was almost over...
body: I loved the HP series (I read them to my children as they were growing up).  It is THE most fun I've ever had reading a story.  So, when JK Rowling had another literary offering, I wanted to read it.  I was looking forward to finding out what she would write for adults.

author: Susan Corda
title: casual vacancy
body: I found the book hard to read I had to work at it to read and I only read the first four chapters. It was like going to school and doing homework

author: G. Little
title: Not what I expected
body: I kept waiting to get to the good part and suddenly the book was over.  Took me 2 months to

author: Cynthia Snowden
title: Yuck!
body: I confess -- I read to escape.  And to escape to a better place, or at least a familiar one.  This book starts off with unpleasant people doing unpleasant things in unpleasant places.  Who needs this?  Pas moi.

author: Roland D. Fesmire
title: Reminded me of Sinclair Lewis
body: Great writing and great characterization. Read only if you intend to slowly digest the plot and character interactions. Not a quick read.

author: Philip Osborne
title: Fantastic Read
body: A real page turner. The characters are so real and their stories so realistic. JK Rowling has tapped into village life an written about people we meet every day. The Casual Vacancy is an amazing book.

author: meranda
title: Decent
body: The hype on this book really worked against it. Since it was the first post-Potter book, a lot of assumptions and expectations were made that it couldn't live up to. An okay story, just not one you'd expect from the world's most famous author today. Definitely not for children.

author: T. Wendt
title: Engaging
body: Overall, engaging reading. There are lots of characters and it takes a while to understand the family and social connections.

author: WilmaNC
title: Excellent!!!
body: Having never read any of the Harry Potter books, and only being able to tolerate the first movie, ( I am an adult...) I thoroughly enjoyed this book. In this age of complaining about poor people acting entitled, it was refreshing to read about the way life really is for some people, and to show some of the compassion that can be given, if people just open their eyes to what is around them. I loved the book, loved the characters, loved Ms. Rowlings writing style. I hope she writes more books for adults in the future. Highly recommend this book!!

author: Ann
title: Thoughtful and thought-provoking
body: This is a complicated story about people being there for each other, and failing each other. The story unfolds subtly with humor and pathos. I came to really care about the characters and went back to re-read parts and make sure I understood what happened and what was said. There are no magic wand solutions, but the author shows the same understanding that we all are neither inherently evil or good, but defined by our choices as in her earlier books. Very well written.

author: Sandy P
title: definitely worth your time
body: I have never read a Harry Potter book, so I can be objective and make no comparisons. Plot kept my interest.  Good character development and interesting ties between the characters. Gave new meaning to "living and dying by our actions and decisions.". The last few pages left a bit to be desired.  Felt like a quick wrap up and could have been better structured.

author: Jane G.
title: Don't like it
body: It read like a teenage novel.  It was way too simplistic.  I really didn't like it at all.

author: Pen Name
title: Ms. Rowling disappoints
body: I couldn't believe that the person who had such a wonderful way with language and plot could have written this novel.  I had to force myself to finish it, and then I wondered why I actually read the whole thing,  It never got better.

author: CM
title: Okay
body: This book seemed like J.K. Rowling was trying too hard to write for adults. The book is about a town no one would want to live in and all the messed up people who live there. Apparently the one "good" person has died creating the Casual Vacancy on the town board which causes everyone's secrets to be exposed. Not something I would recommend reading.

author: Andrea  L Heath
title: It's just okay
body: Still reading this. It is not one of those books that you can't put down. Not Potterish, but not great either

author: CLAIRE BIRNBAUM
title: a different type of reading!
body: It is amazing how from a simple day to day small town occurence, an excellent writer can create a compelling story! Kept me wanting to read to the end.

author: Lisa  A.  Garcia
title: I love it!!!!
body: Amazing! Fantastic! Seriously awesome! Way to go, Ms. Rowling!!! You rock the pages of any story and allow the reader to jump into you imagination for many warm fuzzy's!!!

author: keason
title: such a depressing take on society
body: I guess it tells an ugly truth, but i was hoping for more humor and less commentary on man's inhumanity to man.

author: Robert J. Landy
title: A bit too confusing
body: Have a problem  keeping the characters apart.  But I have not finished the book yet.  Doubt if I will change my mind at completion.

author: Wayward Kitsune
title: It was ok but didn't captivate me like HP has
body: Plot

author: Julie Susan Wood
title: a great read
body: I really enjoyed reading this this book. I was different from the Harry Potter series but just as well written as as they were.

author: D. Gustavson
title: Whew.
body: This caught me by surprise, getting more intense as it went along. I'm going to recommend it to some social worker friends.

author: Virginia Beasley
title: J. K. Rowling - Casual Vacancy
body: I did not read this book.  I purchased it for my granddaughter, age 15.  I know that it was

author: Lori
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: If you enjoyed any of her hobbit stories you will definitely enjoy this mystery a quick read  very interesting storyline. she is a master at creating characters you grow to dislike intensely as you continue...I loved it

author: Mike
title: A sad story!
body: Too many characters right from the start; it's a little confusing! A third through, I finally figure out the different families! The story is very dark, and it's haunting to read about all the dysfunctional families, and how the young ones are affected by them! Quite sad actually!

author: KayN
title: I Read The Entire Book!
body: Yes, I read the entire book, even after I had to go back and reread a hundred or so pages because the author had so many different characters in this book and went into such great detail that it ended up being a lot of telling and not showing.  If this would have been a series, perhaps it would have been acceptable, but not in a single book.

author: Beverley Gutscher
title: A great read.
body: Ms Rowling has an amazing command of the English language.  SO well written, you can "hear" the characters speaking.  A wonderful book, incorporating and acknolwedging many aspects of typical English small town life previously not recognized in anything I have read.  Don't expect a precise plot or a definitive beginning, middle, end.  This book is about people, and life with all its turbulance and peculiarities.  A great read, especially if you have any experience of small town English living.  I hope there will be more like it to come.

author: What A Nerd Girl Says
title: Full Review on my Book Blog!
body: I currently run my own book blog and you can check out my full review of the book here. All of my reviews are spoiler free, unless otherwise noted!  [...]

author: Mary Balacuit
title: The Casual Vacancy is no Harry Potter
body: As opposed to all the negative reviews for The Casual Vacancy, my opinion for the book is that it is one of JK's yet another good books.

author: sharon bunker
title: would not recommend this book
body: The story is not well developed. The characters are introduced in such a way they confuse the reader. None of the characters is developed into either an agonist or protagonist. It is hard to get involved in a story when you feel no investment in the characters or story line.

author: Jennifer Harness
title: nothing casual in this writing.
body: Written with the care and detail of writers from the past. I feel as if I know the individual characters personally. I was a little disappointed with the ending, I would have preferred the final insight to have come from one of the other characters.

author: Nimish
title: Trash by JK Rowling
body: It has been couple of weeks since I bought this book under a dollar fromkindle. It has been a journey of pain completing this book. The book lacks excitement and has multiple characters going in circles around the death of a councillor. I would not recommend this book to anyone.

author: William W. Mouroux
title: Not an easy read to relate to
body: The style of this story is very different from the well liked Harry Potter series and difficult to relate to any single character. Almost seems like another version of "Catcher in the Rye" with all the swearing, coarse language, and criticisms. As usual, the kids are

author: CalvinHobbes
title: Different
body: I enjoyed this book, but I found it slow, (Unlike Cuckoo Calling, Robert Galbraith aka JK Rowling) It had a good moral but I felt a bit let down with the end.

author: Fran
title: Great Read
body: I really liked the story that shows the dynamic of a small village.  I live in a small town and know how people think they are so much better than everyone else because of their property or if they are on council.  They have the same problems as everyone else.

author: Jack Hansen
title: Too depressing; not what I expected.
body: Brace yourself to hear offensive language in this British account of misery, helplessness, and hopelessness.  I made it through the 2 CD set but it was not enjoyable.  If anything, it describes the treatment people receive when the government is expected to provide for its citizens in a socialistic manner.  No evidence of philanthropy anywhere and a statement that life is meaningless without the morals and virtues taught in the Bible.

author: kathy
title: GLAD I READ IT!
body: I read the book she wrote after this one and I liked it.I had read that the reviews were bad on Casual Vacancy . I 'm glad didn't listen.I think people were shocked because this was so different from HARRY POTTER.

author: Ted and Donna Rogers
title: Casual confusion
body: Too many characters, some with two names, that are not fleshed out until too late to make this interesting.  I wouldn't recommend it as a must read.

author: EK
title: Wouldn't want to live with those folks....
body: It was really hard to want to get to know any of the characters. I found them all mean spirited, small minded and nasty. Not at all what I want to believe about bucolic small towns where neighbors are kind, thoughtful, and helpful to one another.

author: Sharen Metz
title: A gripping story that grabs your heart
body: This wonderful story begins in an unassuming way, to develop character, plot and conflict, all emanating  from the death of one man in the town of Pagford. The author skillfully draws us into the complexity of behaviors and actions by juxtaposing one character to another and raising unresolved issues in every chapter. As the "plot thickens", tensions rise until a bitter ending causes change within the town and its people. This story is a highly satisfying "read". while also drawing  one's attention to the frailty and flaws of human nature.

author: Sheri
title: This is NOT your kid's Harry Potter
body: I am BEYOND tired of people comparing this book to the Harry Potter series.  People.  JK Rowlings is a WRITER, which means she will write what comes into her imagination, not just continue the same old, same old to satisfy readers who hold repetition dear.  This same criticism was railed agains Elizabeth George when she stepped back from her Dectective Inspector Lynley character and wrote a novel from a different perspective (although Lynley was tied in at the end).

author: Charles W. Brice
title: Worth the Effort
body: A Casual Vacancy is structured like a Victorian novel: many characters written in the omniscient point of view so that the author can slip in and out of the minds of each character. The book is complex and multilayerd. JKR begins with the death of Barry Fairbrother, a councilman in the small down of Pagford. His death causes ripples to move through the cauldron of pettiness that is Pagford revealing the truth behind the facades of many of the most prominent members of the community. This book comes the closest of any I've read in years of replicating the experience of being a psychotherapist, of learning what most lives are really about behind their appearances. JKR's psychological acumen is outstanding, especially when portraying the dynamics between prominent hypocritical parents and their mostly dramatically disturbed offspring. In the character of Simon Price, she presents the best depiction of a malignant narcissist I've ever read. The first 60-80 pages are difficult because the author presents many characters (reminiscent of Richard Russo) and the reader must work to keep them straight, but the labor involved is more than richly rewarded. I'm afraid that the books mixed reviews are coming from reviewers (even from some of our most prominent newspapers) who simply don't want to spend the time on complex novels that can't be speed read. God knows what these reviewers would have done with Dostoevsky or Tolstoy. They certainly lose patience with other brilliant authors - Murakami, for instance. Anyway, A Casual Vacancy is a brilliant novel, worthy of the woman who created the Potter series.

author: M. Falcon
title: Slow start, heavy ending
body: This one was just okay, nothing fantastic. I enjoyed how the story flowed smoothly from one character to the next, rather than jumping around like a lot of books do to follow each character's story line. The transitions were natural and made reading comfortable. That being said, I felt the book had a very slow start. I was disappointed when I reached the halfway point and we were still talking about the same man's death. Then we jump forward to the end and everything happens all at once. The events naturally needed to happen to end the story, I just wish they were spread out a little, I felt like I was being rushed out of the story by the end of it. It also seemed as though JK has lined the ending up to make a sequel, which bugged me a little with the open ended-ness of the different characters' happenings. All in all I'm disappointed I bought it full price and won't read it again HOWEVER, I probably would pick up a second if it turns into a series.

author: Jennifer M. Resendez
title: Enjoyed this book
body: As an American I know little about your typical English village so was very interested in the details and background story.  The story itself is bleak and to me thought the ending was cut short.  I would recommend this book b/c I was quickly pulled into the story and characters.

author: texas girl makes good
title: Just forget about Harry Potter...
body: Aside from her usual fine, sophisticated writing style, JK Rowling has left Hogwarts behind. The good guys don't always win. The bad guys don't get their due. It's not a book for kids.

author: grandma flo
title: good read
body: This book was very well written. The story is about the  lives and politics of a small English village. It is a microcosm of

author: Patricia W. Golde
title: A great but difficult read
body: J K Rowling is one of the great writers working today. She develops her story line with care and ingenuity. Her sentence structure is beautiful.  However for me the simultaneity of the story lines and the intertwining of her characters is a chore to handle especially since my reading vehicle is a kindle.

author: judy davis
title: JK's Dark Side
body: Rowling spent too much time building/describing/listing features of characters that were neither interesting nor important to the plot.

author: Leona Ramsay
title: I thought she was a better writer tthan this
body: This book was so dreary I could not read it all the way thru.  It would be very nice if she would write something as livly as her Harry Potter books.

author: Coup183
title: I found a new writer
body: She's off to a great start and I'll be watching for the next one. I like the format she's using and the chapter headings.

author: Christine Goode
title: Hard to read yet hard to put down
body: My husband downloaded this book for me since I am a frequent traveler and thought it would be an "easy" read - meaning I wouldn't miss my flight because I got engrossed in the plot. All I can say is that I would have had to have read all 1000+ pages to get to the plot because this book is NOT a casual read. You have to really pay attention to the people and who belongs with whom or you will really lose the impact of the characters and their interaction.

author: Gwenniepoo
title: Good story
body: I like JK Rowling, I like her writing style.  but I could not figure out what was going on in the story and have not been able to finish it.  I will try again.

author: Chelsea
title: Still havent finished it
body: Had this book almost a year and cant seem to get into it. Its got a good story line; Its just slow moving.

author: Frankie
title: TRASH, see my review of Cuckoos Calling
body: same as Cuckoos Calling. This is like walking, (running once you get the aroma) through the final level of Dante's Inferno. It is a sewer of excrement. Rowling had better return to more intellectual pursuits. The Potter series was excellent, this is stupid.

author: NinaRyb
title: disappointing
body: Unfortunately this book didn't meet my expectations. I started reading it and have put it down multiply times. It's a difficult read because there is nothing captivating or wanting you to read more happening in this book. Waste of time and money

author: Ash the Flash
title: Great story and characters, but sloppy editing dragged it down.
body: I really liked the story that Rowling crafted in this book, but I have to say I was very surprised/disappointed at how many issues there were in the writing that could have been easily fixed if an editor had bothered to give the narrative a good look. (I could be wrong, but I'm assuming her editor didn't give this much thought and perhaps just figured "It's JKR, of course it's good" and sent it to print without a thorough reading?)

author: Diana Roberts
title: A lumbering read, with excellent writing and depressing characters
body: I got to the 32% mark in my Kindle before this book started flowing for me. The first third of the book just lumbered along introducing one unlikable character after another. The only thing that held my interest was the strong prose. Finally, a few of the younger characters came alive & I was rewarded by finishing one of the most depressing novels that I have ever read. If I did not love my EReader so much, I would have thrown it across the room after completing this very disturbing book.

author: HopewelLibraryofLife
title: Vivid portrayal of gritty small town life
body: From the reviews here on Amazon I expected to throw this back. We all know J.K. Rowling (Harry Potter) can tell a great story, but the average for this one was only 3 stars. I think that's an injustice!! Once again, though, it maybe a case of the book being better on audio. Tom Hollander is a great voice for this story. Rowling's story begins when Parish [Town] Councilor Barry Fairbrother dies in the Country Club parking lot of natural causes in his wife's arms. This then creates a "casual vacancy" on the Council. What happens next is WHY the Bible tells us God keeps vengeance strictly for himself!!

author: G. C. Pender
title: Couldn't Finish It
body: I couldn't get into this book. I forced myself to plod through a few chapters before giving up.

author: Carol N. Doty
title: A boring story with lots of gossip
body: I was eager to read a JK Rowling novel that wasn't about Harry Potter, and what a great disappointment it was.  I was bored from the beginning and then saddened to find her handling of interactions between the haves and the have nots predominantly with gossip.  I am sorry I purchased the book and was happy to give it to the library book sale rather than to a friend or family member.  Lots of authors burn out after their first book or best series.  I felt Rowling burned out before she got to this one.

author: dawn carter chambers
title: MUCH Less than expected.
body: I so looked forward to reading this book... Bought it in soft cover to take to the beach.  I'm an avid reader, and generally read on Kindle, but wanted to hold this one in my hands.  What a disappointment.. The characters were predictable, the plot was slow to develop, and the book was too long.  Only because I always finish any book I begin, I read to the bitter end of this dismal and depressing failure.

author: UScustomer
title: Drawn-Out Soap
body: Still absorbed by teenagers and unrealistic fantasies-- author seems to have little understanding of deeper adult emotions. If it's supposed to be a character study, none are very well developed, and the story is so thin you can skip entire sections without losing the thread. I wouldn't have bothered if one of my friends had read it first and warned me off

author: Marie P.
title: Surprised with not enjoying a J. K. Rowling book!
body: I agree with some of the others that read this book. It is so boring and hard to really get into the story since I was not enjoying the read. There was too much jumping around from one family to another. I thought that since I thoroughly enjoyed all the Harry Potter books, that I would enjoy Casual Vacancy also...not in this case. I would definitely not recommend this book!

author: Fran Griffis
title: Good, but I expected more
body: Knowing JK Rowling wrote this, I think I had very high expectations.  It is an engaging story and the writing is in her usual fluid style.  Many of the characterizations were full and well drawn, especially the young people.  I found the adults less well limned and occasionally had to back track or retrace in my head who was who.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Great character study
body: Instead of "Casual Vacancy," this novel could have been called "Casual Unkindness" or even "Casual Cruelty." It shows the ease with which many people take out their own unhappiness on each other every day. J.K. Rowling, with her gift for bringing even minor characters to life, also gives them all chances to act differently, to choose the path to being a better person -- but as in real life, most of them don't. With evocative language and dialogue and striking turns of phrase, Ms. Rowling pulls you into the interior lives of the characters and their families.  As a long-time Harry Potter fan, I really enjoyed this complete change of tone and direction from Ms. Rowling.

author: Sadie M.
title: Kindle Format is Terrible
body: I have very much enjoyed this book, but reading it on my kindle has been a nightmare--I have to have my font setting on the largest setting available, and even then, the font is tiny and difficult to read (I'm 29, by the way, and do not have vision problems).  I tried deleting it off my kindle and re-downloading it several times, but that didn't work, leading me to believe the font size problem is related to the e-copy itself. I would recommend going with the print edition of this.

author: Jeddy
title: Never got beyond the first chaper
body: Too wordy .  Too many characters introduced rather poorly.  Actually boring with a slow pace that never picked up.  Would not recommend.

author: Fran
title: Sorry I bought it
body: The WORST book I have ever read! Can't believe it is by the same author as the Harry Potter Series.

author: Kathy Mair
title: Great characters
body: Rowling's gift for creating real life characters on a page is as evident here as it was in the Harry Potter series. The ending was a little flat, for me, but it was an entertaining read nonetheless.

author: Ellen Murphy
title: Characters Without Passion
body: I knew from the first that this would be a departure from Harry Potter, but I was disappointed in the entire book.  It was very hard to get started, but since others seemed to have reviewed the book without finishing, I decided to see if I could get through the text.  I did, but I am not richer for it.  There were too many characters and I simply could not keep them all straight, especially since some of the names were frequently interchanged with nicknames.  The tone of the book was quite melancholy, which was fine, but the greatest failing is that the characters were not interesting.  I simply did not care about them.  The author managed to write a pedantic book without passion, and I know she has the capability to do better.  The book is a disappointment and I can think of many other ways to spend your time.

author: maryw
title: Didn't like it
body: Too much bad language .  Story boring. Took to long for story to develop. I have enjoyed her other novel under a different name

author: Christine
title: I just want to say that I did enjoy this book - the author wrote with such insight into these families - amazing.
body: It was as though you were part of each different family - such insight - a book really well worth reading.

author: Susan Peck
title: A Casualty of Boredom
body: So many characters who I care nothing about. Boring, lifeless, self serving. One star is one star too many. So disappointing

author: Desmond Keats
title: Average book.
body: Much like her new book, published under the fake alleged SAS agent turned author Galbraith; this book is a little boring and filled with prose that just elucidates useless details that have no take on the matter at hand, and although this is treasured in Harry Potter, which is a fantasy rich with details that we are unaware of and hence love to read about...Rowling's venture into other genres seem forced and unnatural: her characters seem real but not really, you can never shake the feeling that the whole thing is fictional, that things happen as they're supposed to happen, with very little elements of surprise or thrill. Plot use elements of chaos and randomization to get characters into, and out of tough situations, and although the former is obliged, the latter feels like cheating.

author: Dee
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I found this book hard to capture my interest; it wasn't until the middle that I became serious about finishing it. Maybe her next novel will be more captivating.

author: louise a. kerr
title: she needed  a good editor
body: It was to long and very repetitive. She should have cut down on the number of characters--they were hard to sort out and mostly unlikeable.  It seemed uniformed about the social situations she was trying to high-light.  This might have been a good read if the publisher had not been so anxious to gain from her famous name.  I have no doubt that she has sold many books but I don't think this book was of a quality that she should be very proud of.  I advise her and her editors to take more care next time out.

author: Linda R. Wheeler
title: Casual Vacancy
body: I bought this book immediately after reading 'The Cuckoo's Calling', this book wasn't as enjoyable in my opinion.  I couldn't decide if it was a teenage book or what.  I found it hard to keep up with who was who, and who was married to who.  I stuck with it through the end but it wasn't one of my favorites.

author: friendlyfire
title: Casual Vacancy still haunts me
body: It is JK but not Harry, more adult and more internal. No quidditch here. It's also a lot more British. Some of the terms stumped me and the Kindle dictionary. It goes quickly and keeps the reader wanting more. It's dark too. I cried.

author: me
title: interesting
body: Not the quality I was expecting but interesting view of contemporary British village life and social issues.  Another complex plot with a multitude of interesting characters.  I prefer a writer to let the characters reveal themselves, as we know Rowling can masterfully do

author: Andrew Harrison Mcminn
title: Very unique.
body: Jkr always is very discriptive writter. Although i would rather be reading another harry potter book. This story will tide me over.

author: S. Boyer
title: Audiobook is Excellent!
body: This review is based on the excellent audiobook. First, my JKR background. Yes, read all HP's with my son and loved them. Thought Rowling really evolved as a writer from Book 1 to final in the series.

author: Beverly Rojas
title: British setting
body: Loved being in the small town with all the intricately woven characters.  Vocabulary was different and much more interesting that most books I've read.  Would definitely recommend it.  Left it in Thailand with a newly wed couple for their enjoyment after I finished reading it.  Definitely recommend it.  I really enjoyed J. K. Rowling's first attempt at adult fiction.

author: Dorothy
title: This is a wonderful story.
body: I could not put this book down!  Rawlings writes about real people, with all their illusions, unfulfilled hopes, hurts and self deceptions,as well as their skills, intelligence and compassion.

author: Tamara
title: Author
body: I loved the Harry Potter series and thought I would enjoy anything she wrote.  Could not get into this particular book.

author: Chrisy Loves Cows
title: J.K. I'm so disappointed
body: It was filthy. I was so excited to see what else she could come up with but it was hard to see past all of the language and sexual content to see if it was good writing anyway.  She distracted from the story instead of enhancing it.  So disappointed.

author: Michael Tobis
title: An unexpected gem
body: I was stuck at an airport layover with nothing to read and the bookstore selection was small. I had not heard of this book and did not have any prior interest in it. I picked Rowling because I was in need of distraction. I think I intended to read a quarter of it and leave it behind in the Atlanta airport as I've done with Harry Potter books and other airport purchases.

author: Marilyn Andersen
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Hard to follow all the many characters and took me 200 pages into reading before I found this book worth continuing.  The British city govt. system is not easy to comprehend to American readers.  Adult situations.

author: Marilyn
title: Appreciate the literary skill but plot dragged
body: I probably shouldn't review books that I don't finish but I was all primed for a winner and after plodding through a couple of hundred pages I put it down.  Very possibly it comes to life in the middle so know that I didn't finish this book.

author: RTK123
title: Classic Rowling
body: The descriptive writing and character development are unequaled; it's a bit of a dark story and its hard to find someone to like or root for but nonetheless its a great read.

author: Pat N.
title: Different
body: I have not read the Harry Potter Books, though my grandchildren love them. Decided to read this mystery of hers. It is an interesting book and a good mystery. I did have a little problem with the British words and accents, but I did enjoy it for the most part. Adult readers of The Harry Potter Books would surely enjoy it. Definitly not for young people.

author: Melanie
title: total disappointment
body: I was so excited to hear JK Rowling had a book out after the Harry Potter books - I loved the whole series (although I think JK got a little lazy in the middle of the 7th, I mean really... how long can they wander around not knowing what they were looking for?) but.... casual vacancy was the most boring book I ever forced myself to read. I don't mind dark, I don't even mind a little depressing if the story piques my interest, but this book was a hellacious waste of my valuable time. I give it 0 stars... we KNOW she can do way better than this piece of trash!

author: Naseberry
title: Very entertaining
body: I enjoyed this book a lot. Good plot, good characters, the gradual revelation of past secrets made for suspense, I wanted to know how things would turn out.

author: Donald Vincent
title: Very Casual
body: Rowling wrote a book that when I finished I said, "An interesting story".  Very good descriptive writing.

author: Tina Hayes
title: Tragic Tale of Personal Struggles
body: J.K. Rowling's "Casual Vacancy" is a story about what happens in the small town of Pagford when Barry Fairbrother dies, how the people he knew coped, and who will take his place on the town council.  This is a very tragic tale that shows how everyone fights some sort of daily battle in their lives, whether against bullies, fear, addiction, loneliness, or society itself.

author: S. Anderson
title: Good book, very strong language and adult content
body: Definitely not for anyone under 18.  Her characters are well flushed out, although I can't say I care much for these people; gives humanity a black eye.  I had to keep reading though because I wanted to know how the story ended.  I was torn between 3 and 4 stars but thought it was better than just "ok."

author: MAX WENGER
title: Vacancy denighed
body: I thought the language was too vulgar.  The book was not rated that I cpild see, and probably would not have purchased it if I had.  I'm not sure her purpose was for writing the book, except maybe don't  be a poor slob living in

author: Dreamer10
title: Very Happy with Purchase
body: Even though this book got mixed reviews, I really liked it. I found it very interesting reading and could hardly put it down. I think J.K. Rowling did a great job with the very different venue from Harry Potter series. (I totally loved Harry Potter!) I plan to purchase her next novel "The Cuckoo's Calling".

author: Charlotte Bolthouse Bartelt
title: Fantastic
body: I've read the Harry Potter Series multiple times so I was, of course, excited for this book. It was a little slow starting, but then had me hooked. Growing up in a small, pretentious town I can say that J.K. hit the nail on the head. She also was able to get me so invested in the characters that I cried more than I probably should have, but I wouldn't expect anything else from the "queen."

author: Catherine Griffin
title: What a disappointment!
body: The reason I read books is to enjoy a bit of fun outside my own life.  How disappointing to read a book mired down in miserable circumstances and socially inept people with crummy and competing agendas....this book reads like LA politics!

author: Barbara Tompkins
title: didn't like
body: I think the book is not one of her best.  I didn't think it is

author: Amazon Customer
title: Casual victory
body: This book was quite a disappointment, keep waiting for it to get better ,but it never did. Boring !  I'd take a refund on this one.

author: Lagunadeb
title: J K Rowling does it again
body: Outstanding book with heart

author: Ann
title: interesting character study
body: I have never read the HP series and was not frightened off by those fans who did not like the book. I found it to be an interesting study of caste and character. Don't listen to those who say that there are too many characters, if you enjoy a different, interesting read, this book is definitely worth your time.

author: Sister Louise
title: Vulgar language was too much!
body: I barely made it through the first three chapters and then stuck the book on the bookshelf.  I'm no prude but the overuse of the "f" word was very offensive and quickly lost any intended emotional ambience.  I hope I can find some poor soul to give it to.

author: Cloggie Downunder
title: a brilliant read.
body: The Casual Vacancy is the first adult novel by popular British author, J.K.Rowling. This contemporary fiction is set in the seemingly idyllic English village of Pagford, where the sudden death of Parish Councillor, Barry Fairbrother creates a casual vacancy on the parish council. As subsequent events are narrated from the points of view of various different characters, the picture emerges of a village whose inhabitants are not all satisfied with their lot in life, a village of simmering tensions waiting to boil over. Rowling's characters are easily recognisable as the denizens of the typical English village, but at the same time, show individual depth and appeal (or repugnance, as the case may be). And it seems quite a few of the characters have a secret (or two). The setting, characters and events will resonate with readers, and these same happenings drive the characters to desperate actions that ultimately result in tragedy for some. Rowling manages to pack quite a lot into this novel: she has an obese megalomaniac, drug addicts, computer-savvy teens, a fawning wife, a violent husband and father, an anxious teacher, and a caring social worker, to name just a few. There is domestic violence, rape, racism, corruption, self-mutilation, bullying, gossip, teen pregnancy, child abuse and SQL injection. But if this sounds depressing, it is relieved by the underlying black humour that fills the novel.  This all comes together to make a brilliant read.

author: A. Barree
title: Anthony Trollop redux
body: In the tradition of Anthony Trollope, Rowlings develops a seemingly simple situation in small town goverment into a full blown drama.  The story evolves from the various characters' reactions to the sudden death of Barry Fairweather, a man who provided support and stabilzation for many of his fellow citizens. As the story unfolds, these individuals' backgrounds and feelings are revealed.  While some unravel to the point of crash and burn, there are those whose dignity is preserved or restored. I particularly enjoyed the author's technique of revealing, largely through internal monologue, the inner lives and feelings of not only the adults but the adolescents of the town.

author: Rita Vanek
title: Complex Characters and Relationships
body: Great book, engrossing character development.

author: *tella
title: surprse! The Casual Vacancy
body: I was pleasantly surprised that I enjoyed this story as much as I did.  I have not read the HP series or seen the movies, there was always so much talk about them, I felt as though I had.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Couldn't get into it
body: I wanted to like it, but after a couple of chapters I quit reading. Nothing grabbed my interest enough to want to continue. I got as far several finding out this man died, how they each had a connection in a different way...I decided it might be one of those books better listened to than read. If I change my mind and pick up the book to try it again and like it, I will get back to you:>)

author: Deb
title: Fascinating character study of the evil in people's hearts
body: I absolutely loved this book and couldn't put it down.  Every person had multiple layers of deceit, envy, cravenness,  self-importance.  The character study and interplay is fascinating.  Truly the dark side of a beautiful English village.  The writing is fantastic as you might expect.

author: KAREN  Levy
title: The  Casual Vacancy
body: Did not like it all!!!!!!!! I Did not like the story, people or anything about this book. I was very disappointed,

author: derek strine
title: Sucked
body: Its was boring and a huge let down. I think rowling should not write if shes not goig to try.its not like she needs the money... Just a huge let down no where near as good as harry potter

author: Ashley
title: bor-ing
body: I only bought this book because there was so much hype over it. I didn't care for any of the characters, the plot intersted me zero, and it was too slow. I always finish books and this one was torture.

author: Tennlady
title: Not My Cup Of  Tea
body: I couldn't get past the second chapter.  Boring and lots of unnecessary bad language.  I wouldn't recommend it.  A waste of money!

author: AR
title: Well crafted character study
body: I read this book on holiday.Unlike some other reviewers I quickly got hooked on the individual characters and how the initial event causes a ripple effect through the local community.Some of the villagers were a little stereotyped but overall her description really captured the characters for me and whilst few were likeable all felt human and real.For the first time in ages this book left me choking back tears - a sign of good writing in my book !

author: Lottie Mixson
title: Excellent story of interconnected lives in a small town
body: The death of an individual sends ripples throughout a small town. Superbly written, excellent character development - the story and writing should qualify it for classic status.

author: Jennifer Larson
title: All the action in beginning draws you in
body: Reminiscent of the girl with the dragon tattoo with introduction to so many characters so quickly.  It was hard to keep straight who was who and how tied together and that is important to me so it was slow for me as I had to go back and re-read to get how the characters were related, not necessarily by blood but in some cases by location or profession, etc...she is a spectacular author, just takes a lot of work for me as I said I have to know how all tie together to make me happy, so not a good afternoon read just for leisure, I had to think to keep up.

author: Ann
title: Casual vacancy
body: Can't really recommend.  Well written but no likeable characters.  Realistic, but depressing subject matter.  Barely finished it -not sure why I did.

author: JoAnn
title: Disappointing and Depressing - Skip It
body: What a disappointing read! I hoped it would get better, but was disappointed until the bitter end. There was no character in the book that I cared anything about. It was not at all appealing; too many pages of drugs, sex and people hating each other. Even those sad topics could be, and have been presented by authors in an interesting story.  Wish I had read some reviews before we bought the book. Hopefully JK Rowling finds her voice in something readable in the future. A final note, I've read a few of her Harry Potter books and they were pretty good. I was not expecting anything similar, but I did expect an interesting story.

author: Amanda Storlie
title: Not my favorite book
body: So, I'm not sure what I was expecting, but I couldn't finish this book. In fact, I hope I can still return it. It was slow, there were a LOT of characters (the character that ties them all together is dead), and it was just so meticulously detailed that even half way into the book nothing has really happened. Not going to finish it if I can return it; I'd suggest checking it out from a library if you have to read it. Don't waste your money on it. Sorry, J.K. Rowling, maybe your mystery series is better?

author: Jennifer Willmott
title: Ok
body: I found this book was well written and I found myself getting into the characters, but I was unhappy with the ending, I felt that most of the characters that were introduced did not get a proper ending, I was left wondering what would happen to a lot of them.

author: Carol DeCrescentis
title: Book is not as interesting as I expected.
body: I am finding it hard to stay with the story. I will try and finish it but I am not sure I will.

author: Smileysativa
title: Sssooo slow
body: Only got interesting after the first half. Took me nearly 6 months to actually get through the first half. Don't think I'd recommend it unless you have absolutely nothing else to read.

author: Jesse
title: diappointing
body: I was excited to read another book by JK Rowling. This book was tedious and lifeless. I do not recommend it.

author: Jeanette Kerr
title: Amazing Relationships
body: This book has all the ingredients that one can relate to. The interactions of teenagers with parents at their worst. And thinking that everyone else has great family relationships looking from the outside. But... the old saying about what goes on behind closed doors....

author: Sabbykoala
title: A book that is really about nothing
body: I was surprised it was this short. Nothing fantastic about this at all. I was waiting for some kind of storyline  to appear when  I realised that it was about to end.

author: weeping willow
title: Don't think about the author - just read with an open mind
body: I really enjoyed this book.  I devoured it in a few days and was sad to turn that last page.  The subject matter is far from gay but that's what life is, isn't it?  We're all trying to make our way through this world, in our own little lives.

author: jallen
title: Casual Vacancy is not a casual read
body: Excellent character development with devastating realism. Rowling develops compelling story lines that draw you into a dark story of small town prejudices and infighting. Well worth the read.

author: Thelma Meyer
title: The "real world" of dreary Muggles?
body: Maybe 1 1/2 stars,  I stopped reading after a few chapters.  I suppose its all about "Muggles" and we know how awful they are. Perhaps Rowling grew up with Muggles -- and had to create a magical world to escape them.  She's better off writing about her created world.  The "real" word she tries to enter is dreary.  The people in this book, as much as I've read are not exactly awful - but they are not interesting - and there are just too many of them.  It wasn't worth the effort to get to know one dreary individual after another.  I - sigh - put it down.

author: Joanne Tailele
title: Cumbersome
body: Way too many characters to follow, 30, i believe. I would have given it a one until book club, when one reader found some redeeming quality that upped it to a two.

author: Yildiz Sethi
title: A psychological and social read
body: shows how people interact and how entanglements and character comes to the fore and how w are all connected in an intangable way

author: educ81
title: Don't Get It.
body: I picked this book because it was rated number 1 fiction book. Honestly, I don't get it. I tried to struggle through it. I kept thinking it would get better. It never did. Finally, I had to stop reading half way through. This is very rare for me not to finish a book. Quite a disappointment.

author: Sisyphussays
title: Disappointed in Rowling
body: THE CASUAL VACANCY is a beautifully written book.  It's a pleasure to read a book that uses the English language in such a wonderful way.  Unfortunately, by the time I reached page 150 I was fed up with all the backbiting, dislike/hatred and temper tantrums of husbands toward wives and wives towawrd husbands, parents toward their own children, neighbors toward neighbors and so-called friends toward friends.  I know what Rowling was trying to do but it was deeply disappointing and disgusting to waste such beautiful writing on such a negative book.

author: Robin Snyder
title: Definitely a Departure
body: So I finally finished this book. It took me much longer to get through than a normal read.

author: xansgram
title: Very Disappointed
body: After reading all the Harry Potter books, I had never read a writer with such a vivid imagination.  Unfortunately, I didn't see it in this book, I got half way through it and couldn't read any more.  Very disappointed.

author: Gabrielle V
title: Not for everyone. Obviously.
body: I am one of those who read HP on-time (I think I was about 10 when the first HP book got big). I enjoyed the series, although in the end I started to feel it got a little too battle-friendly. I enjoyed the boarding school atmosphere the same way I enjoyed Enid Blyton and Tom Brown as a child, not magic battles. I'd go to other authors for that.

author: SaucyKatLady
title: heart wrenching
body: JKR knows how to writing is magical even if there is no magic in it. Don't expect Harry Potter but a story that is real and realistic to communities that we live in every day and the realities we choose to ignore cause we can.

author: bookgirl
title: don't go into this book thinking you will find HP
body: This is a well written book but it is not the magical world of Hogwarts. It is the ordinary world of Pagford and yes in this small town there are some crappy people who have crappy things happen to them but that's life. I have to say it is refreshing to read about characters with real flaws, especially the teenagers. I work in education and yes kids do drugs, bully, drink, have sex, hurt people (including themselves) and aren't always the hero. And so called pillars of the community usually have skeletons in the closet. This is a story that intertwines several families through a series of tragedies.

author: Tamara Olsen
title: Okay
body: Not the normal JK Rowling. Takes a bit to get into it. Good read eventually. Nice drama and mystery read

author: lin
title: Trust J K Rowling to build depth. Keep reading. It will stick with you.
body: If I hadn't trusted what an incredible author J K Rowling is, I would have tossed the book. She seemed to have dispensed with her skill to engage the reader into a main character, but trust me, she pulls it off in a most backdoor fashion. The characters are flawed, human, and eventually... vivid. Only well into the book, do we get the insights and compassion we have seen in good ole Harry & company. It's a side of life we don't usually seek out for casual escapist reading. Nearly half the book is spent in giving us the seamy side of her characters before she lifts the veil and we see beneath the sheen of their delusions of themselves. In the end, they recover some deeper introspection to their attempts to appear perfect. This is not a perfect world. It is a world of "work in progress" and a messy business it is. I find myself assessing how giving and caring I've been and will become, as this book distills itself in the trickle down aftermath of reading. It's a tough read and poignant to the point of painful, but Rowling always takes the higher ground, bringing depths to the most vile, uncovering the twists of fate that created the Snapes and Vordemorts. Even our beloved Dumledore emerged with flaws. In "Casual Vacancy" we come to know the deceased Barry Fairbrother through his profound influence on others' lives. She shows us that we are all capable of more... more depth... more compassion... more humanity... more beingness... and gives us this excruciating set of examples of what not to be and do, and then, what we could... if we dared... BE.

author: Dolly
title: I loved this book.
body: I can not wait until she comes out with a second book. this was the most amazing read I have had due to the fact

author: vmcla
title: Perfect Storytelling for Serious Readers
body: Any reservations I had about reading this book were blown-away in the first few pages where readers who love unusual storytelling will be hooked and launched into an absorbing reading experience.

author: Bonnie
title: And they all lived miserably ever after
body: Well. J K Rowling wrote a legendary fantasy which beguiled the world. Not me, I never got further than the first Harry Potter, but I had nothing against it, it was just not my kind of magic, I prefer Zelazny for that genre.

author: Elisabeth
title: Definitely not your run-of-the-mill book
body: With 3806 reviews already posted, there isn't much more that can be said.  My comment:  the book is brilliant!  I expected to like it, I wanted to like it, but found myself struggling at the beginning, not sure what was going on and disappointed. Then, things started falling into place and I realized suddenly how cleverly the characters and plot were being fed to me and everything started to make sense.  Yes, I agree that it could be considered a dark comedy but it isn't a pretty book.  Get rid of your expectations before reading this book because this book is something different.  The writing is superb.  There were times where, after reading a passage, I had to stop and read the passage several times aloud marveling at how those plain and innocuous words could be assembled in such a manner as to create such powerful expression.  I loved it.  I am impressed.  I look forward to more of the same.

author: Lady Rain
title: Purchased as a gift
body: Purchased as a gift for my daughter who is a JK Rowling fan.  Arrive new and on time.  She was happy.

author: Barbara D
title: The storyline was dull.
body: The ending was good... it brought the book full circle but the plot itself was lacking. You did get to know the characters well.

author: Julia Padgett
title: the kids are alright
body: I think the biggest problem I had with this book is that the younger characters have depth and dimension to them while the adults (mainly) suffer from just facet --- and that facet is bad. Only one or two adults do you have any sympathy for in the entire book (and one of them dies at the beginning). The rest of the adult population seem to be line drawings of what is wrong with humanity --- delusional expectations, overwhelming desires to escape from reality, self-righteousness, narcissism, corruption, drug addiction, me-me-me-me. It just doesn't strike true that an entire book could be made up of such a sorry lot of humanity. The kids do come off slightly better and are definitely given a range of emotions, struggles and shades of depth. However, again, the person you are holding out hope for also dies. I just hope the next book by Ms. Rowling applies the same rule to the adults that it does to the youth --- we are complicated creatures, write it so.

author: bh
title: ugly, cynical, disappointing
body: I admire the writing; it's nothing short of brilliant. What I did not like at all is any of the characters. They are all seriously flawed, and I do not believe that reflects real-life people. I wish I hadn't bothered to finish it. It left me sad and bummed. And, I'm afraid, it's put me off Rowling.

author: Jann Cassady
title: Depressing
body: Not Harry Potter that's for sure...just seemed like a lot of messed up people and lousy situations.  Not what I expected.

author: sandra vandehey
title: I love the British!
body: Though I don't think this book is for everyone, the inner personality of the small British town was an an interesting read.

author: Michael R. Pease
title: Life behind the masks.
body: I'm amazed at the intimate and detailed knowledge of small town life Rowling brings to her story, especially of such a wide range of social strata.  She makes the reader feel compassion even for the most despicable of her characters.  I can hardly put it down, and I don't have a clue how she's going to end it.

author: Lilia
title: Just not that good...
body: I loved the harry potter books growing up, and as I became and more discerning reader, I was able to set aside the problems with the writing to enjoy the story.

author: Carol Mathis
title: Tragic, Insightful Comedy of Manners
body: I have read A Casual Vacancy at least 4 times.  Each time I have found something new to be amazed by, something new to be touched by, something new to learn from.  It is certainly more Dickens than Wodehouse, a serious work of fiction about social inequality and cruelty and the results of that cruelty.  Rowling is an acute observer of human behavior, and her criticisms are right on the money. The more comical aspects of the story are rather tart; I can see why people missed the dry humor.

author: Mayor Mom
title: Mayor Mom
body: Bought the book, not because of the well known author, but because I thought the subject matter would be an interesting and fun concept.  What a depressing slog to get though this book.  There was not one character I cared about, but made myself finish the book just to see how it ended.  Can there really be a town so filled with vile people, even in the author's mind? Not one redeeming page.  It appeared that the author was trying for an ending that left you with some hope, but even that fell flat.  I will be dropping my copy off at the second hand book shop for credit to buy something that is worth reading.  I have to try and get an remnant of this read out of my head.

author: Chana
title: This was a disappointment
body: I bought this as a gift for my daughter who loves Harry Potter. She was disappointed with this. I asked why she said this just isn't her genera.

author: AM
title: Not recommended
body: I have not read any Harry Potter books and had no particular expectations. I got the audio book at Cracker Barrel for a long road trip and hoped for the best. I was amazed at how bad this book was. I thought the underlying premise, setting, and characters could have made for great drama. But, ultimately the book is about six dysfunctional families and you pretty much want to strangle all the adults. There is rape, incest, domestic violence, and other unpleasant actions. However, there is no suspense or mystery--when anonymous things occur, she tells you who is doing them as they happen. There are no likeable characters, just unhappy parents, unhappy teenagers, and a lot of bad results. The moral to the story is apparently that at least some people will appreciate each other more and get past their anger once really, really bad things happen. I found the plot boring and probably shouldn't have hung on until the end.

author: Texas Girl
title: Disappointed and couldn't finish the book
body: I couldn't finish this book.  There wasn't one character that I really cared to find out what happened to them.  Most of the time I was very bored with the story line and would fall asleep.  I loved Harry Potter but the creativity that Rowling displayed in creating the world of Harry Potter was lacking in this story.

author: Mario
title: Casual Reading
body: I was never a "Harry Potter" fan so when I noticed

author: Kindle Customer
title: inrigue in the every day life in the UK .
body: Realistic portrayal of life in a small community in the UK  an official dies unexpectedly  many vie to succeed him .  Great look into small town especially the school system

author: Theresa A. Behrens
title: Disappointed
body: Being a huge fan of the Harry Potter series, I was disappointed. I might have enjoyed it more if it had been written under a pseudonym, but do understand Ms. Rawlings wanting to write a different type of story.

author: Michael Speers
title: great
body: Loved it, well written, great characters, story line is clever, sad, wise, insightful and funny. Bring on the next one soon,

author: Toni Osborne
title: Boring
body: I have not much to say on J.K. Rowling first novel for adult readership. Rarely do I give up on a novel "The Casual Vacancy" made the list. After labouring through 250 pages I simply couldn't waste more precious reading time on a very boring story concerning a parish council election in a small West Country town. This story is an unadventurous study of provincial life with some superficial excitements. A large cast of young characters taking drugs, swearing and having sex weaves through a multiple and interlocking plots that are flat-lined by predictability. I wasn't able from the start to immerse myself in the people I found them very frustrating and a real farce. I gave up....that is all I can say.

author: Reader Girl
title: Dissapointed
body: JK Rowling is a great author - no denying that - she has a way with words. And it's understandable that she wants to stray from the HP series. But I had to force myself to get through this book. Way too many characters, and the material just wasn't interesting. It was depressing. I hope her next non-HP book is better.

author: Larissa Masterson
title: Mixed Feelings, but I think I am glad I read it.
body: I downloaded the book without reading the description or any customer reviews. I bought it solely because of the author. I am an adult and a huge Harry Potter fan. I was not expecting this to be anything like Harry Potter, but was excited to see what else JKR wrote.

author: Thoughtful Reader
title: OK. it's not war and peace
body: It is a quite well written and well plotted novel. The characters are interesting if not particularly deep. I thought it was a good effort by a skilled writer.

author: Pippa
title: a struggle to read
body: I had anticipated this on the basis of a good friends review. Sadly it is one of the very few books that we will have to disagree on. Whilst parts were insightful the depth was lacking as the story covered too many characters with a similar level of intensity, so no one had any greater depth or meaning in the story.

author: Barising
title: Slow moving with to many characters to keep track of them.
body: I found this book boring.  It's a small village with many various different characters, but little too distinguish one from another until you are very deeply into the book.  The ending portion is when the book finally comes to some point about the individual characters.  The most difficult thing about the book is much of it is written in "Cockney"  and many words were half the word with the apostrophe for what the character wasn't saying.  If you are British, this book would probably be more enjoyable. Cockney is not in the dictionary on your Kindle.

author: Kaci
title: Very Disappointed
body: I bought The Casual Vacancy hoping it would be just as good as Rowling's Harry Potter series, as I'm sure everyone else did.  However, it was hard to make myself keep reading.  There were too many characters, so they were hard to keep up with.  Also, I felt like there was no real climax.  It was more like several smaller stories put together.  There were too many subplots.  It seems like Rowling tried to put too much into one story.  The writing style was not nearly as clear as the Potter series either.  I didn't enjoy the book at all.

author: L. Steidl
title: I was so excited to read this book.
body: I read the Harry Potter series well into adulthood, and loved every book. I was excited to see what Rowling would do with adult fiction. This book was just dreary. It's as if every character in Rowling's fictional village were a Dursley. Now, I think the Dursleys were well written and necessary to the Harry Potter series, but you couldn't build an entire book around them. I disliked every character in this book, and I didn't care what happened to any of them. This story contained some good writing, and was obviously well-researched, but the unrelievedly boorish characters ruined it completely. I cannot recommend this book.

author: Amazon Customer
title: A Brilliant Book!
body: In a wide departure from her previous work she has written a complex commentary on English society in a small village and the innermost thoughts of the people living there. It's a social commentary on class structure, a deep analysis of the inner secrets and public faces that the individuals possess, and an intricate plot.  It has stayed with me for days after finishing it. I think it has all the elements of a classic.

author: Vicki Noble
title: Totally Cynical
body: I don't know what all the hype is about this author writing a book "for adults." She approaches her characters in the most cynical way, as if she can't stand any of them and they deserve whatever they get--they are caricatures, at best. It's as if none of them has any spiritual center at all; they exhibit only the most negative character traits: envy, jealousy, hatefulness, cruelty, indifference, arrogant self-focus, crippling self-loathing, competitiveness, ruthlessness, and general heartlessness. I read to the bitter end, thinking that surely she was going to pull something out of the hat--but no such luck. Ruthless herself, she tied up each pathetic little life in a paragraph and brought the book to a merciful end.

author: Marissa Richardson
title: An uncomfortable read, but worth it.
body: This book is a very uncomfortable book to get into. Let's just get that out of the way. And I think I know why.

author: Franci A. Washburn
title: Disappointing
body: I tried to approach this novel as if I had never read Rowling's Harry Potter books, as if this story was written by a new author whose work I had not read.  I would be disappointed if this were an author new to me whose previous works I had never read, but with my experience of reading Rowling's Potter series, I am doubly disappointed.  The best I can say about this book is that it is well-crafted.  Rowling seems to follow all the rules a student learns in a first year creative writing workshop, but like those novice writers, following all the rules doesn't breathe life into the story, which is devoid of life.  I simply don't give a crap about any of these characters or what happens to them.  Yes, as some reviewers have pointed out, there are some poetic lines here and there, but even a blind hog can find an acorn now and then.

author: Donald R. Stephani
title: A book review of sorts
body: Perhaps Ms. Rowling had to write this novel to free herself of all the good in Harry Potter, but it is my belief that she should have never sent it to publication. To me it's like the letter you write when you are totally mad at someone, you write it but never send it.

author: Wendie Vanderwater
title: Better than I expected!
body: I loved the Harry Potter books and wasn't sure how this story would go.  It was a very interesting story that had some excellent characters.  I may read it again.

author: Kindle Customer
title: So, so disapointed
body: Expected so much more from this book. Too many stories going at once with a thin plot line. Really one of the worst books I have ever read. Considering that the Harry Potter books were some of the most enjoyable.

author: Jocie
title: Boring
body: Tried three times to read it. The characters are unlikable and this prevented me from being able to continue on. It was a disappointment.

author: Timo
title: Thankful it's over
body: This book made me miserable, but curiosity kept me reading what felt like hundreds and hundreds of pages.

author: Anne Marie Brun
title: Boring
body: I loved the Harry Potter books. But this book is neither a trilling fantasy, a great detective novel nor a literary masterpiece

author: Geraldine Thalen
title: Which of these people is Rowling?
body: I wasn't expecting Harry Potter.  I was hoping to be lured into a fictional world with real people.  If Rowling thinks the world is peopled with the likes of her characters, I feel very sorry for her.  Yes, we are all flawed.  But the only characters with a modicum of goodness are ridiculed by the narrator for being dumpy and bad dressers, or tightly wound outsiders.  These are the only possibilities for humanity?  The disdain her narrator expresses for these bumbling do-gooders (Kay and Tessa and Parminder) in her descriptions of them reveals to some extent her own attitude.  Why else would the narrator describe them in such negative terms?  Howard Mallinson (ok, she kind of got the name right) is beneath contempt because he is obese?  This is the narrator's perspective.  Yes he is selfish and inconsiderate and a lecher.  Focus on those qualities, not his obesity.  Did Rowling think we could forgive the others but not the obesity?  I just don't understand the malice she carries for less-than-attractive people.

author: Hans van der Meulen
title: Where is Harry?
body: I'm still reading it, when will it ever end? I know it's J.K. Rowling, but where is the suspense, excitement or Lord Voldermort? Please return to Hogwarts once more...

author: Nix
title: Expect nothing familiar
body: Oh this book! I know many people did not like it or perhaps expected something different. Having heard all the hype before reading the book I went into it with an open mind, expecting nothing familiar.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Boring
body: This whole story could have been written in  30 pages, certainly expected better from Ms Rowling. What a depressing cast of characters.

author: UCLA Steve
title: Amazing.  But, started slow and got worse before turning incredible.
body: This is one of the best books I have ever read, although I almost gave up on it for good - twice.  Keep on reading and the story eventually, while admittedly quite dark, ends up turning absolutely brilliant and uplifting.

author: Brooke Davis
title: Review
body: Very interesting. You really get involved with characters, they are so well written. Definitely a page turner, with a sad abrupt ending.

author: Marsha Carry
title: Boring
