American and British humor is very different, especially when it starts to creep into the dark comedy territory. I thought the petty conflict she created to serve as a stage for her characters to come to terms with themselves and each other was brilliant. I would highly recommend this book to those who like character-driven fiction and don't mind a writing style that intermingles comedy with the macabre.

author: MGS
title: Waiting until the next one...
body: Although there were a few droll clever humorous bits, the main flaw in this work is that you don't like any of the characters, nor do you care what happens to them after the first 40 pages. In order to write a biting social commentary, a writer must first make us care about something or someone, and that doesn't happen here. I stopped after the first 50 pages, skipped through and read the final few pages. Unfortunately it ends as dismally as it starts. Perhaps her muse fled after Harry. Too bad she didn't stop with Harry because that series was brilliant, and she needn't have written anything else to have been remembered as a light in literature. For real insight into contemporary Britain, read the Adrian Mole series. It isn't really for kids...

author: BigSister
title: A Lot of Work to Read
body: When I heard Joanne Rowling interviewed as this book was coming out, I was absolutely fascinated by her and by her life story.  Finally I read the first of the Potter books, enjoyed it, and could see why the concept and series of books would be such a hit among so many, young and older.  I made sure to see the movie based on that first book, as well.  I was finally in the world millions had entered years earlier.  With that step behind me, I eagerly turned to "The Casual Vacancy."

author: Lorien
title: Incredibly detailed character driven story.
body: This book may fall a little flat on American audiences, so all reviews by US readers need to be looked at a bit carefully to be certain they do not criticize this book for it's extremely English world view.

author: Joseph Doolin
title: Rowling should stick to kids' lit
body: This is really a YA book with some attempt at foul language and adult issues thrown in.  Only got through half of it.

author: Margaret Mitchel
title: Yuck!
body: It's hard to believe that  a writer with Rowlings skill could produce this.  There is not one character that I cared about.  The writing seems to be of a forced intensity.  Save your money.

author: ruxandra pauna
title: Definitely a book worth reading
body: The book depicts life in a small English town and the characters are well portrayed.

author: Catherine Mastrangelo
title: Great reading
body: Nice book with a twist. I enjoyed reading this, and loaned it to my sister for her reading pleasure and enjoyment.

author: Sapphire Guenther
title: J.K. Rowling
body: J.K. Rowling is one of my all time favorite authors, and is high up on the pedestal next to Edgar Allen Poe and J.R.R. Tolkien. This new book of hers is definitely an adult book, but nothing to graphic at all! It's an interesting read.

author: Isral Debruin
title: Fascinatingly tragic character study
body: I thoroughly enjoyed reading this well-written character-driven book about the politics and difficulties of living in a community. Rowling's engaging and witty writing style and her ability to flesh out characters in every way make this a fascinating read. My favorite aspect of this story was how many angles of the narrative are explored. The reader is provided with enough information and vantage points to carefully turn over and examine each of the many primary characters, their thoughts and motivations. Throughout reading this book, I found my internal opinions and suspicious about characters shifting back and forth. I liked this aspect a lot, though I'll admit that it was sometimes challenging to not have a true MAIN character to mentally hold on to. Still, this is exactly what made this book so interesting.

author: Jamie A. Scott
title: Harry Potter
body: It's no Harry Potter, but JK Rowling is a gifted writer and if you enjoyed her work on the Potter series, it's not a bad read

author: C. Grennes
title: Wanted to like it, but didn't
body: Honestly I just really didn't like this book. It was slow, soo long, and had way too many characters to keep track of . I quit halfway through, which I almost never do.

author: Sybille Schaufler
title: The Casual Vacancy - a disappointment
body: Most boring book I've read in a long time. The foul language was no redeemer. I think J.K. should stick to Children's/young adult books.

author: Scott Michels
title: This Ain't Your Kids' Harry Potter
body: I first discovered my love for reading through Harry Potter, and JK Rowling has reignited my passion with The Casual Vacancy! Other critics were upset with how many different characters there are in this novel, but if you stick with it she will rotate in between the same characters over and over until it becomes easy to remember who is who.

author: L. Kelley
title: The Casual Vacancy by JK Rowling
body: I am still reading and I wonder why.  It is like a soap opera.  I can't seem to put it down because I feel there must be something that is going to happen but it's a long time coming.

author: Writergirl
title: Excellent writing but story is perhaps too 'real'
body: Rowling has done an outstanding job in creating a multitude of characters that all have their own passions, ideas, hurts, idiosyncracies and agendas.  In other multi-protagonist novels I have read, usually only one or two characters really get developed and the rest are filler.  Rowling has not created a single character that she doesn't know intimately.

author: Kindle lover
title: Great Character development
body: I really felt like I knew the characters and needed to know what happened to them. It was Thoroughly enjoyable

author: Anonymous
title: So terrible!
body: A waste of money.  Hate to admit I paid $18.99 for this book on my Kindle.  I wanted to like this book because Rowling wrote it and I loved Harry Potter, but can't say that.  Could not get past the 1st 15 pages, so much explicit details on things that don't really need to be in detail.  I think that she tried to be like Fifty Shades of Gray, but in a political sense.  Failure on all counts.

author: Dolly
title: She should have stuck to young adult fiction.
body: Having loved the Harry Potter books, I was curious to see what Ms. Rowling would do with a more adult book. My conclusion... stick to what you're good at. This book drug on and on. Not a single character was truly sympathetic, probably because every character was sketched so thinly, with no depth or variety. I like stories with flawed characters. But the inhabitants of Pagford and Yarvil were so two-dimensional with their flaws that even the attempt to redeem a few of them at the end seemed contrived.

author: bingleyfam2
title: Duh
body: I have never actually read the book. But a friend of mine did, and she says that it was sad and stuff, but what J.K. Rowling was trying to portray is LIFE. News flash,not all books have unicorns ans rainbows and happy things as the theme. No, life does not either. And for all of you who are complaining about this not being the next Harry Potter, think about this. Would you give The Hunger Games a one star review just because it is not the next Gregor the Overlander? I don't think so. Seriously people. Think before you speak. Wow.

author: Bridget Stanley
title: Very easy reading
body: I really enjoyed this book. Was very addictive. Not sure about the ending though as it kind of left you hanging

author: C. Cook
title: Couldn't get into it
body: My book club read this. I never finished it.  Just too complicated for someone who doesn't have a lot of time at one sitting to read.  With only short opportunities to read I found I had to keep rereading where I left off to get back into it. I made very little progress this way and eventually gave up.

author: Nicole
title: Very very different than what I expected but I loved it
body: This was so very different and not at all what I expected. I loved that JKR decided to write about this side of life that never gets written about in this way. It was a story with lots of characters that I had to keep track of but when I worked them all out I found it really great. Different, unexpected, definitely worth a read and I applaud JKR fearlessness at publishing this.

author: charliemum
title: Would not recommend!
body: Lower class English town with lower class people.  Did not like the book.  Would not recommend and am suprised by this author writing such trash.

author: DailyReader
title: Like Watching a Train Wreck
body: This book has many characters.  Maybe too many.  It's full of people that are either horrible or pathetic.  Part of the reason I continued with the book is because of Tom Hollander's reading performance.  Other than that none of the people in the plot have any reason to care about them.  Or the story, which wasn't much.  It ends in a not at all surprising way.

author: Laura M. Sever
title: Very good book
body: It was very engrossing, but I liked another reviewer's comment that what happened to the characters would have happened to Harry Potter had he not had a protector.  I bought it on audio book and found myself thinking (and talking occasionally, but just to myself), in an English accent.

author: Ana
title: Awesome
body: This book took awhile to ship, but not an outrageous amount of time.  The book was almost like new, just a few marks on the cover.  I am extremely impressed with the price and quality.

author: sf mommy 99
title: Boring and tedious
body: This really pains me to write a bad review for the book, because (1) I LOVE JK Rowling's writing and (2) I'm a total Anglophile and am actually interested in this stuff.  But wow what a boring and dreary and tedious book.  The funny bits aren't funny.  The 'deep' bits are predictable.  The 'shocking' bits are gratuitous.  I tried both reading the book in hardcover (I was so excited!) and listening to it from Audible.  Neither method was enough to get me past Chapter 8.  If it wasn't JK, I would have given up long before that. I hope her next book is a big improvement (that one, I'll probably get from the library...).

author: Mary
title: Depressing
body: I found this book dark and depressing.

author: pl11
title: a boring book
body: I read about 40% of the book, and it was plain boring.  There are lots of characters, they do various things, and all this does not connect to a single plot.  Maybe the book would be more interesting later, but I don't want to waste hours reading a boring stuff.

author: skoulo
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Dark and depressing. If you're looking for the characters and magic of the Harry Potter books, you will not find it here.

author: Patricia Forster
title: Wriitng for an adult audience is not Rowlings strength
body: Very gossipy and light. Facets that are good though are that the book does highlight child neglect, and the inability or difficulty some have in raising themselves from rock bottom in society, and societies neglect of these people.

author: Janet Chiappini
title: Not a bad book.
body: A bit of a slow starter, but by the end of the book, you are totally committed.  Totally unlike Rowling's other books, you will enjoy getting to know these family's and finally understand why they are what they are.

author: Amazon Customer
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Good read but very slow in the beginning. The ending was not what I expected three were a lot of jaw dropping moments but all and all good read

author: Izzy
title: Great
body: The book was great quality, it was sent within the alloted time, and it was a good read. I liked it.

author: L.Lacy
title: Intriguing yet depressing
body: The book has very well developed characters, but they are all flawed.  The whole town is just a big mess and the untold.heroine  never realizes it.  The book will capture your attention but it is sort of like watching a train wreck.

author: lisa
title: hmmm
body: i wasn't entirely sure what to expect, but i wasn't too impressed with this book. i read it a month ago and barely remember the plot. it passes time, that is all.

author: Jaye Davis
title: The Casual Bore
body: I guess after reading the Harry Potter series, I expected this to be online entertaining wise. I expected too much. The permise of the book was okay but it dragged on waaaay too long. I also think more people thought it was to be a MORE adult theme but it wasn't. This book would have been okay for teens to read but I think even they would have been bored after a few chapters. I sincerely hope this is not the kind of thing she will write in the future. She definitely needs more pazzaz!

author: Karolina
title: Disappointment!
body: I read all the Harry Potter books and had really high hopes for this one. I read maybe about 150 pages and had to put it down. First book in years that I couldn't finish.

author: Amazon Customer
title: not expected from JKRowling
body: This book doesn't look like it comes from the author of Harry Potter series. Too much bitching and nonsense. avoid this book.

author: Travel the road
title: Weird ending
body: Liked the book, but had many characters to follow.  Also, the ending was odd.  I felt no resolution after the last page....the primary question of the book was nOt answered.  Did the clinic stay open or not?

author: Edith Robinson
title: Wished I Had My Money Back
body: The content was of no interest to me, I found myself thinking "I couldn't care less about these people" ! I read approximately one-quarter of the novel closed it and never looked back. What a waste of time and money!

author: Virgie Alexander
title: A real disappointment
body: Characters and their relationships were really hard to keep track of.  Rowling jumps between using nicknames and given names for characters and their relationship to one another isn't clear until at least mid-way through the book.  Lots of hate among characters and the closest thing to a "good guy" in the plot dies at the end!

author: Elizabeth J. Lawson
title: Horrible characters!
body: How could JK Rowling bear to write about so many revolting people with so few, if any, redeeming features? I could hardly manage to cope with reading about them!

author: J. Mitchell
title: Different from HP books, but still the same
body: I found the format of the book consistent with the HP books, in that you had numerous characters organized into families, just as you had the different Hogwarts groups.  I thought the number of characters would be overwhelming, but a few chapters in, and I knew them all by name and character.  I have to say I loved the book and finished it at 4:00 am.  The character's quirks, flaws (some quite serious)and foibles rang so true to me. Who doesn't know the poor girl who married well and tries to over-compensate?  Who doesn't know someone handicapped to some extent by mental illness, and trying so hard to hide it? And how about the married women who are searching for their own identity and also for that spark they feel is missing from their lives?  The teen-agers are as confused, curious, mean-spirited and kind by turns as teen-aged children sometimes tend to be.  I was surprised to learn via this site that the book was supposed to be humorous.  Like most reviewers, I realy didn't see that aspect.  The ending was a surprise.  That's quite a statement for a serious reader to make.  It's a long book, more character study than action, but very rewarding.  I recommend.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Expected more, disappointed
body: The antics of the shallow, unsympathetic and dismissable chartacters in this book just lurch along, with little ultimate redemption. The only interesting character in the book was the deceased main character, who may only have been interesting because he had no boring, shapeless inner monologue. Much of the book was painful to read, but not in a way that enhanced understanding of your fellow man. It just made me thankful that I do not live in a small town in England, perhaps.

author: Jamilah
title: Good but a little more disturbing than I expected
body: I really enjoyed reading this book but probably would not have chosen it if I knew there would be disturbing scenes with children.

author: Avid Reader
title: Casual Vacancy
body: J K Rawlings has a special talent for storytelling that has brought readers, young and old, back to reading.  Her talent is so precious that I loathe to see her demean herself by writing such trash.  Many times I was tempted to discard the book but, because I'm not a quiter, perservered to the end.

author: Summerroll
title: Worthwhile, Truthful Portrayal of Humanity
body: This novel suffers from comparison to the Harry Potter series, only because HP succeeded on such a stratospheric level.  HP had the advantage of a slow crescendo, the patient accumulation of characters and plot lines, the unique relationship of author to readers that saw growth of the characters parallel to real time.

author: Tlkmaui
title: First JK Rowling book I have read
body: Not a Harry Potter maniac it I did like this story.  It drags at times but overall was a good solid read.  Interesting characters and several story lines kept my interest .  give it a try

author: Shelley
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Really enjoyed the style of writing. The characters were either ones you knew well or could easily imagine. Such flawed characters! Very readable. A lttle disturbing at times. Thought provoking.

author: LP
title: Rubbish
body: JK Rowling is not a good writer. With Harry Potter, it doesn't matter as the story she has created is so wonderful. This book's storyline is poor, which makes the overly descriptive and childish style of writing unbearable.

author: Thomas Worthy
title: Really Disappointed
body: I was a big fan of the Harry Potter series.  I was looking forward to this book when it was announced.  However, I have to say it was a real dud.  I finished the book, but when I closed it, I asked myself what was the point?  The only decent person in the city of Pagford died in the first few pages!!  If this is Rowling's outlook on life, I find that very sad.  To say that people are so selfish is disturbing.  Everyone is only looking out for themselves!!  It is a real twisted look on "reality".  Some of the reviews called this real life.  I have to say I disagree.  This is definitely not the life I know.  Maybe you have to be English to understand.

author: Kirstie
title: I liked it!
body: This book starts off slow, but by the end you're invested in the characters.  It's rewarding if you stick with it.

author: Naomi toohey
title: Politics in Village Life
body: I am perhaps one of the few people in the world never to have read J K Rowlings Harry Potter books.

author: Gabby
title: Honestly I've tried reading it but there's so many characters ...
body: Honestly I've tried reading it but there's so many characters too keep up with. I can't seem to get into it.

author: IsisBaast
title: Big Fan of Harry Potter, But Not This
body: I waded through the first 200 pages, being introduced to the numerous characters in the book and how they related to each other. It was slow, but a doctor (who I was seeing) saw I was reading it, and commented to me that it did get much better further into the book. So I muddled my way through the next 300 pages plus. It did get better, about the last 1/3 of the book really picked up the pace. But, I still can't say I liked it; mainly because the characters are so unlikeable. With the exception of the teenagers, the adults are basically self-absorbed, petty people with one father being an abusive bully. The poor children have to grow up with these people as parents. A friend of mine said that reading this book must be comparable to a homework assignment, and yes that is how I felt as I struggled through its 503 pages.

author: Krizten
title: Not the worst thing I've ever read...
body: This book wasn't horrible, but it was a little much for me. I'm no prude, but even this was a little bit..strong, I guess you could say. I did read the Harry Potter series, and that has probably influenced my review more than I am consciously aware of. The book wasn't bad for a first attempt at something so different, but it seems like she was trying too hard to step out of Harry Potter world and into the adult fiction one. I also feel like the book switches back and forth between characters far too much; it was honestly a bit mind blowing. All in all, not a bad book, but definitely not one that I'll read again and again as I do with most books.

author: Judith Chamberlain
title: An Angry JK Rowling
body: I thought this was an interesting but surprisingly angry or even bitter book. I suspect that some of the anger came from her own experiences as a child. The story was good but there were times I found myself pushing on, hoping it would go somewhere. I was not expecting a grown-up Harry Potter, but I don't think this was what I expected either.

author: Erin
title: Oh JK.
body: I got this for someone durning the Christmas season, they claim they can't read very much of it, and still haven't finished the book yet.  Being a massive Harry Potter fan, I thought the writing would still have the same pull, but I guess it didn't.  Makes me a little sad, but I'm sure she will jump back.

author: Ruth B.
title: not finished - struggling
body: started reading this and gave up a couple of chapters in. Will probably go back and finish at some stage

author: happybuyer
title: Casual Vacancy
body: I bought it because I grew up with and love Harry Potter dearly. This book was well written, but a little too sexual and grungy for my taste. Would not recommend for readers under 16 or 17. The large cast of characters were a little hard to keep track of at first, so I had to read the first few chapters twice before proceeding. Well written, gripping story with the highly developed characters JKR is so skilled at creating.

author: Margaret Gall
title: Definitely up to standard
body: I approached this book with trepidation even though I loved the Harry Potter books. I guess I expected a grown up version of those stories. It was, however, a truly good read. Completely different....very adult..but still consistent with JK Rowling's previous writing style. Very good

author: Joan G.
title: Casual Vacancy
body: This book was very different than the Harry Potter books.  But I enjoyed it.  It was more adult in reading.

author: pwes67
title: Ok
body: It took me a long time to even become interested in this book.  It is better now and the story is interesting and believable but I cannot say I have a character I have connected with.

author: sfirrito
title: Didnt like this one.
body: Could not get into this. Very confusing at the beginning, middle and then it becomes abit clearer at the end, if you make it that far.

author: Sean P. Endress
title: "The books that the world calls immoral are the books that show the world its own shame." - Oscar Wilde
body: Rowling's "The Casual Vacancy" is, in some way, indeed aimed at her prior audience. The children that grew up with Harry and company are now in their early twenties, the demographic which this reviewer believes will have the most interest in this work.

author: Elspeth A. Nickerson
title: Divisions of class tear an English town apart
body: Didn't like the copious swear words, and Rowling didn't seem to like her characters very much - was quite disappointed.

author: Barbara M. Molinari
title: I did no enjoy reading this book
body: While the book is well written, the story is abysmal.  There is no joy in it at all.  Every character seems despicable in some way.

author: Sandra Goss Lucas
title: No value to this book
body: There is no redeeming value to this book.  Every character, every family was dysfunctional and pathological.  There was little plot and little character development.  I was very disappointed in this book.

author: Barb OC in CT
title: She should stick to fantasy.
body: If I hadn't enjoyed the Harry Potter series, I might have been less critical of this book.  I didn't find any reason to care about the characters, nor did I find the story engaging.

author: Lamond Harrison
title: filthy
body: Sorry I was looking for a book written for adults not an "adult" book.  In the first few chapters she described juvenile female anatomy, Love affairs, and masturbation.  That is when I stopped reading.  It is a shame that adult means written porn.

author: Bad Cat!
title: Sorry That I  Bought It.
body: As big a fan as I am of J K Rowling's Harry Potter books, I hate to say how much I did not enjoy "Casual Vacancy."  I knew it was written for adults, not children, but adults were some of the Harry Potter series' biggest fans, so I didn't know how different this book would be.  "Casual Vacancy" just made me miss the Harry Potter characters more.  I quit this book in the middle, which is something that I never do.  "Casual Vacancy"  was just a disappointment, so depressing an attempt to seem to be clever.  I'm sorry that I bought this book.

author: kenneth dominey
title: Casual ?
body: Not a great deal to say of this book very lighthearted and easy reading not something I would buy in the bookshop...............

author: Sara J. Hunt
title: Very disappointed...
body: What a let down.  So difficult to read and understand for someone from the States.  The terms used were totally unfamiliar to me.  I am an avid reader and the value of this book remains a mystery.

author: Lisa W. Lippert
title: I was moved to tears
body: Apparently JK Rowling said she didn't want to talk to anyone that didn't cry at the end of this book- I'm in! I loved and loathed these characters. I think Rowling was gutsy and I loved the way she was driven to write this and not care what is said about it- if that true. I wonder how many of JK Rowling's  readers would see the book differently if she had used a pen name. I'm glad to live at a time when she is producing, I look forward with anticipation to her next undertaking.

author: waitoki
title: casual Vacancy
body: First book that I have read from this author, no Harry's for me.

author: Pen Name
title: Boring
body: Couldn't get into the book, thought it was hard to follow. Although maybe that's since I took such long breaks between reading. Nothin like the HP, so if up didn't like that maybe you'll be interested in this, but to me it wasn't even the same writing style.

author: Sam S Surprise
title: Sad world, sad characters
body: First, I found the story line fractious, and difficult without a central narrator. And second, every person lacked any redempted qualities except the dead guy, and in the ending was just as unsatisfying. I felt like someone asked Rowling to try an adult book and was obligated but not committed.

author: William S Jamison
title: Geroff me
body: Okay. Well, this was interesting. Not Harry Potter of course though I noticed a few phrases that were reminiscent. "Geroff me" for example. There is an interesting interplay between the youth and the adults too. As usual the youth out smart their elders. Some magic involved too - though computers this time instead of wands, but this still means ghosts speak to the living. It seems we still get the same mix of kids too. Fats instead of Big D. Kids lie that they have strange diseases that scared people away from them. Kids break lots of rules. They moon other teams and win medals for it. But there is much more drinking and many more words that could not have been appropriate in the HP books - at least up until 7. But I agree with two of the three main phrases in the reviews gathered so far that:

author: SM
title: Wonderful Book about Real People - Do Not Expect Harry Potter
body: I'm a huge Harry Potter fan, but was ready for this book to be nothing like it.  One thing that is consistent is JK Rowling's beautiful writing, ability to weave a complex story and insight into human nature.  Unlike Harry, The Casual Vacancy is about as close to reality as one could hope in a work of fiction.  Be ready, this book has swearing, sex and ugliness, but not without purpose.  Superficially, the book is about the vacuum left in the townspeople's lives when a relatively young town councillor suddenly dies.  More profoundly, the book is about how people affect one another, sometimes for good, sometimes for bad.  Many of the scenes are painfully sad because they are so honest.  But I did not find this book entirely depressing.  I found it inspiring in that it made me appreciate the good in my life, reaffirming how important it is for each one of us to notice one another and try to care as best we can.

author: Suzanne Levy
title: Good read...
body: Very well written and made me smile...good characters and overall very much worth the effort.  I definitely recommend this book.

author: Kermit1207
title: A great book for adults
body: This book is interesting although it is not Harry Potter.  I purchased it because I wanted to see what else J.K. Rowling could do with her writing.  I was not disappointed.  It has a great story line and keeps you wondering where it will turn next.

author: Louella Terry
title: If you liked Harry Potter this book is not for you!
body: I can't believe this book was written by the same person who gave the world Harry Potter!  It was so bad I could not finish it.  I was confused by the constant change of POV and the poorly written dialogue. I found it difficult to connect with any character because she was on to different one so quickly.

author: My Prozacmoment
title: A waste of time and money
body: I was so looking forward to this book.  I loved the Harry Potter series so when my book club chose it as a group read I was thrilled.  After so many of us couldn't even choke through half of it.  It was cancelled as the club read.  That's how bad it is.  Long drawn out chapters, written in great boring detail. And I do mean great boring detail.  For instance, do we really need to know how a toddlers turd sounds when it hits the toilet water?  Because she actually described it. The author goes on and on about characters she can't make the reader care about. The plot is set in the very first couple of pages, with a death.  After that you spend the rest of your time waiting for what you hope will be the real plot, but it never happens.  Really she could have just written.  So and So died.....the end.  I gave it one star only because I couldn't give it a minus star rating.  This book was in a word.  Disappointing.

author: Elaine S. Hambly
title: Thought Provoking Coming of Age for both young adult and adult
body: Thoughtful, sensitive, realistic and insightful. A portrayal of reality behind closed doors. Excellent. If the reader is not British they might need to look up several slang terms peculiar to the British.

author: Alan C. Zumwalt
title: Slow
body: I used this book to get me to sleep.  It had a lot of characters, who didn't do very much.  I couldn't finish it.

author: Mary C.
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: The Casual Vacancy is an excellent book--well-written, featuring a host of masterfully developed characters and skillfully interwoven strands of plot.  It's also depressing as hell!  Few of the characters are likable--at first.  Yet one wants to keep reading.  As the strands continue to intersect and the characters from these strands interact, the story becomes increasingly engrossing--and almost every detail mentioned once ultimately plays a part in the outcome.  By the end, the reader is sympathizing with quite a few characters, happy for a few and even grieving for some.  All this, because a member of the parish council in an idyllic English village was too busy to see a doctor about his headaches!

author: Jennifer C. Parris
title: Great Read
body: I've never read the Harry Potter series but was very interested in reading this book as I knew it would be something different.  It started off a little slow for me but once I read further and uncovered more about the different characters and families I was hooked.

author: joan nash
title: Can you enjoy a novel that does not have one character you like or admire?
body: Even the children were nasty, except for Robbie.  This novel felt like it was written by someone who found no goodness in people.  Everyone's flaws were magnified, and their small acts of kindness received little attention.

author: Book Dork
title: A Mess
body: Why you shouldn't waste your time reading The Casual Vacancy by JK Rowling:

author: frances becker frances
title: worth a read
body: having never read harry potter I wasnt sure what to expect, the book is a multi faceted story which was intriguing and appealing.

author: Lucy O'Finner
title: Unwholesome characters but read to the end
body: JKR obviously does not like people.  She has created a plethora of the most unwholesome and unlikable characters who are abused, abusive and dysfunctional.  They lead unhappy lives, wallowing in self-pity, dreaming of revenge, and venting their frustrations and rage on family and friends.  The only two characters who show leadership, warmth and compassion meet untimely deaths.  However petty and sordid, their stories unfold neatly and I was compelled to finish the book to know what happens to everyone.

author: Jennifer Bousfield
title: Not a Harry Potter best seller
body: I felt this book needed harsh editing to make it more readable.  Too many characters with nick names which became confusing and the story much too long before arriving at the catalyst and conclusion.

author: MJ90
title: Mixed Feelings
body: I have mixed feelings about The Casual Vacancy. I didn't really get into the novel until almost halfway through. That's about how long it took me to get a firm grasp on all the characters and their relationships. That said, I did become more engrossed once this occurred because it is imperative to understand who all the characters are to fully enjoy the story. It was a struggle to get to this point, however, because the beginning moved so slowly that I had to force myself to continue reading, hoping that eventually things would pick up. And they do, but you just have to get through the strain of the beginning, something many people may not want to do. Overall, the book was OK for me. The beginning was quite a struggle, but by the end, I enjoyed my time with the citizens of Pagford.

author: Mr. L. R. Hollowell
title: Keep Reading
body: Even though well written, the book starts slow. As others have indicated, initially there seems like too many characters and they are difficult to keep separated. But as the story develops the characters being to remind you of people you know and eventually I found myself caring about even some of the more despicable individuals in the book, and hoping thing will eventually turn out well for them. Rowlings is a great story teller and she has effectively proven she is not limited to just one genre.

author: susan b
title: A fun, light read
body: A well-developed story, a quick read, and an interesting look into everyday life in a small England town. On the other hand, the characters really didn't have too much depth or dimension, but were simply 'types'. Not destined to be a classic by any means, but an enjoyable read overall.

author: Natalie
title: Not great
body: This book was ok - not fantastic. I was prepared for a different experience than Rowling's previous works, but was not 'wow-ed' by her writing. The plot was still interesting enough.

author: Dr. Cook
title: Unsympathetic characters make it hard to care
body: I looked forward to this book having loved the Hary Potter books. Unfortunately Ms Rowling has created such unsympatheti, small minded, mean , drug addicted people to populate her two feuding towns that she makes the reader wish a great flood would drown the lot. A bit more sunshine please in you next endeavor. Thanks!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Different from Harry Potter, but enjoyable all the same
body: This is much different from her Harry Potter books, although some of the themes are the same--i.e., troubled but essentially innocent children in a world of ill-intentioned or misguided adults, with the exception of Barry, who seems to be a Harry Potter of sorts, but unfortunately, died at the outset, which set events in motion.  I think anyone who likes serious literature, can deal with gray instead of black and white, and is prepared for something different from Harry Potter will enjoy this book.

author: Jan Francke
title: Kudos to J.K. Rowling
body: I think J.K. Rowling really deserves a huge amount of respect for being brave enough to break with her past in such a dramatic way.  Few books have an original idea and this one does.  Well written and concise.

author: ccoy3
title: Very good read
body: Not your Harry Potter!! Very good and interesting read. Keeps you turning pages to the very end.  I really enjoyed this book.

author: Gavnook
title: This is NOT  Harry Potter
body: Rowling  has given us a clear, insider's view of a collection of families living in a small West England town.  A single event has a different effect on each family and all their disfunctions come into play  while respondinrg to this singular event.

author: CH
title: J.K. Rowling: an excellent author
body: I'm still not sure if I liked this book or not. It talks about real life, which in my case isn't the type of book I'd love (and I bet it happens to a lot of Harry Potter fans, like me, who would prefer fantasy stories).

author: Penny Hawkins
title: Poor reading don't buy
body: Miss Rowlings attempt at an adult reading was very poor. I would not buy another one of her books. Bad choice

author: Sharon Moyer
title: Hard to put down book
body: The product arrived in a timely fashion and the more I read this book the more I discovered that it was one of those books that's hard to put down once you start reading it. I believe that J. K. Rowling did well in this writing of her first adult novel.

author: Marguerite Chipp Matthews
title: Watching ordinary people can teach us extraordinary lessons about ourselfes
body: If J.K. Rowling continues in the style she has established in The Casual Vacancy, lovers of Barbara Pym and Jane Austen have a new, and living, writer to read.  I had no interest in this book based on many of the reviews. Although I know Rowling is a craftsmanlike writer, H.P. was never my cup of tea. Then,  somewhere, I read that this book is about ordinary people. Having finished it today, I cannot wait for her next book. Finally a still living author who writes un-bombastic, intricately crafted, tales of how people of all classes live their daily lives. She understands children, teens, adults, the elderly. Rowling is such a marvelous student of human nature in all of its glory and shame. Again I must compare her to Jane Austen in both the intricacy of her plot and the basic simplicty of her characters, many of whom, sadly, never seem to get the lessons Rowling clearly understands. Can't wait for her next one!

author: Allie
title: A Guilty Pleasure
body: Any reader who buys this book in the hope that it will be Harry Potter for grown-ups is in for a disappointment. Turning her back on the realms of magical possibilities JK Rowling sets out to prove that she can write about the actual world in all its gritty authenticity. Pagford is about as far from Hogwarts as it is possible to get; Rowling wastes no opportunity to describe all that is seamy about provincial life with its petty politics and parochialism, crime and grime; the mundane and the inane of small-town England. From a protracted flight of inspired fancy her imagination has plummeted to the slimy underbelly of life.

author: Chris
title: just wanted to see what her style of writing is beyond Harry Potter
body: The story kept my interest. The characters were interesting people. It's not exactly a blockbuster storyline, but it was ok.

author: June Hyjek
title: Very Disappointing
body: Having read all the Harry Potter books and loved the way Rowling created an incredibly fantastic world with such richly developed characters, I was considerably disappointed in Casual Vacancy.  The characters were boring and 20 pages in I was tired of what seemed to be the plot, although I really couldn't get a handle on why is was worthy of being called a plot.  I tried to read it from the beginning several times, but just couldn't get through it.  Tried to tag sale it and wasn't surprised when no one wanted it.  Not worth the space on my kindle.

author: terri arsenault
title: Unmoving
body: I believe the author should stick to wizardy.This story was difficult to follow and somewhat confusing as to the need of really to story lines. I would not recommend to anyone.

author: Amazon Customer
title: good story telling
body: The ending was a bit abrupt and predictable. There was many things aboutthe book I liked but it just didn't quite come together for me.

author: Pat Godley
title: quite a change from the Harry Potter
body: Living in England for years I was smiling as she described life in a small village really delighted in the scenery . I was saddened by the reality of the all that she wrote about ; poverty drugs relationships etc.

author: Cynthia Winford
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I  was disappointed with J.K.Rowling's adult novel.  She should stick with Harry Potter or choose another character with magical charms.

author: K. Dean Driver
title: What's the point?
body: I had only read the first Harry Potter book and, though I'm not into the fantasy genre, found it well written and engaging.  I was surprised to hear about the subject matter of The Causal Vacancy - it sounded like an impossibly boring idea for a novel, but I figured that an author of Rowling's stature might be able to twist it into something interesting.  I was wrong. I read about 1/3 of the book before I gave up, never having connected with any of the characters.  I really didn't care who lived and died, or if the low-rent tract of land went to this town or that.  Other reviewers say this was an in-depth study of human emotion and relationships, but I never ran across that aspect of it.  Try again, Ms. Rowling, and this time choose a more interesting concept, and populate it with at least one character with depth.

author: Barb Freeman
title: The Casual Vacancy was a 'must read' after reading Harry Potter!
body: I have read all of the Harry Potter series and I loved them. They were very well written and crafted, drew the reader into the story and were difficult to put down. "The Casual Vacancy" was also well crafted by J K Rowling but the writing was too organised! It did not 'ring true' at times and therefore did not 'grab' me! I finished reading the book but I felt the writing did not reflect the spontaneity of that in J K Rowling's previous books.

author: ChristieLee
title: Definitely NOT a Harry Potter story
body: If you are looking for another story in the style of Harry Potter, look elsewhere. This is a very adult title about a small town in England, complete with all of the small town politics, backstabbing, and pettiness. It is not a light hearted novel, and the good guys don't necessarily win.

author: Mangoman
title: Makes me think Rowling had a ghost writer for HP
body: Let me start by saying I only read 100 pages - but that was enough to convince me that there were way too many characters, they were all boring, and it would be hard to imagine a duller plot!!  If there is such a thing as too much character development, or too much detail - it exists in this book.  There is nothing that makes the reader want to turn the next page - except the belief that surely, soon that marvelous Rowling wit must make an appearance.  But it didn't - at least not in the first 100 pages.

author: bboop
title: A Disappointment
body: With all the raves about the Harry Potter books, I thought this would be a good choice for me.  Wrong.

author: L. W.
title: Worst book ever
body: I loved J.K.'s Harry Potter books so I bought this one when it came out.  BIG mistace, she should go back to Harry Potter!!  It is beyond stupid, boring and I could go on.  The characters are pathetic.  I read the first 5 chapters hoping it was going to get better, then I skimmed the rest of it and quit.  The only thing this book is good for is starting a fire in the fireplace!!!  I am really dissapointed especially since it cost so much!  It's not worth the paper it's written on.  J.K. I want my money back!!!

author: val wilkins
title: Great character development
body: I was curious to read an adult Rowling book and really enjoyed it.  Her depth of character development and description is really well done.  She creates so many emotions in the gradual insights into the main people in the story. I will read more of her work.

author: Tucker Girl
title: Took a while to figue out all the characters
body: This book is very dark. The beginning is confusing trying to figure out all the characters. At the half way point I started to get into the story.  Not a happy book, for sure.

author: K. Erickson
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: The book arrived on time, well wrapped and in very good condition. The Casual Vacancy is a very well written book with lots of turns and twists! I would expect nothing less of J.K. Rowlings after the Harry Potter books.

author: Jeanne M
title: Couldn't force myself to finish it
body: I got almost half way through and just couldn't force myself to continue reading.  Not only was it not engaging me, the story just was boring in my opinion. It wasn't just the political nature of the book that turned me off, it just seemed to not have a clear plot--rather lots of reactions to one person's death and nothing compelling to keep me interested about the dead person and things people were discovering after his death.  Maybe if I had kept reading, but I felt like I had given up too much time without feeling engaged in the book at all.  If Rowling hadn't written it I would have given up far sooner (I didn't expect or want another Harry Potter-type book), but I have such respect for her past writing that I keep reading expecting the story to develop and it never did.

author: Sherri Jackson
title: Love
body: If came pretty fast

author: mahjongg maven
title: Not for me book.
body: I did not like this book, totally dysfunctional town of losers.  Do not enjoy 4 letter words constantly being used.  Story line difficult to follow.

author: Alyssa Keys
title: Interesting and captivating
body: While not at all like the Harry Potter novels, this book provided a good story and kept me in suspense.  I found myself anxious to keep reading about the continued drama in the little town of Pagford and to follow the emotions and decisions of its inhabitants.  Our book club is reading the book this month, and I have been excited to talk to the other members about the story!

author: David P inman Jr
title: Casual Vacancy
body: Couldn't get past the first few boring chapters. My wife will have a go at it next and tell me if I didn't give it a fair chance.

author: Judith L. Sigman
title: The actual vacancy by J K Rowling
body: This book had way too much profanity and sexual content in it

author: Lawrence Moss
title: A CHANGE FROM HARRY POTTER!
body: I was rather disappointed. I thought it was slow in getting off the ground and there was far too much

author: Random Guy
title: I think it's just something she wanted to get out of her system.
body: By far not my favorite book. It was a laborious read. Although I admire and adore the Harry Potter series, I hate to down-play a work of the famous, talented and highly acclaimed J. K. Rowling. I feel that this book wasn't worth my time for other than to satisfy my curiosity as to what else might be in her head. I hope there's more.

author: Rosalind Kelly
title: Casual vacancy
body: I struggled to finish. Found that there was too many characters . Had to write down the pairings and who was friendly with who. A complicated story.

author: SuperJR
title: Rowling scores big, again
body: If you read this book expecting Harry Potter then of course you will be disappointed.  If, on the other hand, you approach this book without preconceptions, misconceptions or expectations of wizardry then you will be rewarded handsomely with a superbly plotted, dramatic, humorous, insightful, rude, lewd and ribald tale.  This book is full of extremely memorable characters, some lovable, others despicable and detestable.  This is a tale of love, hatred, bigotry and redemption; there are wonderfully inventive and evocative descriptions of lusty sex; there are many laugh-out-loud moments, and also teary moments.  As with her Potter books, Rowling gives us huge amounts of detail and back story, and, as with Potter, all elements are deftly and skilfully woven together at the end so that everything makes sense.  The last chapters, where seemingly everyone's lives unravel in one way or another, are a tour de force that had me gasping in amazement at the skill of the author.

author: L. Rodriguez-knowle
title: Unsatisfied Reader
body: I usually don't hate a lot of books but, this is one that I really disliked. I found no redeeming value in this book.

author: Alistair Blunt
title: The underbelly of the rural idyll
body: Grunge and gloom is the predominant mood of this book. I would have liked to give it 3.5 stars for its between OK and quite enjoyable but not a great book, with the JK Rowling straining the bounds of credibility at times. This community has problems. Almost all of them are either abused or in unhappy marriages or neurotic. Those that are not are self satisfied prigs. Not a nice community! But it does just about succeed in keeping one's attention and giving the reader a desire to know what happens next, which is the art of a good storyteller. Worth a read but don't expect too much.

author: Iris E. Cantlon
title: Novel
body: I was so disappointed.Perhaps I was expecting too much after Harry Potter but I really could have done without all of the details of teenage lust.

author: grey_elf
title: The Casual Vacancy - UGH!
body: The Casual Vacancy...what can I say...Ugh! First of all I will say that this book is not the genre' I like to read, i.e. Harry Potter. Having said that, it should not be compared to Rowling's Harry Potter series as it is NOT Fantasy fiction. What it is, however, is painful to read. To me, it was a pointless, somewhat boring, meandering book full of mean-spirited, unhappy, characters with few or no redeeming qualities. Wading through the characters' constant gratuitous spewing of profanity was an assault on the eyes. I blame the publisher's greed to capitalize on the Harry Potter success for this less than inspiring work by an excellent author. JK Rowling certainly deserved better from both her editors and her publisher.

author: Messenger
title: Casual Vacancy
body: Bought it for my husband because he is such a Potter fan, but he didn't like it. He stopped reading it. I'll read it myself, but haven't had the time.

author: Chris
title: Charming but ultimately disappointing
body: First of all, I absolutely loved Rowling's writing style in the book.  Her storytelling is fabulous and I was completely charmed.  The book moves at the glacial pace that small towns typically do and I enjoyed that.  The characters were all facinating in their own unique ways.  Yes many were cliches but aren't we all cliches when it comes down to it.  My biggest complaint was the ending.  THERE WASN'T ONE!  It felt like she got to a deadline and simply stopped. Instead we are left with a deeply depressing ending with nothing learned and nothing gained by any of the central characters.  So I spent many enjoyable hours meandering through this small town but ultimately what was the point?  Sorry JK but I need a little more.  I don't need a happy ending but I need to feel like there is an actual point to a story like this.

author: barbara jennings
title: Thought Provoking Read
body: Very different from what was expected, many complex characters and reminiscent of the darkly psychological writing style of Elizabeth George.

author: Megan Prokes
title: Compelling read
body: Having read all of Rowling's Harry Potter books numerous times, I wasn't see what to expect from "A Casual Vacancy". However, it grabbed my attention from the first page and kept me thinking about all the characters straight to the end. A really great read!

author: G. Hutson
title: Bleak story, raw characters, yet admirable, if not fascinating
body: I received this as a gift from my wish list. Although I am an enormous fan of Rowling's Harry Potter series (my all-time favorite books), I did not enter into reading (listening to) this book expecting it to be in the same tone as the Harry Potter series, or with the same mass appeal. I assumed, correctly, that Rowling would go to great lengths to present herself as an entirely different sort of writer, one with breadth and flexibility, and not aiming to please a large audience. I think she accomplished that in spades with this novel. It seems clear she only wished to tell a story in her own way, about her own point of view on human nature, and without any regrets.

author: Kyle G. Pearson
title: Depressing
body: I had a hard time finding anyone among the mean, petty, cruel & vindictive people in this book to care about.  I'm still wondering what the point of the book is.  It brings to mind the Pink Floyd lyric "...hanging on in quiet desperation is the English way...".

author: Helen Cope
title: Love.
body: Read it and hate everyone in it except four most unlikely characters. Redemption comes to all, with remorse and revenge mixed in.

author: Noels
title: Casual Vacancy  Oh Yes
body: I was dubious about this book despite being a Harry Potter fan. I wondered if she could keep me glued to the story as she had done in the past. The short answer is yes, I loved it and did not want to put it down. I have recommended it to so many people as people have the misconception the J K can only do childrens stories. Not so

author: Saima
title: High Expectations
body: I had high expectations for this book because I am a huge J.K. Rowling and Harry Potter fan.  However, I was disappointed.  But maybe it is impossible to live up to the precedence that Harry Potter set.  I would have considered it a decent book if it had been written by anyone else, but I expected more from J.K. Rowling.

author: nelsi lopez
title: Rowling's last book
body: Sorry to say, I started it and could not continue, I have it there to read some day.  I will need a notebook to write down every personage because I can follow it better that way.  I didn't like the content, I liked her children's book so much more.  The best writing I ever read,  I'm going to be 61 in May and I am a kid at heart. I love books with a better content.  Sorry J.K.

author: V. Vachula
title: A solid piece of fiction
body: Wow. Such mixed reviews! It seems everyone states whether they've read the Potter series at the top of their review, so I will state that yes, I have read the HP series and yes, I loved it. It's hard to believe this book was written by the same author. So while reading The Casual Vacancy, I forgot about that fact and I truly enjoyed it! As other reviewers have mentioned, there are a LOT of characters. But you do get to know them and I found them to be very interesting. People are funny. Some reviews said how shallow the characters were, but I found them to be just the opposite. Her characters are deep and well written. If you find the characters dull, then you will not like this book. The characters are the book. The plot seems secondary - just a framework for these characters to operate in. JK Rowling tackles a lot of serious issues in this book. I've seen other reviewers list the myriad of issues to support a negative opinion - how it was unbelievable that so many heavyweight topics were squeezed into one book. Looking at it that way, I see the point. Rowling covers death, addiction, self mutilation, rape, mental illness, poverty... geeze it sure does sound like an after school special. But honestly, I never felt that way while reading the book. I thought it was engaging and interesting story written by a very talented author. It was a pleasure to read a work of fiction by someone who can actually write when so many best sellers these days read as though they were written by teenagers.

author: Riley Fickett
title: A Change of Pace
body: This book was hard for me to get into. Wrapping my head around small town politics was boring, and often I found myself wondering what the point of the election plot line was, as it didn't really make a huge impact on the novel as a whole. I was much more interested in the stories of the students and they way they viewed their town and the adults that run it. Despite this book's flaws, it's beautifully written in true Rowling form. Don't go into this story expecting an adult Harry Potter. This US a huge change of pace from the story we all fell in love with.

author: Jane Braun
title: JKRowling adult book - wanted to see how she wrote for adults
body: Story starts out slow - many characters but all interwoven - takes an everyday situation and makes an interesting story about it.  Will be looking for more books for adults from Rowling.

author: Geneva G.
title: THIS is her adult novel?
body: Rowling must have gotten tired of writing about love in the Harry Potter series because there is precious little of it in this book.  Most of the characters are miserable human beings, with only a few rays of the good aspects of humanity shining through.  While it is honest to say that most of us have a bad side, the negativity and cynicism in this book are over-the-top.  Don't read it if you want to be uplifted.

author: Carpe Librum
title: Spent too much time waiting for something to happen...
body: If this book was written by someone other than J.K. Rowling I never would have looked twice at it. Maybe I should have gone with that instinct. This book was over 500 pages of waiting for something to happen.

author: Hussain Mustafa
title: AMAZING!!!AWESOME!!!!FANTASTIC!!!!
body: I just love this book. Im a huge fan of Harry Potter and JK Rowling and she is the cleverest writer in our time. Im fortunate to be born in JKR era and i recommend this book to HUGELY to all.

author: Frosty
title: JK Rowling still great
body: JK Rowling shows her ability to put forth a new story for a new group of readers.  I really liked this book!

author: Heather Van Gerven
title: Fowl Language
body: There was so much "F" bombs in the first chapter that I couldn't read any further. Very disappointing. I expected better.

author: Sagie Research Ltd
title: I found it boring
body: I enjoy the language and sense of humor but found the plot boring and the pace slow. Stick with Harry Potter.

author: Grannie_Fibro
title: Reality check
body: A skilful novel which may shock many, but for those of us who have worked with a broad cross-section of people, and have lived in country towns, there are no shocks or surprises. This work describes the society we live in, the good, the bad and the ugly are revealed, and the reality, the motives, the vanities, and a wealth of other human failings are revealed and offered up or consideration.

author: Bonnie
title: somewhat depressing
body: It's a well written novel.  The characters are all a bit depressing.  No one seems to be content or even happy but it still held my interest to the end.

author: Klaus V. Luehning
title: A Stab into another field.
body: OK, but the verve and intensity of her Harry Potter books exposes her interest in diversity but lack of conviction.

author: Judith L. Bonnell
title: Boring
body: Did not find any redeeming qualities in this book, even when making allowances for the difference in country's culture. By the end I was still waiting for it to wind up with some interest.

author: sandradaystar
title: Rowling does it again!
body: I loved the Harry Potter series and truly appreciate JK Rowling's skills. I never thought The Casual Vacancy would compare to Potter. Maybe that's why I liked it so much. Wonderful read on its own. Worth the time and money.

author: Lynn Lott
title: A Worthwhile but Difficult Read
body: It's hard to believe the same author who brought us Harry Potter with all the magic of his world could also write a book so depressing and dismal.  Rowling drew me in based on her past reputation; she kept me reading based on her brilliant writing ability. I can't remember reading a book this well written in recent years. Her characters started off bad and got worse.  Her plot could only lead in one direction - there was NOT going to be a happy ending.  Yet I couldn't put the book down.  I can only hope that the characters represented the worst possible in people, and that in real life, people have some redeeming qualities.  I'm not sorry I read the book, but it was challenging to become part of the dysfunctional and dark world Rowling created.  Be prepared to be stirred up emotionally.

author: Allynn T
title: OK, but just that
body: JK Rowling is a fantastic children's author but not much of one for adults.  The characters are simplistic and there's none of the depth or inner life or descriptiveness that readers expect from adult fiction.  Even the vocabulary used by Rowling is simple, much like the Potter books.  Though the themes are adult - drug use, small-town politics, class, race/ethnicity, aging - the book is simple storytelling, surface skimming.  It was an enjoyable tale but nothing more.

author: Sandy
title: Blah
body: This book was a disapointment. Really not a grabber in any of the story lines. Really glad I bought the Kindle edition for much less cost than the hardcover.

author: Cliff Lamb-Rosas
title: A long read about unlikeable charcters.
body: I suppose I committed Amazon heresy by going to the local library to check out this book before buying it here on Amazon. I can tell you, I'm very glad I did.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Brilliant
body: I'm writing this several months after reading it, so my memory won't allow me to make a very detailed review.

author: lanie
title: needs work
body: Actually I thought it was a very slow read, it had very little substance.  She did much better with Harry Potter.

author: Lakeside
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: To me this was over rated and hard reading.To many good books to get bogged down in on badly written novel ,which is my opinion.I am sure other people love it as it was on the best seller list.

author: Jeannette Katzir
title: A generous ONE star
body: A Casual Vacancy, by J.K. Rowling

author: flimfrik
title: A great read
body: I truly enjoyed and admired this book.  I needed to say that first, because it's hard to write a positive review about a novel where characters are so flawed and difficult, especially when there's nothing flashy about their story.  I understand that when the stakes seem so low (a small town council seat) people compare them to the Good and Evil stakes of the Harry Potter books and find them wanting, but as happens in dismissive reviews of many of women writers who attempt this kind of novel, that seems like such stereotypical and lazy criticism.  How people live their daily lives is where it all starts.  How people express their compassion (or not) through local politics, through family politics, through personal whims and desires -- that's the basis for where we end up as a society.  The society Rowling presents is indeed petty and unforgiving (and at many instances unforgivable) yet why is showing it on a more personal level not praiseworthy?  Rowling takes on big topics -- various kinds of familial abuse, drug addiction, bullying -- from an everyday perspective, describing even the most unlikeable characters with both charity and open eyes.  She's especially good (no surprise) at getting into the minds of her teenage subjects, and unlike the mostly black-and-white characters of the Harry Potter books, these are kids I recognize, with complex motivations.  The crimes are (mostly) small-time and the acts of heroism are baby steps, but what can I say? it all rang true for me.  Unless you need magic or spies or armies to make a novel resonate for you, check it out.

author: turnerpage
title: A  Novel for Our Time
body: The Casual Vacancy, J.K. Rowling's first novel for adults is set in the fictional town of Pagford, an area where the gap between the 'haves' and the 'have nots' grows ever wider with each passing day.  The Casual Vacancy of the title is the job advertisement for the election of a new parish councillor, after the death of the much-admired Barry Fairbrother, who keels over in the opening pages of the book.  Fairbrother, a working class hero, who never forgot about those less fortunate than himself, is one of the few characters in the ensemble cast, that you can really warm to.

author: Kindle Customer
title: The Casualty Vacancy
body: J.K. Rowling is one of my favorite authors.  I read all the Harry Potter books, and saw all the movies.

author: Heno
title: Give it a go,
body: Rowling has an amazing talent for bring characters to life. I could practically see their faces. This is a story of the knock on effect of one man's death and the many varied consequences. Also showing a less pleasant side to modern day England which is probably spot on. I would defiantly recommend this book, great read.

author: Lady Day
title: Uh, no.
body: Sorry, but I stopped listening to the audiobook six chapters in.  How disappointing.

author: oigadigavale
title: I did read the whole thing. Meaty, compelling, mature, ambiguous.
body: I find it virtually impossible to imagine anyone younger than college-aged able to get anything worthwhile from this book. At that, I think being at least in one's 30s is going to enable a reader of The Casual Vacancy to have the perspective to really understand what's going on with these characters. I don't believe the young will understand the characters' motivations and how they are interacting within their environments and relationships and influencing each other.

author: Anty MN
title: Very disappointing.
body: Nothing I like in it. The story, the characters or anything. I imagine it's like watching Coronation Street. Maybe she should stick with Harry Potter.

author: Ghiarella
title: Didn't like the charachters
body: J.K. Rowling writes beautifully.  I love reading her stuff because I can imagine every detail of the character and their life.  With this book, that is the problem.  The only likeable character died in the opening pages.  I kept reading and reading, waiting for someone that I could enjoy reading about, but it never happened.  I would feel depressed and sad at the lack of any redeeming qualities in the characters.  I wanted to badly to like the story, because I think the author has a beautiful style of writing, but in this case, the story was lacking a strong, likeable character.

author: Lisa Haydon
title: Very good but very realistic as well
body: I liked the book a lot. Some much depth and insight. However, it was very realistic whereas the Harry Potter books were more fantasy. I like my casual reading to uplift me. I get a lot of reality already. But excellent writing.

author: Catherine D. Belles
title: The Casual Vacancy is okay
body: It isn't a bad read, the sentences and phrasing are sometimes quite lovely.  The setting is idyllic and yet people have all these interior sins/issues that prevent them from matching the exterior beauty they want to project and protect.  This is a study of a small ecosystem that has suffered a major loss, the vacancy which then results in all sorts of personal and community changes to fix or fill this vacancy.  It is an interesting sociological and perhaps pastoral study of how one person's life and death means so much in so many ways to so many people.  However, this is not Harry Potter, the changes are not exciting, they just happen.  No magic, no wizards and no extreme evil to be combated.  Just normal people - evil enough without magic.

author: Tar Larner
title: Despicable Characters in Small Town England
body: JK Rowling's penchant for black & white good versus evil youthful characters in the Harry Potter series is abandoned for an un-nuanced look at small town life in semi-rural England. The death of the apparently only nice person in town (on the first page) precipitates the dash to unethical behavior by everyone else. By the end most characters reveal some mitigating  traits but it remains a glum place. Rowling thinks she is redeeming herself by presenting an adult novel. Its unlikely to lead to six sequels, but she does pull the reader into these sleazy lives.

author: Mrs. Lynne Sheppard
title: A bit 'soapy'
body: I found the book very hard to get into at first, it was like small-town gossip.  I enjoyed the Harry Potter books, but found this one very depressing.  I was a disappointed reader.

author: Kirstin
title: Disappointing
body: Not one single positive or uplifting character.... Still not sure what the book was even about - there was no actual plot or climax!

author: E. Schlossberg
title: Needed a flow chart to keep track, but otherwise a decent read
body: Ever read a Russian novel, where there are seemingly hundreds of characters and it is impossible to keep track of the relationships among them without creating a family tree or flow chart?  This is that book, but in English.  I had to consult my chart regularly, until I hit page 250.  At that point, I finally grasped who was who and I was able to ditch the chart.  And, that is the major problem with this book -- WAY WAY WAY too many characters fighting one another, secretly in love with one another, sabotaging one another, etc. etc.  Having said this, the book is a really good, sometimes snarky, expose on class in England.  There are surprises and secrets sprinkled throughout the book, and I liked the plot development, but keeping track of everyone was really tough!!  But for the character confusion, I'd rate the book a solid 4 stars.  Oh, and I have not read the Potter books, so my review is based only on what I read, not on what what I wished the book had been or based on differences between this book and the HP series.

author: Danny A. Reynolds II
title: Very different from Harry Potter
body: I grew up with the Harry Potter series, and I loved each and every one of the books.  This book is completely different, but I enjoyed it almost as much.  There were some slow parts that I had trouble getting through, but the majority of the book was a fun read!

author: Sam Spade
title: Competently written, but dreadful story
body: First: I am a Harry Potter fan and read this knowing it was completely unrelated to JKR's other stories in both style and content. Now that that's out of the way...

author: C. Heiremans
title: Amazingly complex
body: With The Casual Vacancy, J. K. Rowling has proven that not only can she give voice to The Boy Who Lived, but also to the myriad denizens of Pagford. Rowling deftly weaves between characters, helping the reader understand their usually misguided and often malevolent actions. I greatly enjoyed this book, even though it was strange reading some of the mildly graphic descriptions and vulgar dialogue. These are not two things that normally upset me, but as a long-time Harry Potter fan, it was strange to read them from the woman who wrote the books that I grew up with. If you enjoyed the narration style of the Harry Potter books, or you like small town politics, I strongly recommend this book. If you were mainly a fan of the content of the HP books, you may be disappointed.

author: saffayroux
title: Awesome complexity and aesthetic
body: Cool mix of a formal 19th century novel and a gritty cockney look at suburban life. I love the feel and rhythm.

author: Debra Enright
title: Wasted my Money
body: I really couldn't get into this book.  It is extremely boring.  Was really disapointed.  Wouldn't recommend it at all.  Do you think I should keep reading doesn't it get better?

author: momma
title: I want 500 pages of my life back.
body: Its not her writing skills, its the 500 page, 100 character, unfinished story she chose to tell. It might be forgivable if this was her first novel. But it was slow to start and took me 400 pages to care what was happening. And although she alludes to what the future may hold. The ending was blunt and unfulfilling.

author: Beverly E. Perez
title: Not the page-turner that the Potter series was...
body: I was such a Harry Potter fan that I've read all of Rowling's books, including the shorter Potter-related books. When this book came out, I was naturally curious to see what direction Rowling had taken after the sensational success of the Potter series.  This book is very different from Potter.  Whereas every sentence in a Potter book drew you deeper into the magical world of fantasy that Rowling had intricately woven, The Casual Vacancy was a gritty and unflinching glimpse into the reality of some people's lives.  The book is slow to pick up and most of the characters are loathsome and unforgiveably self-absorbed. The only sympathetic characters are the dead Barry Fairbrother, the tragic anti-heroine Krystal and the mostly invisible wallflower Sukvinder. Living in the stiflingly idyllic hamlet of Pagford with a gaggle of contemptuous sociopaths seems a bit like torture.  In the end, I was almost happy that Fairbrother was already dead, that Krystal was finally put out of her misery and hoping that Sukvinder's newly discovered confidence leads her to get out of there as soon as she can.

author: jiminyklickit
title: It's clearly not written for Potter fans, but...
body: Rowling has a great eye for characters and social dynamics, but little can prepare a Potter fan for this dark tale of small town ambitions.  UK is different, but sadly, it is too much the same, as well.  It would be naive to say it's shocking, but this is NOT for young readers; it's probably fine for 14+, if they're interested.

author: Debra Hamel
title: No one to root for, really
body: Pretty much every man, woman, and child in beautiful Pagford and its ugly, socioeconomically depressed appendage known as "The Fields" lives a miserable existence. Children hate parents, spouses hate spousees, everyone is mean or depressed or abusive or abused. J.K. Rowling's first post-Potter book The Casual Vacancy shows us that muggles can be every bit as unpleasant as Death Eaters. I did eventually become somewhat interested in Rowling's characters, and ultimately the story was moving, but it took much longer than I wish it had for me to become invested, and all the while there really wasn't anyone I wanted to root for. (Okay, there were a couple of teens who were more abused than abusive, but I still wouldn't want my daughters hanging around with either of them.)

author: HLB
title: Utterly unlikeable characters
body: I was so disappointed in this book.  I read until the end, waiting to actually care about ANY of the characters, and it never happened.  A depressing tale of English small town politics, with a depressing cast of characters who engage in all sorts of bad behavior.  I did give two stars rather than only one, because it was well written and edited.

author: Melissia Lenox
title: Life truly
body: I read this book almost straight-through. I was captivated by the bringing to life of the thoughts people harbour and the peek into their motivations. I look forward to Rowling`s next endeavour into adult fiction.

author: September Willow
title: Very good book
body: Daughter is a fan of J.K. Rowling. Of course this is not what one is used to with this author, but very intriguing read.

author: Nic
title: Not What I Expected
body: About the Book:

author: mizlee
title: a dog walking on his hind legs
body: The question isn't how well, but why. If Rowling was trying to drum up support for her charities, you'd think there'd be somebody in the 500+ pages who isn't repulsive. Doesn't she know any nice people? Are these numerous characters a new version of Dementors? Frankly, I only finished it so I could have the pleasure of saying how worthless I found it.

author: just cathy
title: Too Much Sadness - No Likeable Characters
body: While the characters in this book were well developed there was not one of them that was likeable or relatable.  There are a lot of good books out there containing tremendous sadness and little to redeem it, but most contain at least one character that the reader can appreciate or relate to.  The Casual Vacancy has none of that.  The characters were all so self absorbed and ignorant of how their lives and feelings impacted those around them that I really didn't care what happened to any of them, even little Robbie.  One reviewer likened this story to Peyton Place.  While I can see the parallel, Peyton Place was a much better story overall.  I'm glad I received this book as a gift and didn't spend the money on it myself.  It will not remain part of my library, I will donate it to a library book sale.

author: Meghan Lafferty
title: Great read!
body: J.K. ROWLING is an exceptional writer.  This first adult novel of hers proved her unique ability to draw the reader in through her detailed descriptions of characters and her talent for sucking you into her story.  While completely different from the Harry Potter series, it was one that I would definitely recommend!

author: JOHN ROSS POPE
title: To be or not to be  disappointed.
body: To be or not to be  disappointed.  Like Lady Di in a dress off the peg at M&S. J. K. Rowling is one of the best storytellers of our times but  with this novel she appears to have had nothing better to do than scribble about,  a disjointed tale as though she were to write about the five toed chicken from Dorking.  Too many underdeveloped characters, an obvious rehash of social decadence, a pseudo-pompousness of those who think that they have versus the very oversold have-nots --makes for a very long story which takes the reader almost nowhere.

author: PEDRO ZAVALLA
title: Terrible book, dull and boring
body: Its  just, well,  terrible. Im going to put it again, so I can get the 20 words.  T-E-R-R-I-B-L-E

author: C.L. Mannarino
title: Great Read!
body: I came away impressed by JK Rowling's adult book overall. I think she had strong points and the book kept me engrossed.

author: Joan Molamphy
title: rubbishy
body: wasnt to my taste and found it hard to concentrate on thestory didnt hold my interest in a way i could enjoy the story

author: H. Karaca Kestelli
title: Slow & not a gripping story about a small town
body: I am not much of a book critique, but despite most of the positive comments, I really didn't like the book.

author: Ruth
title: Not nearly the storyteller that she was with the Harry Potter series.
body: I found the story confusing and the book just ended -  Too many characters. No conclusions for many of the characters.

author: C. Sanford Murray
title: Casual Vacancy
body: I am still trying to get through the book. It is character-heavy. I am a fan of the author but think she should stick to Harry Potter.

author: teri karole
title: Keep trying,JK
body: Loved Harry potter books w my children, but couldn't get thru this.  Too many characters, boring storyline, rarely quit books, but I had to quit this one. Sorry JK.

author: Anne B.
title: Sigh
body: I *so* wanted to love this book.  I *so* loved Harry Potter.  Well, truth be told, I liked the early books in the Harry Potter series.
