Rowling has a talent for seeing the thought processes in depth of her entire cast of characters, and I found it challenging and downright eerie how much she understands the pettiness and myopia even the most respected citizens harbor.  It was a true study of how a population's diverse outlooks can converge into action that can be either galvanizing or devastating.  I loved the challenge and hope she continues in this vein in the future.

author: Janice Lynch
title: If J. K. Rowling hadn't written it I don't think an editor would have recommended it.
body: Did not like the story nor did I care about any of the characters, good or bad.

author: Cristobal Asenjo Marquez
title: Great expectaitons
body: Thought it'd be better, after the fantastic Harry Potter saga, so far not bad, but it's not that great. I don't dare to recomend

author: Danielle L
title: Casual Vacancy
body: The character development is great and keeps you reading, but there are a LOT of characters and it's a long book.  While the main conflict was resolved in the book, it seems that many of the subplots were left unfinished.

author: e-reader lover
title: Small Town Life
body: It's not Harry Potter, no Wizards, witches  or monsters.  Just the ordinary people living in a typical small town that could be anywhere but is in england.  There are good people, bad people, cheating husbands and people driven by  all teh dreams and desires of ordinarty folks everywhere.  A nice story of ordinary people trying to live in small town England.

author: Penny Bulgarella
title: NOT SO MUCH
body: Couldn't get into this story. First book I purchased for my Kindle.Don't know if it was the book or using the kindle that made it so difficult.

author: Ellen Rosewall
title: A master storyteller at work
body: I am not among those who was put off by the dark tone of this novel -- although I admit, at times I wondered if there was anyone in this town worth liking.  By the end, though, as the pieces came together, I was swept into J.K. Rowling's masterful storytelling.  Every word of her writing has a purpose, and if you pay attention, the payoff is wonderful.

author: Anita M. Nichols
title: Not a very interesting story line.
body: Just could not keep my interest up.  There was not much adventure or suspense until the very end, which is where the story should have started.

author: bookgirlgail
title: hard to get through....
body: This book was chosen for my book club so i thought i should finish.  i found the book to be extremely hard to read and  figure out the point of the story.  The ending got a little more interesting but i would not recommend this book.

author: Angie
title: Meh
body: A book club read

author: bkgrace
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Well written but a bit depressing.  Some of the British slang was difficult to follow. Found it hard to follow the story line.

author: Book Woman
title: Makes You Reexamine Your Life
body: Don't expect this book to be like Harry Potter.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Rough edges
body: This book was slow starting for me but then I found a connection with the characters. It was a bit crude for me as well.

author: Mary Fritz-Wilson
title: Loved it
body: I loved that Rowling gave two sides to every character - good and bad and you could choose whether to like them or not.  Rowling also is so gifted at creating a setting so that you can clearly see it in your own mind's eye and feel you are there.  Like the Harry Potter books, I enjoyed every moment I spent reading this book, not just for the story but for the pleasure of the way she puts words together.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Somewhat Disappointing
body: As a huge fan of Rowling's Harry Potter series, I was disappointed that none of the creativity of language from that series was evident in this book.

author: BABs
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I had a very hard time getting into the story.  There are so many characters to keep straight that it's confusing in the beginning.  I think it dragged on a little bit too much in general.  I kind of lost interest about half way through the book.  It did pick up at the end and had a pretty realistic ending.  Don't pay full price for this book.  It was a bit of a disappointment after reading the Harry Potter series.

author: G. Morris
title: Not one redeeming point
body: I love Harry Potter. Really love them all. I know from these books that Rowling knows about character development. The good guy needs a flaw and the villain needs some virtue. I guess when she started to write an adult novel, she threw that knowledge away. In Casual Vacancy there is a cast of characters that I would never want to meet. I didn't like anyone. The only good guy died on page 2. I was mildly intrigued by the teenage heroin addict but that's it. I might read her next novel but this one was a waste of my time.

author: LadyBlue88
title: Is this the same person who wrote Harry Potter?!
body: How do you top Harry Potter; you don't! I was so looking forward to Ms. Rowlings New book; something new, fresh, different, a departure from Harry (though I am still going through "Harry Potter" withdrawals books and movies; though books rule!!!). Pre-ordered Casual Vacancy on my Kindled and waited; when I received it I wanted to dive right in, but personal matters prevented me from doing so. It was total agony; though during my wait I began to hear rumors of disappointment over the book. No longer could I wait, leaping head first, locking myself away, not to be disturbed until further notice. My joy was short lived, after a few chapters my mind began to wander,to a grocery list, laundry, etc., anything but the book I was trying to read and rarely ever do I get sidetracked when reading. I'd been ill, so I decided to put the book down and wait a few days refresh and feel better and begin anew. So three days later I attempted to try again, and again I just could not get into Casual Vacancy.

author: ziacri
title: Well written, a merciless analysis
body: A merciless analysis of the petty daily issues of countryside life, and the drama they can lead to.

author: lois claire
title: Casual Vacancy (AWFUL!!)
body: I absolutely loved the Harry Potter series and have read them several times. This book is awful. It is boring, depressing, not a happy book. I read quite a bit of it and then skipped thru' trying to find something to like. Even the last couple of chapters were not worth the read.  I was so so so disappointed. I probably  won't read another one of her books. I feel so sad that this was such a disappointment.

author: Liz Soldwish-Zoole
title: I really want to like it...
body: I want to like this book. I really do. It is well written, and the device of killing off the most important character as a way to open the book is brilliant, but I don't like or care about these characters and can't maintain enough interest in the story to finish the book, despite multiple starts.

author: JS
title: Dark
body: Lots of characters, all unhappy. Hard to put down once you get all the characters straight.

author: Tom Triumph
title: As Good as Martin Amis or Ian McEwan
body: The thing about this book is that the pages turn slowly.

author: Ryan Grooms
title: The Paper Critic - Review
body: The Casual Vacancy had the most potential to be a great book, and if you read my review when I got this book and the future expectations I had on this book you would know that there was a lot of glaring problems I had with this book. And I would love to present my first abandoned book to everyone. I just couldn't get past the glaring problems with this book and how horrible it is. If you like slow moving dramas that really just involve a bunch of self-centered morons, this would be the perfect book for you.

author: Fountainheart
title: Excellent writing, though not a page turner
body: I had a hard time rating this book (three stars and a half) because many parts are worth 5 stars and it's wonderfully written, but, for some weird reason, overall it lacks the magic (pun intended) and tension of Harry Potter. I enjoyed the writing but didn't care much about the story or the characters. The structure is such that there are no main heroes, it's a well done human fresco of the people of a small British city, featuring many 'small characters'. I imagine the author wanted to show/prove that she can write an excellent serious book, in a different style, with different heroes, and she fully achieved her aims. You need to have time and patience for this book, and although you'll savor it in small doses for the great insights into various types of people - J K Rawlings is an astute observer of human nature - you'll struggle a bit to finish it. It's a book you won't lovem but you'll highly appreciate.

author: Cathie M. Quade
title: True colors shown
body: I find it amazing how little people care about hurting other peolpe's feelings.  Ture colors shown and vicious actions seen.

author: polo reader
title: Disappointed in this author.
body: I did not expect this type of writing from such a famous accomplished author....  The language was too strong for me

author: Coordinator Clive
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Takes too long to 'get into the story' with long drawn out introductions to the characters. Perhaps I'd have enjoyed IF I was a Harry Potter fan and 50 years younger.

author: sernarama
title: Good first grown-up book
body: J.K. definitely knows how to write a novel. This book was good, but a little predictable. Had her usual wit, overall a good read.

author: Mell
title: disappointed.
body: I was very disappointed. I could'nt force myself to finish this book, it was such a slow, painful thing to read. I loved HP, so I thought I'd give it a try. Not for me .

author: Kindle Customer
title: Disturbing
body: I was very disappointed in this book. The characters were unbelievably cruel. The story moved from one depressing scene to another.  I ended up skimming several sections in order to finish the book.  It's one thing to write of the plight of man, but there should be some moments of hope. Not a book I would recommend.

author: Cindy Dickerson
title: Wow, what a bore!
body: If you're looking for the action-packed scenes found in Harry Potter, don't read this book. In a word, BORING. Small town London full of secrets, lies, and hypocrites. So depressing. I didn't find any of the characters remotely likable, I couldn't root for any of them and I had to force myself to finish the book. She throws about 30 characters at you in the beginning of the book and expects you to remember them all as the story flies from one prospective to another, so confusing and unnecessary.

author: ceb
title: The Casual Vacancy.
body: I guess I was expecting Harry Potter quality and it just wasn't there (my opinion at least ). Perhaps it just wasn't my type of story.

author: Susan Wolfe
title: Too depressing!
body: Great author, I adore Harry Potter and re-read them constantly.  This IS a masterful character study, and many of the characters in this book will stay in my mind forever, BUT not one of them is likable and it's just such a horrid little look at the dirty side of small town politics and people.  BUT because the people are so real to me, it's really is a masterpiece.

author: aamooref
title: Way different than expected
body: I did not expect JK Rowling's first book outside of her Harry Potter series to be this sad and dark! Definitely an unexpected ending...

author: Ed.Doc99
title: No likable characters???
body: I was really looking forward to reading Rowling's first foray into adult literature. I have read all of the Harry Potter books and enjoyed them all. "Casual Vacancy" starts and ends with funerals, and it has no joy in between. The characters are finely drawn, but the only likable one has died before the book even begins. I was disappointed in it.

author: Valerie Roche
title: Great!
body: If only we had gotten to see more of what the dursleys lives without Harry potter in it.... this is what it would be like.

author: Lcharnin
title: very realistic
body: I read to escape, but too much of this story hit too close to home. This book did not fulfill what I look for in a novel.

author: Catherine
title: Disappointing!
body: Well developed characters, but unsympathetic. Rowling's indepth physological insights create a town peopled with self-centered, unlikeable characters. While the plot was almost lost in the character description,  I didn't like any of them enough to really care what happened to them.

author: Georgiana Witherill
title: I did not finish!!
body: At first i like this book! But then it got so boring i did not finish...

author: Katie R Gillespie
title: Wouldn't wast my money on it.
body: It truly was a let down considering the Harry Potter Books!!  I just couldn't get into it :( Don't wast your money on this book.

author: Joanne M. Trew
title: Depressing!
body: I find it hard to believe that JK wrote such a depressing story. I have a rule that I always finish every book i start no matter how bad, because sometimes at the end there is a redeeming quality. Not so with this book. I find it hard to believe that any small town could possibly be this dis-functional.

author: HeyMoe
title: Character Study
body: You certainly get to know the characters well, over 15 of them, which is the bulk of the book. The underlying plot is pretty shallow, takes a long time to develop and it all comes crashing to an end in the last chapters.

author: Diversified Interest Girl
title: Amazing adult lit - dare say modern classic
body: A Casual Vacancy has been grossly under rated. J. K. Rowling did a great job with Harry Potter but it was, at the end of the day, a children's series. A Casual Vacancy, on the other hand, is no doubt one of the most incredible adult literature books I've read. The reading level is high. There are many, complex characters and a rich, deep plot that brings you right in. Like Harry Potter, the book is long. And like Harry Potter, I finished the book within just a few days. It was impossible to put down and I spent more time thinking about the book, and wishing to dissect it with someone, than any other book in recent memory.

author: Suzanne Clarke
title: Bleak, bleak, bleak
body: I found this incredibly bleak, and the characters unlikeable. The subject was mostly about filling a council seat, and the politics involved in these unloveable character. Everyone was trapped in a situation without hope of repreive.

author: angel
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I had a hard time understanding this book. I lost interest and the plot never appeared. I read it to the end but would not read anything like it again.

author: Book reader
title: Casual attempt to make more money
body: Not even worth a rating.  I have read such books as the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire.  I got 46% through, before I ready felt this was a waste of time.  My wife only made it through 20%.  Don't waste your money!

author: Molly Garman
title: Gritty and painful, like Andre Dubus III
body: An excellent book, hard to swallow and sure to leave you with tears in your eyes. The story pounds forward and feels very much like Dubus' The Garden of Last Days. Very unexpected, but incredibly well done.

author: P. Lenny
title: Excellent Book
body: A Casual Vacancy is an excellent book.  Well written, great wit, very tragic.  One of the best books I have read in the past 6 months.  Kudos to J.K. Rowling for tackling so many topics with such wonderful insight.  This book starts as a nice story about people, but goes behind closed doors and reveals all.  It moves on to subjects that exist everywhere, but most people don't want to see or talk about.  Many surprises, tragedies, and great writing.  Do yourself a favor and read this fabulous book.

author: Autumn Smith
title: Jk Rowling proves diverse
body: Delighted by this story I liked the turns it took and the tragic ending

author: Erin
title: Rowling's 180 degree change in subject is a success!
body: Completely different than what I expected...in a good way! Rowling departs from her well known and loved Potter series and delves into the dark underbelly of society. She takes a no holds barred approach in regards to her topics and characters. She introduces a lot of different characters in the beginning, but stick with it! She makes you feel anger when you should probably feel pity and sympathy when you should feel disgust. A very powerful and realistic book. One of the best I've read in a long time. I have, and will continue to, recommend this book.

author: Caroline
title: Slow start, good finish.
body: When I started reading it, I thought there were too many characters. Towards the end I could see how these characters play fairly significant roles in the whole plot. Quite enjoyed the read but I think the names are rather Harry Potter-ish.

author: Ann Reego
title: I can't get into it.
body: Guess that I was expecting the prose of "Harry Potter".  This book is dry and very difficult to get into.  I have not finished it because it has not "hooked" me.

author: TLCarter
title: Good Read!
body: J.K. Rowling has done it again.  Enjoyed the book! Slow start but worth reading.... I became hooked and just couldn't put it down. Found myself laughing at small town gossip and crying for the sadness of the truth. Look forward to more books by this author.

author: Proofreader
title: Rosamunde Pilcher takes a walk on the Dark Side
body: This novel, at first appearance, resembles a Rosamunde Pilcher set piece with a village full of stereotypical Brits who speak, dress, live in vicarages and homes with names and not numbers, and work at careers that many characters in one of her books often do.  But Pagford is different, sort of like the way the apt. building in Rosemary's Baby was different from all the other ones nearby - it's a town full of dysfunctional, unhappy, guilty and mentally fragile misfits masquerading as the town's leaders.  No one seems to have avoided the negativity, except perhaps for the sexy Sikh doctor who does a lot of sardonic smiling.

author: timduck
title: 'Prefer the witches, wizards, etc.
body: "The Casual Vacancy" is certainly a change from the "Harry Potter" novels which rocketed Ms. Rowling to fame, fortune, and instantaneous name recognition!  "The Casual Vacancy" is  a story of a small, but snobby, English village in which a village council member drops dead with an aneurysm or stroke (I can't remember which).  Of course he must be replaced as quickly as possible as not to disrupt governance.  In the ensuing days the citizens of the village show their true colors and reveal their allegiance to one "side" or another.  They also show their class-conscieniouness and pettishness.  To add to the mess, the neighboring village is lower-middle-class whom the uppity citizens may look down upon.  The lower class village does provide crime, drug use and addiction, and vulgar behavior.  Of course there is overlap between between the villages.  "The Casual vacancy" is somewhat enlightening as to the workings of the British class system.  Had the book been written in the 1950's perhaps it could be a companion to "Peyton Place"-there are similarities; but neither would raise an eyebrow today.

author: Mesamom52
title: Not what I expected from a review
body: I received the book for Christmas as per my request. I wanted to see how Rowling would write adult fiction, being a huge HP fan. I had read a review in the local newspaper which was positive. What I did not get from the review was the amount of profanity and sexual subject matter. I could not count the number of times the "f" word was used, as well as others. Even if this is the way the characters would talk in "real life", the omniscient author can use other words and let the reader use their own imagination. I did not need these words to understand the despair or anger the characters felt. One of the reasons I like children's fiction is that because the author can't use profanity, or perhaps uses only mild profanity, they must have a broader vocabulary to describe emotions. Liberal use of profanity I think is often used as a crutch. While appreciating the social and personal issues of the characters, I was not interested in reading about their sexual issues in explicit terms. So, I was disappointed with the book. As soon as I finished it (I did care about the fates of the characters) I took it to a second-hand book shop for resale, and gave the proceeds to charity. If you are interested in the book, I suggest checking it out of the library before purchasing it for your collection.

author: John F
title: A Unique Story
body: A beautifully written story. This book contains a gripping tale of a tangled web of intrigue. Hard to put this book down from beginning to end.

author: PeachieMom
title: An eye-opening page-turner
body: In a perfect world, husbands and wives treat each other with respect, parents nurture and protect their children, and people understand and support each other.

author: Gail Reynolds
title: The Casual (or causual) Vacancy
body: The domino effect of a death on a small British village was interesting enough to finish.... but not very inspired.  Very few of the characters were even a little likable... maybe just more tolerable than others.  The secrets harbored "behind closed doors" were many and varied.  Perhaps because of reading this book,  I may be more aware of unusual situations that one may encounter on any given day, but one just puts aside due to self-absorption or "sticking ones nose" where it doesn't (but maybe should) belong.

author: Charles P. Frederick
title: Good Book. Very interesting for Harry Potter fans.

author: Joan
title: mmmnah
body: This book is so-so.  I loved the HP series but this book is not the same level of "good".  It is rather boring and too long,  The premise is somewhat intriguing but there are so many characters.  I can't keep them all straight which means that the author is not letting me get to know them before just using their names.

author: Scout
title: A novel about the forgotten Ron Weasleys of our world
body: Harry was a hero, Hermione was a genius, but Ron was just an average teen, a bit clumsy and unlike his brothers and friends, possessed no extra ordinary talent.  It was opportunity that made Ron great.  He had the opportunity to shine (and to fail) because of the adventures and troubles his friends got him into.

author: Nello
title: Seething depths beneath a picture perfect little town
body: This was one of those books I didn't want to finish. There is little to compare with the Harry Potter series, except to say a good writer writes good books. J. K. Rowling clearly knows people well and has the ability to create very true to life characters across a wide range of personality types and social strata. They ring true through and through. Darkly funny, tense and a wonderful expose of the seething depths lurking beneath picture perfect Pagford. Highly recommended.

author: Kathy Turnball
title: Book club selection
body: Unfortunately abandoned by myself and other book club members I think you had to have a better understanding of English " culture."

author: Gina
title: Highly recommended
body: It was a realistic look at human nature and prejudices.  It makes you want to change yourself and what you may be able to do that makes a difference

author: Sharon Martelli
title: A riveting read
body: I wasn't expecting to be drawn to this narrative as much as I was.  I am very happy that J.K. Rowling is now writing for adults, although I must say, I thoroughly enjoyed the Harry Potter series even as an adult.  I look forward to reading her future works.

author: TM
title: A bit tedious
body: As noted, a bit tedious a read, so not worth the cost to buy.  Wish I had gotten it from the library instead.

author: Davis John
title: Hmmm . . .
body: Rowling is a great author, but I'm afraid I didn't enjoy this book.

author: Judith A. Elliott
title: Another success
body: Once again, I gave this new book from J.K. Rowling to a friend for Christmas, someone whose boys read every Harry Potter book.  I'm sure it's a good read, and will read it after she is finished.

author: Amazon Customer
title: complexly simple
body: I purchased on kindle.

author: KAT
title: I think I get it, but still didn't enjoy it
body: Have you ever wished you could know what people really think of you?  Or wished that some people knew what you really think of them, though you can't or don't want to confront them?  I must admit I did not finish this book, but I read enough that I got the feel of it, and after thinking about it for some time I believe this is what the author was trying to do.  She allowed us inside the characters' thoughts - the good, the bad and the ugly, but unfortunately mostly bad and ugly.  So after coming to this realization I have a bit more respect for this work (so I've deleted my previous 1-star review) and naturally I can appreciate that the book is well written, but I still have no desire to finish it because the characters' interactions with each other are poisoned with loathing, fear, despair, etc., and I shudder to think that this is how life actually is, of which we would all be painfully aware if only we REALLY knew what was going on in other people's minds.

author: Sheryl Ann Waage
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: This book was hard to wade through. It did get better in the later chapters but if this had been one of the free books offered, I would never have finished it.

author: MrsO822
title: Did not live up to my expectations
body: Let me preface this by saying that I read this book solely because it was written by J.K. Rowling. The description did not really appeal to me, but since I loved her writing in Harry Potter so much, I felt I had to give it a try. Maybe I would be pleasantly surprised?

author: Nancy A. Jones
title: A rather tiresome and pedestrian novel
body: If Rowling had been an unknown, I don't believe this book would have found a publisher.  Quite a predictable plot, and not even very well written.

author: YoyoMitch
title: Ms. Rowling CAN write for adults!
body: I had resisted reading Ms. Rowling's newest book for fear that her seven previous novels (all best sellers) would prove her writing skills to be a fluke or limited to the Young Adult genre of literature. My fears were, of course, unfounded, as her newest novel validates that history will place Ms. Rowling on its "Most Enduring" list, noting that her talents are expansive, her eye sharp and her courage astounding.

author: JustMe
title: Interesting Story, Well Told, But...
body: It is patently obvious that J.K. Rowling needed to write this book.  She needed to give voice to the characters who inhabit this world; the lower, working and middle class people who all - each and every one - live separate from this world, and not of it.  They are the lonely, the misunderstood, the alienated.  They are legion.  For all of the couple of dozen characters we meet within the covers of this remarkably bleak book, there is hardly one who does not end the book as they started - lost and lonely.

author: Beth Prescott
title: A Required Reading for J.K. Rowling lovers!
body: I ordered this for my mom who is a big fan of Harry Potter books. She really likes it so far. I get to read it next. I think it looks great just by reading the covers. I think you all would enjoy this! No problems what sieved in ordering it. Came in just a few days. lOVE AMAZON,,,,,

author: MJR
title: Anyone who loved Harry Potter would hate this book
body: I had very much prepared myself for the fact that this book would be nothing like Harry Potter, and was even excited about a totally different genre, and more grown up subject matter, however, I did hope that JK's target audience would bear an ever so slight resemblance to her Harry Potter crowd. I was hoping that those, like myself, who were 12 when they started Reading Harry, and grew up with the book would be the ones whom the book was written for; no longer 12, but still in love with the characters we grew up adoring.

author: Tlc430
title: This book!
body: Jk Rowling has once again created a masterpiece of literature. Very different from the Harry Potter series, JK Rowling has managed to create another book that captures the minds imagination. Must read!

author: Michelle Jenkins
title: Good book
body: Jk Rowling brought you full circle in this book, very good read. She described every place and character in intense detail. You could easily picture them in your minds eye.

author: bookworm
title: It's OK
body: A decent first Post-Potter book for an "no kids allowed" audience.  Sort of a depressing soap-opera story, but the characters are well written.  No matter where you live, these people could be your neighbors or even "friends." Makes you think...you never really know what goes on in the homes or minds of others...

author: farmnteeth
title: Good!
body: It's no Harry Potter, make no mistake.  Cut her a break and let her be the fantastic story teller that she is.  As with prior books you can identify with her characters even if they are nothing like you.

author: Louis J. Calabraro
title: recrudescence
body: Excellence should be rewarded

author: Donna C93
title: Loved it!
body: Beautiful ending! A bit of John Irving-esque. All things came around nicely. The characters had great backstories, and stayed true to themselves. Lovely!!

author: Suzee2
title: A depressing book
body: The big issue facing the town council in the small town of Pagford is what to do about the Fields - a low income public housing development - and the drug addiction clinic that serves many of the Fields' residents.  When council member Barry Fairbrother unexpectedly dies, several residents decide to run for his seat so they can advocate for or agaist the Fields.  This leads to a series of events where family secrets are revealed and tragedies unfold.

author: Marsi Marquez
title: Review
body: I liked it! It was intriguing and really different from the Harry potter series. I do recommend it. It is different

author: Irene Adler ~Kindle Forum Pro~
title: Disappointed and a bit disgusted....
body: Okay, I knew this was not a children's book, and certainly not going to be "Harry Potter" for adults, but I was surprised and disappointed by "A Casual Vacancy."  Without revealing the plot or going into detail for those who may want to give it a try, I can say that at first the sheer volume of foul language in this book was disappointing.  I am not a prude, and I am not overly-sensitive to bad language, and given the right situation and company, I can swear like a sailor.  However, this book is literally "f*ing" this and "c*nting" that every other sentence.  I felt like Ms. Rowling went out of her way to show the world that this was "a book for adults" by making the language so foul that even the most liberal-minded person would not want even their adult children with earshot of the language in this book.  Now, I realize that Ms. Rowling may have been attempting to accurately depict her characters, but I really felt the use of bad language was more than gratuitous, and that it was filler for lack of more plot or character development.  Does all of lower class England curse non-stop? My second largest problem with the book was that ALL of the characters were extremely difficult to like. Even with the more sympathetic characters, you had barely a glimmer of understanding of their point of view before you found yourself not caring about them again a moment later.  The only character that I liked was the dead guy (Not giving anything away there, as that happens in the 1st chapter.)  I did manage to make it through the whole book, but I would certainly never want to read it again.  I would recommend this only if you were really curious to see what Ms. Rowling's non-Harry Potter offering is like.

author: Pauline Murray
title: My review of The Casual Vacancy
body: I was very disappointed by this book . The language by both adults and teens was awful and ;made the reading quite unpleasant. The characters in the book garnered little sympathy except for the teenagers.  I expected better from J K Rowling having thoroughly enjoyed the Harry Potter books. This was not, in my opinion, a successful move into adult literature.

author: P. Baker
title: adult fiction
body: enjoyed this title...always feel it is somewhat hard to get involved with the English point of view in books, but found the plot to be believeable...I cried when two of the characters had sad endings...loved the intertwinging of the adult characters and the juveniles...sometimes it hard to do the right thing and it can be the youngest one who knows the right way.

author: Nettybj
title: J.K should stick to writing children's books
body: This book felt as if the author needed to put everything that she was unable to put in her children's books into this one piece of work.  It would have read well without a lot of the vulgarity.

author: M McQuarrie
title: Big Disappointment
body: I am so disappointed in this book. I haven't even finished the first chapter. I realize that this was written for adults but I didn't expect that it would have so much foul language in it. I don't use that kind of language and don't enjoy finding it in the books I read. I don't plan on finishing it and it will be going into the trash where it belongs. That's too bad because I am sure that it has a wonderful plot and I would have enjoyed reading it. Sad.

author: Kaitlyn
title: Interesting
body: In the beginning it was very confusing. Way to many characters introduced in the first couple chapters. But as you read on you get to know them and it draws you in to the lives of the town.

author: Tangochick
title: Fantastic Story
body: I got the audio book at the library for my 2 hour daily commute.  This brutal tale of seriously flawed characters fumbling their way through small-town life is honest and heart-wrenching.  The almost completely self-absorbed adults in this novel let down the adolescents and children in so many ways, all of them possible in today's self-centered world.  I hope there is a follow-up so that some of these people can redeem themselves.  As far as the writing goes, each character is so well-developed, that I feel like I know them personally.  Tiny pieces of information that could be meaningless are brought to life in unexpected ways.  This book was excellent, and the audio was exciting and well-performed.  I couldn't wait for my day's commute to see what was happening next!

author: Courtney
title: Excellent Book for JK Rowling
body: As a huge fan of her Harry Potter series, I knew I had to read this book as well and I am glad I did. This book is absolutely great. It brings the reader in and also has that london/england vibe. I recommend to anyone that loves other J.K Rowling's books!

author: Lane
title: Loved It
body: I judge a book on three factors:

author: Rosemary
title: More, please
body: I haven't read any of the Harry Potter series, so I was curious to see if Ms. Rowling could deliver an adult novel.  She hit it out of the park.  One of my favorite kinds of books--complex, varied and interesting characters, and a draw-you-in narrative.  It is a pleasure to read a book that keeps you on your toes to pay attention to all the little details.  I am not the biggest fan of mysteries, but I love Ruth Rendell for the same reason.  Neither of these ladies dummy anthing down for the reader.  Every little detail is important as well as interesting.She portrays small town life with deadly accuracy, revealing all the petty (and not so petty) dealings that people have with each other.  A perfect example of the big fish in a small bowl theory.  I laughed, I cried and I hated it to end.  No novel is perfect, but this one was pretty darn close.  All I can say to JK Rowling is to quote Oliver Twist. "More please".

author: Daphne Kay
title: Interesting
body: I thought the concept of the storyline was interesting but found there wasn't enough depth to the characters.  An enjoyable read but not over the moon about it.  The Harry Potter series were far better.

author: corina
title: It is a profound, insightful book. Not a happy book
body: I loved the book. After going through the 503 pages I found myself sad that it was over. J.K. Rowling took me to a world unlike my own but inhabited by characters that I could recognise around me. The personalities developed have so many layers that I found it hard not to empathise with all of them at one point, and resent their attitudes at another.

author: Melissa Closser
title: Too hard to follow
body: There were so many characters that you couldn't follow the story line. They are so intertwined in their releationships that you got easily confused. I only read about 25% of the book and stopped.

author: Susan Spreadborough
title: Great Read!!
body: I really enjoyed reading this book, set in the UK, quite different to Rowling's previous novels. I shall certainly look out for her next novel.

author: Kindle Customer
title: good
body: This book was good but I really dont think it was alltogether a huge hit by know means. It was just a ok read.

author: Stellar rouge
title: A jolly good read:-)
body: JK Rowling has written a book as accomplished as that of any writer. I found this book to be difficult to put down. The only and its a small only problem  I had at first was getting my head around who was who as there is a very long cast of characters. Excellent plot. Deals with a raft of topical issues. Would definitely recommend to anyone who likes a good yarn.

author: Joyce Hoffmeyer
title: J. K Rowlings - Vacancy - XXX Rated
body: I was extremely disappointed in the quality of this book.  If I was rating it, it would be XXX.  There was an extreme amount of cuss words with the most used beginning with "F".  This book discribed 16 year olds having sex and explicitly describing the individuals thoughts and actions.  This book needs to be sold from under the counter as is Playboy is some cases due to all the smut and what could be considered as child pornography.

author: Maureen M. Agnew
title: J.K. Rowling's new book
body: This novel concerns the death of a local British politician in a small English town and the ramifications of that death among various dwellers of that town.  The problem with this kind of a subject is that many characters are focused upon.  Therefore, the dilemma for the author is how to differentiate those characters for the reader so the latter is not confused.  Happily, Rowling is up to the task; characters are clearly defined in personal characteristics, speech, and thoughts.  Rowlings successfully depicts small town British life with both its inhabitants' concerns and clashes while bringing the town of Pagford itself to life.

author: Ponnana
title: A storybook for the adolescents
body: It must be truly intimidating to attempt a book after the runaway success of the Harry Potter series, and one must add, the unexpected success of the series. Whether it is the burden of these expectations, or whether the author is simply comfortable writing only for a certain audience, the book is unmistakably written for the legion of Potter fans.

author: Warpenny
title: I was dissapointed.
body: Lots of people and behind the sceans interaction like Harry Potter, but not exciting and full of bad language to make it an "adult" book.

author: K11
title: Rowling is a Wonderful Author
body: Rowling's HP series is my all time favorite, but I did not go into this book expecting it to be another HP novel. I knew Rowling intended this to stand alone, so without those expectations, I could really enjoy the novel. I did enjoy it very much! Getting through the first hundred or so pages is difficult because there are so many characters to set up, but when you start recognizing the names and plot lines the story moves faster. However, even when things felt slow, I couldn't help but be awed by the wonderful storytelling and precise description Rowling uses. She is fantastic writer and even if you didn't like the book, you cannot leave without appreciating Rowling's gift as a writer.

author: Sheila Quercetti
title: 2 stars
body: I thought the characters were unmemorable and weak in character.  The overall tone of the book was filled with despair and hopelessness.

author: C. Basura
title: Not Harry Potter
body: I hated every character. Not a single happy person in the book. Is this a look at her previous life before she wrote HP?

author: buggles52
title: Sorry, don't read Potter
body: I can't compare this to a Harry Potter book, but I can say it was a great ADULT read.  The characters were exquisitely developed and Ms. Rowling does not shy away from the darker life/death issues.  You will laugh and cry - but please read it yourself before you decide to let your teen read it.

author: HB-Rizzle
title: Hit And Miss *Spoiler*
body: So, I knew this was meant to be a more serious, adult book, and I didn't compare it to Harry Potter's success. I read it like I would any other book, not judging it for what the author has written before. Unfortunately, it's a hit and miss for me.

author: Carolyn
title: Disappointing
body: Having been elevated to another dimension reading Ms Rowling's Harry Potter series, I was disappointed with her adult offering in The Casual Vacancy.  The whole book read more like the smutty offerings of the British tabloid press.  Ok for some maybe, but personally not very entertaining.  I kept hoping the storyline would improve...  Can't believe it made the best seller list.

author: Thai Di
title: Ehh...
body: I am a great fan of JK Rowling's writing.  She tells a story and she can tell it well.

author: Linn B. Eldred
title: Dissapointed
body: I did not even try to listen to it after reading a short way into the book.

author: Deanna J. Royal
title: Depressing!
body: Sad, angry,desperate people bent on hurting or besting each other.  The F word spills over almost every page.  A great disappointment after having enjoyed all the Harry Potter books, loving J.K's imagination.

author: joann mcilvain
title: Horrible, stick to childrens books
body: I was very excited since I loved all of the Harry Potters books. I do not like reading books with bad language for one thing which surprised me from her but the story was just so awful and the characters sounded like they were from some criminal minds episode. I took it back after reading a third of it and got my money back to spend on something worth reading.

author: Hilary
title: The creepy vacancy?
body: Truthfully, I was really excited about this book because I was such a Harry Potter fan. But this book got a little creepy at times and I'm still not quite sure what the message was. Rowling does a good job with her descriptors and painting a picture of who her characters are, I just didn't feel an underlying message. Worth a read though - certainly a different side to our Harry Potter author.

author: UNLV
title: Pretty Good Book So Far
body: Author is one of the reasons for this purchase.  There are many extensive discriptions in this book that allows reader to vizualize the plot.  Easy read as well.

author: S. A. Hudgens
title: Love JK Rowling but miss the 'magic' of Harry Potter
body: I love JK Rowling's writing and she does an excellent job in this book.  However, while I knew better than to expect Harry Potter repeats and/or similarities, I did not particularly like the characters in this book, nor did I especially care about what happened to them.  I missed the wry humor, the creativity, and how easily it was to be drawn into Harry Potter's magical world.  I will continue to read anything written by Rowling because I admire and respect her work . . . .just a bit disappointed in this one

author: Kim
title: Not sure where to begin
body: After reading the HP novels, I was anticipating the next work of art by JK Rowling.  What I found is a novel that seems to be written for the sole purpose of shock value.  It is a complete departure from the writing style, symbolism, and wholesomeness of her previous works.  The only point I see in this book at all is that Rowling wants to distance herself as far away from the HP novels as possible in an effort to avoid being pigeon holed.  If that was her purpose, she has succeeded.  I found the plot's cohesiveness to be lacking.  The story has a very confusing start with introducing characters with very little connection to each other.  Over time there is some connection, but as a whole the plot and characters are not developed enough despite the staggering amount of pages in this novel.  The last couple of chapters seem to be hurriedly wrapping things up so that the book can have an ending, but the ending is in itself very lacking.  There were enough f-bombs to sink the Titanic, and the amount of time spent on pedophilia, drug addiction, rape, incest, adultery, teenage promiscuity, self-cutting, etc. don't serve much purpose in the novel.  Again I think Rowling just sat down one day and said to herself "I bet if I write about all the crappiest things that happen in society, they will never say that all I write is children's books."  Again if this is what she was thinking, she succeeded.  But I would have rather her goal to have been to write an awesome novel that doesn't need adult language and themes to make it sensational.

author: Deb
title: Better than expected
body: Based on some of the other comments here and reviews of the book my expectations were not too high, but it really enjoyed it.  A great group of characters who were very human and believable, and an interesting socially relevant plot.  If you are expecting Harry Potter you may be disappointed, but I enjoyed this exploration of Muggle land.

author: Jay H Hoogeveen
title: More "Vacancy" than Substance
body: I did not even cone close to liking this book.  I detested the language, the so-called plot, and the writing in general.  Rowling should stay with her genre and bask in the sun where she deserves to be due to her marvelous harry Potter series, instead of wallow in this muck.

author: Caza2uk
title: Great
body: Despite the reviews I read about how disappointing the book was I still thought I would give it a go; and I'm glad I did!

author: MEC
title: Great, great book
body: I am one of the few persons who has not read HP. Therefore, I was not able to compare it with anything from her.  All I could say is that I love it. The characters are perfectly described, you can truly recognise the characters in our society... And it truly made me think a lot, how we are all related and connected. Any action from us  will always have an impact on our society, no matter how small this action might be. I absolutely recommend this book.

author: Maryam
title: magic of the words and not magical words
body: I read too many negative reviews before I buy the book. I bought it anyway and good that I did. but there are some points to take before you buy the book:

author: G-Force
title: Worst book I've ever read...period.
body: Slow, tedious, dull, poorly written, boring, unfocused, disorganized, migraine-inducing...there simply aren't enough adjectives to describe how bad this book is.

author: Cynthia Harmon
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: This book is so awful I can't finish reading it.  I can't remember the last time I couldn't finish a book.

author: A. W. Callaghan
title: Real life portrayal. Not for the faint hearted or non thinking reader
body: Seriously entertaining in exposing real human foibles, stark realities and fanciful desires.

author: Taylor
title: Just bad all around
body: It was just really awful. I couldn't even finish it. There seemed to be no plot. It was scattered all over the place. Two stars.

author: Marsha E. Stodolski
title: Engaging writing but depressing and unrealistic treatment of the subject matter.
body: This book presents a fictional small town full of petty, miserable people who practice petty politics, are frustrated in love and are devoid of altruism - except for the character who died and is mourned as the would-be savior now gone. The dead saviour had made an attempt to help some of the public-housing kids living amongst drug-users, etc.

author: Fred V. Lowe Jr.
title: We're Not in Hogwarts Anymore (Alas)
body: Self-mutilation, drug and acohol abuse, child neglect, child abuse, child sexual abuse, abject poverty, crimes of various sorts, various stages and kinds of infidelity and betrayal, several personality disorders, violent family conflict, even gross obesity and virulent acne -- what on earth has Ms. Rowling missed?  And all in a small English village with a not very credible veneer of propriety.

author: Janet Donavan
title: I felt like I knew these people
body: I liked this book a lot,  probably because I like good characterizations and while reading this book, I really got to know the people J.K. Rowling was writing about.  They felt like real people to me.  If you are looking for action or policemen or beautiful, rich women and handsome, rich men, this is not the book for you.

author: Pat Vokes
title: Very disappointing
body: I did finish the book but only because I was hoping that something good would happen.  When I read a book, I like to escape everyday ordinary life and be swept away from my normal reality.  All the characters in Casual Vacancy had many flaws, there was no hero or heroine, it was tragic, very sad and depressing.  I bought it because I loved of the Potter series and I was bitterly disappointed.

author: Paula Smith
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: It was about the dumbest book I have ever read. Would not read her books again, She needs to stick with fantasy

author: Tashie
title: The magic continues
body: It is unusual for a book to kill off the hero in the first few pages, but somehow Rowling manages it when her arguably `main character' Barry Fairbrother collapses and dies in the very first chapter. It is the effects of Barry's death on his seemingly idyllic hometown of Pagford which open the windows into the inner workings of the town's people.

author: Arielle
title: Too many, too much, too little
body: I had high hopes for this book, but I was disappointed. Rowling has a gift for exposition and creating a vivid, believable world - as we saw with Harry Potter (which is the only mention I'll make of her famous series). Her flair for detailed explanation did not serve her in the setting of "The Casual Vacancy" because the reader already knows this world and she didn't use it to her advantage in relation to character development. Rowling repeated herself over and over while trying to fill-in the characters' personalities without varying the message or delivery. I didn't think the book picked up and found its plot until at least 70% of the way through. It was dull and seemed to be more about bashing a point in about the need for welfare than any recognizable plot. Too many characters, too much exposition, too little action.

author: Sue
title: The casual vacancy
body: I gave my niece three books per her request and she loved all of them. This site should have a designation if the purchase was a gift...

author: Margaret Crow
title: A little tedious
body: This book is ok, its just not really that good.  The characters are not that interesting, nor is the story.

author: Molly Hassig
title: Great
body: Very good, difficult to put down. A mature book with a great plot and lots of twists. Definitely recommending to others.

author: WON
title: Harry Potter and Casual Vacancy Are Connected
body: Casual Vacancy is the story of the people Harry Potter was trying to escape when he went to Mugwort. You can easily turn this into a Harry Potter Prequel, for example, just by adding some budding wizardry and magic to the mix. A sort of what happened before the kids came to Mugwort. In fact, the story itself could be a Harry Potter book by just changing all the characters to magical fantasy ones. All the themes are still there, except no magic. So, when people say it's a big change I don't think so. Many of the catalysts in the plot lines are moved along by children. Life and death, good and evil, venal and carnal, petty and profound -- St. Michael stepping on evil, parental/adult power and chidren's reactions. And on and on. Instead of the fantasy characters and charicatures of the Harry Potter books, she decided go with "reality". Instead of being able to escape into fantasy (and then from the pan to the fire anyway) kids and characters were stuck with reality and all the fantasies they could create right there.

author: linenmaven
title: Definitely Not Harry Potter!
body: This was a breakaway from past books for Rowling. Very dark and disturbing, but not in a good way. Well written, but not very enjoyable.

author: YJ, Detroit
title: Didn't want to set down; sorry to finish
body: One "rule" of writing is to not hop from one character's head to another and back within a scene - unless you're extremely skilled. Rowling does it so beautifully. Also, every single one of her characters - and there are a lot of them - are so REAL. The ending was bittersweet, of course. But the last line makes me think that Rowling was worried about leaving the reader with too good a feeling about the future of Pagford and its residents, so she casually suggests that the congregation was unwilling to see some or other truth or something. One thing about the editing: All the stories cohered wonderfully. The book was a great length. The characters' arcs were satisfying. But the proofreading wasn't as near-perfect as it was in her previous novels.

author: Karen DeVerna
title: boring
body: I did not like Casual Vacancy at all.  The characters were extremely unlikeable, the story was boring, and it was very depressing.  It took me forever to plow through this book.

author: Kerri M
title: Brilliant
body: I was enthralled by this book from start to finish. Rowling is a brilliant writer and deft at creating characters who feel so real, you actually miss them when the book is finished and want to know what happens next for them. Each character in this book is unique, and she gives each one depth and vividness. Some are hateful; some you root for. But each of them is real and complex. This book is not full of action, but rather is almost entirely character-driven. And yet I found it fast-paced, and I couldn't put it down.

author: BettyAnn
title: If she hadn't written Harry Potter...
body: Slow moving and seemingly pointless story.  I bought this book because of the immense popularity and success of her Harry Potter series. This is a disappointment.

author: Ms. G.K.Cleary
title: Disappointed read
body: I bought this book having enjoyed her childrens books (Harry Potter series). I feel that she has not crossed over well to writing adult novels. It felt disjointed and not an enjoyable read.

author: BeautyBoss
title: Loved it...
body: Just finished reading this book and I know many people are criticizing it but I really enjoyed it. I fell in love with all the characters. The only thing is I feel at the end of the book the author was in a rush to finish the story.

author: June Campbell
title: Darned Good Story Telling
body: I have never read J.K. Rowling's books before, but if she writes another adult novel, I will be lining up to get it. I loved this book.  To be perfectly frank, I didn't like it at first. I was reading the Large Print edition and I read at least 100 pages before I was into the story. I contemplated giving up, and I am so glad I didn't. Once the story caught me, I was hooked. The British wit is priceless. The story is character driven and despite their obvious flaws, you really care about most of the individuals who make up this book.  The book's ending is one that should be kept secret, so I will not spoil it for those who have not read this book. If you like novels, read this book. It's good.

author: Tatie
title: Disappointing and a Waste of Time
body: The Casual Vacancy starts off slow and never picks up speed.  The many characters are hard to keep straight, and after a while you stop trying because none of them are likeable anyway.  Many side notes in parentheses go on for pages where a paragraph would suffice (and at 500 pages there is certainly room to cut).  It seems like Rowling felt she had to prove herself capable of writing an adult novel and resorted to big words and lofty, unnecessary descriptions.  Once you get through the tedium and reach what could have been a decent climax, it ends up being depressing and making the characters even more vile.  What a huge disappointment this book is.

author: Jo-Anne S
title: Another day
body: This is familiar JK style of writing, descriptive and a  familiiarity of characters.  The story moves through the details of the various lives of these unlikeable, dissatisfied, and self centred characters.  I did not connect or empathise with any of the characters so really didn't invest in their journey, so the unsatisfying ending kind of felt satisfying.

author: peter minchin
title: The Casual Vacancy by JK Rowling
body: I was a bit disappointed in this book. I think JK Rowling has spent so long writing for young people she is stuck there. There are a lot of teenagers in the book, and they dominated the story. I am not interested in reading about teenage boys masturbating or having sex in strange places. The premise of the story is good, but I think the author lost sight of the fact that it was for adults.

author: k
title: a good read
body: I liked the way she developed the characters and their reasons for their reactions to each other. Quite insightful into human realtionships

author: LInda M. Graham
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Rowling is a master at creating and describing characters. The village of people she created in A Casual Vacancy captured my interest and i couldn't put the book down. Those who don't like this book are looking for more Harry Potter (based on the reviews i read) and want more fantasy stories. I think Rowling is an excellent writer and hope she continues to write more about the real world.

author: CH
title: Grtty side of reality
body: This woman has such a gift of writing. This is not a cheerful drama It's filled with adult themes, although it spares us from gory details.

author: Hammy
title: Do not listen to those cursed green one stars
body: this is way better than tha cursed jaer hell harry potter. I loved this good gleaming book.  shall curse the one and two and any cursing three four five stars right back. be reasonable this is such a good boook. gltoonlyknottelling you hell before you crack you will never demolish my family they will livr forever you woll be cursed we our family will never be cursed. you have no power. to never make me curse never

author: French Freak
title: A Worthy Read
body: Like so many others, I bought this just to see what on Earth JKR would come up with as an "adult" novel since her work for children was so incredibly inventive. As I made my way through the first two or three chapters, I was starting to feel really disappointed - there wasn't much in the way of off-the-wall creations or even action; we were just looking in on the day-to-day lives of normal (and in some cases downright dull) people. I actually put the book down for a day or two while deciding whether it was worth finishing. Not presuming to speak for anyone but myself, I have to wonder if this might be a common problem: we half expect to find ourselves reading something like a "Harry Potter for Grown Ups", and that is NOT what this novel is. It's almost the exact opposite of HP - where that series was all fantasy and invention, this book is a searing close-up on reality. And in the end, that's what kept me reading it. Rowling has an amazing sense of what motivates people, and a sadly accurate view of how often self-interest trumps the common good. Some reviewers have said these characters aren't likable, and I know what they mean - it's all but impossible to find someone to root for in this mess! Then again, if I'm being honest, their imperfections and shameful faults made them more relatable to me. I HOPE I'm not as morally bereft as some of the more pronounced villains who represent the extreme fringes of bad decision making, but the majority of these unlikable characters are just lost, or searching for they-aren't-sure-what, and taking wrong turns as they try to create a better life for themselves and their families. I felt sorry for them because I know how hard it can be to feel fulfilled, or how hard it can be to look yourself in the eye after at the end of the day. And that's only speaking of the individual characters - the larger storyline of the haves vs. the have-nots was equally sad, shameful,...and accurate. It didn't make me feel warm and fuzzy, but it kept my attention and made me think about myself and my responsibility to improve the world around me.

author: ralph rogers
title: very good
body: This book took you into British culture and living that no other has done The characters was very different  from one I m used to in other books.

author: Mrs Peggy M Wilson
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: It was a little too much like a British soap for my liking.  I was expecting something a little less predictable.

author: Ellen Carr
title: J K ROWLING - THE CASUAL VACANCY
body: I found this story line tedious and very repetitive. I found the storyline extremely boring. I think Rowling should stay with fantasy which she is exceptional at. I would not recommend this to anyone and wish I could get a refund.

author: ghiltebrand
title: Great for expats living in the UK
body: JK Rowling has something to say about small town culture and the petty mindedness of humanity in general.  In the first few chapters, it can feel very offensive. But if you stick with it, there is something beautiful there as well, and a message for all of us to look beyond our own concerns and empathize with people in other circumstances.

author: Jona mcnamee
title: Sounded familiar
body: The language is somewhat harsh at times. The book was a book club idea. Grew up in a town just like one in the book. Poor side of town with people you didn't associate with in high school. Dated a boy from across the tracks, he turned out to be my best friend and we shared many wonderful memories. He didn't have an easy life and his life ended very much like Krystal .

author: Gaspo
title: Worth the time
body: This is slow to start but creeps up on you.  It reminded me of Mark Haddon novels but with much more to say on the social structures of England.

author: Linda Lipson
title: Save me from living in Pagford!
body: It would have been nice to have some likable people (ok there were 1 or 2) besides all those jealous, hypocricitical characters!  A fast read with decent writing.

author: SKC
title: Stay with this one!  The crazy times await
body: First off, I have never read a single Harry Potter book, nor seen any of the movies. When this book won on Greatreads in the fiction category, I thought I would give it a read.  I was also curious, about this book knowing that JK Rowlings was a terrific writer and this would be a very different style than Harry Potter.

author: mojojojo
title: Harry Potter Writer
body: This is well-writen book, however, there are too many vulgar words for my liking.  I think she could have done well with the book without these words.  I know she said it was for adults to read.  Aw well, it was quick reading and the plot was somewhat predictable.  Worth reading.

author: Richard Rutkin
title: Didn't even bother finishing
body: Really disappointed.

author: Jan
title: A Casual Vacancy
body: The story of what happened to members of a small community after the death of one of its prominent members is gripping and harshly realistic. It brought back memories of my social worker days as well as highlighting the problems face by so many of the Special Ed students I currently work with.

author: mighty_power7
title: It may not be Harry Potter, but the magic of her writing is still there
body: I think a majority of the negative reviews were due to people expecting Harry Potter, and I thought JK Rowling had made it clear from the beginning that Harry Potter this is not. That being said, I can still see hints of some HP characters in the characters from this book (namely, Vernon and Petunia Dursley as Harold and Shirley Mollison), but overall, this book is vastly different. This book is certainly macabre (but so was Harry Potter), but it is a real page-turner in my opinion. The characters were very well defined, and very relatable - I think I can name a person in my real life that is similar to each of the characters. This book will especially resonate with you if you live in/come from a small town. The pettiness of small-town politics was spot on, and how everyone knows everyone, word spreads fast, etc. It takes place in Britain, but it could have just as easily been Michigan.

author: sully481
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I think J.K Rowling should stick to writing for young people.  I had a hard time getting through this book.  At times, I felt

author: 70Randy
title: Too many characters
body: Loved all of the Potter books especially the earlier ones. Tried to get through about 100 pages of this but the number of ill-defined characters left me behind. Trying to sort them out became too much for me.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Not Harry
body: Strange story. I was compelled to read it as Rowling's writing is always good. But this is the most unlikable collection of characters, I've ever run across. :Like Martha Grimes, it seems she's a one character writer.

author: Rebeccca
title: Stick with it
body: Takes a bit to get into it, but turns into a great book. By the end you have a bunch of characters that you feel you know.

author: Dooley
title: Now I'm a fan of J.K. Rowling
body: This is a good book.  I was so pleasantly surprised at her writing skills.  I had her sterotyped with Harry Potter and sort of expected that mode of writing.  Mrs. Rowiling kept me reading constantly and at the same time I was worried what I was going to do when I finished the book because then I would not have anything to look forward to.  There is such a cast of characters and your feel as if you know each and everyone of them.

author: Sarah
title: Blown Away
body: I grew up reading Harry Potter and when my 19 year old self discovered that J.K. Rowling wrote another book, I knew right then and there that I must read the The Casual Vacancy.

author: Georg Hofmeyr
title: A really deep read
body: JKR did it for me. This book conveys several hard and uncomfortable social messages at different levels, but the delivery tone is light and witty - an irresistable combination. I especially enjoyed the richness of the characters which  provides an often disturbing  glimpse into life in small town Brittain - it reminded me of John Steinbeck's Cannery Row. Read it.

author: karen
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I purchased the J K Rowling book the last of Sept and didn't get around to starting it until yesterday. Kindle purchase. It is a filthy book and so negative. I know it is to late to return, but I would like to register a protest. When I got to the page that had the f word on it three times, I stopped reading it. What an awful book from an author I deemed to be safe.  What an unworthy effort from a great author.  I gave it one star because the software would not let me out without at least one.  It is unworthy of even one.

author: G. Starr
title: not Harry Potter...
body: a little disappointing...lots of characters that are easily confused...was hoping for more descriptive writing...she painted such vivid scenes in the Harry Potter books...

author: V. Blair
title: downbeat, even bitter, but fascinating
body: If you insist on a happy ending, do not read this book.  If you insist on sympathetic characters you can relate to, do not read this book.  But if you are intrigued by the idea of getting J.K. Rowling's caustic take on English village life, The Casual Vacancy will pull you in with a cast of characters who are highly varied in their selfish and opportunistic reactions to the death of, apparently, the only decent man in the village.  In truth, there are a couple of teenagers and a junkie who will spark some sympathy, despite their own bad behavior, because they are arguably more sinned against than sinning.  I found myself caring what would happen to them, and even what would become of some of the more venal characters.  Most were entirely believable, although occasional unmotivated cruelty by adults sometimes rang untrue.  Involving right up to the, you guessed it, bitter end.

author: ra in ca
title: I wanted to like it
body: Having read most of the HP books, I find J.K. Rowling to be one of the best (if not THE best) story-tellers of our time.  So I was excited when I bought "The Casual Vacancy." I wanted so badly to like this book. But I didn't. In fact, I disliked it so much that I had to force myself to finish reading it.  Sorry Ms. Rowling--I still think you are an incredible talent--I just don't like this book.

author: Paula Ferrell
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: The storyline is superb, but the whole language and situation is definately R rated.  I was fully engaged nnc couldn't put it down!

author: J. Marvin
title: Horrible Book
body: I thoroughly enjoyed JK Rowlings series Harry Potter and was antipating the arrival of this book Casual Vacancy.  What a huge disappointment!  I tried to read this book, even skipped to the end but could NOT finish it.  It is filled with profanity and sexual content that disappoints.  I find this to be a book of filth and will NOT read or recommend it to anyone.  I hope that JK Rowling realizes that it isn't filth or profanity that sells to adults but rather a well written book, with a good plot.  Shame on JK Rowling for advertizing this as a book for adults, it's not fit for anyone.

author: Kindle Customer
title: A good read
body: All the British language was a bit distracting from time to time, The story line was interesting with enough twists and turns to keep one interested.

author: Jennie Becker
title: Looking great!
body: Thanks! The book arrived before Christmas and my daughter was THRILLED to have it as a gift....it was in perfect shape!!!

author: Jen
title: Casual Vacancy
body: May be because I'm not British I just didn't love this book. I didn't even finish it. Here's to hoping she wrotes more quality books in the future

author: Buffster
title: The casual vacancy
body: Love Jk, so bit disappointed, not finished book yet but finding it very confusing, too many characters to keep track of! :(

author: Marc Long
title: Good
body: A little too jumpy at times but always interesting. Completely not what I expected from this author but good to see a different perspective in her writing.

author: Critical Cosmologist
title: The human price of economic polarization, detraditionalization, neoliberalization
body: Read in two days. Could not put down. Insightful about psychological neurosis of social relations in everyday life, the loss of communalism in the face of aggressive market centered individualism which has commodified everything and made it so we have no one to turn to, a dire condition that hurts vulnerable children the most.for those who are interested in personal life under late capitalist modernity.

author: ReviewsMatter!
title: not an easy read, but a wonderful read
body: (yes, I am a Harry Potter fan)

author: Mary L. Cherba
title: JK Rowling surprise
body: I was not a fan of the Harry Potter series so was skeptical what to expect. But I enjoyed this book. JK Rowling has a fluid style that keeps you and the characters engaged. Definitely for adult reading.

author: Filmmaster 6
title: Should I buy this book
body: This is defiantly like his 50 shades of gray. It is slow moving and not very riveting. I would not rush to buy this work.

author: Bill Lescher
title: Great writing, bad characters, bad plot
body: I still love and respect Ms. Rowling's writing skills, but I just didn't like this story.  It was sort of like being forced to interview a handful of small-town families who were only allowed to reveal their dark, negative, petty sides.  I couldn't like or root for a single character.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Good, not great
body: A good casual read.  A bit heavy on liberal leaning politics for my personal taste.  Slow start, better toward the end.

author: Carlos
title: Good read, entertaining and overall enjoyable
body: I read all HP books, and bought this book more out of curiosity than anything else. Even if it is no literature classic, it is quite enjoyable!

author: Amie McCracken
title: Amazing in its own right
body: It took me a while to get to The Casual Vacancy by J.K. Rowling. I was so worried. I had seen so many reviews that didn't particularly shine a very good light. But then I decided to just dive in. I like literary fiction, and I was dying to see if Rowling could prove herself. I had always said, seven books is cool, but she would really prove herself as a writer when she wrote something outside of the Harry Potter world. (At least to me.) So here was the proof. And man did she do well.

author: Ginny
title: A great read
body: Rowling makes all the characters in this book instantly memorable.  She makes each character come alive on the page so that I felt that I really knew each one.  It was difficult to put this book down, and I probably will read it again.

author: Laura Metzger
title: Good book but not great
body: I like the book, but a little slow in getting to the point.  Ending was so-so.  I love J.K. Rowling but this was not her best work.  Worth the read though

author: Kathryn J. Riss
title: Trashy novel - don't waste your time or money!
body: I was extremely disappointed by J.K. Rowling's new novel.  Unlike her Harry Potter series, which had interesting and admirable characters, mystery, exciting plots, and an overall theme of good vs. evil, this book has NO good characters, NO interesting plot (or plot at all, actually), and is full of filthy language.

author: Terry
title: I hated this book.
body: I wanted to love it because i devoured the Harry Potter books but this was dark and depressing and had NO redeeming qualities. I had to finish it because I thought something good would happen but it never did. Yuck!

author: Paulita
title: Strong Message -- Needed more Emotion
body: Well, I did it. I finished all 503 pages of J.K. Rowling's first adult  novel, The Casual Vacancy.

author: Carolyn Wheeler
title: Not Harry Potter
body: A much darker novel than the Harry Potter series, but Ms. Rowling keeps the reader involved and intrigued.  A very good read!

author: R. M. Palmer
title: Disappointed
body: I think I expected too much from this author.  After a thrilling Harry Potter series, I expected this to be a top notch read.

author: Irene Rogers
title: The Casual Vacancy by J.K. Rowling
body: I should have read more about this book before choosing it.  I haven't finished it yet so it may get better.  I don't like some of the off color language.

author: Pulchrakia
title: Great Read!
body: I don't doubt for a second that this book has gotten many negative reviews because it was written by J.K. Rowling.  I've seen complaints about the bad language and inappropriate scenes in this book, but seriously - if this book had been written by anyone else, no one would've cared.  Plus, the language isn't that bad.  I mean, I don't think it's unexpected for a character with a serious drug addiction to use foul language, right?  You cannot compare this book to the Harry Potter series or expect Rowling to handle both stories the same way.  I think J.K. Rowling does a great job at weaving together a story with many different characters and subplots.  One thing Rowling does better than many authors is really make you feel like you're just as involved in the story as the characters are.  It started off a bit slow but that's not completely atypical of novels, and there are a lot of characters which takes some getting used to.  But once you do, the story picks up and really takes off.  I never wanted to put it down!  Rowling can write about politics and family dramas just as well as she can write about wizards - not an easy feat.  Can't wait until she writes another one!

author: Laurie L. Marsh
title: Fine Qualtiy Recording CD but didn't like the book
body: Am a huge Harry Potter/J.K. Rowling fan so even though the condition of the CDs were in great shape the content of the book was hugely disappointing.  Lots of foul language.  Unhappy ending and much sadness.

author: AB
title: not very interesting
body: writing is good of course, but the whole story is not that interesting and took too long to get to important parts.

author: Rainey
title: Surprised at how much I loved this book.
body: I was surprised at how much I loved this book.

author: Ella I. Williamson
title: Life was just too miserable for everyone
body: One of my children liked it.  I might like it better another time.  Just have read too many dysfunctional books of late.

author: julie fitzgerald
title: Great read
body: Slow at first as she builds on all the characters, halfway through I could not put it down! Depressing but good!

author: sky searcher
title: Not to my taste
body: If you like stories about petty, small-minded individuals and their hormonally and psychologically developing, mid-teenage children in a small English town, you may like this book. The youngsters are better delineated than their parents, but are still rather two-dimensional. I had no sympathy with any of the characters. There's not much plot--the novel is mostly concerned with how this handful of families reacts to the opening of a seat on the parish council (the "casual vacancy") due to the sudden death of one member.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Just ok
body: Lots of characters. Convoluted. Would not have finished it except it was my book club choice. Enjoyed the setting, good description of some characters

author: DeniseH
title: Harry Potter it ain't.
body: Knew from reviews that she was departing from anything remotely close to previous serious. But she should have stuck to that genre. There was not one character that you could cheer for or hope something good would happen to.

author: Lynda Hathaway
title: No Fun
body: I did not enjoy this novel.  I could not get into the plot.  Not my kind of book at this time.

author: Jane G. McKenna
title: Fascinating interplay of characters
body: I bought this book after reading the excerpt online.  I was curious to see if J.K. Rowling could write an adult novel.  I was very impressed.  It's well written.  The descriptions of the English countryside are perfect and her characters very believable.

author: sole sister
title: disappointing
body: tedious and long winded

author: Carole
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: This book was tedious.  It was my book club's January choice so I "pushed" myself to complete it.  Would never recommend it.

author: Rachel Moffett
title: Great read!
body: I'll admit, I preordered The Casual Vacancy simply because it was written by J.K. Rowling. Being a self-proclaimed Harry Potter nerd, I expected this book to be another Rowling masterpiece (even though I knew it would be nothing like Potter). I was pretty disappointed when all the negative reviews started rolling in, which made me wish I had waited to see what people were saying about it before I made the purchase.
