This book was not cheap for a Kindle version! And I was still regretting the purchase once I started reading the book.

author: sumu
title: We all know she can write!
body: Well done J.K.  She has proven to me that her "magic" with words is still there and quite grown up.

author: Alicia M Stokes
title: Boring.
body: I've never read the Harry potter series so I had nothing really to go with her writing style. My boyfriend kept harping on me to read Harry potter but I refused because I've already seen the movies. So, naturally I'm pretty excited to read this book once I downloaded it. However, the first couple of pages I felt like she kept jumping around too much. I understand the background information needs to be made, but after reading the first 50 pages of the book, i put it down. I've had enough. This book just couldn't hold my attention. Maybe I will give this book another try here in a month or so, but right now....I have no desire.

author: Sylvia Nguyen
title: A Most Disappointing Read (spoiler alert)
body: I finished The Casual Vacancy and all I can say is that I absolutely hated it. The only good thing about it was that it ended and that it's not a series so I don't have to ever think about it again. I'm really happy I didn't end up buying it like I thought I would, only because of J.K. Rowling's name on the cover.

author: Reader
title: A waste of time
body: Very disappointing and a complete waste of precious time.  Not close to the great story telling of the Potter series.  Hopefully this is the first and last of this effort.

author: R. Akers
title: For my book club
body: The story started a little slow and there was some predictability in the plot.  However, overall, a nice job from this author

author: carol
title: Not a great read
body: I was very disappointed in the book.  Once I got a handle on the all of the characters (there is around 22) the book seemed dragged on and on.  The premise of the book is great but it could of been written  a 100 pages shorter

author: Miss Aries
title: The Never Ending Book
body: This was one of the longest books that I have ever read.  I agree with another reader that there were too many characters.  I knew from the first page that I was not going to like this book but I decided to finish anyway.  I want the seven days back that it took to read this book.

author: Rose
title: Save your money and your kids from reading this!
body: This is my first review on a book, but I felt I had to let people know that they shouldn't let their kids read this book!  It is meant for adults only, and even adults will find it too much of a bad thing.  Very depressing, lots of foul language, sex, smoking, drugs, truancy, lying, stealing; pretty much all the things you'd never want your kids to do.  There's not one part of this storyline that turns out good in the end.  I'm so saddened that she would choose to include all of these things knowing her biggest followers are KIDS!!  Very poor judgment.

author: Dorothy Teets
title: casual vacancy
body: Vey well written and interesting story and an interesting cast of characters.  Story kept me interested and I did not want it to end

author: Brooke Dowling
title: Best price I've found for my kindle app on the mini iPad
body: Excellent author, great buy, good price. :) amazon is wonderful for things like this. Will continue to shop here for books and more.

author: Gail G.
title: Take your time and take notes!
body: J.K. Rowling's first effort for adults is a resounding success. The only caveat: go slow and take notes for the first few chapters. The story starts slowly, too, and there are so many characters, you might forget who's married to whom. The plot line and the way the characters interact and intertwine is worthy of a Ken Follett novel. And it all comes to a crashing head in the last chapters. Brava, Ms. Rowling!

author: Donna H. Wolfe
title: Disappointing
body: I couldn't get through it, it was so dull and had so many characters that made little or no impression on me enough to remmeber them. Very disappointing.

author: McKea 1835
title: Miserable
body: I enjoyed Rowling's writing; her vocabulary and ability to set the scene or mood is entertaining.  But her miserable people in their miserable lives wore me down.

author: Gil Osborne Woodstrom
title: Sad
body: Maybe it was my mood, but I found this book so sad. Not one character in it had any joy in their life. Very depressing but we'll written.

author: M. E. Mathews
title: Complex, real characters, unfortunate lack of intriguing plot
body: To be frank, I was impressed by the complex and true-to-life characters but disappointed in the plot.  I think Rowling has perfected the art of third person omniscient, of which I am a huge fan.  However, I found the book dry, long, and boring... yet still worth reading.  So, three stars.  I look forward to her next book.  The HP books have brilliant plots, so I know she's got it in her.  Maybe her next work will have the best of both worlds.

author: Anita Schlosser
title: Flat read
body: Skip this one it's very dull, there is nothing very interesting in the story line I kept expecting something to happen but it's about boring people I just couldn't care about.

author: Amie Bullard
title: Not what I was expecting.
body: I pre-ordered this book, and was excited that Rowling had written something new. I quickly became disappointed with this book. The book takes way too much time to start to get interesting. There is way too much time spent on developing characters that, honestly, didn't need to really be developed. I found it laborious to read about the towns, and found myself wanting to finish the book just so it would be done. I can respect the detail that she put into the lives of the kids, and thought it was bold of Rowling to touch on such hard issues (especially with her fame being made on children's books), however, I don't feel that the book was as brazen as it should have (or could have) been. Rowling's message is lost in too many words, about too many things that weren't really important.

author: KMT
title: Not great
body: She should probably stick to wizards and fantasy. There were no characters I cared about, they were all self absorbed and not particularly likeable.

author: Black Plum
title: Surprisingly Not So Bad
body: I must say that I really didn't expect much from J.K. Rowling's first adult novel. The plot sounded boring, and the first few chapters were extremely off-putting. But it actually wasn't half bad, though certainly not as good as Harry Potter. When the aforementioned Barry Fairbrother dies, the seemingly idyllic town of Pagford is thrown into turmoil. There's tons of controversy over this district called "the Fields", full of drug addicts, which many think shouldn't be part of Pagford. Though it seems like a typical English village, Pagford is home  to some pretty nasty people. On the surface, the plot seems unremarkable, but really, the novel was interesting, though also slow, in parts.

author: Steph
title: Worth the Read... Worth 5 Stars
body: If you are looking for an uplifting novel, then this really isn't it. The characters are mostly all insecure or unlikeable or hypocrites or just plain sad, but that's what makes this novel so great. It doesn't present any one perfect character but instead a bevy of very real people who are quite imperfect. They have the faults that many of us can recognize within ourselves or acknowledge in people we know (even if we turn a blind eye to it most of the time). I felt as though I knew all of the characters so very well by the end of the book, and yes, I hated some of them, felt nothing for a few, but had a good deal of sympathy or at least understanding for the rest. You know that something bad is going to happen, but you are kept guessing who it might happen to because so many of the lives in the small village of Pagford are so messed up and teetering on the edge of disaster. What does occur by the end of the novel forces certain veils to be lifted and certain truths to be exposed, causing some of the characters to change for the better while others go on being their same (if not more) unlikeable selves. I'm quite glad I didn't let all the negative reviews keep me from this book and this amazing author.

author: Jackie
title: preordered book as i am a Harry Potter Fan
body: definitely not what i was expecting. it is a little boring hard to get into it. as a harry potter fan was expecting more

author: shellseeker
title: A Now Book
body: This story describes, almost perfectly, our time and culture.  I love the way characters are developed from their own points of view as well as from other characters opinions of them.

author: Amy K
title: Huge Harry Potter Fan
body: I gave this a lower rating because it took me very long to read. I usually get through books pretty quickly. It is a good book, but it is NOT Harry Potter. It is very difficult to read a book by J.K. Rowling and not have Harry in it.

author: Lynn
title: BIG DISAPPOINTMENT!
body: Not the typical Rowlings book, Guess I was hoping for a  "Harry Potter".  Just not a fan of her new genre. Definately not a page turner and not sure if I'm gonna finish it, cuz I need to reread the beginning to remember what's going on.

author: Shelley Cataldo
title: Tom Hollander nails the audio
body: I finished this book several days ago and haven't been able to stop thinking about it.  A big reason for my enjoyment is the performance by Tom Hollander.  I must admit, I was disappointed to find that it wasn't read by Jim Dale, whose reading of the Harry Potter books was beyond compare.  But he wouldn't have been right for this book.  Tom does the voices and accents superbly, and really made me feel strongly for Rowling's characters.  Several scenes brought me to sobs.

author: Elise Landais
title: Who do you think you are?
body: A very interesting look into the society today and maybe more important a look into yourself. Very well written as always.

author: Alan Hurst
title: Not Harry Potter
body: Very different read from an author I enjoy. Small town politics and small town gossip from a British point of view. I enjoyed the characters and the character development. An enjoyable read.

author: Michael A Smigel
title: Very Overrated
body: This book was very slow for the first 3/4's of the book.  Very soap-operish and I expected something better from this author.  It got better at the end, but I wouldn't recommend this book highly by any means.  Most of the characters were unlikeable and it mirrored too much of today's society where people are preoccupied with the wrong things in life and are oblivious to more important topics like their children and helping them to grow into worthy adults.

author: Belinda
title: Nice Change, Rowling
body: I thought I hated this book for the first half, but I'm glad I persisted. The ending really had me reeling, and I finally connected to the majority of the characters. I could see people I knew in some of them- scary but familiar.

author: Jessica H.
title: Interesting storyline
body: Casual vacancy has the good character development that we love and expect from Jk Rowling. I'm still reading the story but an enjoying it so far.

author: Elizabeth
title: Boring!
body: I gave up a third way in.  It took way to long to get into the story.  I just wanted to should "come on get on with it!"

author: Eleanor Deacon
title: Csual Vacancy was a disappointment
body: tHE BOOK A CASUAL VACANCY I WAS DISAPPOINTED i THINK SHE SHOULD STICK TO WRITING BOKS LIKE THE hARRY pOTTER SERIES

author: Kaylea Jayne Brooks
title: People Don't Understand Good Writing
body: Obviously, people can't see amazing writing if it slapped them in the face.  This book was crafted perfectly.  It is dark, I'll give them that, but it shows the underbelly of society in a small town, the politics, the hatred and apathy of people and how death affects them all.  It is tragic, but at the same time eye-opening.  I could identify with several of her characters, and they were all developed wonderfully.  People who couldn't get into it or couldn't understand it are missing the point.  This isn't meant to be a happy Harry Potter book.  It's an adult novel and it's about life.  Real life.  I guess I understand the book better because I, myself, have known tragedy, and I can relate to this.  It isn't boring to me, and the people aren't completely unlikable.  They're meant to be real people, and I commend J.K. Rowling for creating such a great story.  Her talent is immeasurable.  If you like Twilight, 50 Shades of Grey, or other terribly written, garbage literature, you probably won't like this.  It's actually good.

author: DSpizz
title: Disappointed to say the least
body: After Harry Potter, I was really looking forward to another book by J.K. Rowling but I really expected more.  This book had so many characters that didn't really amount anything and were nondescript.  The premise itself is really just insipid.  I'm sorry that I didn't like the novel more and am somewhat embarrassed to admit that I will probably read whatever she writes next but this one was very anti-climactic overall.

author: Mary
title: This book gets inside kids' heads!
body: At first the petty quick to judge mental dialogues of characters put me off.  Then going with the flow and allowing myself to perceive from adolescent perspective began make a significant and appreciative impact.  There are/were places within characters' developments when adult care and compassion might have made a difference in outcomes; but true to life adults too are absorbed in self, the esteem of the community and keeping up with the Jones-so-to-speak.  Ultimately the tale addresses the interior impulses of developing adolescents as well as the all-to-often casual vacancy of adult role models in the sometimes cruel dramas of teen angst.  If you are a parent, read this book and notice the cues we as adults give our teen age children who do notice the disparities between what we say and what we do.

author: Colleen F Dale
title: Good Read
body: Very good story, but moved a little slowly in the middle.  Would have benefitted from a little more editing and wordiness.

author: Chris Brunner
title: I really tried to like this
body: I have given this review a lot of thought. I have been on the fence as to just how I was going to rate this book, but then my wife said I should look at the books I have rated 3 stars and see if this would fit with those. The more I thought about it, the more I realized that I didn't enjoy this as much as any of the books I previously gave three stars. So this is why I gave it two.

author: J. Bailey
title: Terrible book!
body: I have never read a book with so much foul language, and there wasn't a single character that was likable.  It was very depressing, and wouldn't recommend it.

author: Real New Yorker
title: Really good book
body: Gave it four stars because I thought the ending was too abrupt, otherwise I really enjoyed it.  Even though the setting was England, it reflected the society we live in here as well.  It's not a pretty picture, but a real one none the less.  More people need to read it and maybe those that are unaware will become enlightened.  Unfortunately, those that are aware and just don't care or agree with the people of "Pagford" will get nothing from it.

author: Heidi G
title: Didn't hold my interest
body: Got through three of the discs but couldn't find enough interest to finish the book.  The characters just didn't interest me, despite my hope that they somehow snap out of the doldrums they are in.  And the thought of listening to the remaining 12 discs did not make me happy.  I was NOT put off by the language; instead, I thought it entirely appropriate to the story, to the grittiness of the lives  of the protagonists.  But the story didn't hold my interest.

author: pek256
title: I only read half.
body: I only read half but I found the story to be slow, uninteresting, hard to follow, lowbrow, and all of the major characters are boringly fiercely crazy.  The story is more boring and uninteresting than real life.

author: Linn Wehler
title: Good Book at a Good Price
body: This was a gift for my daughter. The best price I could find it for at this time. Arrived quickly and in good condition.

author: PB
title: Enthralling
body: JK Rowling created another fascinating world, this time for adults.My whole book club enjoyed it. It's not Tolstoy, but she definitely does characters well.

author: Ruth
title: sad
body: Rowling definitely made the transition from young adult to adult.  Lots of characters with their own involved stories to tell.

author: John P. McMorrow
title: Depressing
body: Is there any human defect that's not portrayed in this book ?? I kept hoping for some redeeming value but did not find it.

author: Dorothy S. Tabler
title: Cynical and depressing
body: When I read the description of the book, it held the promise of mystery and intrigue. The reality is that the political issue is uninteresting and could have been dealt with about 200 pages sooner. Only 2 characters have redeeming qualities. One died at the beginning and there were hints we wouldn't have liked him either if he were among the living. The other came to a dismal end. The rest of the people in the outwardly beautiful town were despicable. Harry Potter was filled with hope, the question of the nature of good and evil, and the conclusion is good is a choice and love is what makes it tick. Despite how it was marketed, there was so much more than children could possibly see. I expected even more from this book and got only misery and ugliness.

author: Juliery
title: Trying not to be the author of Harry Potter
body: In my opinion, J.K. Rowling is a fabulous writer. She did an amazing job of bringing a town to life in this novel. However, in her effort to move on from the series "that shall not be named", she brought in every kind of sorrow, betrayal, profanity, and I felt very depressed by the end of the book. In fact, many of the characters situations are unresolved, as I guess real life is, but to me I felt like the author was going to extremes to stay away from what she is currently popular for. In fact, some of the teens are the same ages as the students her in other novels, but very worldly. It seems that in the whole town, not one family has a normal relationship and no one has a good parent/teen relationship.  I would not recommend this for a teenager as it would encourage some of the behaviors you wouldn't want them to have. I was REALLY disappointed with the plot but love her style of writing and the way she develops each character and reveals the story from their points of view.

author: Riley Davis
title: Refreshing from our favorite author
body: I was very pleased to hear that J.K. Rowling was going to be writing a book geared towards adults, especially so soon after she wrapped up the Harry Potter series. The Casual Vacancy is definitely for adults, and if parents are wondering if it's a book that their children who love Harry Potter can read, I would definitely say no. It deals with very strong adult themes, includes swearing, drug and sexual references.

author: Stephanie Wagley
title: Rough start and a sprint to the finish
body: All in all, a great book. You just have to be patient in the beginning, because there are so many characters involved. Once you reach the point of knowing who they are,  the book takes off and keeps you guessing until the very last page.

author: Babby of Two
title: A Funny, Dark Comedy
body: J.K. Rowling rolls all of the small village stereotypes into one dark and funny romp...she doesn't treat the modern problems of the poor as comedy, but she does poke fun at the pretentions of those in the middle.

author: Margie Golick
title: I like it a lot.
body: This is a sad story about dysfunctional families and the impact of the parents' unhappinesses on the lives and self esteem and relationships of their children. It is obvious that J:K; Rowling loves adolescents and after having written for and about the privileged  and those who can escape into a world of phantasy she turns her attention (and ours) to those who cannot escape. Every problem of contemporary society is touched on: poverty, racism, sexism, self-mutilation, prostitution, drug addiction, delinquency, suicide, obsession with technology You come to care deeply about the characters, even the sick self-centered ones and one desperately to help/

author: sandra
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I was a good read.  I enjoy English settings. The author did a good job protraying the village style of English living and held your interest. The Casual Vacancy

author: Caleyjaggie
title: A Casual review
body: I have just finished reading "A Casual Vacancy" by JK Rowling. It's hard to read her first book after the phenomenally successful Harry Potter series without comparing it. Well it is still JK Rowling and her writing still has that way of drawing you in, her characters jump of the page as grey outlines and are slowly coloured in and take form, until you believe you know them, but this is not the black and white world of Harry Potter, it's a very murky grey world, more Bleak House than Hogwarts; more Less than Zero than Deathly Hallows.

author: Carolyn Huggett
title: Disappointment
body: It is hard to imagine that this is the same person who wrote the exciting Harry Potter series. Two words sum this book up.

author: imagramma2
title: The Casual Vacancy disappointment
body: very dark reading... made me very sad. I knew going in that it was not a 'Potter' book, but I did NOT expect anything like this from her & I did not like it!

author: Sue Lortiz
title: Did not like this book
body: I could not get into this book. I stopped reading it and I never do that. But,  I had no problem with stop reading this book.

author: Roberta Conte
title: Not my Favorite,
body: Kept me going, but a lil flat in spots  --- but why  did I expect H. Potter adventure?!  But still admire Rowling's talent.

author: Cathryn Neill
title: Super Read
body: So unlike the Harry Potter series, but yet still so well written and easy to read. thoroughly enjoyed the book.

author: Mary Miller
title: Hard reality and no Magic Wand
body: This is a tough book in which JK Rowling clearly wants to distance herself from our perception of her as a children's writer. It is not a pleasant read, but nevertheless grips, entertains, and asks hard questions about the complacency of English society as we know it. The language is uncompromising, and Rowling never lets her reader off the hook. Her characters are sharply drawn, whether smug rural know-alls or abused kids. Drugs course through the veins of the story, poisoning lives and feeding predjudice. The book hurts, and we learn from it that Rowling, for sure, can write about a great deal more than fantasy.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Great characterization
body: I loved the array of characters developed in this story of village life. What an assortment of troubled souls!

author: Sue
title: Not what I was expecting
body: I was a bit disappointed - after the Potter series I was expecting something equally thought provoking and slightly quirky.  This was a good read about a small parish in England.  If I hadn't been expecting more I probably would have enjoyed it.  As it is, I felt that I was reading a soap opera - it basically followed the same recipe.

author: Leanne Crozier
title: Surprising
body: I enjoyed this book - was a good read and an interesting blend of stories. the characters were well developed and felt very real.

author: Donah Strong
title: WANDerful transition
body: As a fan of the Harry Potter Books I was motivated to discover whether J K Rowling could captivate me in a new formate.

author: Amazon Buyer #1
title: This is no Harry Potter
body: I chose this rating because there was no clear enemy to focus on, unless it is gossip.  It toook too long to get a story going and the character development was only strong with the teens, not the aduts.

author: W. Babcock. D.B.A.
title: A must miss on my reading list!
body: I just finished JKR's first novel

author: Phyllis Kort
title: Very disappointed!
body: Knowing of the popularity of the author, I looked forward to reading this book.  BUT, I found it to be a very sad, depressing look at what must be current day England/Scotland.  The dreadful way parents talk to children, the empty lives of these people, their anger and smallness, is just terribly disheartening, despite an attempt, at the end to find graciousness in the misery.  This book depicts a dreary, hopeless world, almost unrelieved throughout.  I don't think that JK Rowling's showing us all this underbelly will change anything.  I'm so tired at having this outlook shoved in front of me at every turn.  These are not pictures of reality as I live and know it; they are distressing prophesies that, with a modicum of the milk of human kindness, I personally hope and trust will never come true.  I think art, music, TV, literature and movies should climb out of the mire and show us a positive possible world.  Give me Alexander McCall Smith anyday.  44 Scotland Street is intelligent, kindly, loving, philosophical, inspiring, EDIFYING.  So what, pray tell, is wrong about that.  Skip the cool chic and give me uplifting material.  We would all be the better for it.

author: Kirsten Nicole Mellor
title: Very good - this ain't no Happy Potter universe
body: The reviews compariing this to HP are just plain silly. This is interesting look at modern English village life. Well done and engaging read.

author: Judy M
title: Wonderful read!
body: The inhabitants of a small English village are beautifully captured with all their faults, problems,and conflicted relationships. It's impossible not to get drawn into their lives.

author: 123esmo
title: Expecting more from J.K. Rowling
body: I was expecting more from J.K. Rowling, it's a bit depressing and slow. I read a lot, however I just can't finish this book, boring.

author: Gwen Ortlepp
title: The casual vacancy
body: Very strange.  Nothing flows and it has a pointless and mundane storyline.  Very disappointing from such a highly thought of author.

author: Ladyemerald
title: The real world--great book!
body: I work in social service and this book is right on the mark!  The world isn't always pretty. The story compelled me to keep reading till the very last page.  I enjoyed it tremendously.

author: David R.
title: Small town politics
body: Definitely not Harry Potter but a pretty good picture of the pettiness of small town politics.  I guess they are the same whether in England or the US

author: Donna OBrien
title: Don't bother
body: This is one of the worst books I have ever read.  I did complete it, hoping that at some point there would be at least one character I cared for.  In the end the only one, is a child that has very little to do with anything, more like an afterthought that she threw in.  DO NOT waste any money on this book.  I am sure it will abound at used book stores and should quickly be returned to libraries, be patient.  I love to read, and do so every night.  It has taken me months to finish this book.  It is so depressing, and shines a horrible light on humankind, I could only read a few pages at a time.  If you do choose to read this dark, depressing story, be prepared, it only gets worse.

author: T. Virany
title: Rowling Reinvented: Dickensian Writer with a Social Conscience
body: Forget about Harry Potter, J.K. Rowling has reinvented herself as a Dickensian writer with a social conscience in her timely first adult novel,The Casual Vacancy. It is so good it left me in tears. It even has a 'Tiny Tim' and an updated ghost who, unlike the one in A Christmas Carol, can hack into a website.

author: Irene
title: Didn't like it.
body: right of the bat, left and right, 4 letter words.  I tried to read past them and tried to get interested but never did.  I may have reads it half way, by force.  Then gave up

author: Jenny Kowald
title: Superb writing!
body: Sure. Darker, sadder and more 'real' than Harry but if people were honest - the sheer brillance of this womans writing shines through here just as much if not more. Extraordinary.

author: Leslie B Stahl
title: Loved it!!
body: I've never read a single Harry Potter book but I know J.K. Rowling can write so I decided to give this a go. Amazing! The author really understands human behavior...so much so that it's almost uncanny. I laughed out loud at some parts and cried at others. The best thing is that there are no clear good guys and bad guys. Each character is capable of behaving well and also behaving very badly (though some more than others!) The end is absolutely shocking (don't read ahead) and heartbreaking so be prepared. Anything can happen to anyone in this book, just like real life, and the product makes for a very satisfying read. I want more grown up books from Ms. Rowling!!!

author: Becca
title: The Casual Vacancy was just that a casually written book that in which substance was "vacant".
body: J.K. wrote a flat boring book. I was very disappointed. The beauty and success of her Harry Potter series was the vividness of description, the pace, and excitment generated by the suspense created. In this book she seemed to be trying to develop characters with deeper psychological issues, but  she failed to communicate these issues clearly, nor did she show any change and development in the characters. It needed more intellectual depth.

author: Robert H. Williams
title: Serious reflection on sociological and psychological factors for adults and teens.
body: Fun to read in light of having read the Harry Potter books.  The motivating forces for adults and teens are well displayed, as well as the hipocrocies for all.  Enjoyable and, at the same time, seriously focused.

author: Heather Querin
title: Wow
body: This was fabulous and very intriguing.  I did find a ittlle long winded and laborious through the middle but it redeemed itself with a fascinating and exciting finish.

author: pamela d. warrick
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I was so caught up in the "magic" of the wonderful Harry Potter books that I think I took J.K.Rowlings writing ability for granted.  "The Casual Vacancy" is full of intriguing characters & rich dialogue. I enjoyed this book very much.

author: Ins
title: Very well-written, but they are all Muggles!
body: To be truthful, I wanted to see how JKR wrote when it was not Harry Potter. She does write well, she has got a very good grip on real people and real problems and she has excellent insight into the thoughts and reactions of men and women, rich and poor, young and old. She creates characters that become interesting, you end up liking or disliking them. It turned out to be one of those books which you want to get back to until you find out what happened. In short, I liked the book and recommend it.

author: M. Booth
title: Not Harry Potter!
body: I really loved this story of life in a grubby little town. The only weakness was that no character was positive enough for the reader to root for. This is a true Naturalistic novel where no one wins and everyone loses.

author: janis spencer
title: The Casual Vacancy by J.k. Rowling
body: Have not had a chance to read this as yet, but have read the storyline on the book jacket and it looks to be an excellent story!!! Know I will enjoy it as much as the Harry Potter books!!!!  Rowling is a great storyteller and am quite sure that this book, her first novel for adults - will not disappoint!!!!  I am very much looking forward to reading it!!!!!  Will add to this review after I finish reading it!!!!

author: A. Brittain
title: A Masterful First Attempt at An Adult Novel
body: The Casual Vacancy is a fantastic book filled with realistic, rich characters, but with a few glaring flaws. From the beginning the book is a little dry, and I admit that I had to force myself through it on more than one occasion. But the reward for that is a deeper understanding of what it means to be a writer and what it means to be human. None of the characters in this book are necessarily likeable, but they are relatable. You can relate to Gavin's desire to say the things he wants, but also his inability to actually do anything about it. You can relate to the awkward sexual adolescence of Andrew, and the heart breaking dissatisfaction that Dr. Jawanda feels for Suckvinder. I've heard a lot of complaints about how dark this book is, but there was nothing portrayed in this book that I hadn't either experienced first hand or heard about growing up. Yes, the things that are spoken of in this book are horrible, but to pretend as if they don't happen is nave and unfair to Ms. Rowling as an author. It is obvious that she might have been trying a little too hard to write an adult novel, but if she had written anything less it would have been compared too closely to Harry Potter. The Casual Vacancy is a master piece in itself. Once you're introduced to the actual meat of the characters it's hard to put down, and you're left wondering how much you have in common with these people, and what that means for you. It makes you re-examine and also reaffirms what we tend to think of people. It describes a small town (much like my own) so well, that I felt like I had also grown up in Pagford. Yes, this book had a weak ending. And yes, it was a bit morbid and dark, but for her first novel since Harry Potter I was more than impressed and It has quickly become one of my favorite books.

author: Denise Rogers
title: JK Rowling with a complete change of subject matter!
body: From wizards to parish councils - there couldn't be a greater divide. As a Harry Potter fan of course I had to read this book and I've bought both the Kindle version and the hard cover to collect. Its raw and emotional and about real people. I don't think its going to be universally appealing because of the subject matter but if you're like me and think that JK Rowling is a brilliant writer then you'll enjoy her latest offering.

author: ND
title: Interesting
body: Explores different social and economic issues. Characters are interesting as there is not a definite hero. Good read, hard to putdown

author: Jo-Anne Himmelman
title: Review of the Casual Vacancy
body: Have never read any of JK Rowlings books so I had no preconceptions. I read the first 50 pages - my assessment level. I either keep reading or give up. I gave up - finding the descriptive element too graphic and sometimes inappropriate. I removed it from my Kindle and  stored it in my archives. Don't know if I will ever give it another chance. Unfortunately  I purchased it based on the rave reviews.

author: Jaime Johnson
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: This was even better than I expected from JK Rowling. The overwhelming calamity that spurred from a township's council elections was almost tangible and highly indicative of the society we live in this very moment. American or British; politics has a way of mucking up EVERYTHING! Well done Ms. Rowling!!

author: M.R.B.
title: No Harry Potter
body: After the wonderful Potter series this was a letdown to me. It moved so slowly and I kept waiting for something exciting to happen. I picked  it up and read a little and put it down again until I finally finished it. So mundane and I had looked forward to a new series from Rowling.

author: JennaRaLee
title: One of the best of 2012
body: Like most readers, I pre-ordered this book simply because of my longterm love affair with J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter series. I had heard the mixed reader and critic reviews before I even started it and I kept an open mind going into it and I urge anyone who hasn't read it to do the same thing!

author: Jennie
title: A Casual Vacancy
body: As a rabid fan of JK's HP series and all things Potterworld, I was most curious to read her 1st adult novel.  For my taste it didn't hold the reader's rapt attention in quite the same way and I actually felt it was embarrassingly too adult in places - it just felt wrong to hear that kind of foul language uttered by Rowling!  The plot was also very slow to develop and the twists were a bit too predictable.  I did enjoy the feeling that it was written for a distinctly British audience, requiring me to look up various slang terms & brand names - it was very much like being immersed in the English lifestyle even more so than we had been with HP Wizarding World.  My impression is JK perhaps was not as committed to this effort of one book as she had been to her previous series of 7, but it was definitely an interesting read.

author: PBL Bookclub Maryland
title: An unpleasent read.
body: I did not enjoy reading this book.  I found the language objectionable.  I could not find any of the characters to be likable.  I will not recommend it to anybody.

author: Amazon Customer
title: A real "don't bother" book
body: This book would have a hard time getting self-published if the author was anyone other than JK Rowling. It rambles terribly and the language is filthy, just for shock value. A definite don't buy.

author: Electron Bill
title: How could JR have written this?
body: I loved the Harry Potter novels very much, but here, other then the detailed assemblage of English social life on all economic levels in a small community, no other redeeming qualities come through.  The author has a way of giant prose from few words, retaining intimate detail into their character, but here you feel so repulsed by the characters and they aren't even villainous. It seems JR Rowling may have an ax to grind against her former neighbors, who knows; Evidently, she wasn't very fond of them or her new characters in Casual Vacancy. She paints these people with loathing as she flays their lives apart as petty and boring.  It must be nice for her to so fabulously wealthy now, no doubt, but I would like my fourteen dollars back.

author: Nancy Ambler
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Internecine small-town politics would seem an unlikely focus for a novel, but she makes the tensions both involving and emblematic of larger issues. Characters are broadly drawn, but appropriately sympathetic or antithetic.

author: jt
title: Boring !!!
body: I have always been a huge Rowling fan with her Harry Potter books but this was a major disappointment. I gave up half way through because there didn't seem to be any hope of anything interesting ever happening.

author: That one really harsh critic
title: disgusting
body: THIS IS THE WORST NOVEL THAT I HAVE EVER READ!!!!!Being a fan of Harry Potter, I really had high hopes for this book, considering it's written by JK Rowling. Well......it just wasn't Harry Potter. I understand that she probably wanted to write something different than fantasy. 100 pages in, I just couldn't find much that was redeemable about it, and quit reading.  There was barely any story line. All I could gather was that a man named Barry Fairbrother had died, leaving a seat empty on the Parish Council.  There were a few lines of description that this man was trying to do some positive work to help the people who lived in the Fields, but that was it. Was this supposed to be the story? I don't know, there was too much vulgarity hiding it if it was. If JK Rowling had actually concentrated on writing about the work he had done for the Fields people, and the gap that he left behind in improving that community when he died, this would have actually been a great story. But......NO! Instead she had to spend pages and pages writing DISTURBING and VERY graphic sex scenes, using the F word as many times as possible, and as many scenes as possible involving drug usage.  This was just gross. If she was an unknown author, it wouldn't have bothered me so much, but........she's JK Rowling. EVERYONE KNOWS THAT SHE IS CAPABLE OF WRITING MUCH BETTER THAN THIS! SHE SHOULD BE EMBARRASSED TO HAVE HER NAME ON THE COVER OF THIS BOOK!!!! I know that I  won't buy any more of her books in the future.

author: Jan St. Peters
title: Such a talent for character development and plot
body: J. K. Rowling made a smooth transition from the Harry Potter series to her adult fiction book, Casual Vacancy. My husband and I took turns reading it aloud on a long camping trip and were thoroughly entertained by the twisting plot, depth of characters, and interweaving of characters' paths. It is a mistake to try and do any comparisons with her previous series. This book needs to stand on its own merit. Initially, the vulgar language was a little puzzling, I think because you can't help being in "Harry Potter mode," but once you get to know the characters, it is completely in character. Great read and hoping for more.

author: Mary
title: So very disappointing
body: I have read all of the Harry Poter series and loved them.  This book I could hardly force myself to finish.  It seemed to support bullying at school.  Lots of vulgar language in 13 year old.  The parents had no idea what their children were doing and the children showed no respect for their parents or their teachers.  Sex among the 13 year olds was seemingly OK as was drugs and alcohol.

author: cookie52
title: not what I expected
body: it is an okay read...am struggling with it...put it down for a bit and will pick it back up...not sure what I expected but not holding my interest.

author: Stephanie Wilson-Hartzog
title: Horrible!
body: Don't waste your time or money this has to be one of the worst books ever written in the world!

author: missjones
title: good read
body: Nice story felt a bit rushed at the end maybe she wrote it with a movie in mind - never did figure out where the long lost sibling went to

author: WhatTeacherSaid: Vicki
title: J.K.Rowling's Adult Book Thought-Provoking
body: Extraordinarily well-written book about what happens to a town and its inhabitants when they are forced to deal with the unexpected death of a man who seems to be an ordinary citizen. He has formed relationships, both positive and negative, with the villagers, and these suddenly severed ties force those who remain to visualize a future without him. I can't say that I loved the subject of the book, but the characters are compelling, if not likable. I find myself thinking about them even now that I have finished the book. I don't think you can ask much more of a novel than that.

author: MVoz
title: Great Book
body: Great book, very different from her usual writing (Harry Potter) However, she really brakes out the mold and I was particularly impressed about her ability to relate to a wide range of characters. I was worried anything but teenage boys would get the wayside here, but she writes middle age fussy British women as well as abandoned poor slum daughters equally well.

author: Marie G. Kaplan
title: Post Harry Potter
body: If she tried to have this trite little piece of fiction before her Harry Potter fame, I am sure it would have been rejected.  I expected something more and was left wanting.

author: Jayne
title: Polotics
body: As I started to read the book, I found it dull and boring, as it was mostly speaking of Polotics, but as I continued to read it, I found myself captivated by the story, and by some of the characters, such as Krystal Weedon and Gia Bawden. I wanted to see where these characters would go, and found myself enjoying the book so much more when I was about half way through as I realised it was not all about Polotics.

author: Karen Patton
title: This book is awful!
body: This book is one of the most boring books ever. I couldn't finish it and I almost never quit on a book. Can't believe I spent that much money for this piece of crap!

author: Jennifer Boie
title: Great Book
body: Great book, interesting, hard to put down!  JK Rowling has created another masterpiece.  I've already reccommended it to two friends looking for new books!

author: Caroline Gangl
title: Good post-potter attempt
body: I was interested to see what JK could do with an "adult" novel. I was a HUGE Harry Potter fan and thought the books were allvery well written.

author: cd
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I enjoyed reading this, although sometimes I had a hard time following all the characters. I did like it though and was glad I read it.

author: eli
title: waste of time
body: I read until the very end, hoping the book would improve. It did not! A very disappointing first adult novel, no real plot but a series of negative events with too many characters. Not a pleasant read at all.

author: Titah Thoughts
title: High expectations, lesser returns
body: Having read her other novels, I had expectations of fast paced action but this book is different.

author: Gary G. Hegna
title: Major disappointment
body: This book was far from what we expected and it does nothing to "grab" your interest. I read it when I have nothing else to read.

author: L. Matthews
title: Very enjoyable read.
body: I enjoyed the Harry Potter books and this confirmed what a good writer she is.  Characters and plot were engaging.  Not a light read by any means and some dark subject matters.

author: Joseph P. Bradley
title: Great Gift
body: I bought this as a gift, and the person was very pleased.  I've heard several comments about how much they enjoy the story.  The binding is also very good and comfortable to read.

author: BikramJunkie
title: Really 3 1/2 stars
body: The story line kept my interest.  I thought the characters were interesting but I didn't like the end. I cried.  just a little.  I wish that Fat Dude would have died instead!

author: Pmorganjones
title: Great first adult novel
body: Bought this for my fianc for Christmas, she was a huge Harry potter fan, so she couldn't wait for this book to come out! She recommends for all to read

author: Tamara T. Pitts
title: What a Mess
body: I wanted to like this book.  Really.  I guess I should have known better when copies of the hardcover started appearing in the "New" bin at Half-Priced Books.  Let's face it, the magic isn't here.

author: DIANA
title: Liked it
body: While I found it a hard read in the beginning it turned out to be a mystery and heart break in the end. I look forward to reading more from this author.

author: Mary Mac Cabe
title: not as good as I expected.
body: Too many characters - hard to follow. Then a little predictable at the end.  Finished it - but it was a struggle.

author: Kathleen
title: Excellent Read
body: This is a fabulous read. I was unsure about this one because I could never get into a 'Harry Potter' book/CD and didn't really know what to expect. I would recommend this book to everyone. It is so 'unputdownable'

author: Karma
title: Okay Read
body: I was initially intruiged by the summary on the back of the book, but found it rather a boring read.  The story line is dragged out and very unexciting.  Would never have finished it if I was able to put an unfinished book down.

author: KBrown
title: I am still deciding on this one
body: I had to read this book but would have given up after the first few chapters if I didn't have to keep going. I almost always finish books, so for me to consider quitting is a statement in its self...however, I really loved the last 100 pages or so and almost wished I could go back and reread it to figure out what I had missed the first time through. But 400 pages of dread vs 100 pages of joy...hmm, don't think it balances out!

author: Pollypaws
title: Amazing!
body: J.K Rowling shows once again that one of her greatest gifts is how she develops the characters to be so real.  This book is NOT Harry Potter, it is a book for adults.  It is so well written.

author: Jenni
title: Confusing characters
body: I really liked the Harry Potter series, which had many, many characters. However, this book starts out with so many different families and relationships that I had to stop and think each time a new character was introduced. It didn't help that many characters had nicknames. One paragraph had the given name, the next a nickname. I had trouble keeping track of all the characters throughout the book.

author: Catherine Davies
title: DEPRESSING
body: It was a well written book  but the character were all so negative in their thoughts and actions. No redeeming features. Very depressing read.

author: beverly
title: JK's still pretty good
body: I liked the book, didn't love it.  She creates an interest in her characters that even if you don't love the story, you have to go along for the ride and see what happens to them.

author: Shas
title: Dark story
body: This was a much darker story than I guess I was expecting. Very contemporary storyline, and interesting setting in  a small village with all of the in fighting going on. The younger generation characters were portrayed in convincing depth, and showing the angst they tend to be preoccupied with. Devastating ending. This story won't be what readers of Harry Potter novels might expect - although the depth of detail in the story will be familiar. Will appeal to readers who like a story about interactions and relationships and their complications.

author: meghan schell
title: Completely unexpected....in a good way..
body: The only reason this book isn't getting a full 5 stars from me is because it took me so long to really get into it. The first three quarters of it drags on and I truly only forced myself along because it was J.K., and I felt obligated to finish it. The care for the characters and their day to day life crept up on me. And I actually had to set my kindle down towards the end and take a breather because I was so overwhelmed with emotion concerning the well-being of a character I didn't know I had developed concern for until that very moment.

author: Heather Stewart
title: awesome follow on from Harry Potter!
body: Great book - really interesting characters - sad in parts but overall a great read.

author: Brandi Canann
title: Goodbye Hogwarts, hello Pagford.
body: I thought this was an excellent read from a fantastic author. I so enjoyed how J.K. Rowling took the mundane lives of a small town community and made them so interesting. Each character has a depth to them that is both real and heartbreaking. There is such a rawness to the characters of Pagford that most authors normally don't show. I highly recommend this book.

author: LuLu
title: Boring
body: I found it to be boring. Some parts were okay. The ending was horrible. I feel like I wasted all my time on the disappointing ending. I really feel as if there wasn't an ending.

author: Jessica
title: Not potter, but thats okay!
body: This book is not Harry Potter. There is no magic, and no secret world. It is not a kids book, its an adult book. It is a town that could be very real with people that could be your neighbors.

author: Paul R DesRoches
title: A story with little redeeming value
body: I haven't read Rowling before this point, but have enjoyed the mythical reality of the Potter series on the screen.  But this reality based "adult" storytelling is long in the tooth, tedious, and particularly taxing and pessimistic.  I pushed through to the bitter end, but the end was even worse for wear than the bulk of the volume, leading to a feeling of dissolution, despair, and failure.  So if that is the goal of the celebrated author in this foray into adult drama, then this is a success.  Otherwise, it is less than that and does not merit a great deal of attention, in my humble opinion.

author: Albert
title: Dark and Depressing
body: A very dark and depressing view of our society.  There were too many characters introduced too quickly; I was half way through the book before I could keep them straight.  I frequently put the book down for days at a time, and continued to read it, not with interest in the story, but with a desire to finish it so I could read something else. I do not recommend it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: great characters
body: I had heard people suggest that she was a failure at adult fiction compared to the Potter books.  I disagree entirely.  Yes- this is very different, there is not the same dramatic action, in fact- there is not a huge amount of action, especially in the first half of the book.  The first half is almost entirely reaction, to the death of the main character.  She does a wonderful job with developing a number of different characters.  Many characters have a surprising response, and there is a great deal of suspense trying to figure out the interpersonal connections of the town, seeming wrapped up in small-town politics.

author: I luv 2 read!
title: Pretty good
body: For Rowling's first adult novel, I thought it was pretty good. There were a lot of characters, but I enjoyed following their development as the story progresses. If I had read the synopsis of the book and it didn't have Rowling's name on it, I might not have picked it up. But overall, I enjoyed the story even though the specific story-line isn't my usual read.

author: Amy Leigh Strickland
title: A Beautiful, Social Book
body: This novel received mixed reviews, and I can see why. After a decade of whimsical, yet dark Harry Potter books, nobody expected this slow-building, cynical look at class warfare and self-centered suburban drama.

author: Judy
title: Not Harry but still Good!
body: Gritty story about contemporary English life in a small town.  When someone dies unexpectedly, leaving a vacancy on the equivalent of the town  council, a dramatic local power struggle develops. I was drawn in by the character development.

author: Val
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: A long meandering depressing story with way too many characters.  Life can't be this bad in any town in England!

author: Pat bailey
title: Casual Vacanvy
body: Much darker than I expected. Amazing character connections with really well drawn characters. Built around a deceptively simple plot that turns out to be about very complicated relationships.

author: Carisa Knight
title: Not for me.....
body: This might be entertaining for some but I quit reading about halfway through. The characters were utterly unlikable and the story just wasn't interesting enough for me to want to keep reading. All the foul language and lack of morals in any of the characters made it even worse. Maybe it would've gotten better but I had had enough.

author: diane
title: gratuitous swearing and bad language
body: I became distracted by all the swearing and bad language.  I would expect this from a male author, but I expected better from JK Rowling.

author: Jennifer
title: A Muggle Book For Muggles and About Muggles
body: I kind of feel bad for J.K. Rowling. She had phenomenal success and garnered millions of fans worldwide with her wonderful Harry Potter series. (And, I might add, she had the courage and willingness to end it after seven books instead of going on and on like some authors and ruining a perfectly good series.) So now, when she dares to write a completely different kind of book (a Muggle book about Muggles doing Muggle stuff), I don't think she's getting a fair shake because it is almost impossible to read this book without thinking of the Harry Potter books. As HP fans will quickly realize, this is nothing like the Harry Potter books. (I think my friend said it best when she said "it's a book about the Dursleys." If Harold, Shirley and  Miles Mollison couldn't pass for Vernon, Petunia and Dudley Dursley, I'll eat my hat.) So let's forget Harry Potter and talk about this book.

author: Jane Steinbach
title: Good story
body: So different from Harry Potter but an interesting essay on poverty and people's attitudes towards it.  Wonder if the understanding of its complexity comes from Rowling own experiences.

author: Rae-Ellen Graham
title: Interesting Psychology
body: Great book for anyone interested in what may be going on behind the mask which most people present to the world. Particularly loved the inter-generational relationships and what constitutes a "community".

author: Amazon Customer
title: She can't write a bad book
body: This is not anything like Harry potter.  I enjoyed this story very much.  While it got a little confusing at times as a whole it kept my attention and interest.

author: Eddiedoyle007
title: Excellent Micrcosm
body: The characters in this book were really well developed, to such an extent you really felt you were prying into their deeply hidden thoughts.  Apart from this, the book really shows a huge range of human emotion and that not only is all politics local, in the modern world, all politics is personal.  A fantastic book

author: Dsolo
title: Not so casual novel
body: I am more of a reader of escapist type literature, so I only picked this up to see what J.K. Rowling would write when not writing Harry.  On the plus side, the characters were fully fleshed out and you could really visualize the village and it's people.  I should have been prepared, as Miss Marple had warned that a lot goes on in a village.  Unfortunately, the only character who seems to be sympathetic is the one who creates the casual vacancy with his death.  The majority of the people in the book were unpleasant in various ways.  There was no real redemption at the end, just a hint of it.  I am someone who cries very easily, and did not find myself crying at the end.  I felt sorry for the character, but given the circumstances, the ending seemed inevitable.

author: Gary Leal
title: Good read
body: This book is not quite the inspired effort of the Harry Potter series, but it also shows that J.K. Rowling can write excellent books beyond HP. I thought this was an intriguing and unusual book--very British, with perhaps a need to have a feel for life in a small English village to fully appreciate, but worthwhile reading for anyone.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Rowling does it again!
body: I am usually offended by profanity, but she uses it not to shock, but to make a reality.  She also mostly stays away from using religious names and words as profanity. The story is convincingly real, and compelling. The humor is often about snobbery which deserves to be laughed at!

author: Reality tourist
title: well writtent but melencoly abounds
body: Ms. Rowling has a gift for story telling but as i ventured further into this book , frankly i couldn't finish it. it seemed to go on "forever" and the plot has many, many characters which in a series would be OK, but for a stand alone, it is wearisome to this reader to have so many characters and little except the death of a counselman to bind them. the characters- the children and some of the adults, are very sad indeed and that has nothing to do with the death that occurred.  i hope that one day i can go back and finish it but for me i can't do it right now. I hardly ever NOT finish a book, bad  or otherwise.

author: Cat and Book lover
title: well written
body: I was disappointedwith this book. Maybe I expected the brilliance of the Harry Potter books but this was very dark. Full of filthy language and not one likeable character. But it is well written and that is only reason I will finish this.

author: jenh
title: Great read for a first time Rowling reader
body: I just finished the book and granted, I did listen to it on CD.  But I loved it!  I read a few chapters of Harry Potter when it first came out but never went back to it. I picked this up from the library on a whim and thought it was great!  I love character driven books and felt this one did a good job of exploring a wide variety of people, particularly the chaos and emotions of those in poverty and substance abuse situations.  I hear people relating their experiences with this all the time in my work and thought J.K. Rowling nailed it.  These stories were true to many people's lives and experiences and I thought similar to other novelists, like Julia Glass, Kate Morton, Pat Conroy, and Barbara Kingsolver who talk about the ugly,complex sides of people and don't simply label them as good or evil.  I hope she continues to write this type of fiction!

author: david platt
title: I was expecting more
body: The story was somewhat interesting but I felt the characters never became fully-developed and that some story lines never fully resolved.  It almost seems that she got bored towards the end and just wanted it over.  I wouldn't recommend it.

author: Linda Lee
title: Emphatically for Adults!
body: I really enjoyed reading this book but had some initial concerns.  First of all J K Rowling killed her hero in the first chapter. It seemed a mistake at first but as I continued to read I saw the tragedy of it unfold and also the deft and fairly believable way in which J K Rowling  resolved the gap left by the casual vacancy.  I was also  concerned that all the characters still alive were quite unlovable - the hero had died at the beginning.  However by the end I could see that his work might continue if not exactly as he had planned.  Overall it is a disturbing book in many ways and I couldn't get over the feeling that the author was determined to put her stamp on writing for adults in a rather heavy handed way.  I would have liked a range of characters rather than lots of unlovable ones and a very few with some saving graces.  That said, I felt that , like many of the characters who benefited from his actions, it was a pity that Barry had died early as he had obviously started to make some unhappy lives better.  Of course Pagford is really a metaphor for society  at large.  I would recommend this book to those who like serious themes, thoughtful characterisation and well written plots.  If you are not one of them why not read "The Secret Keeper" as it is an easy read and no thinking is required!

author: Emily Hignight
title: Slow start for me but I really enjoyed overall
body: I just had a bit of trouble at the beginning getting to know all the characters and keeping them straight in my head and as a result my interest wavered a bit, but by the time I finished the book I was highly invested in the lives of these characters and the outcome of their actions and words. Several moments in the Harry Potter series made me cry but I cried longer and harder for some of the people in this book. Trust me, stick with this book, it's reinforced my belief that I'll always read Rowling books

author: Amazon Customer
title: Excellent Read
body: J.K. Rowling is without question an excellent author. Although I must warn you this book is not fantasy, it is realistic fiction. This is not a book that I would consider if you are looking for anything near Harry Potter. This is a book for well read adults.

author: will
title: She needs a good editor.
body: I heard J. Rowling interviewed on the radio regarding this book, and one of the things she said intrigued me.  She said she wanted to portray characters in poverty because she felt that her experience with being "on the dole" gave her some insight into that condition. The book provided little evidence of insight, into poverty or adolescence or any of the myriad themes she touches upon in the book.  Her characters are one-dimensional stick-figures,(an evil dealer, a clueless adolescent, a bully, a marriage-crazed divorcee, a bitter lesbian, a fat person, an ambitious person, a suffering daughter, a gossipy shopkeeper...need I go on?) and poverty is all about sex, drugs and rock-and-roll.

author: Jutta Koepke
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: I don't like the pornographic style in some chapters. But it seems books nowadays must have a good portion of sex and violence and f-words to make a selling. Very descriptive and not relaxing at all.

author: Carolyn
title: In the top ten best ever books I've read
body: Great to see this magnificent children's author translate into the adult world. Whilst I read and enjoyed all the Harry Potter books I always felt as though I was intruding into the world of young people. Now with Casual Vacancy I have experienced JK Rowling for my own age group. I loved the way the book skillfully showed different viewpoints of the same situation and served as a reminder of how the lives of people are interwoven.

author: Eve
title: Casual Vacancy
body: This is the first book i have read of hers, their wasn't much to the story, i think maybe she should keep to writing for the younger people

author: patrick j tonry
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: the book was superb, arrived in superb condition and on time...I enjoyed this book over the Christmas vacation and could not put it down

author: Readervirg
title: The Casual Vacancy by J.K.Rowling
body: Wow!  She went over the deep end between children's books and adult fiction.  We read this in our book club because of curiosity and all 12 of us hated it.  The characters were pathetic, the story had no purposeful ending and we didn't have much to discuss at our meeting.  Hope she does a better job next time.  I loved and reread the Harry Potter Series.

author: Robin Geery
title: Good read.
body: The story is filled with interesting characters and an intricate unfolding of events.  As the reader learns about the characters s/he is made aware of the many ironies that exist in the relationships of  small town people  and small town life.

author: Bonnie F Kane
title: Sort of a negitive tone to it
body: I like this book, except that so far it is rather negitive.  None of the charactors seem very likable.  However, I do intend to finish it, if only because it is JK Rowling.

author: Rhoda Galvani
title: Casual vacancy
body: I was disappointed...the Harry potter books was so inventive and this was like a poor true romance novel..so bland with little depth to characters..and no one I would ever really want to know...

author: Cbs
title: So depressing
body: Every one of the characters seemed to be depressed or just depressing. Only one of them seemed to have a better outlook at the end. I know life is like this for many people, I just don't want to bring them in to my reading.

author: Linda K.
title: Thoroughly enjoyable read!
body: I've never had the least desire to read the Harry Potter series but thought I might try the book J. K. Rowling wrote for grown-ups.  I loved it!  The character development is wonderful, and the doings of the folks in Pagford were endlessly fascinating to me.  Rowling shows a great sympathy and understanding of the poor and downtrodden, those the rest of us tend to look down on, as well as the points of view and petty egocentrism of the well-to-do.  I cared about all these characters personally by the end of the book and hated for the book to end!

author: Hockey fan
title: I almost loved this book
body: I was curious to see if Harry Potter's creator could transition to adult fiction... And she just about did. The book was, in fact, strangely compelling, even though I didn't love it. Sme of the descriptive passages seemed to belong more in the Harry Potter genre than in the world of adult lit, but overall the story was good and the characters well developed. I will be curious to see what she comes up with next.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Interesting and unexpected
body: This ain't no Harry Potter. Rowling has developed interesting characters grounded in reality and created unexpected social interactions. This is worth reading

author: William Madison
title: A bit of a bore
body: As a fan of JK Rowling, I naturally dove into this book with the highest expectations. I Know that many fans would find distaste with such a dark work, but that is not what disappointed me. I applaud an author for escaping from his or her element when writing. It is refreshing to find new ideas and works, instead of trying to recreate a previous work due only by its success. This book, although political and witty, proved to lack depth and character to me. The characters took a long time to develop, and once they did it took far too long to establish a connection and a point. Of course others would argue that that is the way of politics, which the book certainly seeped of, and was much too overbearing for my taste. I will continue to support JK Rowling, but cannot recommend this particular work.

author: john Denney
title: Casual Vacancy
body: I've read 100-125 books per year for 25 + yrs.  I read every subject as well as older classics, poetry & text books, I may not finish two, but usually one book a year that I've started.  I simply could not finish this book.  I gave it 100 pages then bailed.  I'm sorry, but it lost me.

author: Julie
title: Would have liked  Potter prequel better
body: While I knew JK Rowling was venturing into adult territory with this book, it was a bit weird to read for someone whose a fan of Harry Potter. It's not bad, but at times it was hard to take so much of people who aren't very likeable. I kept hoping someone would redeem themselves but that never happens. Also, I think it goes on a bit too long. Could have ended about 40 pages before it does. I'm glad to have finally gotten New material from Rowling, but next time, can it be  Potter prequel? Her fantasy world is just so creative.

author: kismet1113
title: Give it time to grow on you
body: This is a book that needs time.  It is not that it starts slowly or is not interesting in the beginning, but it takes time to sort through all the characters and develop bonds with them.  Once you do, the book is hard to put down.  This is not something to read over a period of time...there are too many characters and plots to walk away from it for any length of time.  Do yourself a favor and give yourself a long weekend to totally immerse yourself in this novel and you will be greatly rewarded.

author: Racheline
title: She's done it again!
body: I was not sure if I would enjoy this as much as the Harry Potter books. And there were many characters to keep track of, each with many various connections and agendas. But once I had them sorted out I began to find the heart of this lovely book. Again J.K. Rowling found pathos in the lives of teenagers and their points of view. It takes a bit to be drawn in but it's worth it.

author: AngiK
title: good read
body: I had trouble getting into this book but once I did I was hooked. I would recommend this to friends and family.

author: Katie
title: Another great book
body: I loved this book. The symbolism and the juxtaposition between scenes and characters makes a person think a lot. It's great.

author: Ereader
title: Want to be uplifted and inspired? Then don't read this book!
body: I did not read a review, watch any interviews, or hear anything about this book before I read it. I simply saw it in the store, picked it up, and bought it. The book was well written and had solid characters that were well developed. It's sad, and at times quite depressing, however, I don't mind a sad book and it was offset by some subtle humor and sarcasm. Unfortunately, for every positive the book offered, there are five negatives outweighing it. I simply did not like this book. It seemed that the author was trying so hard to show she could write an adult book, that she totally over-did it. It's like the Lindsay Lohan of books. She was cute, fun, and adorable. Then she decided she wanted to show everyone she was grown up, but goes way too far, and instead of coming off as mature and adult, it comes off as childish and completely inappropriate. The book had so much vulgarity and swearing, that it was hard to read. There were a few seriously disturbing scenes included as well. I couldn't enjoy the book. I read the majority of it, but could not finish. I kept waiting for it to get good, and it never did. There was nothing uplifting about the book, and every time I finished reading a part, I was left feeling uncomfortable and vacant. If you are looking for a book that is lovable, inspirational, good-natured, or fun, this is NOT the book for you.

author: Jan Foster
title: A great read
body: A really interesting  read. A complicated web of characters and their interactions with one another.The ending is not expected at all.

author: Jane
title: Highly recommended!
body: J.K. Rowling proved through the Harry Potter series her ability to write fantasy, and now she has proven her versatility and talent as a writer of realism with the publication of The Casual Vacancy. The thread that runs through all her work and gives it universal appeal is her deep insight into human behaviour and her ability to weave it into compelling, compassionate stories.

author: Fran Szmit
title: started slow but got very interesting!
body: I chose this rating because of the start of the book.I kept reading and found it very enjoying after all!

author: Amazon Customer
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: i did not enjoy this book ,it did not hold my attention i taught it drag on a bit would not recommend.

author: Katherine Verstraete
title: Love
body: I got this book because I am a BIg fan of JK Rowling's other works of Harry Potter and all of the variety of spin off from that series. I'm excited to begin a more grown up reading of her works. So far it's got a good story line and great character development. If you're in the mood for a fun and easy read that isn't your typical grocery store smut pick up a copy!

author: Jane Pollak
title: Review of The Casual Vacancy
body: I enjoyed reading this book even though I had not read any of her Harry Potter books.  I read someone's comment who said it was difficult in the beginning to keep the characters straight, and that was true enough.  However, I was soon able to sort through them all and became interested in seeing how the story turned out.

author: Clue Giver
title: Really enjoyed the change
body: I knew this would be nothing like we have seen before as fans of JK Rowling.  I have always considered myself a fan of Rowling rather than just a HP fan; and all the things I have come to love and expect from her writing was present; clever, complex polt, witty turns of phrase, and beautiful descriptions that are true to life.  I am no expert, but most importantly for me is that there is more to the story than merely the story... just as in Harry Potter there is much depth and symbolism that transcends the story.  I hope to see much much much more from Rowling in the future.

author: Jacque Wortman
title: Awful!
body: Don't buy this book!  It is awful.  I rarely put a book down and don't finish it.  I really tried to fine a reason to finish it and it just got worse.  Don't waste your money.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Proves that she is a storyteller for all ages.
body: I'm sure fans of the Harry Potter books were put off by this tale of the citizens of a small town, but J.K. Rowling sure can draw you in and tell a great story. She has a way of making her characters real and human while at the same time weaving a magic web that gets you caught up in caring about what happens to them. Her use of dialect was spot-on...I could hear Krystal's voice in every line of her dialogue. The use of obscenities  and sexual situations definitely let you know that the author was distancing herself from her previous works, but at the same time they were necessary to the story line and did not feel like they were merely being used for shock value. Rowling takes a snapshot of modern life in a country town and shares with us the anger, hope, desperation, pain, fear and love that people experience and shows us once again, but differently, we are not alone. Excellent story. I hope she has more to share.

author: June Robb
title: J. K. Rowling really knows people
body: In this book by Harry Potter's author, I was impressed by how well she understands how people think, especially children.

author: Nick Green
title: Not for me
body: No humor! No suspense! No plot after 11 % read! Only appalling people! So I stopped reading. If I'd realized this sooner after buying the book, I'd have returned it. I am not sure whether J.K. Rowling wanted to prove that she can ugly, too. So sorry, cause I loved the Potter-series. But maybe I had just wrong expectations.

author: Suzanne Eastman
title: Glad I read it, glad I'm done with it!
body: Rowling is exceptional at character development, and is now showing great prowness in her ability to weave a "normal" length story.  Unfortunately she made every effort to create a cast of characters that are all somewhat or very undesirable.  I cannot say that I found any attachment or desire to get to know any of the characters any better, and feel that they all have such depressing lives, that I do not want to visit their little hamlet ever again.  Maybe that is the point Rowling was trying to get across?  Still a master, but I hope her next venture finds a more endearing cast, and less foul language as it does nothing towards the story line, only creates an unecessary distraction for the reader.  Bottom line is, any book that leaves me with this strong of a reaction, good or bad deserves at least 4 out of 5 stars!  Glad I read it, glad I'm done with it!

author: Helen
title: Well written book with horrible emotional impact
body: While there's no question of Rowling's ability to write and to develop characters, the emotional impact of reading this story was, well, like encountering a Dementor... the story sucks away what seems like every joy and happiness.  I'd only recommend reading this in order to study a well-written novel or if someone finds themselves too happy and optimistic about the world.

author: Pam Curry
title: Disappointing
body: I was hoping for a great read but sure didn't find it. Too many uninteresting characters and a head-shaker plot/story. I finished with grim determination and the ending was in-line with the rest of the book. Boring. She can do better than this!

author: Ronald Auerbach
title: Rating for Casual Vacancy, buy R.K. Rowling
body: Very disappointed in Casual Vacancy.  I found  this book. to be very boring.  I had expected so much more from J.K. Rowling.

author: Stephanie Raghavan
title: Rowling holds her own in adult fiction
body: I need to be upfront here and admit something to you all - I hated the beginning of this book. As in I almost put it down. But the thought of shunning Rowling like that made me a little sad (I mean come on, the woman created the single greatest wizard series that ever existed - where was that magic hiding??), so I powered through. And then about 150 pages in (which is really quite a lot of pages to struggle through), something clicked and I really started to enjoy myself.

author: Old Dancer
title: The seamy side of English village life
body: It's as if Maeve Binchy went on a bender, became a mean drunk and found the seamy underbelly of English village life.

author: Thomas Richardson
title: Casual vacancy
body: Definitely not Harry potter, not a murder mystery but an amazing thriller. I couldn't put the book down for anything#

author: CCW
title: Not up to the hype its been given
body: Casual Vacancy left me disappointed. Disappointed that such a huge runaway success of a book could be so poor in literary content. To me it was just a paper-thin story, perhaps even a fantasy of the author that she now felt safe in committing to paper. There is too much emphasis on telling us about the multitude of characters and not enough on allowing the story to tell itself to a point where the plot disappears under the weight of the characterisations and the cloying social comment. It's that weak plot that destroys the book; the political manoeuvring to fill the casual vacancy on the council and in turn control the jurisdiction under which a particular community will find itself administered. Really, it's not that exciting.

author: Debbienz
title: Interesting Characters, Relationships and Agendas
