I was also pleasantly surprised that it's much less preachy than I've been led to believe, I suspect J. K. Rowling and I don't see eye to eye on matters of social security and public housing, but not once does this book veer into progaganda, and if it didn't change my opinion about anything, it also didn't make me feel angry or even particularly challenged.  Yes, it's a tad expensive and I'm the first to admit that I bought it so I wasn't left behind when people were discussing it, but if it's not worth paying for right this minute, it's still one you want to bookmark and not forget about.

author: Joshua Gross
title: It Doesn't Have to be About Wizards To Be Good
body: This was an interesting book. JK Rowling created some in-depth characters and situations, and it was interesting to read how they interacted with and misunderstood each other. The plot and characters were well crafted and came together well at the end. I think JK Rowling has written a perfectly fine book for adults and has proven she knows what she's doing, despite all the readers out there wondering why there's no wizards and why it's not more fun. The Casual Vacancy explores the lives of realistic characters in a confusing and often tragic realistic world. It also raises many questions about what's important and what's not, and how things appear as opposed to how they really are. I read this book because I appreciate JK Rowling and I knew reading something she had written would be worthwhile.

author: Avidreader
title: disappointed
body: I managed to wade through almost half of the book before I gave from boredom.  This may be a great "work of literature" but it failed to hold my attention. Too bad it cost so much.

author: PollyC
title: Character pictures
body: JK Rowling writes in nice clear prose, and you don't catch her trying to be clever - she just is clever. The Casual Vacancy is true to form. I have never understood the HP bashing, and I don't understand the criticism leveled at this new novel. If it isn't to one's taste, then that's not the same thing as it being a 'bad' book. Bad writing is always obvious, but good writing can be both obvious and innocuous. JK Rowling is certainly a successful writer, but I also believe her to be a good writer.

author: vegantrav
title: No, it's not Harry Potter.  Yes, it is fantastic!!
body: Full disclosure: I adore J. K. Rowling. I worship her as a literary goddess, as a muse nonpareil. I think she is one of the greatest storytellers in human history and a superb writer to boot (not the greatest writer, though: in my estimation, that honor belongs to both William Shakespeare and Fyodor Dostoevsky). Thus, my review of The Casual Vacancy may not be completely unbiased.

author: Mae10286
title: very good novel
body: I actually really loved this book.  It took me a bit of time to get into it, but the second half flew by.  There is enough intrigue and little questions answered along the way to keep you going.  Funny and Sad, very well written.

author: lildog
title: It takes a village...or one good man
body: The Casual Vacancy generated a ton of speculation and excitement as people looked forward to JK Rowling's next literary effort. I was very excited when I downloaded my copy to my Kindle and sat down to enjoy her work. The book is a sort of parable, as JK is fond of developing stories that operate on several levels.  At its most simplistic level, its about the death of a town council member and the ripple effects that death has on the members of his small community.  On another level it is a study of the politics and infighting of small town governance.  On yet another level, its a closer look at the inner workings of relationships rife with physical and emotional abuse, and the co-dependency that fuels these dysfunctional families.  And ultimately, it is a concrete demonstration of the evil that occurs when the village has no interest in helping to raise its neglected children.  Is it a happy story?  Not really.  Is it an interesting character study?  Absolutely.  You come to understand and sympathize with the members of JK's community, some of them against your better judgement.  JK Rowling has an amazing talent for writing and bringing these odd ensemble characters to life.

author: James Horlan
title: Hogwarts Nowhere to Be Found
body: This is probably the best Maeve Binchy novel since Circle of Friends......wait, what?  It's Jo Rowling?  Oh right.  You sure?

author: SusanB45LK
title: Train Wreck
body: I will never get the several hours of my life back.  Sorry.  Stick to Harry Potter.  And, I had such high hopes.......

author: Ruth Glennon
title: There must have been Dementors hovering nearby as she wrote.
body: I feel like all the happiness had been sucked out if me. As if I will never be cheerful again. Need some chocolate.

author: Cassidy Fontana
title: Given public opinion, I almost feel like I should apologize for more or less liking this book...
body: This an incredibly difficult book to review, because I had such mixed feelings about it over the course of reading. In the beginning, I found it surprisingly vulgar (not just because it's JKR, but more so than many other adult books I've read), and I also thought it was somewhat slow. To an extent the vulgarity comes from the kinds of characters Rowling portrays, but in my opinion she takes it further than she has to.

author: Linda
title: Horrible!
body: Do you want to get depressed? Then read this book. It has it all: child abuse, child molestation, rape, prostitution, heroin, self-mutilation, cyber-bullying, domestic violence, ample swearing, etc. etc. etc. I guess Rowling was attempting to showcase her versatility by veering as far from the Harry Potter books as possible. This book is depressing from beginning to end. Don't waste your money.

author: IrishLass
title: I wanted to like this book, but it just wasn't likable
body: I've read and re-read the Potter series, so I couldn't wait for Ms. Rowling's first "grown-up" book.  Maybe if I'd had lower expectations, I wouldn't have been so disappointed. The book had no redeeming characters, the pace was plodding, and I found it hard to finish. If it had been written by anyone else, I would have abandoned it, but I kept thinking there might be a hopeful twist.  I'm not suggesting a Pollyanna all's-well-that-ends-well finish, but a nice mixture of positive and negative personalities would have been nice. I hope Ms. Rowling returns to the fantasy genre...there's no doubt she is gifted, so hopefully this is just a hiccup in her successful career.

author: S. Spilka
title: A Rousseaistic Quandary
body: I must confess that when I was reading the book, I wanted to write a review that would bury it. Like many others, I felt that the adult characters in the book were intolerably mean, cruel, and selfish. However, now that I have finished the book, I am propelled to praise it. Simply put, I miss it. Unbelievably, I want to be in Pagford again, with its unsavory characters and heart-breaking victims. Why? Because the book is vivid and powerful, and its ending packs a punch.

author: Margaret Sebastian
title: Love it!
body: I have to write 20 words and "I loved the book" isn't enough.  I have the CD version and feel as if I knew the characters by the end.  Beautifully written JKR - more please.

author: Leanna
title: Another Great Effort from Rowling
body: I am absolutely a J. K. Rowling fan, having grown up along with the Harry Potter series. I pre-ordered The Casual Vacancy with the highest expectations, and while it certainly doesn't measure up to the Potter series, it's still a great read on its own. The characters were all expertly crafted, and while the plot got a little lost during some parts of the story I still couldn't put the book down. It's a quick, easy read that I'd definitely recommend.

author: Traveling Wilbery
title: This novel makes you think about your values, although it's not original and is very depressing
body: Before I started reading the novel, I scanned reviews and was amazed at the number of one star reviews. After finishing the novel, I think, I know why  there are so many. I think, people expected JKR to come up with something as original as Harry Potter series.  Alas, Harry Potter happens only once, and we all are thankful that it did happen :-))

author: Nancy Anne Kirby
title: It really gets better after the first 100 pages or so...
body: I've noticed a majority of the one and two star reviews put the book down around the 100 page mark, and that is why I wanted to review this book.  First of all, I am a big Harry Potter fan- I absolutely loved the book series.  Second of all...try to forget that the same author wrote this book- it is nothing like Harry Potter.

author: Upstater
title: I loved it!
body: This is exactly how I imagined JK Rowling's comeback. It is a TRUE book that should be judged on its own merit ( I love HP books, if that matters). Once you clear your mind of any expectations about what this book should and shouldn't be, you will find a rare and profoundly moving literary work of an amazing writer. English( American) is my second language and yes, I understood and enjoyed every bit of the book( I'm mentioning it because a lot of people commented on the "trouble" they had with reading the book because of British English). Not only that, I swear I "saw" the future movie in my head while I was reading it, including I now have my own "cast" for it, because as much as JK Rowling denies that this is a "filmable" book, I sincerely doubt she believes it. The book is excellent, her writing is even better.

author: KateJones
title: Grim and depressing
body: I knew this was going to be a different book from the Harry Potter series, but I had not at all expected something so dark and grim and depressing.

author: Antoinette Klein
title: J.K. Rowling Isn't Just For Kids Anymore
body: I've never read a Harry Potter book but, of course, knew of this author's extraordinary fame.  Therefore, I was anxious to read her first book written specifically for adults.  Also, I am a great fan of those who write of life in small English villages.  But be forewarned:  this is not the quaint and cozy village as found in works by Rosamunde Pilcher or Maeve Binchy.  This is a dark and seamy tale that explores the worst of rural life, the not-so-neighborly residents who wouldn't lend a hand if their life depended on it.

author: Gentle Reader
title: Waste of a good writer
body: Couldn't bring myself to continue reading after the first seven pages.  Somehow I expected a charming, well-written story with interesting characters and intriguing background.  What I got was the British version of a Danielle Steele novel.  For those who are looking for a charming, gentle read, this is NOT it.  Lesson to self: never assume that a great writer will continue to be a great writer when changing genres.

author: Michele
title: Tragic, but everyone ought to read it!
body: This is one of the most tragic books I've ever read. I ended up speeding through the second half in one day to get it over with because I didn't want to linger over it. One reason it's so particularly sad is that it's about modern life for many people, both well-to-do and poor. I hope a lot of people read this book. I think it could be an eye-opener for many.

author: seagreen
title: a literary disaster
body: It's not just that this book is unlike the Harry Potter books, it's that it lacks the range, beauty, clarity, height, breadth, imagination and compassion of those books. I didn't just feel disappointed-- because this is an author I truly love-- what I felt was more like grief. No, I did not read the whole thing. I couldn't. I'm going to return it and hope for the very best next time around.

author: Elizabeth Bennett
title: Say it ain't so, Jo!
body: I found Casual Vacancy an overwhelming disappointment.  Too many characters, such sad teens..two of whom remind me of the Columbine shooters, although they did not mount a mass attack...Each of the characters is well-sketched, but I hit compassion fatigue pretty early.  It's a sort of Lord of the Flies meets HArper Valley PTA in an English village.  Rowling is still a wordsmith, manages complex plotting deftly, and can capture nuance perfectly.  But worth reading?  Oh no.

author: Marva
title: Don't spend your money on this one
body: Don't spend your money on this book.  I wish I hadn't spent mine!! I couldn't even get past the first chapter.  It is filled with sex and foul language.  It is dark, dismal and depressing.

author: sydney reader
title: no surprises...
body: HP was a derivative pastiche, spawning Twilight and company, and if you think about it, HP was filled with a good deal of quasi-sadistic violence, directed at children. Little wonder then that her first adult effort was adult in every sense of the word but one: there is no depth. Overall, the vacancy in this ponderous and pretentious book is anything but casual and confirms the suspicions of many, if many other reviews are an indication of public opinion: a lackluster book from a less than mediocre "author"- there are better books in the world, and I hope that readers will continue to appreciate substance over tripe and hype.

author: heather
title: a promising start but......
body: Unlike most people, I went in to this book knowing that it would be different and VERY different it was......it took me days to finish this book, not because I didn't like it but because it was longer then it need to be and characters/events were usually a couple pages to long.

author: Hally Hazelmann
title: Really wish I hadn't bothered
body: The book was well-written as far as the style, characters, descriptions, etc, but so depressing and just tawdry and pointless.  It's as if JKR can only allow "magic" people to be good.  The parent-child relationships make me wonder if she has huge issues with her parents.  It's hard to believe a town this small would have quite that many horrible people, horrible parents and horrible kids.  I enjoyed the HP books, have read lots of contemporary British adult fiction and was curious about what Rowling would produce. I struggled through to the end of the book, but was very glad to be finished with it.

author: lgl
title: A great read - no one said it would be HP!!!
body: I am very surprised by all the reviewers who compare this book to HP, and despair.  It's like comparing toothpaste and a candy bar because they both might be made by the same company.  This is adult realistic fiction - it's not young adult fantasy.  Very well written, very literate, very rich and even though it's 500 pages, it's good to the last drop.  I read this book over a weekend and enjoyed it all - wasn't even tempted to skim.  Entertaining yet not superficial.  Yes, the book actually touches on real life, even some of the aspects of real life that are not pretty.  Nothing tawdry, just real things that happen to real people.  It's not sensationalized nor is it sugarcoated.  I am glad that I did not believe all the negative reviews and got to enjoy this book.

author: Brian J. Buehler
title: Took weeks to get through the first third
body: Being a huge fan of the Potter books and movies, I signed up for the pre-order of The Casual Vacancy as soon as possible.  When it arrived, I tried to start reading the Kindle version.  It literally took me weeks to get through the first third of the book.  Had the author been anyone I did not have a strong pre-existing admiration of, I would have quit and given the book a single star.  It really feels like a two-star book but according to Amazon's scale and my feeling that it is basically OK, it gets 3 stars.

author: Amazon Customer
title: One star is way too generous
body: This is the worst book I have ever TRIED to read. Mostly narrative, little actual dialog among characters. I could stand no more after about 100 pages, and that was torture. It was my book club's choice, and that is the only reason I threw $14.99 in the toilet. Great sleeping pill.

author: annelan
title: disappointed
body: I have not read Harry Potter - So was looking forward to a book by the Author that appeared to be something I could get into and I loved the concept of the story- I have it on Audio book 13 hrs over three parts  - the first few chapters where great I had great hopes - JK can really write but I had to give up reading it 3 parts thru and I have never done that before  - It got so unendingly squalid and hatefull mean and dirty that the thought of another few hrs of that would likely do me in - It's like all the nasty stuff of a hundred peoples life has been set loose - I am not a "Pollyanna" reader but this was just too much- Maybe if it wasn't sooo long 13hrs of desperation is 7 hours too long.

author: Blondie
title: NOT worth the price
body: The worst book I have ever read.  Boring story about people I could not have cared less about. I only finished it because of the price I paid.  AND the fact Amazon made me wait over 10 days to get the this book which I pre-ordered.

author: S. C. Burnside
title: So boring, I didn't even finish reading the Kindle sample!
body: I got the sample sent to my kindle, and was so bored, I didn't even finish that. I didn't expect this from JK Rowling; I am very disappointed. I saw an interview in which she said it took her 4 years to write this book...maybe she bored herself!

author: dizzerina
title: Some Familiar Themes (if you love Harry Potter) in a Very Different World
body: There are parts of this book that are fascinating and parts that don't really pay off. Krystal Weedon and her family are a pretty strong plot line, and I think it would have been a much better book if JKR had tightened it up to just her story and reduced the story arc of other characters to more of a supporting role, and how they relate to the Weedon family. Or maybe more of Sukhvinder too, her plot and ending felt very much like that of a character like Neville Longbottom, just most entrenched in the Muggle world, obviously. But there were so many storylines that just felt like, "well, this stuff happens in the real world." Yes, it does, and the descriptions are probably quite accurate. But that doesn't make them particularly rewarding to read, outside the occasional recognitions of some emotional truths. The arcs aren't that satisfying, and they don't particularly reward the effort of keeping up with them.

author: Kharol S. Means
title: Stick to children's books.
body: I expected more from the woman who wrote Harry Potter.  I did not want to read about pre-pubescent boys scratching their balls or their hard-ons....give me a break, that stuff is every where. Does she consider it necessary to sell a book ?  Went downhill for me after page 20 or so.

author: Julie Jennings
title: Stark portrayal of human nature
body: The people in this book are wretched and sad, the only good one dies within the first few pages of the book. He had the same limitations yet he managed to survive and thrive. He made a point of trying to help bring those less fortunate along with him. She seems to have picked out the vices she most dislikes in people and assigned them a character in her book. Each has a pronounced problem and you are shown why, they are so well written that I found that I wanted to slap some of them and put my arms around others. The book will hold you and make you think long after about the characters. In a way it seems to be a mirror, you must have the fortitude for self examination and the willingness to see the truth. She lays bare the most base attitudes and behaviors, it is subtle in some and extreme in others and you are made aware of just how much damage can come of it. There are chain reactions through out the book and there is a very tangible sense of how fragile life really is. This book is not a cozy as one reviewer mentioned and while there is humor, it is dark. This book is meant to make you think about yourself, your actions and your attitude towards others.

author: VintageFan
title: Dark and Morose
body: I am another in the minority who did not read the Harry Potter book series, however, I did see the movie series with my Granddaughter.  I purchased this book because I was curious about what type of story Ms. Rowling would write for an adult audience and was intrigued by the descriptions I read. I was hoping for a sharp, funny and insightful look at small town politics with its' real-life consequences. Instead, it was immediately evident that this story was another dark and morose tale of children being victimized by  cruel and dangerous adults, and in turn, victimizing each other. Ms. Rowling is adept at painting an exacting picture of the effects of cyclic poverty, substance abuse and child abuse that is apparrently as dire in the UK as it is in the US. She is also dead on at illustrating the chiasmic flaws in an ineffective and impotent child welfare system that is also apparrently as dysfunctional there as it is here. The last two chapters of the book were  the best, in my opinion. It left me crying, as a tragic ending will often do. While I feel Ms. Rowling is a very good writer and has a talent for weaving together many plot lines at once, this book wasn't what I expected or what I had hoped to read on my fall vacation.

author: elizabeth andropolis
title: Too Close for Comfort?
body: Instead of presenting the struggle between good and evil in a realm somewhere between reality and fantasy, Rowling confronts us with the world or our own making wherein our choices determine the fabric of our present society. This makes for uncomfortable reading, as upon honest reflection we see a glimmer of ourselves and neighbors in her characters. The story is firmly set in England, yet the plight of each person surely has a worldwide counterpart. The citizens of Pagford and Yarvil seem incapable of honest self-reflection. It is only when faced with tragic interconnected situations, that may have been averted if they hadn't been so self-centered, do they pause to think beyond themselves...yet some still fail to perceive.

author: Samuel B. Pierson
title: Dull as Ditchwater
body: Snooze inducing and terminally boring. A pointless excursion into English suburban life. Too much exposition, and I am not engaged with the characters. The Only thing interesting was the barrage of un-potterlike profanity.

author: RachelVol
title: Not as bad as everyone  makes it sound.
body: I was excited to read JK Rowling's new novel, but then after reading many of the reviews I was worried I would be disappointed.  Thankfully, I was not!  The plot, setting, and characters are nothing like Harry Potter, but especially when I first started reading, I kept noticing similarities between her writing style in this "adult" novel and in Harry Potter. However, I made a point to disassociate this novel from her previous ones.  I think you do this novel a disservice by associating it with Harry Potter.

author: Bonnie Jane
title: Ugh
body: What a disapointment. While JK certainly doesn't need the proceeds from this book, somehow I think she owes her readers at least a shot at an entertaining read.  Enough has been said about plot etc. The effect of this book is depression and boredom.  Can she successfully put one word behind another to make a sentence? Sure. Is the outcome pleasant to read?  Not in this case.  JK has said that she doesn't much care what people have to say about her book, she wanted to write it. So there.  If this book did not have J.K. Rowling on  the cover I would not have bought it.  Adult fare  she says.  I will stay a kid, thank you.

author: Wendy
title: Great Read
body: This was a great book. 5 stars.

author: jlh
title: Sorry JK, but I'm disappointed!
body: I had hoped to love this book, but am afraid that I found it to be filled with characters who are mired in lives that are sad and pathetic.  The adults are bitter and dissatisfied; and the children are on the same path.  I tried to feel some sympathy for all of them, but am afraid that I was glad when I came to the last page.

author: Michael
title: Thoughtful story
body: I enjoyed this book more than I thought I would. I was immediately drawn to these very human characters. It defies the idea of good and bad characters. Regardless of how I felt about each character, they all faced their own dangerous and sometimes deadly and destructive demons. The lessons j.k. Rowling imparts are beyond the stories in her literary works. I'm inspired to stops and consider the personal struggle of others and be a helpful force in their lives wether foe or friend, vs. a destructive force.

author: Awaken
title: Disappointed
body: What a let down in reading this book. Not worth purchase nor worth the time to check it out in the library. The cost didn't bother me at all but the lack of .... Everything it is not!  It is so true about being inspired in life creates magic. This book was void of any! Very disappointed.

author: V. Lord
title: Into the minds of the petty Pagfordians
body: Ever the astute purveyor of internal dialogue, The Casual Vacancy takes us on a dark journey into the petty minds of citizens of Pagford, a small town in the west of the U.K.  Whereas Harry Potter's story highlighted every brave, kind, loyal impulse of man and took us on a journey of self-sacrifice and victory over evil, The Constant Vacancy does the opposite.  I found it depressing, and the heavy voiced narration of  Tom Hollander in the Audio CD version didn't help.  Everything was tinged with a dark undertone; there seemed to be no hope in sight for any of the characters.  I found I did not like any of the characters enough to care what ultimately happened to them, and I am even seriously reconsidering my desire to retire to just such a small place as Pagford, some idyllic place in the countryside of the U.K. now seeming to be a horrible grouping of nasty minded, petty individuals I'd do well to avoid.

author: Jamie K. Schumann
title: Worst Book I've Ever Read
body: I'm so glad I did not purchase this book, but I carry tremendous guilt that I am the person who asked that our public library pay money to order it!  Not one likeable character, no real plot, horrible all the way through, then an even worse ending.  I would not have even finished it, other than my optimism that JK Rowling would at some point in the book, make it all worthwhile.  Did not happen!  Had this been her first book, it would have been her last.

author: T. D. Myers
title: Really?
body: Okay, I know this is her 'adult' book, but really? Cursing in what seems every second sentence? You're better than that Ms. Rowling. The characters are just boring. I could not finish it, but may try to again. Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, I won't be buying her next book. I'll wait for a copy at the library.

author: E. Robinson
title: Great Book!
body: This review doesn't have spoilers.

author: Favorite Grandma
title: Very disappointed
body: I was very disappointed with JK Rowlings new book.  I was excited to buy it but after just a few pages, I realized that I could not read this book.  It is full of very vulgar and offensive language.  I actually returned it to Amazon for a refund.

author: Dark_morph84
title: Great Deal!
body: I was very excited to get this book, it came exactly on the date it was suppose too, and it was in perfect condition! Couldn't wait to get my hands on one! Also much cheaper than the book store. It was listed for $35 and was sold on Amazon for $20.90!

author: D
title: Pretty awful
body: Wow.  I loved her writing with HP and was really looking forward to her new effort.  Unfortunately, she seems to equate "adult fiction" with the idea that it must contain disgusting language, images and people.  It's an insult to the reader.  I wouldn't recommend this to anyone.  Save your money.

author: Kalba
title: Don't Expect Magic
body: While I wasn't expecting a return to Hogwarts or anything about Quidditch, I was expecting an interesting and perhaps readable book.

author: Claire
title: Casual Vacancy Big Disappointment
body: I was excited to see where J.K. would take her story writing but sadly disappointed that her Adult book needed to tell a story so filled with explicit and vile language and scenes.  I feel her story could have been told with out every other word out of many characters mouths being the F word.  I understand the some of the characters have a horrid life, I get that.  I have read quite a bit of this book hoping to get to the good stuff.  Not finding it.  Not at all what I expected from the book cover.

author: Nanci
title: Giving up - for now
body: I've only read 93 pages, but am giving up - or maybe taking a break? - from the book. I ADORE the Harry Potter series, and knew going into this that it would be very, very different. I didn't expect to love it, but I did expect to enjoy it. Instead, I've met a cast of characters, none of whom I like, and it feels like, after 92 pages, we're still in the intro.

author: Joshua Glowzinski
title: What?
body: Ok, maybe it is because I have been really tired when I am trying to read this.  Maybe it is because a lot of the stuff in this book is in reference to what I assume is and are English places and things.  But, I can not comprehend this book at all.  I mean, I read a chapter and instantly forget everything I've read.  No, I do remember key parts.  But the rest just leaps from my mind.  I got to page 30 or so and decided to start over.  She spends a lot of time telling things about characters right away.  Just little things.  I just have not gotten into it yet.  I guess I need a dictionary.  My eyes kind of pop out.  I will try again though.  I mean, it's on my iPad, so I own it for good.  I get the feeling that it is written well, just a lot of stuff that is above me, words, phrases, places and things.

author: DownUnder
title: Cold and clinical
body: I've never read JK Rowling before and was keen to read this novel based on the majority of reviews which referred to humour - even if black humor - and brilliant depictions of people and life.  The brilliant depictions are true - undeniably Rowling is a gifted writer.  I didn't find any humour, black or otherwise, in this unrelenting picture of self-involvement, class warfare and pettiness.  I can only hope it isn't a real reflection of life in British villages.  Like watching a car crash repeatedly on film, I had to keep going (a testament to the author's skill) to see if there was some kind of redemption or hope available for this sorry and infinitely sad cast of characters.  Nope!  Buy it:  the writing is excellent, but the story line left me feeling rather like the character Sukhvinder.

author: C. Gibbon
title: Not a Great Effort
body: This book really dragged at the beginning. The introduction of so many characters made them very hard to keep straight. I think I finally got most of them into my head about halfway through the book. It was just a story about a typical small town and its problems with a sad ending. Definitely not worth the price. I sincerely hope that Ms Rowling does not continue this story (because I could see an opportunity for a sequel) in her next attempt at an adult novel.

author: Wade McGinnis
title: Maybe in magazines, but you'll still be my star.
body: J.K. Rowling has written here one of my favorite type of stories: loads of characters seemingly disconnected, yet their stories come together in intricate ways.  Some reviewers aren't comfortable with the many characters whose moral codes are in the grey area at best, but I think that's what makes this a great novel.  Rowling has weaved together delicious drama and interpersonal conflict in her first adult novel, and I will continue to read anything she publishes!

author: C. M. Poole
title: I enjoyed it after all
body: This is by no means a children's book, which I think we have established.  This is also a very British book.  Most may not understand some of the slang used (especially by the more 'lower-class' characters) unless you understand British slang and culture very well.  If you have seen the TV series Skins, then I imagined it to be similar, only there is a lot more adult character attention and politics.

author: Patricia A. Murphy
title: The Casual Vacancy Is Formally Vacant Of Likeability
body: Perhaps the reason for J.K. Rowling writing this dark, joyless novel, with truly unlikable characters, was to prove to the world that she could create something that doesn't appeal to children. If so, she succeeded. Trouble is, it doesn't appeal to adults, either. Certainly not to this one. The Harry Potter books started out fun and they grew progressively darker and less amusing. Even so, they were good reads.  Maybe that dark side managed to completely take over this author to the point where all entertainment was, unfortunately, blotted out. I had high hopes for something  immensely  readable here.  I'm fairly certain I won't be anticipating anything of value should there be another book from Rowling.  For sure, didn't get one this time around. Not a book I'd recommend. With all the books on my list that I want to read, I'm rather sorry I wasted any time on this one.

author: J. Reid
title: The Not So Casual Battle of the Classes Drama!
body: J.K. Rowling has once again engulfed her readers in another world.  This time its not full of witches, wizards and magical creatures, but the real life demons addiction, prejudice, abuse and poverty....to name a few.  The characters are richly developed and well crafted, allowing the reader insight into why and how they've become the people they are.  While all manner of unpleasant dramas unfold in the seemingly ideal town of Pagford, the heart of the book is the battle between the classes and the potential repercussions to society of turning a blind eye towards the poor and disadvantaged.

author: James Duckett
title: I Wanted To Love This
body: I picked up The Casual Vacancy because of my love for J.K. Rowling's previous books. This is not my normal genre of reading choice, but I thought good writing would make it enjoyable. I know this is not a MG or YA Fantasy, and I'm not going to knock it stars because it isn't.

author: allana
title: i did not like it and just skimmed through
body: it would be unfair to review this book  as i did not read it fully actually not much at all but amazon keeps on making it pop up and asking me for a review so i had to find a way to stop this,generally i did not buy it the school i work in had a copy lying around i skimmed and scanned and lost my interest quite quickly this of course does not mean others might not enjoy it i didnt at least those bits i rushed by ,now i hope amazon will leave me alone kisses to all and to all a good night

author: Beverly Hopkins
title: BORING!!!
body: I was disappointed in this book.  I was so bored, I did not even finish it, and I honestly tried to (three times).  Too many characters and confusing to follow them.

author: H. KITE
title: Incredibly Dull
body: I kept waiting for something to happen in this book.  However, it never did.  I find my local village meetings more interesting than reading about the problems in this small town.  Very disappointing.

author: L. Peterson
title: Rowlings Move to Adult Story
body: This book was a major disappointment.  I loved the Harry Potter books.  Thus, my expectations were high for the author's move to adult characters.  I purchased the book at the Philadelphia Airport before flying to a rural destination for four days knowing I would have much time with little or nothing to do.  My first criticism is that she introduces way too many characters in the first few pages and we are supposed to keep these people--parents and their children--separated one from the other.  To complicate this process, she alternates from using their given names and their nicknames.  Unlike War and Peace, there is no list to help the reader remember who the characters are.  I had nothing else to read otherwise I probably would have given up after 50+ pages.  All of the characters keep returning over and over so one does not feel that some are important and some not.  My second criticism is that all of the characters are dysfunctional.  There is no one to like or cheer onward.  One does not care about anyone in this tale.  I do not recommend the book.

author: Amazon Customer
title: First Off- Quit Comparing this to Harry Potter. Totally Different Genre..
body: No. It's not a fantasy book. It never claimed to be a fantasy book, and obviously if you read it, you must be able to read, so take some time to read the sleeve and notice that this was never meant to be a fantasy book. If more people had done this, this quite enjoyable piece of literature would not be rated a mere 3 stars. Honestly, it's ridiculous. Most of the poor reviews are from people who were disappointed it wasn't Harry Potter.. If you rated it poorly due to this reason, you should be ashamed of yourself. If you rated it poorly because you have legit problems with it, then good for you. But I highly doubt most people truly absorbed the story, because not everyone would rate it as highly as I chose to, but it sure as heck wasn't a 1 star read. Come on now... 1 star is like... Dan Brown. Even that Twilight garbage is more like a 2.. hat. Rowling writes better that that, even if you didn't like the story at all.

author: PB Backenson
title: Enjoyed The Casual Vacancy very much.
body: I loved how J.K. Rowling fleshed out each character. Two-thirds into the book I was thinking about how their lives were unfolding as I went through my day as if I too were a resident of Pagford and they were real people. I look forward to more from Rowling. She's a great writer.

author: Dharma
title: Terrific Book. Hard for American readers to understand
body: This is a terrific book. Great characters, excellent pacing, fearless, and full of insight. It won't win any Booker prizes because it has way too much plot, and not an ounce of gloss or superficiality. The complex web of characters emerge from the accumulation of details as real people, not admirable, but convincing.

author: Ian R. Bruce
title: Uneven
body: It's hard - maybe impossible - to put aside the Potter legacy and read this adult novel on its own merits.

author: Beatrice31
title: Really Not Good
body: I loved the Harry Potter series the way I love ice cream.  A LOT.  I had really high hopes for THE CASUAL VACANCY.  I love adult literary fiction. When I read the teaser I pictured something like the quirky movie, WAKING NED DIVINE. I thought, WOW that's really awesome that she'd write something totally different. I was hoping for the magical feeling without the magic.

author: T. C. Pile
title: Rowling Conjures a Tale for Adults
body: No one can say that J.K. Rowling cannot conjure up a good story, and the Casual Vacancy is most certainly a good story. The plot is every bit as intricate and twisted as any of the Harry Potter books, the characters are fully drawn and believable, and the action keeps you in suspense, waiting for the multiple threads of narrative that Rowling lays out to align and spontaneously combust. You can feel that explosion coming early in the book, as layer after layer of the peaceful veneer of small-town life in the English countryside is peeled away to reveal the simmering cauldron of anxieties, neuroses, overblown egos, class and racial tensions, and suppressed rage that lies beneath.

author: Brittany D
title: Great Character Study
body: I think plot details have been reviewed pretty well by this time, so I'd like to comment on the characters.

author: James Montgomery
title: It's not supposed to be like Harry Potter
body: Rowling wanted to write something completely different from Harry Potter. She has made it clear that this is aimed squarely at adults. I thoroughly enjoyed this gritty novel even with the large amount of verbal obscenities. However, be warned it's morbid & the ending doesn't tie everything up nicely. (i.e. who stays in Pagford & who ends up romantically involved with whom)

author: Alex Knight-Hernandez
title: Eh
body: Good book, with a lot going on and a boat load of characters. The e-book version costs way too much and on top that you can't lend it out! What's up with that??

author: Wozzie29
title: Ho hum
body: I did not read the HP books so came to this novel with few expectations. There is no doubt in my mind that JKR is a very talented wordsmith.  However, I found the book hard going and I'm reading others in between, that is, while I plough through.  Too many characters and I don't give a hoot about any of them, not much happenning... I'm sure it's very subjective but I'm having a lot of trouble getting through the novel.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Loved this Book
body: I've read the HP series and I couldn't wait to see what new direction JK Rowling would take us,  I was not disappointed, the same masterful storytelling is evident.  I was so wrapped up in the characters and their lives that I find myself wondering what's going on with them now and I miss reading about them.

author: Amazon Customer
title: An excellent read
body: The start of this book is very slow and I was suprised Rowlings had chosen such a dull topic. After all local politics is tedious is any country. However, she draws you in with the development of her characters who despite being flawed and generally unpleasant lodged themselves in my mind leaving me thinking about them long after I finished the book. This is not a light hearted or humerous book, but is a easy read which I highly recommend.

author: Nathan Webster
title: Very dark, very British - and very good. Rowling is legit.
body: Obviously, after seven Harry Potter books, JK Rowling was basically all set as far as her checkbook was concerned...but while I certainly enjoyed those books even as an adult, there's always the question of "is this all there is?" As though those stories weren't enough, since they were "fantasy."

author: Tess
title: So Disappointed
body: So disappointed in this book.  Very boring.  I kept waiting for the story to take off but it never did.  A very depressing cast of characters and such a sad commentary on small town life.  I so loved the Harry Potter books and was expecting much more from this author.

author: S. Klein
title: A bit surprised
body: Let me preface by saying I did not go into this thinking about HP. I knew that this was an adult book and not in the fantasy genre. I got it (from the library, thankfully) out of curiosity because I wanted to see how well she could write an adult book.

author: Sam
title: SNOOZEFEST
body: As a fan of J.K. Rowling I was excited for her first adult novel. Was I expecting Harry Potter......no, but I was expecting a good read. Boy was I wrong. Rowling herself describes this book as a Black Comedy but there is one thing missing, there is not one thing funny in this book or even slightly amusing. With great anticipation the book finally arrived in the mail and I opened it ready for an evening of good reading. It has been a week now and I have only managed to get to page 56 and am calling it quits. In all fairness I did pick out random pages throughout the book and read them only to find out that it felt like what I had read in the first 56 pages. The characters, like the book itself, are flat and uninteresting, the cussing and the sex seems like she is trying to say See I can write for adults, except you don't have to be vulgar and crass to make a book good. Maybe if Barry Fairbrother had lived the book would have been better. Rowling also said that she didn't write the book for her fans but more for herself....maybe she should have had bound just one and kept it on her bookshelf and saved us all from wasting our money. If she writes another book will I buy it? Maybe after I have read more reviews and not just because she wrote it expecting it to be great. If I could ask her one question it would be will you please refund me my money so that I can buy a good book. My recommendation: Borrow from the library if you really want to give it a go, but don't waste your money.

author: Psin Khan
title: OHH, No!!!!!!! It is a jamble and has no energy.
body: Was unable to finish reading The Casual Vacancy. Just not the type of story I like to read. In looking back at the HP books I can see a hint of the style for this book in the Order of the Phoenix.

author: Teresa Pietersen
title: Everyday Life Under A Microscope
body: This is not fantasy and is in no way a Harry Potter book.

author: Kelly Brouillard
title: horribly boring
body: I had no delusions that The Casual Vacancy was going to be anything like Harry Potter. I was interested because I'm such a fan of JK Rowling. But man, what a huge disappointment. This novel was horribly boring. I got as far as page 132 and then couldn't motivate myself enough to pick it up again. I wanted to keep going because I'm such a fan of Rowling, and I was determined to finish, but alas I just couldn't do it. I would pass if I were you.

author: Barbara Griffea
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Not Harry Potter, completely different genre, but just like I did with the Potter series, I will eventually reread this book.  It is that good!

author: Andre C. Brummer
title: Extremely Disappointing - Beware Language
body: I had enjoyed HP and was looking forward to reading "The Casual Vacancy". After 15 minutes I tossed it in the trash can, where it belongs. The constant swearing and blasphemy was too much for me.

author: Debbie Johnston
title: sleeping pill , and yes I did read Harry Potter !!
body: I love her writings and NO i was NOT expecting a new Harry Potter....  the book starts off great and then moves into a boring offensive language that doesn't help... I just took too long to read it.... after the funeral it got even worse..... where was the  desire to get to the end ?? I still haven't found it. All the swearing just lost me....

author: R.Reader
title: Overall, a pretty depressing book, but the characters are very memorable ..
body: I never touched Rowling before, so I cannot and will not be comparing her potter work to this. I will not be holding her in any godlike regard. I have read The Casueal Vacancy with clear eyes. I understand the risk an author takes to offer something new to their public, and so I commend Rowling for that.

author: Kathleen J. Menard
title: DISAPPOINTING
body: Disappointing doesn't begin to describe.  Characters are pathetic.  It's a good thing that this is not her first writing attempt

author: Christopher E. Reid
title: disappointing and disgusting
body: I pre-ordered this book because I (used to) admire the author and was eager to read her new story. I stopped reading about 1/3 of the way through. I feel soiled. This book is devoid of all the things I love about her previous books. It's like she set out to prove she can write "adult" fiction. One third of the way in, I have no idea who the protagonist is or what the main plot is. No love, no hope, no positive virtue of any kind. No striving against evil. Just evil and depravity.

author: Phyllis Guster
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: YES, this book was written by the author of the immensely popular Harry Potter series. NO, this book is NOT Harry Potter.

author: S. Mari
title: Like Huck Finn or The Wire
body: I had not read any previews saying the book would be funny - and I actually feel awful for the readers who did. There is are funny moments, but these moments are like in life, painful, awful moments that are only funny years later. This book was not flat as many reviews claim, there simply was no dual at the end between good and evil. JK Rowling's readers will sort themselves out sooner or later and this book will get more readers who can review it without the word 'disappointing'.

author: fREADom
title: A Huge Disappointment
body: As with all of Ms. Rowling's books, I pre-ordered and waited in anticipation for "delivery" day.  While her HP books were intended for a younger audience, I was enthralled by her writing style, character development and creative plots.  I couldn't wait to read her "adult" book and share it with my 81-year-old mother.

author: kate
title: The only book I ever deleated without finishing
body: never having read Harry Potter I had no preconceived expectations. All Ican say is I am so glad I did'nt pay 50 NZ dollars for the print edition. Awful

author: Jeanie
title: Imagine Harry Potter as a Real Boy
body: It seems this book is one that people love, or they hate. The one star reviews for price isn't fair to the book or its author, nor are the reviews from people who didn't read it, or just a read bit of it.

author: Silicon Valley Girl
title: Just substitute sex & drugs for wizardry...
body: ... and Bob's your uncle in J.K. Rowling's new universe.

author: vad
title: Disappointed
body: I just started reading Casual Vacancy, and I must say that so far I am disappointed.  I really don't know about the kind of person J.K. Rowling is, but I am appalled at her use of profane language and sexual situations.  It always frustrates me when a female author feels she has to resort to the kind of profanity many male authors use.  I was expecting a grown-up book, not an adult book.  I am certainly not a prude, but I am so tired of foul language.  There is a plethora of words in the English language to be used without constantly using profanity.  I guess I'll have to stick to elementary and middle school fiction!

author: Erica Driscoll
title: disgusting disappointment!
body: I was so excited to read this new book by JK Roeling!  BUT, it was a complete waste of time and money.  UGH!  What a disappointment!  I feel like she tricked me into purchasing a pornographic book.  Much of the language in books today is unnecessary, and I can often overlook that.  However, her pornographic and explicit language was totally offensive--I would NEVER have purchased the book had I known she was going in this direction.  I will never buy another book of hers--ever.  BIG MISTAKE, Ms. Rowlling!  Disgusting!  BTW, I did not even finish the book because it is THAT offensive!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Bleak, Boring and Disgustingly Profane
body: I wasn't expecting this book to be anything like the Harry Potter series.  However, I had high expectations based on the fact that J.K. Rowling is an exceptional writer.  I heard that the book was very dark.  However, that was OK because the HP books had gotten darker and darker without losing that dry wit and sarcasm which made them so enjoyable. But I was very disappointed...

author: blacklily
title: Casual Vacancy Review
body: Many people dislike this book but i don't think its because they are judging the book against the Harry Potter phenomena and not this book alone.

author: eeoyrefan
title: If this book were an Every Flavor Bean, it would be TRIPE.
body: I downloaded a sample of The CV to my Kindle over the weekend.  After reading it and encountering (just in the sample chapters) not only Ron Weasley's favorite expletive (BH!!), but the s-word, f-word and...perhaps most appalling of all from a female author...the c-word, I can tell you I WON'T be ordering the book.

author: Karen L. Stephens
title: Searing Social Commentary
body: I loved this book - yes it took a while to get going - with a huge cast of characters, each painstakingly introduced. However, the lengthy beginning certainly paid off as you become immersed in the daily, tortured struggles of people trying to find a sense of importance, 'authenticity' and meaning in the small community of Pagford.

author: Noella
title: It Isn't Harry Potter: But It Is J.K. Rowling
body: Like the myriad of reviewers before me have said, The Casual Vacancy is certainly not Harry Potter, but it is still J.K. Rowling. The book is written in her word using the same flourishing writing styles of the beloved pages of Harry Potter, and for this reason, it is impossible to separate the two. If you have never read a word penned by Rowling prior, than this book might take on an entirely different role for you. If, however, like so many others, you have read her works, it is downright impossible to forget them.

author: skc
title: Sudden death
body: I know I cannot be alone in my thinking, as soon as sudden death occurred I was expecting a guest appearance by Harry attempting to capture the evil creature inflecting death an suffering on the muggles, but 60 pages in and still no Harry.  Very upsetting.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Junk
body: A better title for this book would be The Jerks.  If you want to read 500 pages of selfish, boring characters without one redeeming quality then this is the book for you. I had to will myself to finish it, should not have bothered.

author: David L. Snow
title: Just OK
body: I was expecting more of this book but I feel it didn't deliver.  With more than 80 characters it became confusing and I really didn't care what happened to any of them.  It seemed to drag on for me and I kept expecting something big to happen.  I was disappointed in the book and felt I could have spent my money better elsewhere.

author: Susan Dobmann
title: If you like the Fword than you'll love this book !
body: I am a huge Harry Potter fan.  When I bought this book I did it with the understanding that it would be nothing like Harry Potter.  If I had known about the overabundance of swearing I never would have picked it up. For example, Chapter 2 is less than 4 pages long and contains the F word five times.  A little swearing is acceptable for effect, but it was obvious that it would only get worse.  Needless to say I put the book down. If I could I would return it for a refund. Too bad that she alienated her audience with unneccessary language this way.

author: Margot C.
title: It's not Harry Potter, but no one said it would be. And it's good in its own right.
body: I'm a die-hard Harry Potter fan, and the greatest parts of that series include the quality of language, that it's entertaining and readable without being silly or simple, and the way Rowling creates complex, compelling characters--they have secrets, and I need to know what they are. Those same qualities come across all the way through The Casual Vacancy, which feels real and true, and it made me think about the characters and their relationships, why I did or didn't like them, and what their motivations are for their actions. While I was reading it, I kept thinking that I felt like I shouldn't enjoy it--it was upsetting and unnerving at times, and none of the characters was entirely likeable--but I totally did; in fact, I found it hard to put down. The plot isn't a sweeping, action-packed epic, but the subtlety with which Rowling crafts this small English town held my attention and kept me thinking after it was over.

author: chandria1026
title: This book is awful...could not finish it.
body: I will be honest with you, if I could have given this a negative star...I would have. I would like to state that I am an avid reader and I do go through at least a book a week, sometimes two. This is the first book in about ten years that I could literally not finish. Everything about it is awful. The only thing I am grateful for; that I have waited to get the book from the library and did not have to pay for it. Do yourself a favor and save your money and time!

author: Catherine Dawsn
title: A Casual Vacancy
body: Over the past few weeks Ms. Rowling has been doing the talk and promotion circuit. The reviews on her newest novel - and only 'adult' release thus far - have been less than generous. And, some have been downright nasty - reflecting (I dare say) some of the human characteristics her story explores.

author: L. Erickson
title: Heartbreaking and Tough But Masterful - Stick With It
body: There is a lot of misery in this book, and no magic. The problems the characters face - poverty, addiction, abuse, mental illness, sudden death, infidelity, and many others - are relentless and cannot be fixed by the wave of a wand. That is one takeaway from this novel, along with the truth that we are all connected, whether we like it or not, and our moments of heart, of caring, even when imperfect, are all that stands any chance of healing the wounds of the world. That sounds cliche when I write it here, but as this novel unfolds, it comes forth as a deep truth slowly revealed, and is anything but cliche.

author: Cynthia
title: What a disappointment !!
body: I hate leaving a one-star rating for anything by JK Rowling - especially a book I was so excited about reading, but after, literally, forcing myself to finish this book, I can't give it anything more than one-star.  The book was long, very boring and I spent most of the book waiting for something to really happen.  But, the ending seemed very abrupt and incredibly depressing.  I certainly hope this isn't the kind of book that she'll feel the need to write more of.  How very disappointing !!  Its not very often I feel "sorry" about reading a book, but this is definitely one of them.

author: Garnet Reviews
title: Magical Writing about Muggles
body: J.K. Rowling is a true wordsmith.  This book can be read simply for the joy of experiencing how she puts sentences together.  The story is full of insights into the inner workings and self absorption of characters forced by the nature of their birth into society to behave in predictable ways.  It is sociology and psychological insight at its best.  The critics probably scanned the book and found something "ordinary" in an "ordinary" town in a short time span.  Nothing blows up, no death eaters, so they are dissapointed.  I could not put this book down.  I found myself laughing and marveling at some of the ways the language can be used, by the self-importance of the characters.  There is someone you know in this book, someone from your town.  I thoroughly enjoyed this book but I am a student of human nature and excellent writing.  Just a wonderful book.  Can't wait for more, J.K.

author: Colleen Loehr, M.D.
title: I was transformed by reading this novel
body: This is a brilliant and powerful novel. With fearless accuracy Rowling describes what is ugliest and then goes deeper- drilling down to the deepest truth of all- the inexplicable beauty hidden in ugliness. In life we go through changes, and the characters in this novel go through deep changes- and I changed with them. As human beings we are saddled with selfishness and smallness, yet sometimes the walls of egotism are torn down and something  surprising comes through. The last several chapters build up to a crescendo ending. Without sentimentality or shallowness, going down into the grittiest of human experiences, J.K. Rowling manages to find jewels of redemption.

author: Mary Lavers (in Canada)
title: So, uh, it's fine...you know...it's okay...but hey! Don't we all just love JKR so much?
body: It was never a question of whether or not I would read J.K. Rowling's first novel since the Harry Potter series, and her first book for adults. Obviously I would read it. I've been a huge fan of Rowling's writing and storytelling for well over a decade, reading and re-reading the Harry Potter books more often than I have any other book (let alone series of books). She's been a big part of my reading life for years. Obviously I would read anything she writes. As some reviewers have said, she's "review-proof." I, like so many others, would read her work no matter what. The question is, could I write an honest review?

author: Ian
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Boring characters poorly developed that failed to engage the reader. Too much inane, detailed, conversations that after 236 pages, well, this vacancy remains unfilled.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Like running a marathon without getting a glass of water at the end.
body: I am neither a fan of the Harry Potter series or not a fan. I read them at the time my granddaughters and niece were reading the series to keep up with the books that had "taken over" their young lives. While I didn't find the Potter series to be especially well written, I always kept in mind that it was written for children. The Casual Vacancy is not a children's book and should not be read with the same kind of expectations.

author: Pandorasecho
title: Lumos
body: Of course all the reactions that are in all the other reviews of this book happened for me.  I was delighted that JK Rowling Was going to be publishing another book.  I was sad and unbelieving and hopeful and worried when I heard that it would not be part of the Harry Potter universe.  I am after all a functioning, adult woman, who just happens to also be a major Potterhead.

author: Caroline Niziol
title: Solid Mystery Novel from JKR
body: If the vast amounts of outrage in the reviews on Amazon are any indication, this book was not what people expected next from HRH JKR. Its only elements in common with the Harry Potter books are teenager protagonists and a British setting. Despite many warnings and careful marketing of the book to an adult audience, cries of vulgarity appeared almost immediately.

author: InvisibleMonkeyhouse
title: Not for everyone, but a satisying read nonetheless
body: A Casual Vacancy, the long awaited adult novel from Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling is a different kind of book. Not only is it as far as possibly different than the HP series, it is also a book that is different from all adult novels. If you are looking for something similar to Harry Potter or a good wholesome read like the Potterdom was...put this book down and head to the teen section. This is a black comedy novel FOR ADULTS and even made me as an adult a little nervous at times. Not to put too big of a spoiler on things but there is rape, sex, scandal, child abuse, drug abuse, and lots of British jargon to hold it all together (think tracksuits) in this small town.

author: Simply Keith
title: Brilliant, Disturbing, Not for Everyone
body: Having read some of the more negative views, I have to say this:  Would you have ranked "1984", "The Bluest Eye", "The Grapes of Wrath", or "Great Expectations" so badly? Guess what, some of the best stories aren't fun-filled light reading!  Some of the best works are disturbing, even sad. So, if your view of literature is that a book can only be worthwhile if you can breeze through it having a fun adventure, then don't bother with this book.  This is something else entirely.

author: L. Horn
title: Make it through the first 25% and it gets better
body: If this had been written by anyone other than J.K. Rowling, I NEVER would have finished it.  The first quarter of the book was truly awful.  I hated all the characters and there were way too many of them to keep track of, as well as the book just being filled with unnecessary vulgarity.  However, at about the 1/2 way point I realized I didn't hate it anymore and by 70% done, I was actually enjoying it and wanted to find out how it ended.

author: Jane
title: Most of the book is petty, unpleasant people hurting others.  The ending is sad and depressing.
body: During the first half of the book I took a lot of notes, more than normal.  I didn't know who was going to be important.  It turned out almost everyone was important, so I needed those notes.  There were nine households with parents and children to keep track of and additional characters as well.  By the middle of the book I was wondering when are things going to start getting good?  Later in the book I was impatient for it to be over.  The last thirty pages were the best, when interesting things happened to two characters.  One stood up against obstacles and made a difference.  One saw beneficial changes in her circumstances.  But for all the other characters, things just continued as before.  There were a few minor changes, but nothing that grabbed me.

author: E. Migliori
title: Disappointing
body: I was sorely disappointed with this book.  I am not an avid HP fan but enjoyed the books and the movies.  I was well aware prior to purchasing that this would be a book for adults.  However, I expected an R rating, not a XXX.  There was really no way to know how objectionable the content could be prior to purchasing.  I gave her 2 stars for being an exceptional writer but other than that could find nothing redeeming about this book.  There is simply no reason to stuff every political-social-economic topic available into 500 pages of print.  The characters were polarized, not dynamic the way most people really are (ex. Snape), with their good and bad qualities. Many reviewers may object, but I feel like JKR does have somewhat of an obligation to consider the audience that brought her so much success.  Those who say she should be allowed to just follow her "creative muse" are those who like it.  Also what about the HP readers transitioning into adulthood who pick up this book?  It is being sold by the cash registers in my local BJ's!!  There should be a sticker on the cover indicating strong adult themes.  In addition no excerpts were offered of the book so that the reader could get an idea of what they were getting into.  Many authors offer that prior to the book being released.  All-in-all, I felt duped. And yes, I object to the Kindle price - probably determined by her publisher (I am not sure).  It seems somewhat disingenuous for a women who gained her early success while on welfare, to now be charging an arm and a leg for a book, much more than most authors, for a book with controversial content.  I am an avid reader, and spend thousands of dollars a year stocking up my kindle.  I looked forward to this book with much anticipation and it fell far short of anything I expected.

author: Scott E. Hendrix
title: A truly great novel
body: I will warn anyone thinking of buying this book  on the basis of their love of the Harry Potter novels that they may well be dissapointed. Those were fun books and enjoyable to read, but this is a truly great novel. I've seen reviewers who pan it for being "plodding," a novel in which "nothing happens." I would have to disagree, and do so strongly. Yes, there is not a great deal of action if one means that term in the way it is applied to Hollywood movies. But every page is filled with engagingly deep character studies and fascinating insights into the human condition. It amazes me the way in which Rowling paints a portrait of a town that is so outwardly idyllic, but in which there is so much seething conflict seemingly hidden behind every door and every hedge. Along the way she encourages us to think about what goes on within the human psyche, to consider waht drives the people around us, to be sympathetic toward, or at least understanding of, the flaws that we all possess.

author: bandcandy
title: Shades of Black: a world without hope.
body: The myth of Pandora's Box tells of how the box contained all the evils of the world - but at the bottom was Hope. In Casual Vacancy the author gives us a cast of deeply selfish characters who between them exhibit pretty much every vice in varying degrees and commit acts of cruelty and depravity both great and small. What we are not given is any sense of hope. At the end there are hints of repentance and reform, but the book has taught us not to trust such things. Even apparent acts of charity are portrayed as being motivated by selfish reasons. The town of Pagford is a town peopled by grotesque caricatures, where no one can be trusted and compassion is a chimera.

author: Maryellen
title: Good Girl Gone Great
body: Let me start by saying, this is the first book I've ever read by this author.  The FIRST.  It will not be the last.

author: bgg
title: vulgar
body: I loved the HP series and hope this might be as good. There is enough trash out there I was very surprised at the vulgarity she used. I tried to keep an open mind but the trash continued and I gave up after the first 100 pages. The story line itself was OK but just because a novel is 'adult' doesn't mean it has to be that vulgar. Novels for adults do not need to use such language.

author: Verified Amazon Customer
title: another excellent book by J.K. Rowling
body: Great book! I preordered it. Not Harry Potter but still great storytelling by a genius!

author: tara
title: no HP..
body: but then again, that's the point. Harry Potter and The Casual Vacancy really need to stop being compared; they are different in almost every possible way. The Casual Vacancy was by far not the BEST book I've ever read, but it was worth buying and reading. I wouldn't say I particularly enjoyed it, as the subject matter is tough, but I did find myself wanting to get back to it when I took a break from reading. The writing is strong, and the characters are developed well. Their personalities are clearly displayed and their inner struggles are gripping. While their actual lives may not be amazing and interesting, that also is part of the point of the story.

author: Tracy Wormald
title: Slow starting but great read
body: I loved this book.  It was slow starting and took a while to figure out the characters, but its gritty and well written and the story will stay with you long after you have put the book down.

author: Donna
title: Jk---- stick with Harry Potter
body: This was a terrible waste of my time and money!  It did NOT live up to the hype.  I kept reading thinking it would improve....it  didn't !!!  Reading this book was "painful".  Couldn't wait till the end.  VERY disappointing!!!  jK should stick with a Harry Potter sequel!!!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Horrible book
body: I feel compelled to review this book.  This book is the most depressing book I've ever read.  I finished it hoping to find something redeeming at the end but was disappointed.  I can't believe anyone would find this book enjoyable.  Story of dysfunctional families with no joy anywhere to be found.  Very depressing.  I won't be buying another book by this author.  What a shame after the Harry Potter series.

author: Brian
title: Really disappointed
body: Really disappointed. I started this book with a blank slate, forgetting everything about her previous books. I gave it a try, and even started reading it a second time.. thinking I didn't read it properly and perhaps that is why it wasn't very good. No. It's just not very good at all. Avoid at all costs.

author: T. Foster
title: Petty, selfish, unpleasant people and their disgusting behavior
body: This book is filled with petty, selfish, unpleasant people and their disgusting behavior. I'm an avid reader and certainly don't expect my novels to be nothing but sweetness and light, but this book is utterly unpleasant. It's a character-driven novel, but none of the characters are likeable or admirable in the least. This is not a story of good people fighting bad people; it's a story of disgusting, self-centered people interacting with other disgusting, self-centered people. The story jumps so rapidly from one character's POV to another's, I didn't feel invested in any of them; didn't know them; didn't care about them. I actually had to write notes to remember names -- who was whose son, wife, enemy, etc. There is very little plot; no causes or quests I cared about. It's filled with vulgarity in language, thought, and deed. I'd give it an NC-17 rating. I was ready to plow through the unpleasantness out of loyalty to Rowling, but realized around page 120 that, not only was I repulsed by these people, I was bored out of my mind. Rowling is a gifted writer, especially at describing people, personalities, and attitudes, but this novel is page after page of small, petty behaviors, not major actions that move the story forward. When one of the charcters started scratching his hairy navel, I decided I was done. I skipped and read the last two chapters, which were so depressing and pointless, I'm glad I didn't waste my time on the rest. So so so disappointing! Argh! Does Rowling really think the world is filled with nothing but vulgar, miserable people? I heard her describe this novel as a tragic comedy. Well, the comedy is very subtle indeed.

author: Harry potter lover
title: Book ruins Rowling's literary legacy
body: What a disappointment.  Stock characters. No recognizable hero/heroine. No creativity. Nothing special. Save your money, and don't waste your time on this very ordinary book by an author who wrote an extraordinary series.

author: robb quick
title: Moving
body: I don't generally write reviews as books are extremely personal. I do make it a point to read Amazon reviews as the reviewers could be your next door neighbor or another published author.  I was introduced to JK Rowling by my two nieces & loved every book.  This book is nothing like those novels.  Readers need to forgot who wrote the book in order to allow this novel to be viewed on it's on merits.  Yes, there are a lot of characters, but unless you work alone in your home, most of us touch the lives of countless others in our daily routines. And yes, many of the characters are unlikeable, but we all know unlikeable people, some of us ARE unlikeable people.  That said, after being introduced to the characters and how their lives were interwoven, it was very hard to put the book down.  (I am one who will read a few chapters, and if not engaged, will stop reading and move on to a new book.)  I didn't like these people, I felt pity and disgust for them, but I needed to see how their lives intertwined until the final page. I was not disappointed.

author: Peter Eerden
title: Well done Jo. I will be back for more
body: Having just finished reading `A Casual Vacancy' By J. K. Rawlings I was interested to get a feel for the reviews already out there before starting on mine. Polarised is the first word that springs to mind. Comments such as:

author: Gabriella West
title: Like a 19th-century novel in many ways; Rowling's treatment of class goes deep
body: The novel is partially about Pagford's children warring against their parents, and that is certainly an enjoyable subject, one we can all relate to. But Rowling is not content to depict middle-class adolescent rebellion. She goes even deeper, exploring a family from the Fields housing estate, whose daughter, Krystal Weedon, goes to school with Andrew and his unpleasant friend "Fats" Wall. Krystal barely has a family at all: a mother, Terri, who's a chronic heroin addict and former prostitute, a little brother who is learning disabled and neglected. One of the most powerful scenes in the book is when social worker Kay comes to interview Terri and tries to get through to her that her son is in danger of being taken away. Terri is barely there, a wispy wretch of a woman who can scarcely form a coherent thought. Yet Kay, enmeshed in her own personal problems, has this unexpected insight: "But not to feel, not to care... Right now, Kay thought, she's happier than I am."

author: Kaycee12
title: It is OK
body: I am a huge HP fan so I had to get JK's new book. I have to say that there are too many characters which makes it confusing. The story also isn't that interesting.

author: Amy D.
title: Wish I'd downloaded a sample first
body: I don't think I would have purchased this if I had downloaded the sample for the Kindle first.  But I respect JK Rowling's talents so much that I just bought it.  She is much more talented than this.  Whether a book for kids or a book for adults, this is not worthy of Rowling.  So far, I am reading through a litany of character "development", but have not found one likable character.  Except for the reaction to the death of the council member, there doesn't seem to be a plot, and frankly, I wouldn't care what happens to any of these people if there were.  For someone so talented at creating DIVERSE characters and memorable locations, this is completely underwhelming and forgettable.

author: WEB
title: I like it. A lot.
body: I wasn't entirely sure what kind of book I was buying when I picked up Casual Vacancy. The buzz on it had been vague. I heard that it was a mystery, and then that it was about teenagers, and of course that it was "for adults."

author: Mad Hatter
title: Good Book Gone Bad.
body: I watched an interview with J.K. Rowling and became very interested in why she called it a book written for adults and if you didn't cry at the end, she had nothing to say to you...  That was enough mystery to get me to download the free sample on my Kindle.  I was reading at a very good clip and knew I had to find out how this was going to end so  I bought it.  I was hooked and could not put it down in the beginning but somewhere in the middle it became mostly centered around teenage preoccupation along with an extreme overuse of crude language that was no longer necessary to build the characters.  Too many character dysfunctions made it more distracting than intriguing.  And so-called 'big secrets' I found laughable - not shocking.  It's almost as though the Author couldn't decide which of her good ideas she wanted to focus on so she threw everything in there and unfortunately, in my opinion, it became cluttered and lost its momentum.  It's a shame.  One of the questions in the interview was whether or not it would become a movie to which she said, no and now that statement makes sense. Bottom-Line:  I feel mislead.  I feel this was  written for teens in mind - not adults.  And I paid top dollar for a book that sadly, wouldn't be surprised to see in the discount book area by Christmas.

author: themadpotter
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: This book was very disappointing.  I loved the Harry Potter Series, the humor was wonderful in that story.

author: Kim
title: Forget Harry Potter when reading The Casual Vacancy
body: I'll admit that I only picked up this book from the library because it was written by J. K. Rowling and it was actually available when I arrived at the library. I did not intend to read it so soon after it was published and I had very low expectations for it.

author: J. jacob
title: Dull
body: Very confusing, I'm 1/5 of the way through and want my money back. With her talent in other areas of writing Rowling should stick to children's books.

author: SSM
title: Incredible Waste of Money
body: After having read and re-read all the Harry Potter novels, I was eagerly awaiting Rowling's first book for adults.  I expected a well written novel, with characters I cared about, deep themes, food for thought, and a satisfying conclusion.

author: Loves to read
title: Ok
body: This book dissapointed me mostly because none of the charecters were likeable. The focus was always on the worst part of humankind. I was aware going in that this book would be written for adults and not children, but the use of some profanities and descriptions seemed almost crude.  It was still well written from a literary sence, just not enjoyable.

author: EF Sweetman
title: Uninspired attempt to un-Rowling herself
body: I love how nearly every review either claims to be HP devotees or Never Read'em. No middle of the road here. Same with Ms. Rowling's sorry sophomore slump in THE CASUAL VACANCY. I have to think her success with the Harry Potter series made her such an untouchable icon to her editor that no one felt powerful enough to tell her "These characters really stink!" JK Rowling's uber success with Harry Potter was her ability to craft people the reader not only cared about; they were adored, wept over, debated, imitated...ad nauseum. I read this mediocre novel just waiting for redemption but feeling through out the entire piece of indestinguished drivel that the author strove with every detached description to be OPPOSITE of what made her great.
