As a result this novel was lacklustre, plain-vanilla, and somewhat amateurish. Back to the drawing board, Rowling, and find someone who isn't dazzled by your wealth and past to whip you back into writing shape!

author: Kevin Drummond
title: I lasted 200 pages
body: Don't bother buying this book if you are a HP fan.  Way too many people to understand what was going on.

author: Gini
title: From someone who has read this book and appreciated it as a stand-alone novel, drawing no comparisons to Harry Potter.
body: I am an avid reader, however I never make reviews of the books I read on amazon, this is the first one I am posting. I felt that I needed to do something to try and fight back against all these unwarranted 1 star reviews (which I have read through, and find their points appalling).

author: Amazon Customer
title: A rollercoaster of emotion.
body: I loved this book.

author: ann.r
title: J.K. Rowlings Ordinary people in The Casual Vacancy
body: It is difficult to write an interesting book about ordinary people.  However, ordinary people deserve to have their stories told.  The characters in The Casual Vacancy are ordinary people.  Some are ordinary middle-class  adult and teenage dwellers of pretty Pagford leading ordinary lives for their circumstances.  Others are ordinary classless adult and teenage dwellers of the neighboring run-down Fields public housing development leading ordinary lives for their circumstances.  Human suffering does not distinguish between class or age.  All suffer in The Casual vacancy.

author: Brandon
title: Trash.
body: I knew not to expect an award winning book, but this book was just a little overboard on how it was written. The book was written like it was forced to put adult content into it, the book was very choppy and didn't flow. Again I knew not to expect an award winning book but I was expecting a decent story to enjoy.

author: Mrs. Marian
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: J.K. Rowling's latest novel is a compelling story of the downfalls of class distinction, small-town pettiness, troubled marriages, angry and immoral teens, and the effects of abuse and poverty.  It is raw and painful; an insight into the struggles of people with no meaning in their lives beyond what is here and now.  J.K. Rowling is an amazing author, but I was so disappointed that her first 'adult' novel was so full of gratuitous smut.  Harry Potter went through life at Hogwarts never once having to relieve himself or take a bath, but in this novel we get descriptions of every sort of nastiness out there.  The main characters were supposed to be the adults, but Rowling's teens are the driving force in this novel, as well as the source of most of the vulgarity and disgusting behavior.  Why is it that today's authors seem to feel the need to add vulgarity and smut to their work in order to be read?  The Casual Vacancy covers nearly all of humanity's ills in lurid detail.  I can fully understand drug abuse, pornography, teen sexuality, child abuse, infidelity, and pedophilia without being dragged into the back bedroom to witness it. The last third of the book told the same story without all of the x-rated descriptions that were shockingly present in the early pages.  Though I appreciate the message and the reality of those who would overlook a small boy left alone, I won't allow my girls to read it, and my brand-new hardcover is going up for sale.  I am so disappointed.

author: Thoughtful Design
title: A slow read ~ not up to JK's gold standard
body: Expectations for Rowling are enormously high.  If this book had been written Maeve Binchy, we wouldn't be as stingy with praise.  But this book is written by JK Rowling, the Literary Queen of England.  I am a huge fan so I grabbed this book via Kindle download as soon as it was available.  It's taken me nearly two weeks to finish it.  The storyline is slow to develop and the characters are not very engaging.  There are some definite plot twists at the end and some compelling moments, but overall it's just a slow read and an "okay" novel.

author: R. Sherwood
title: I'll never see this in a high school library
body: It's clear that J.K. Rowling is done with unfolding the shining wonder of the magical world.  She plunged also into the darkest depths of her magical world, and is in need of a change of pace from that as well.  The Casual Vacancy is her exploration of the banal and ordinary, the flat concrete grey in contrast to the brilliant chiaroscuro of the light and dark of her Harry Potter books.  There is no hero, no villain, in this book, but rather a small town full of characters of varying importance and qualities.  Their concerns could not be any more petty and unimportant to the greater world.  Everyone hates each other in The Casual Vacancy, and the most positive reaction I felt about any character was pity.  The rest of them I despised more and more as events progressed.  They all enjoyed each other's suffering, and I could hardly care, either, and yet Rowling still managed to make me cry at the end.

author: Angela
title: Good read/listen
body: I recently finished listening to Casual Vacancy.  I was sorry to see it end. I found the book realistic, dark in places, character driven - hard to put down and also fascinating. Yes this is an adult book - and JK Rowling explored some intense issues sometimes graphically - yet she also explored some dark places in the Harry Potter series (which I also have read). The main characters are fully developed and multi faceted. I was never bored. I recommend Casual Vacancy for someone who wants to immerse themselves in a story and is willing to read about realistic, human foibles. My only complaint was ( as someone here also mentioned) I wish it could have been longer. Write on JK Rowling - I'll keep reading and listening.

author: Faith Marston
title: Loved the book, wish it had been a bit longer
body: This book is very character dominated, it took me about 5 chapters just to figure out who everyone was, but after that I couldn't put the book down. I found all the characters not necessarily likable but for the most part they felt real. There seemed to be a bit of poetic justice in the end when Howard has a heart attack and ends up being in the hospital for a long time.  The ending left me hanging a bit and I wish that it had continued on a bit more and not ended on such a sad note. I kept hoping that Barry Fairbrother would end up not being dead and would pop up at the council meeting when they voted on the Fields and Bellchapel. I thoroughly enjoyed the book the writing was excellent and the entire book was very descriptive. I found a few typos in the book mainly parentheses that shouldn't have been there. I was amazed, however, at the number of one star reviews from people who hadn't even read the book and were only complaining about the price. If you don't like the price don't buy it, but don't give it a one star review when you haven't even read it. Reviews should be for one's opinion about the book not for venting because you think it's too high priced. I thought it was well worth the $17 because the hardcover was $35 at the bookstore. I will definitely read it again. Can't wait for her next book!

author: Gail  Grosvenor
title: a dark but so real story
body: as a huge harry potter fan i could not wait for this book. the story was good and kept me reading but if you are looking for magic this is not the book for you. it is a story like a maeve binchy only darker. i do hope she continues to write.

author: Sophie the empath
title: Amazing book, Rich, loving, enriching, magical, but not for TV junkies
body: First off, JK Rowling is one of the best if not the best writers of prose I have ever read. Her prose is like poetry: no wonder that the uneducated, unpolished, sleepwalker doesn't like it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Shouldn't have been published!
body: If this book was written by anyone else no publisher would have printed it.  My thought is that this was an initial attempt at writing long before her popular series, and was published under the theory that her name alone would create millions of copies sold.  Alas, we fell for it.

author: M. Grigsby
title: Yuk! Just Yuk!
body: When I discovered that J.K. Rowling was writing an adult book, I was thrilled. I did not have unrealistic expectation by thinking this talee would be sweet and mysterious, I expected good writing,an interesting plot and a marvelous adventure. Unfortunately, what I received was a vile and painfully dissapointing read. After reading 380 pages, I felt so disgusted and dirty I had to stop reading the book.

author: Lakelady
title: Get It From the Library
body: I wish I had checked this one out from the library and not purchased it for my Kindle.  Had I borrowed it from the library I wouldn't have even finished reading it and would have just returned it after the first 100 pages.  Boring, bleak and dark. Extremely predictable ending.  At least in the HP books good always wins over evil.  In Casual Vacancy nobody wins at anything and you keep waiting for her to pick up the pace, but it never happens.  All in all a waste of time and money.

author: Thomas W. Altizer
title: Skip the e-book, it's a ripoff!
body: I paid $17.99 for the e-book and see that now it is available for $3.00 less.  As irritating as that is, it doesn't hold a candle to the irritation caused by the basic disfunction of the electronic edition of "The Casual Vacancy."  The day after I paid the inflated price for the Kindle version, a software revision was made available to correct margin errors.  Since I hadn't started reading it yet, I downloaded the revision.  The revision however fails to hold the bookmarked pages and every time I go back to the book I have to spend time trying to manually locate where I left off reading.  Highly irritating, particularly at the very high, subsequently discounted price.  As for the story itself, it's engrossing enough to keep the reader engaged and is a true departure from Rowling's brilliant "Harry Potter..." books.  I recommend the book, but do yourself a favor an buy a hardback copy.  The e-book is a real dud.

author: T. Outler
title: Takes forever to get into!
body: This is a 500 plus page novel which I read on my kindle. It took me 77% in to enjoy the book. The last 23% was great. But the average person isn't going to hold on so long for a story to grab them. It does get great at the end. And there are several brillant moments in this book. If you are looking for a Harry Potter keep looking!!!

author: Tyson Peveto
title: Such a Richly Rewarding Read
body: I loved this book. It was one of those far-reaching novels covering so many characters in the small town of Pagford. Rowling slowly builds up this house of cards, this Jenga tower, intertwining all the characters (the cards or the blocks, whichever metaphor you prefer) into everyday life. Then, she starts pulling a card here, a Jenga block there, until Pagford's pretty facade is completely destroyed.

author: BeachReader
title: Surprised me
body: I had a hard time getting into this book. Yes the language can be crass and there are uncomfortable moments. At times I thought, why am I reading this? But then I realized I was having a hard time getting the story out of my head. It still makes you think long after you finish. Are the characters likeable?  No. But society has so many people like this. JK Rowling really surprised me with how deeply this story has stuck with me.

author: Jordan Hofer
title: Excellent representation of human politics
body: Rowling captures the political human animal and the war between its individuals as accurately as Frans de Waal does chimps in

author: richard 75
title: A cup of tepid tea
body: I am not a particular fan of fantasy fiction, although I gamely read the Harry Potter series with my children, so when I heard that JK was coming out with a novel void of giant serpents and smoking wands, I looked forward to reading it immensely. However, by page 20 I would have given my left nut for even one glimpse of a flying motor car or slithering snake.  Rowling offers up a bland assortment of tedious townspeople who she never  developes in any interesting way.  Flat characters,a dry narrative style and predictable plot made this story a dull afternoon with a cup of tepid tea.  Sorry JK, but perhaps you should confine your writing to the hallowed halls of Hogwarts after all.

author: Rachel B
title: BORING
body: I was terribly disappointed.  BORING and certainly not up to her creative abilities.  I hope that she will please return to what she does best.  HARRY POTTER and his future trials and tribulations.  I am 73 and Harry is one of the most fascinating series ever!  Rachel

author: Live to Read!
title: This is not Harry Potter!!
body: Don't buy this book if you expect Harry Potter. My daughter has read them all and loved them. She's seen all the moves, and we've been to The World of Harry Potter.

author: Stevek2000
title: Worst book with illegal price fixing
body: This book started slow, but by the middle you actually think it was faster on the beginning.  Hope the publishers get sued out of business by the justice department, for price fixing.

author: Tim
title: Not very good
body: I bought this book because of the author.  I was very disappointed in the book.  I kept reading, hoping that it would get better or exciting but that never happened.  I liked the idea behind the book and it sounded like it would be good so i preordered it.  What a waste of $17.99.  I noticed that today it dropped to $14.99 but it is not even worth that much.  It seems like someone that has written the Harry Potter series could have come up with a better story than this.

author: P. D. Cantrell
title: Absorbing story, interesting characters
body: I read this book in audiobook format:

author: Moose Spot
title: Sadly disappointed.
body: Before give my opinion I want to tell you I think J. K. Rowling is one of the most talented writers I have ever read. As an individual, she has gone through incredible trials. I love that she has generously given back to organizations worldwide. She has encouraged children to read and stands up for the rights of those who have been abused throughout the world. She is an amazing person.

author: nanofoster
title: Vulgar and wordy
body: This book is certainly not worthy of the time spent to read it or the hefty price you pay at the register.  It strikes me as an explosion of seven books worth of fowl language and gratuitous sex that the author previously could not use.  There are times when you have to reread sentences to get what she's saying because she's trying to be clever or its over the top "descriptive".  Did not finish it even though I paid $30 for it.

author: T. J. Tenholder
title: Not so much fun.
body: This book was a bit of a chore for me to read. To me it is a sad story about sad people in a dreary place. Tweek it a little and you could have a Robert McCammon novel. Some of those drag on, too. Some readers like that kind of stuff. If you are one of them, go for it. Or, perhaps read Bleak House, it costs a lot less.

author: Mary Elliott
title: Very dull plot
body: I'm afraid I just can't go into the lengthy reviews that some people had. There isn't that much to say about this book. I thought the plot was dull, although I did enjoy reading the British term for things and their way of turning a phrase. While I loved the HP series (and yes I DID know this would be completely different), I was very dissatisfied with this overall.

author: Shay
title: Over the top...
body: This is a harsh book about the reality of divisions in small towns. There was substance at first then the book became to scattered. The use of such crass language was not necessary. The characters were over the top. I  don't live in the UK but a small town is a small town. Big fish, little fish mentality is not explored as in-depth because there were to many characters.I would not recommend buying this book but borrowing it from the library...

author: catherine
title: heartbreakingly enthralling
body: having just finished this book, i feel heartbroken finishing it after feeling as if i became a part of the Pagford and Yarvill community-i felt the pain in Krystal Weedon and the desperation and smugness of a community and the constant need for gossip-each character is relatable and we all see bits of ourselves in each of them. i am a lover of the HP novels and reading this-not expecting magic but the superb writing of Rowling was completely on par.

author: John Hodges
title: None
body: Very disappointing book. Author needs to stick to writing books for non adults. Dull muddled read. Sorry I wasted my money.

author: CBP the bookworm
title: Harry Potter this isn't - but it isn't meant to be
body: As a longtime Rowling fan, I was intrigued by the synopsis of Casual Vacancy, and curious to experience Rowling's mastery in an entirely new genre.  But I think I had fewer expectations than some other readers that Rowling's adult work would be "nice".  It isn't.  And that's ok.  A writer whose work for children was accused of being "too dark" and "too scary" isn't going to write something sweetly pretty for adults.

author: Robert Niles
title: Amazing - J.K. Rowling's turn as an English William Faulkner
body: Just finished The Casual Vacancy - an absolutely stunning book. This is J.K. Rowling as William Faulkner - introducing tons of characters, then letting them stew in a stuffy, self-important, backwater town. There's a theater cliche that if you put a gun over the mantlepiece in the first act, someone'd better fire it by the end of the second. In the final 40 pages, Rowling unleashes a fusillade - tying together all elements of her soap opera into a gut-wrenching ending that manages to be both inspiring and an indictment at the same time. Well worth reading.

author: J. Christian
title: Wonderful, engaging, all-encompassing read.
body: I kind of think maybe she should have written this book under a (different) pen name. That way there wouldn't be so many whiners complaining about how "I loved Harry Potter but this was just not my style" and gave the book 1 star. It's unfortunate when an author can't write in a different style without the masses exclaiming she should have just left it at Harry Potter. If you can't stretch beyond your tiny box of what type of books you read, or you can't overlook that the "Queen of Harry Potter" wrote this novel, or you don't like contemporary novels, or you don't like anything that makes you uncomfortable-with-ugly-topics, perhaps you should save your trouble and not buy the book and then leave a horrible, undeserving review.

author: Ryan G
title: Why would she ruin her reputation?
body: After reading initially what the book was going to be about, I wouldn't have bought this book except that it's by J.K. Rowling.  I mean, she is the hottest author on the planet, why would she risk putting out a dud unless it's a sure thing? Why would her management and team of people around her allow her to put out something that wasn't an immediate success?  After 25 or so pages in, I thought, "Ok, this is Rowling, the story telling is great, but man, this book is NOT good."  Any other author and I would have put it down.  75 pages later, I can't go any farther.  I'm finished with it, can't get through it.  Good luck to the next reader and hopefully her next book is much, MUCH better.

author: Sharon Furstenwerth
title: We forget where J.K. Rowling came from ...
body: J.K. Rowling could write an insurance policy and I'd read it - cover to cover . Do not read this book to be uplifted. It is stark reality, and she captures the small town microcosm as well as she captured adolescence in HP. There were really only two characters in the book that I didn't like, and the book is full of characters and how their lives interweave. Most, however, were shown to be human - with all the hearts and warts attached. She not only writes about our prejudices, but she writes about how tragic events can turn lives around, can heal relationships, and can break people apart. This book is like old age - it's not for sissies. If you love J.K. Rowling's writing, however, it is for you.

author: TonksGrrl
title: Still working her magic!
body: I hate writing a review that gives things away.

author: Joseph Horton
title: too bad
body: Not good.  It's a soap opera in a book.  And it's not a good soap opera.

author: Mieke van Reader
title: Entertaining effort
body: I just finished JK Rowling's new book and I have to say that in spite of some shortcomings in the editing, I really enjoyed it.  Yes, it could have been a bit shorter and yes, it is dark.  The characters (and there are more than enough of them) are well drawn, though unfortunately, there is not a sympathetic one among them.  But sometimes life is like that. The sex, drugs, violence and foul language rang true and were not used to titilate or shock.  That's just how things are in the places Rowling writes about.

author: Katherine S McKee
title: read it
body: Fantastic read in a contemporary setting. The characters had depth and the story reminds us all how we are interconnected.

author: L.
title: Fantastically Written
body: I am very, very close to the end so I think it is okay for me to make an accurate review.

author: Zoe
title: DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY!
body: I feel betrayed.  The only good thing about this book is that I got it at the library and wasn't out one single cent.

author: Msreadseverything
title: big flop
body: This is the first book (kindle version) that I seriously considered returning.  While I have bought bad books in the past, I at least bought them in hard cover so I could donate to someone else or to a library.  I read widely in many different topics, types, from fiction to non-fiction, from classics to new ideas.  It is almost like I want to scream...enough building of the characters already...is anyone ever going to do something???? I will admit I am about 1/2 through the read...and I find myself starting to skim...so I can just say I finished it...sure wasted my money.

author: kathysaysso
title: Surprisingly awful
body: This book is tragic - not in the literary sense.  Every last cliched character was despicable.  I actually began to dread reading further because I was bored by the unrelenting sordidness.  Halfway through I had the thought that perhaps she had meant this to be a black comedy.  But there wasn't a modicum of humor to be found in the relentless depictions of abuse, hatred, suffering, betrayal, physical ailments, and crummy weather. A waste of 17 bucks on my part, and talent on hers.

author: Jay
title: Life, Loss, Pain, and Redemption
body: They are all there.  Rowling puts together a story that deals with the class differences and idiosyncracies of life in England. Snogging, shagging, and all other kinds of words we usually don't see on my side of the pond. I thought the story was extremely well crafted. It took a couple of chapters for me to adjust to all of the characters thrown into the story, but they were all distinct enough to be be interesting.  Think of a world where Jane Austen re-wrote "The Wire"... minus the police angle.  Social issues abound and are looked at from all sides.  I honestly thought the book was fascinating!!  I highly recommend!!

author: Rose Shannon
title: I am SO moved by this story
body: This is my first experience with J. K. Rowling. I can only hope she continues to write adult books.  I am an avid reader...how many books have I read in 60 plus years????  Cannot even begin to guess. This book, The Casual Vacancy, is in the top 10 of all time on my list.  I had a slow start because I am normally a mystery, thriller advocate.  Soon, I was swept up into all the characters' personalities, lives, conflicts.  This is not a romance novel..... it is about individuals' shortcomings, misunderstanding of intent and subsequent fall-outs.  The frailty of the human spirit, the pettiness, fears, cruelty of the human psyche and how all of these affect people's lives.  Ms. Rowling's writing skill is so remarkable.  She has taken a group of characters and their lives and placed them into a clear order and class structure within the confines of a small town in England. I KNEW each of these characters, their relationships, their weaknesses, their dependencies. Because the author is so skillful a storyteller I felt like I was actually there and witnessing these events.  Bravo! Bravo! Bravo! Great movie material.

author: LouCocks
title: So Happy The Newest Harry Potter's Finally Been Released!!!
body: I just got this book in the mail, and I just can't wait to spend all night reading the newest Harry Potter!

author: A. KAPLAN
title: A Portrait of Ordinary Lives
body: JK Rowling's first novel for adults is a complex, detailed portrait of an English village, told through the vehicle of a local election to fill the casual vacancy on the parish council left by the death of Barry Fairweather. Rowling has created a complete setting that feels very real, with a geography and history and society that make a concrete impression in the reader's mind. And she's populated it with a very diverse cast of characters (well, mostly white, if I'm honest, but diverse in background and personality) whose lives I really started to get wrapped up in.

author: lawk
title: Brilliant and I hate it
body: JK captures brilliantly the everyday life in England that I grew up with. However, I hate this book because it brings back all the ghastly memories I prefer to forget. This is why I left England to become an American citizen. I admire JK's courage to write this book. It captures history and 200 years from now it will probably be read along with the books of Jane Austin and Charles Dickens who captured the everyday life of England in their time.

author: Lisa Mason
title: The not-so-casual vacancy
body: It took me a while to finish this book.  I almost put it down and didn't complete it before I had read 50 pages, so shocked was I by the perpetual f-bombs and vulgarities of the characters.  I honestly didn't like the book at all at first.  I'm glad I finished it, but I also told my 17 year old son that I didn't want him to read it.  It is very much a book for adults, and I'm concerned that parents will buy the book for their Potter-loving children.  It is an innocence-robbing book.

author: Ferret Fan
title: Dislike the whole concept; dull, boring.
body: I was so looking forward to reading this book and so disappointed in the content.

author: bookworm100
title: Not up to HP standard
body: I am a HUGE harry potter fan, and was very excited about this book. I ordered it months before it was released. I was very disappointed. It has a lot of swearing in it, as well as a lot of sexual references, and I did not make it very far into the book. One thing I really loved about the harry potter series was how clean they were. This is so close to a different writing style I would not have suspected it to be written by the same author if I had not know previously.

author: Marilyn Olowe
title: A gritty and intelligent human character study
body: Wow. Just wow! One of the grittiest and most intelligent human character studies I've read in a long time.

author: BestChickLit.com
title: Brilliant
body: Not once did I think of Harry Potter while reading this book, and because of that it deserves a review based on its own merits, with no comparisons drawn with its sibling novels. The Casual Vacancy is captivating in every aspect and is sure to be set on my bookshelf of favourites for years to come. Each character has a deep backstory with realistic motivations behind their actions. You might not like everyone, but that is the whole point of the story. It is reality. Pagford isn't full of witty characters who have exhilarating adventures; it is a representation of real life, with its foul language and dubious intentions and each character has their own responsibilities to face or avoid.

author: Ajay
title: Real, Gritty  and Eminently Readable - Rowling Triumphs once again
body: I have been having a bit of a laugh by reading all the negative reviews on Amazon. Firstly, we had a whole lot of people whinging about the ebook price. Now, we have a whole lot criticising its 'filthy' language.

author: J. Terry
title: Sharp, Biting, Dark, (sometimes) Funny -  A Worthwhile Read
body: As I write this, the bad reviews for The Casual Vacancy outnumber the good reviews.  That's too bad, because this is a well written book, one that is certainly worth reading.

author: Kindle Customer
title: So disappointed
body: I had been really looking forward to this new book from a talented author.  I stared reading it and couldn't continue.  It was so base and disgusting.  The language was terrible.  I didn't find any redeeming qualities in the book or the people in the book.

author: Margery L. Goldstein
title: A well-constructed, well-written, but dark book
body: This dark but engaging novel has one thing (at least) in common with the Harry Potter books: it deals at length with the disconnect between the actual lives of teenagers and how those teenagers are seen by their parents. The teens in the village of Pagford are not magical, but they do have a power their parents don't recognize: they are comfortable with computers. One after another, they hack into the parish council website to wreak havoc with their parents' lives and reputations.

author: Lynne Millar
title: awful
body: Wow, I can't believe I actually finished this book. I kind of feel like I need to go boil my brain. There's a lot of language and whatever else you can imagine that's adult in this one - but actually the bigger problem for me was the unrelenting, soul-sucking cynicism and negativity. I kept reading because I was waiting for something to shift, for her to show some little glimpse of redemption or hope for ANY of the characters... something to give meaning. It never really happened until the very very end, and by then, it was just waaaay too late.

author: charliebower
title: disappointing
body: Though her humanity and empathy for the human spirit remain, Rowling's wit,taste, charm and wonderful humor are lacking in this book.  The heavy topics are dealt with in an offensive manner.  I'm disappointed in this book, and think she could do much better.

author: Chris
title: Read 100 pages, requested a refund
body: This is the first time that I have ever requested a refund for an ebook from Amazon. This book has so many characters, long back stories for everyone and is incredibly boring. I loved the Harry Potter books, but this was terrible.

author: Virginia Conterato
title: Depressing and full of awful people
body: I don't usually write negative reviews, but this book was a huge disappointment.  The characters were stereotypes.  There was little in the way of plot, and everyone in the book was miserable.  Many were actively trying to make others miserable.

author: mariposa
title: brilliant social commentary
body: this book is not for the shallow reader who merely wants entertainment. this book will uncover deep dark secrets in your own mind you didnt even know you had.

author: Mary
title: Rowling writes with depth about loss, class, small towns, etc.
body: J.K. Rowling writes death so accurately; only those who have directly experienced an unexpected loss will immediately recognize and absorb the exact rightness of it.

author: T. Floyd
title: Disappointed with the subject matter
body: I have only read the first half of the Kindle sample.  I am returning it unopened and unread and regret having pre-ordered the book (first time ever with Amazon).  I wish the book description had been more forthcoming about the subject matter and themes.  I didn't expect Harry Potter but I did hope for the same rich literary style, symbolism, and uplifting themes of the HP series.  Life can be dark and ugly but also light and redeeming.  From the reviews I have pored through good and bad there seems to be nothing terribly positive in this book or its resolution. One big Jerry Springer episode.  I was turned off by the characters even before I hit the crude language in the sample chapters and chose not to finish and delete the sample.  There was no hook to keep me reading.  I will wait with anticipation for her next work and hope that is something more inspiring and with more likeable characters.  I love JK Rowling's writing, just not this particular path she has chosen to take.  Maybe next time--but I won't be pre-ordering.

author: C. Meyer
title: Took it back
body: I bought this book for my 23yo daughter as a birthday present.  One day later she asked me to take it back because it was filthy.  She has no interest in reading the F word all the time.  They say it is J.K. Rowling's first book for adults, but what gave her the idea that truly mature adults want to hear the F-bomb all the time?

author: S. Ham
title: Listen and Learn
body: Men vs. Women

author: Amazon Customer
title: a train wreck
body: There have been many eloquent reviews already which echo my thoughts on this book.  I was not expecting a rehash of Harry Potter, was forewarned it was for adults and had few expectations.  However, I would have put this book down several times out of disgust and boredom, had I not hoped that somewhere, somehow, a little bit of redemption would be present.  I wish I had put it down at some point rather than force myself to keep reading.  Glad I had it from the library.

author: Ella Green
title: Rowling's Best
body: I can't say how happy I was to see this side of Rowling. She has definitely matured as a writer since her first book, and it was great to see her writing at her full potential, in a way she could not while writing Harry Potter. This is an honest account of life, and a great example of how the life of one person can be so deeply entwined with that of others.

author: ArianneMartell
title: Not what I expected.
body: The casual vacancy is not usually my type of book, and it got me time to get into it (around 20% in, I think), but once I did, I was really glad I stick with it. How she handle the characters is very interesting and the ending kind of shock me actually. It was really nice and I'd recommend it.

author: L Ramsey
title: No Way
body: I haven't read the book yet. Just sharing that no way am I going to pay $18 for a Kindle book, no matter who wrote it. I'll put myself on the waiting list at the library. I'll adjust the stars after I actually read it.

author: Lyn Russell
title: A modern Dickens.
body: An engrossing and well crafted expose of middle class complacency and prejudice.  I couldn't put it down and look forward to further adult fiction from Rowling.

author: high flyer
title: Huge disappointment!
body: I loved JK Rowling's style of writing in the Harry Potter books. This book reads like it is written by a 16 yr old.  I am only halfway through and will finish it only because it cost so much. Do NOT waste your money or time on this one.

author: Kelly L. Hensley
title: I feel bad for J.K. Rowling...
body: ...who has a built-in audience with a set of expectations.  She was writing for a very different set of readers in this book.  I haven't re-read the Potter series or listened to the audiobooks for a while, so I was interested to see how her strengths (description, plot) and weaknesses (wordiness, love of adverbs) as an author translated.  From what I'd read of the book pre-publication, I didn't expect any magic or sly allusion to Harry's world.

author: Tony Burson
title: A cast of true characters
body: I was born in England and lived there for 28 years, this is the England I left and have seen during many visits to Derbyshire.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Great Disappointment!!
body: I only read the first 10 pages of this book.  I was totally disappointed.  It is full of foul language which was really offensive.  I don't know anyone who actually uses that kind of language. I truly believe any author worth reading should have a good enough grasp of the language that they can express themselves without using foul words!!!!  A book considered 'adult' does not have to be full of offensive language to make it 'interesting'.  Also it seemed to be a very wordy, slow moving story. I deleted it from my kindle fire!  If I could give it a negative amount of stars I would.

author: JOHN A SHAW
title: no magic
body: I found myself thinking "who was this character" after 150 pages.  It was a hard book to pick up and very easy to put asside.

author: jack
title: dont bother
body: Just finished this book. My advice to all would be dont buy it!!! If Amazon would take it back I would send it immediatly back.

author: J. F. Stepnowski
title: Can't finish it....
body: Alas, I WANT to like this.  I am not put off by the language or adult content.  I am getting tired of having to thumb back through the book to remind myself who, exactly, several characters are - I am getting some of them mixed up with each other.  I find myself wishing for a character list at the front of the book (like you get in some big fat old Russian novels ;-) ).  I am on page 143 and so far have found not one single character I can give a hoot about - not one seems sympathetic or to have redeeming qualities that would make me want to keep reading to see what happens to them.  Sigh.  Page 143 and I think I am done.  :-(

author: Autumn "From the TBR Pile"
title: It was just ok...
body: When Barry Fairweather dies it opens up a casual vacancy on the city council.  A casual vacancy is defined as a situation in which an unexpected opening occurs on a political board, as in the case of a death or disqualification.  Mr. Fairweather's death throws the town of Pagford into turmoil to say the least.  The town has been divided for many years over the issue of "The Fields" and under which jurisdiction they should reside.  Do the residents of The Fields reside in Pagford and use their resources or do they belong to the neighboring, larger town of Yarvil?  Currently the populace of The Fields is made up of low income, government dependent residence so many in Pagford would like to see them sent to Yarvil, Barry Fairweather is a popular resident of Pagford and he came from The Fields and he has made many good argument about why the people of Pagford need to take care of the people of The Fields.  The death of Barry Fairweather heralds a change in the weather for the anti-Fields clan and they are eager to fill his seat with a candidate sympathetic to their cause.

author: Ann M Beasley
title: Depressing book
body: I picked it up on the reputation of J.K. Rowlings previous books. I will not be picking the next one. This is a very depressing book. There is no plot, it is just s character study of a small town and not one of the characters are likeable. Halfway through the book I was thinking, "okay, I get it" and hoping that something would happen but it never does.  Don't waste your money on this book. It is not clever or entertaining.

author: Lynn Dye
title: The warnings were true
body: I was excited to hear Rowling was writing again and eagerly ordered this book at my local library. Before I picked it up, I started reading some reviews and thought, 'oh no, this doesn't sound like something I'd like'. Sure enough, I started the book and read the first few chapters and then I knew I would NOT be finishing this book. Instead, I skipped throughout the book reading portions of it and now will be returning it to the library.

author: Nannie
title: Disgusted Reader
body: Seldom have I ever been so disappointed with a book.  I have read and re-read all of the Harry Potter books and I guess I was expecting a book of their quality.  Boy, was I ever wrong.  I have been privileged to teach for 44 years and also serve as librarian.  I bought this book because my high school readers were wanting more J. K. Rowling.  Before I got past page 14 in the book, I had to mark out copious inappropriate words.  Young people are exposed to inappropriate sights, sounds and words in their lives.  They absolutely do not need to see them in the works of a beloved author.  Shame on you, J. K. Rowling.

author: Grammcracker
title: Disappointed by Content
body: As fabulous as a writer as J.K. Rowling is, this book is simply not for me. The "f" bombs and sexual content (which were unnecessary to the plot ( as usual) , had me walking away. Thankfully , I used the Amazon Kndle option of reading the sample before I purchased the book. This is one Rowling book that will never be part of my library. For those of you who enjoy a good book without the junk I hope this review helps.

author: E. Taylor
title: I laughed & cried & couldn't put it down
body: I thought this was a fabulous story! VERY well written, not a word wasted. JKR has a very sharp perception on human behaviour & it's in full force here. Her writing reminds me of a less twisted & dark Roald Dahl. Highly recommend for those who appreciate great writing.

author: M Gerrish
title: A Very Sad Place
body: One can't escape knowing about J.K Rowling, her difficult background, her stupendous success with Harry Potter. I never read more than a few pages in one book from the series, which presented itself at my nephew's bedtime. I was unimpressed, it felt tedious, although I have enjoyed the movies.

author: Ron Nagy
title: Casual Vacancy
body: Casual Vacancy is one of the few books I ever threw in the garbage. I read 70 pages of dull, negative, poorly placed foul language before it hit the garbage can. I would not classify "Adult" because of the foul language that was forced or better yet deliberately placed so this book would seem Adult. Definitely not an up lifting feel good book or a book I would recommend to anyone.  J Rowling has ruined her reputation and certainly we adults will never again buy our wee ones a Rowling book. What was Rowling thinking when she was writing this book????

author: Dan H.
title: Haven't read it, Wont read it
body: Sorry, but this is one more example of my frustration at having purchased a kindle.  $17.99 for a blast or electronic digits.  $17.90 for a brand new hardcover.  People can talk about it being Publisher's fault all they want.  Paying more, even nine cents more, for a digital version over a hardcover is simply wrong.

author: Leslie A. Daley
title: 'JK Rowling' by name ONLY
body: First off, I'm a complete and total 110% Potterhead.  I love the series, loves the book, can read them over and over and never tire of them.  When I found out JK Rowling was publishing an adult book, I pre ordered it the moment Amazon let me.  I recieved it the other day literally jumping up and down for several minutes before I hurried ot my room to begin reading it.

author: J. Yu-Sian Wang
title: Story doesn't call me ... lots of vulgar, swearing, cursing language
body: I love Harry Potter, and have been delighted with the Potter Universe, the characters, the environments, and the story.  Somehow this story is just not interesting to me.  I read thru the "see inside for a quick peek" ... it still does not call me.  I don't doubt that JK Rowling had put together great prose and great observations, but I just can't read through it without falling asleep. I guess I'm just not  that interested in provincial English country life or something like that.

author: JMP
title: VERY Boring book
body: As an adult, I read all the Harry potter books and enjoyed all seven of them.

author: mimi
title: standing ovation for J.K
body: I enjoyed this book so much, I didnt want it to end. The way J.K knows to describe all the thoughts that go through all of us and at the same time does not stop us from judging others..she is an amazing writer. A lot of small sentences are so condense with so much of the human truth. i loved the book, i really did. bravo!

author: Shelley Morrill
title: DON'T READ THIS!!!
body: I feel like this book was an over correction from Harry Potter, like she was out to prove she doesn't just write about kid stuff by fearlessly writing about the most terrible aspects of human nature.  Maybe someone will feel that's heroic.  I feel it's pointless and unnecessary because it's been done.  A lot.  The plot is simple and I see what she is trying to say, but it is overdone and becomes dull and cliche.  Many books of this genre aim to inspire one to do better and change the world.  This story just makes me depressed.  There is no humor to cut the sadness.  I dislike/hated most of the characters and only a couple I could tolerate.  Why would I read a story with an unoriginal plot and unlikable characters that makes me feel depressed by the first 100 pages?

author: LitChick
title: Rowling is a literary master. Keep in mind this is not HP.
body: As someone who appreciates literature, Rowling amazes me with her talent. Once you put it out of your mind that this is not the wizarding world of Harry Potter, you can appreciate the stunning images of real life invoked from her syntax.

author: J. Conneely
title: IF YOU SEE YOURSELF, TRY NOT TO FEEL THREATENED
body: I gave the book 4 stars instead of 5 because of the slow start.  The editors should have  prevented this, especially for such a high profile writer.

author: O. Lindy
title: I'm so surprised!
body: The writing style is completely different from her past works - if I didn't know that JK Rowling wrote this, I would never guess she is the author.  Her range is impressive.  The characters are completely fleshed out, the language is strong but true, and the setting is so close to reality, as realistic as HP was fantastical.  I am reading The Goblet of Fire with my son, and to switch between the two books was interesting to say the least.  I am very pleased to have read this book and look forward to reading whatever else JKR decides to publish.

author: DB
title: Bold Call For Help For The Kids Who Are "Have Nots"
body: I think the author could have rested on her laurels after her unprecedented success with Harry Potter.  However, instead my take is she felt called to action to point out this problem of the "haves" and "have nots".  For more than half way through the book I was thinking it was mediocre at best.  But by the time I finished it, I came to realize it was a bold, brilliant way to get us to think about the "haves" and "have nots" and how inside people's minds, daily thoughts and hearts they are all the same no matter which side of the tracks they live on.  Granted all of the people in this book were messed up, alhough Krystal and Kay did try to help others.  My guess is since the author has achieved unprecedented success, she has met people in high positions she would not have otherwise met and she has been unimpressed or even disappointed.  I think Rowling's bottom line is there are "have not" kids out there dealing with real problems such as drug addict parents and some of the people who appear to the be pillars of their towns, schools, etc. are not helping them because they fill their days with all of the nonsense/shortcomings we saw in the book.  Yes, I bet the next book will deal with more social issues.  And yes she will probably offend some people again as she attempts to influence them to action.  I think it is her way of giving back after all of her success.

author: Sean P. Endress
title: "The books that the world calls immoral are the books that show the world its own shame." - Oscar Wilde
body: Rowling's "The Casual Vacancy" is, in some way, indeed aimed at her prior audience. The children that grew up with Harry and company are now in their early twenties, the demographic which this reviewer believes will have the most interest in this work.

author: Julie Merilatt
title: Meh
body: Once you get past the novelty of a beloved children's author using vulgarity and narrating drug use and sex, the book is relatively mundane.  The plot lumbers along at a moderate pace, introducing characters of the town of Pagford and outlining their situations.  While Rowling excels at character development, the townsfolk in this novel are unsavory, bordering on detestable.  Junkies, wife beaters, ambitious small-town politicians, despondent wives, and horny teenagers make up this cast.  Once everyone's intrigues are presented, the pacing slows down for the latter two-thirds of the book until the last 40-ish pages.  There's a mildly tragic and somewhat climactic conclusion, but by the end, I just wanted to be finished.  There were some decent little sub-plots and some deserving characters got their comeuppance, but the daily minutiae of Pagford was monotonous.

author: Lane
title: A Beautiful Satire from a Matured Author
body: Rowling's writing style has matured. Her goals as an author, too, have come a long way.

author: Donna
title: Secrets, Sabotage, and Scandal or Oh the things muggles get up to...
body: Casual Vacancy tells the story of a small community in the aftermath of the unexpected death of one of its community leaders and council members, Barry Fairbrother. Several of Fairbrother's peers are ready and willing to fill his empty council seat but not everyone is happy with the nominees. Suddenly this small town is like an episode of Gossip Girl as somebody claiming to be Barry Fairbrother's ghost begins posting on the council's website and outing all of the member's dirty little secrets (XoXo) And while all of the adults are plotting, planning, and pointing fingers, who is watching their kids? These parents may have underestimated their teens' resentments as they focus all of their energy on their position in the community.

author: Joan V. Finman
title: SO DISAPPOINTED!
body: I WAITED SO LONG FOR ROWLING'S NEW BOOK TO COME OUT..........I WAS SO VERY DISAPPOINTED IN IT, RIGHT FROM THE START....I'M NOT SURE I AM EVEN ABLE TO FINISH IT.  IT IS EXTREMELY BORING.  PERHAPS SHE SHOULD STAY WITH MORE BOOKS LIKE HARRY POTTER, I THINK THAT'S WHERE THE MIND SET SHOULD BE

author: JMK
title: I loved it, and don't understand what people were expecting.
body: If more people had approached this book with an open mind, I think it would have gotten better reviews. Despite being told again and again that this book would be nothing like the H.P. books, some people obviously expected something similar. I also think if you understand something about the British sensibility you will like it better too. I've read lots of British authors works and if I had to compare her work to someone else's, I would compare it a bit to Faye Weldon's body of work. In my humble opinion, there is a greater divide between the "haves" and the "have-nots" in England. Rowling (and Weldon) love skewering the upper classes high opinion of themselves. In The Casual Vacancy, the little town of Pagford wants to cut financial support for a drug clinic in the Fields, which lies between Pagford and Yarvil. Pagford fancies itself the quintessential quaint English village, they don't want the taint of the Fields associated with their town. Of course the fact that a lot of the people in Pagford have roots in the Fields is something they'd all rather forget. Rather than realizing how lucky they were to escape the fate of most Fieldians and trying to help others improve their lot, they want to distance themselves from the people and problems of the Fields. It illustrates how quickly some people can forget where they came from once they get a little money. The biggest exception is Barry Fairbrother, who is from the fields, but lives in Pagford and serves on the town council and is trying to help one girl in particular, Krystal Weedon. Krystal is a perfect example of someone whose life could have gone either way. You get the feeling that if Barry had not passed away, Krystal may have had a chance. You see how easily someone can give up on themselves if no one else believes in them. I don't want to give anything else away but I think her characterizations are just a tiny bit caricatured but otherwise they seem pretty spot on. I hope Rowling writes many more books for adults and I hope she is not influenced by bad reviews to write fluff just to please people who'd rather not have a glimpse at a side of life they'd rather not know exists.

author: aeb
title: REAL characters, and an effective message about society as a whole.
body: The Casual Vacancy opens with the death of Barry Fairbrother, a prominent citizen of the tiny village of Pagford and member of the Pagford Parish Council, and follows by introducing all the various characters of the book (citizens of Pagford) and their reactions to his death. Although I didn't find it boring, I felt as though the first third of the book or so contained so many new characters written from so many different points of view that I felt like the first third of the book was more an introduction than anything, and it was a bit hard at first to keep all the names straight and remember who was who. The action moved very slowly and I found myself wondering, "What is going to HAPPEN in this book other than meeting a lot of (albeit very interesting) characters?"

author: Rita Mayberry
title: Good story, just a little long.
body: I am enjoying reading The Casual Vacancy by J.K. Rowlings. I like the character development -- she is indeed a master and getting inside a character's skin and showing what makes him or her tick. This certainly must capture modern life in a small British community.  I am hardly an expert on that, but, lets face it, J.K. Rowlings certainly is. It matters little, though, where the story is set.

author: Norman R. Goos
title: Not worth the time and money
body: The book was somewhat cute, a maze of subplots coming together for a flat ending.  It was not as well written at the Potter series.  The author's knowledge of British hamlet life today and it's street talk was impressive, although it did nothing for the story line - Krystal et al became boring.  Over all, it would have been a good $5.00 paperback to speed read on a flight, but there was no substance.

author: shay's #3 fan
title: soooo disappointed
body: not a reader of Harry Potter...thought I'd try Casual Vacancy....I think the reviewer who wrote she'd rather drink drain cleaner has it just right...I have read more than half this depressing, miserable tome and just can't go any further.  What a disappointment---The publisher should provide tranquilizers...or good stiff drinks...or just tell the eager buyers....it's dark, dreary, depressing...

author: A. Ackerman
title: Couldn't Do It
body: I was so excited to see what Rowling would do for her first adult novel, and I'm greatly disappointed.  I couldn't get into the story at all.  There were way too many characters and I couldn't keep them all straight.  But more importantly, I didn't really care to.  None of the characters were interesting - they all seemed so depressing!  So yeah, I didn't finish it, and even if you tell me it all makes sense in the end, I won't be picking it up again.  At least we'll always have Harry....

author: JQ
title: How did this happen?
body: From Harry Potter to this???? I don't understand.  This must be the first time in over 20 years where I broke my  steadfast rule of always finish a book once it's started.  I just couldn't do it with this book.  It was too painful.  There wasn't a story, just one chapter after another describing one of the many pathetic characters who was "flawed" in one way or another.  It just became a chore to even open the book.  I hear enough of this kind of thing on the news.  Do I really need to read about it in a fictional book too?  I was hoping for a book that drew me into its world and I would want to find out more because I was concerned about each character.  This book was the polar opposite.  I couldn't care less about any of these whiny, shallow, maddening characters.  I wanted so much to love this book because it's J.K. Rowling for goodness sake!  Sadly, I tried my best, but I couldn't even get through half of it before I decided that I'd rather be sorting socks than continue with this book.  Sorry!

author: Brock C.
title: Boring.
body: When I received this book I was excited to see where JK Rowling would take us to this time. She never disappointed with her 7 HP books so I was pretty confident she wouldn't disappoint this time. Well needless to say I was too bored to figure out how this book ended. It was boring and I felt like the author was trying to be too edgy. It drags on and nothing really happens other than some really boring government issue. If you are seeking to find an adventure and some comedy this is not the book. It is definitely an adult book and not suitable for children. I wont bother reading anymore books in the future from this author.

author: R. james Tobin
title: Rowling's Characters
body: J.K. Rowling's The Casual Vacancy is raw realism, with "adult" themes: sex (not all consensual) drug addiction, cutting, not to mention smoking, drinking and profanity; also betrayal and death. Oh, yes, it is also about local politics and about responsibility for the outcast and addicted. There are many characters, few of them at all appealing, but vivid just the same. To understand what Rowling is doing here, one should remember two things: she grew up in the same part of England she is centering her story on here; and, more importantly, her favorite author was Jane Austen, who was interested in character and human relations above all.

author: Booker87
title: Nothing New Here
body: I bought this book hoping to be entertained, but was disappointed. I was led to believe it had a comedic edge, but I failed to find anything funny in it.

author: God is good
title: Vulgar
body: Not appropriate for Harry potter lovers.  I am an adult and was too young to read.  I quit after fifty pages.  It did not catch my attention.

author: Robyn Woods
title: Didnt even finish
body: I dont know if its fair but Im making a review without finishing the book.  But I guess thats kind of a review in itself!  Simply, I was thoroughly bored and disappointed with the little I read. There was no reason for me to be interested enought to continue.  I expected alot more from Rowling.

author: Jamieson Wolf
title: A Book To Live In
body: Welcome to Pagford.

author: Elaine
title: Just awful
body: I have only read the first few chapters of The Casual Vacancy, and I'm printing out the labels to return it to Amazon.  It is awful.  Just awful.  I'd read ahead of time that it isn't a children's book, but I had no idea that meant it would be crude, crass, obscene, and profanity-laced.  And?  It's boring.  Really boring.  I expected so much more from J.K. Rowling, and I'm truly disappointed in this book.

author: Amelia Gremelspacher
title: Portrait of a small town.
body: I liked this book mainly for the character development.  Rowling does a thoughtful job of examining a small groups of people and the enmeshments that snarl their lives.  The events following the death of a counsel man, and the efforts of these people to deal with his absence, set the novel a task of explicating how these people come together.  I think a good job was done in exploring the difference between the public persona and the actual thought and circumstances of each character,  I especially like Krystal, the bad girl, whose genuine love for her brother goes largely unknown, as she becomes vilified as both "a duty and a pleasure" except by those who came to know her.  The implausible elements of some of the ending are the the only setbacks to five stars.  This novel stands up to the hype, and I wasn't disappointed.

author: J. Ardis Cochrane
title: Trainspotting meets Jane Austen
body: Funny, poignant. Easy to suspend my disbelief. I doubt I would have read except from curiosity, famousest author goes feral, etc, ... But I am glad I did. Slightly weirded out by the pride and prejudice echoes in the first few chapters. Then the trainspotting parts kinda took over.

author: J. Dehr
title: It's clearly literature!
body: Most people are probably not going to like this. It's nothing like her H.P. series. It's clearly LITERATURE and she takes a lot of time setting up the characters.  Interesting story and I enjoyed the ending.

author: Ms. Neroli Wesley
title: Strong, revealing and not for children  -- no spoilers --
body: The residents of Pagford are a motley bunch of upper, middle and working class people all stumbling through life as best they can while expressing the weaknesses and longings of humans at their worst. The most sympathetic character makes his presence felt in absence. Like Rowling he experienced the extremes of life and came up trumps fighting against ignorance, pettiness and bigotry. Many of the other characters have few redeeming features but enough of them grow for the ending to be satisfying.

author: Phil Wigglesworth
title: English humor triumphs
body: I took a while to adjust to the tangled web of characters so clearly defined but yet at every step you are forced to readjust your knowledge of them.  This is a clever blend of revealing aspects of each life that initially make you question whether you are mixing up people, but then you realise that each person has a unique personae for each relationship and only in time do you start to see the blend that is the whole imperfect personality.

author: Lexi
title: Remove Expectations Before Reading
body: I loved the book. It reminded me a lot of

author: Cate Berarovich
title: Mugglemarch? Not Hardly.
body: Full disclosure, I grew up with Harry Potter and so I am somewhat biased. While the first book came out when I was only seven, but by the time Harry was defeating lord Voldemort, we were both seventeen. I was part of the generation of children who halfway expected to get an owl on their eleventh birthday, and the name J.K. Rowling was, and still is, as magical as Hogwarts itself.

author: Kenneth S. Wiggins
title: 3 strikes and your out
body: My wife has a rule about dirty jokes... they at least better be funny. If Rowling wishes to write a vulgar book she needs it to be well written and interesting. She struck out on all three.

author: Alex
title: Disappointed
body: I was very excited to see this book and it was a major disappointment.  It was dreary, depressing and boring.  The world created in this book is not one anyone would want to visit.  I find it hard to believe that the same author who wrote the Harry Potter books could have actually written this book.  There was absolutely not one minute of joy or hope in the entire book and I disliked all of the characters.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Too long
body: I struggled through this book because of who it was written by.  If I didnt know the author and her excellent Harry Potter books, I dont think I would have made it to the end.  It started well, but there were too many characters and they were confusing in their roles they played.  There were two really good stories in this book, but because they were in the one book I didnt like either of them.  Such a shame.

author: Hayley Potter
title: A proper review, by someone who's actually finished it
body: I felt compelled to write this review... as I'm convinced that most people bad-mouthing this book weren't even able to finish it.

author: Rob
title: Imagine that Harry dies in the prologue to book one
body: I wasn't sure whether to give this book one star or five stars. I don't normally cry when I read books, but Rowling has made me cry three times. I cried when Dobby died. I cried when Harry went into the forest to meet Voldemort and die. And I cried at the tragic, heart-breaking ending to this book.

author: hema18
title: 'Book for Adults?"
body: I read this book telling myself that here was a new author with a new book. I was well aware that this would not be a similar offering from a well known author of a particular genre. However, I did expect the creativity and imagination that this author is justly famous for.

author: Euphony
title: A Sadly Slogging Satire
body: A writer from The Guardian dubbed this "Mugglemarch" and I must agree the name is apt. The descriptions were decent and the "point" is a worthy one. Sadly, the tone of the story is so jaded and bitter (even if understandably so), that a spark of mystery (or dare I say magic?) would not have been amiss. I know that entertaining her readers isn't Miss Rowling's goal, but SOMETHING felt lacking and all the overworked prose and detailed descriptions in the world simply cannot disguise (what I found to be) a disappointingly mediocre work of satirical social commentary.

author: Andra Jiglau
title: Gripping, perfectly crafted prose
body: Firstly,I am shocked to see so many bad reviews. I hope most of them are from people who expected Harry Potter, if not in genre, at least in feel : good will triumph, people have treasures in their souls no matter how hard they mutilate it etc.

author: D Bloch
title: nothing special...kind of a disappointment
body: the positive:  it was well written and the characters were well developed.

author: LindaV in Gardena
title: Definitely a keeper
body: The book is not for the non-serious reader, nor is it a book for simple entertainment.

author: L. A. McCoy
title: boring
body: When I read, I want to be entertained.  I wasn't. I didn't expect or want Harry Potter, but the characters were colorless.  It may be Peyton Place vs whatever ---as stated in a previous review, but I didn't like Peyton Place either.  I kept waiting to be fascinated with the characters, but it was like a hum drum ...nothing interesting to catch my attention or make me want to turn the page......not my cup of tea.  I don't think I will finish it.

author: Mom22
title: Too expensive for Kindle
body: I have not read this book and do not intend to read it because I think the publisher has priced it too high for the Kindle. I love reading Kindle books, but the price should be lower because the books can not be shared. If I buy the book for just a few more dollars, I can share it with anyone I'd like. I prefer the Kindle version, but I think it's wrong to charge so much for an electronic book.

author: Booklover62
title: Simply A Good Read!
body: Why 5 stars?

author: T. Cutter
title: Make your own decisions
body: If you have any interest in this book, ignore the star rating on Amazon. Most of the low ratings seem to be from people who either wanted a muggle version of Harry Potter, are upset about the price, or are outraged that there is adult content in a book written for adults. Either find a review from a publication you trust or just get the book from the library.

author: Nordic Witch
title: I Give it 5 SNORES
body: So many great writers out there of adult fiction that can't get into print because they are unknown. But have a name and even a guaranteed sleep inducer gets published. I was told this was a steamy, adult book by the H.Potter author. Steamy? As in 15 year olds getting excited and playing with themselves? Ughhh! I gave this book too many chances to redeem itself, but with so many, many characters of which none are interesting... One reaches a point where one realizes that life is too short to be bored to death. Don't care about the characters, no reason to, since they are as realistic as cardboard cut-outs.

author: bookmanbookwoman
title: For Adults Onlly
body: "J.K. Rowling, the author of the famous Harry Potter series has written an adult story that should be read by grownups. It is big business versus those that are small and functional adults pitted against the dysfunctional. The Casual Vacancy will not disappoint Rowling's fans who wanted her to write something that is not for the young at heart."

author: Sharon M. Galbraith Ryer
title: Tightly plotted character drama
body: Ain' no Harry Potter book. And if you're looking for one, look somewhere else. If, however, you are looking for a tightly plotted, intricate political drama about small-town characters who could be real people, this is it.

author: I. Kelly
title: So bad that I like HP less than I used to...
body: CV has, (according to the Kindle description) 81 characters.  Going into the book I guessed that, somewhere amongst those 81 characters, there would be someone who wasn't both boring and a terrible person.  I was wrong.

author: kitplanesue
title: Dreadful
body: There's nothing charming about this book. The foul language, low life characters, gutter scenarios and tedious story line

author: ikirkwood62
title: You can try to separate Harry Potter from this...
body: ... but you cannot. And that's not the fault of the reader, that's the fault of the author. But let's start at the beginning.

author: hm
title: Don't expect Harry Potter, but it's a good book
body: I tried to read this with a completely open mind, since I am in LOVE with the Harry Potter books and knew this probably wouldn't be anything like them. It was a little slow going at first, but it turns out that she is such a good writer that you stay invested even though not that much actually happens, at least in the first half of the book. If you like "slice of life" type books you will enjoy this one. By the second half, I was eager to continue reading it.

author: C. O'Connell
title: Sadly disappointed.
body: As magical and adventurous the characters  in The Harry Potter books were, the characters in this book are the exact opposite.  Only their  dark side is shown.  In this whole  set of villagers,  there's not  one redeeming value presented.  It is probably well written,  but I couldn't see the forest from the trees.  I listened to it, and there is just unrelenting darkness.

author: Amanda Richards
title: 100 shades of "meh"
body: Man down

author: Viva
title: What a let down!
body: I am really disappointed in this book.  The story is so trite and the characters are not very interesting.  The worse thing about it is the language.  If I had wanted to read a smut novel, I could have chosen something a lot less expensive.

author: Samantha Rinne Hooker
title: Meh...
body: Before she wrote Harry Potter, I heard she wrote a few crappy novels. Maybe this is one of them?

author: C. Tyler
title: Totally disappointing
body: After reading the Harry Potter series, I was so happy to see another creation by Rowling.  This book is the biggest bunch of drivel I've ever tried to read.  Her use of so much shocking language and subject matter is really irritating.  She had no purpose in using this type of material other than to make it an Adult book.  The language is unneeded for the story and the story seems to have no real plot.  It is total garbage as far as I am concerned.  I do believe that teens might like it just for the tittillating passages, but adults should be offended by the way the material is presented.  When necessary to make a point, then I don't mind graphic language, but her usage is only for shock value, I believe.  It seems she believes that it is needed to make it an Adult book.  I am sorry I wasted my money on this garbage.

author: jeremy_david
title: Adjusted Expectations
body: This book is no Harry Potter, but who said it would be? If you go in expecting a masterpiece (not only with this book but with most things in general) then you will most likely be disappointed. Just start it with an open mind and be prepared to enter a world full of entertaining (if not morally detestable) people. It's a funny read.

author: BirdieJ
title: Great read!
body: I found this book to be interesting, charming, and touching.  It really draws the reader into the world of a small town.

author: LeeAnne the Librarian
title: Not what I expected - really bad
body: This is the worst book I have attempted to read in a long time. I say attempted because I am having trouble getting through the the first half. It is dull, boring, dark, and pessimistic. Not my kind of read. I will perservere because once I start something I usually finish it. I am so disappointed because I loved the Harry Potter books. I guess I expected more from this author.  Maybe I am not English enough to understand what is going on in the book. I cannot perservere - this book is so bad - I finally deleted it from my Kindle.  I really did try to read it.

author: Joan Sutton
title: JK Rowling kidnapped by Muggles!
body: Yes, there's only one reason she wrote this book:  she was highjacked by Muggles, obviously.  I must admit I haven't finished it yet, but my impression is that she was buried somewhere in Muggle-Land when she wrote it.  I hope she has escaped by now.  I hear she is contemplating another Harry Potter novel - GOOD!  Hope she sticks to magic from now on.

author: Cee Ess
title: Some Vacancy - a comment on Social Darwinism
body: I bought it half price (no tax). For $18.50 I figured I would read it and pass it along to family and friends. I'm not down with all the JK hype, I just wanted a decent read, and I knew she was a good writer having consumed four HP books.

author: Trollhair
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Boring. Boring. Boring. Boring. NOT a adult book. She is still writing for children except this one has  vulgar words and sexual situations (from the teenagers no less). Her style of writing is such that  a fifth grader could read and comprehend. The book read like a bad soap opera. She even wrote it so you can move from scene to scene knowing what others are doing at that particular moment. I am still wondering why I spent two days reading this book.

author: pure_predat0r
title: Death is casual
body: 'The Casual Vacancy' showed me another way in which J.K Rowling is an intelligent, compassionate woman; it's a reflection of societies ugliness that I never would have expected from the author of 'Harry Potter'.

author: GPS
title: If you expect Harry Potter - DON'T buy!!
body: I pre-ordered this book as soon as the possibility came up, and when I received it last week I was thrilled to bits!

author: wantoun
title: It's quite interesting... if you manage to endure the first half!
body: So first of all when you set out to read this, and you're a Harry Potter fan, you need to realize this is NOT Harry Potter in any way. You could have read a hundred novels with adult language, but seeing a couple of swear words from JK Rowling will definitely be shocking at first! You must get over all this if you want to enjoy the book.

author: voracious reader
title: Bleak and not that original
body: I am a huge Harry Potter fan and would read anything J.K. Rowling wrote.  But I probably won't be reading this one over and over. It had so many characters, all unlikable, that it took a long time to get into it.  Many of my favorite books have a setting or characters I'd like to revisit.  I didn't find the "darkly comic" element of this book funny enough to compensate for the fact of nearly all the characters being desperate, whiny, involved in sordid behavior and endlessly thwarted.  I kept wondering what was the author's point in writing this book, since it couldn't be to tell an enjoyable story.  And the horrible details of poverty, drug addiction and various kinds of abuse are all too familiar to anybody who reads the news.  In the last 10% of the book the plot finally started to move along, and some of the characters at the end did get to grow and change.  **SPOILER ALERT**--when certain characters died tragically I was actually relieved, as they had no future and were doomed from the start by the circumstances of their lives (and also the circumstances of the book--it was hard to see how they could sink much lower and this wasn't the type of book where they were going to get a happy ending).  One of these characters was the most sympathetic in the book and only in the last few pages were some anecdotes revealed that added to her humanity.  By the end I thought the author's point was probably to draw attention to the ways in which society fails its most disadvantaged children, and that in an interdependent world this has repercussions for people from other socioeconomic levels.  She accomplished this pretty well but it wasn't new territory, and not the book I was hoping for.

author: kfingo
title: Brilliant!  JKR is Top Notch!
body: This is a dark tale of woe.  There are not many characters in this books that are likeable...but there are moments of hope and light.

author: Reveur
title: My thoughts and feelings as a former Harry Potter fangirl
body: So I just finished The Casual Vacancy by JK Rowling.

author: E. Morris
title: Life in Little Layers
body: The reviews already tallied here have reiterated, ad nauseum, how unlike Harry Potter The Casual Vacancy is so I won't bother saying it.  What I will say is that by reading this new work, a reader of Harry Potter can see just how brilliant a writer for young adults Rowling is.  The language in The Casual Vacancy is lovely.  It is meaty, something you can properly sink your teeth into and savor slowly.  The lightness of touch she had in the Potter series is now clear, having tasted her adult fiction.  It makes the Potter series that much more brilliant in my eyes.  And it makes The Casual Vacancy that much more astounding; it is brave to venture so far from something so comfortable as a writing style one has practiced for years.

author: G. Cat
title: Well written, grown up book
body: Those expecting a Harry Potter book for grownups  will be dissapointed, but if you put aside preconceptions you will find The Casual Vacancy a well written and thought provoking book about family relationships, community relationships, and class.  The characters are not entirely likable but are complex.  It does take a while to sort out all the characters and their relationships.

author: M. HARDT
title: Super book
body: I inhaled this book as soon as it hit my Kindle.  I did not have the formatting problems mentioned by other reviewers.

author: Tom F.
title: A Dreadful Book
body: This is one of the worst books I have ever read.  There are too many characters and by the time you get to know who they are, you quickly realize that you don't like or care about ANY of them.  I did read it but could easily have read the first few chapters and then skipped to the predictable end.  I am in disbelief that JKR  put out this pile of rubbish.  I would never recommend this book and even if you can borrow it for free like I did, (thankfully,) it is still not worth your time. Go back to Harry's world, Jo, "The Casual Vacancy" is embarrassing no matter how much money you make from it.  Actually, all proceeds should got to charity as you deserve nothing for wasting our time with this claptrap of a novel.

author: Kindle Customer
title: a modern agatha christie like village
body: really a great read, though it takes a while to keep all the characters' lives straight.  Rowling has a great ear for character's voices and I am amazed at how well she is able to represent different personality types, especially the teenagers.  I found it very moving and well written, not at all cliched as some have reviewed it.

author: Micker
title: Intriguing
body: I enjoyed reading this book.  It was a glimpse into the workings of a small English town.  I was amazed to find myself amazed that English people could be as dysfunctional as Americans.  I guess it really is a small world.  Although I will always miss Harry, I laud Ms Rowling for striking out in such a different direction.

author: Susan Watson
title: Save your money
body: I spent the weekend reading this book.  I found it boring and very predictable.  I would suggest that "King of the Badgers"

author: Mark
title: you can return it!
body: Not very good work.  You may want to know that Amazon allows you to return a kindle book within 7 days.

author: skqt
title: Abysmal!
