body: Not worth reading. Dull, cheap, vulgar, low, obscene, unrealistic, boring, humorless.

author: Claire
title: Great book
body: I really enjoyed the Casual Vacancy. It took me a while to get into it but after a few chapters I found it very compelling. Yes, many (not all) of the characters are unlikeable once you scratch beneath the surface but I think that simply reflects reality - EVERY person has flaws.

author: Marion Wilhelm
title: Don't bother...it's dull, dull, dull
body: JKR is such a good writer, rich descriptions, clever plots and characters that I was simply blown away at how ghastly this book was. To be fair, I simply could not even finish it and I read phone books and cereal boxes if that's all that's handy! This story moves at a snails pace, the characters are dull and lifeless and the theme is tedious. There is a it of "language" which I don't care about but seemed stilted and unconvincing as if Rowling wanted to convince the reader that she knew big girl words. I am sorry I purchased this book and wish I could return it. Actually I think I will return it!

author: Vavek Zivota
title: If you buy it, keep reading ... it gets better
body: I was not sure what to expect as the follow-up to the Harry Potter books from JK Rowling, so I came with no preconceived ideas on what this book should be, or would be when I bought it.  While a bit disappointing, it was still worth reading.

author: Amazon Customer
title: worthy of your time.
body: I loved it. I think readers of Nick Hornby, PG Wodehouse, Richard Russo, etc... would enjoy this. Ignore all the negativity. It was to be expected when switching genres and audiences.

author: Willread Anything
title: I was amazed how sleepy it made me!
body: I could not have been more dissappointed.  I had very high expectations for this book, after reading great reviews that Ms. Rowling had done it again.  Only this time in an adult market.  Please wait for this to go on sale someplace if you really must buy it.  It is not worth the price or the time out of your daily life that you will lose reading it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Man What a Book to Read So Much

author: S. Family
title: Trying too Hard
body: I LOVE the HP books.  As an adult, I just marvel at Rowling's ability to weave a complex story... she just thinks of EVERYTHING.  She's funny, and I loved most of all the "life lessons" of good-vs-evil, with there being both real evil and real good; imperfect characters who strive to do the right thing.  We cheer for the hard but fair teachers like Minerva McGonogal and Dumbledore.  We love the devoted (though far from perfect) families.

author: Kiwi
title: If only Hermione can cast "OBLIVIATE" on me.
body: Truthfully, I want to forget this book. Where's Hermione when you need her?

author: LadyJane
title: Simply trash
body: Glad I tried the sample before purchasing.  After reading, and enjoying, the Harry Potter books I was very dissapointed in this one.  The language is terrible and there is no real story to it.  Maybe if I read more, but I can't abide the language long enough to try.

author: Amazon Customer
title: A hard book, but a good one!
body: From the first couple of pages of this book, it was like curling up with an old friend. Sure, there is no magic, or huge victories over evil by the side of good, but the writing is familiar and still just as powerful. The Casual Vacancy is not a happy book, it can be downright depressing, but it's an important book to read. If this book was not written by JK Rowling, it probably would not have been published, which is a real shame. Its an important story about something that is effecting most communities due to the bad economy and harsh austerity measure. The town of Pagford is a wealthy one and when Barry Fairbrother, a do-gooder on the local council dies, a fraction of people want to get rid of the poor district of Fields and the methadone clinic. Like what is happening in the UK and the US and all over, some people would rather let the little guy fend for himself rather than work together as a community to help out everyone. The characters in the book are very flawed. The reader might agree with the views expressed by one character but hate their actions in their private lives. The adults can be huge hypocrites and just down right nasty.

author: S. Maxwell
title: If you like dark humor, it's for you.
body: One newspaper review I read before getting the book suggested that all of the characters are like the Dursleys in Harry Potter - mean, small-minded and selfish.  There are certainly some like that in this book, and Rowling uses them to paint a portrait of small town life in England that is alternately funny and appalling.  There's the self-satisfied and self-important parish council chairman whose chief goal in life is to cut off from his village a local housing project and de-fund the social services that help its struggling residents.  There's the middle-aged woman, trapped in a loveless, boring marriage, who secretly obsesses over a member of a boy band she sees in her daughter's DVD collection.  There's the middle manager at a printing company who terrorizes his wife and kids as though they were inmates in a concentration camp of which he is the commandant.  But there are also several characters who are well-meaning and want to do good works that don't benefit them personally - except in terms of validating their self-image.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Disappointed
body: J.K. Rowling has proven in the past to be a great storyteller.  The Casual Vacancy, however, is not her best work.  I am disappointed with the profanity and vulgar language in her book.  A good author does not need to resort to foul language and explicit sex scenes to entertain adults.  I am very disappointed with this book--I am sending it back!

author: SHIRLEY GRIMES
title: PRICE
body: WOULD LOVE TO READ HER ADULT WORKS, BUT NOT FOR 17.99  REALLY??

author: Lisa Jackson
title: Too Many Swear Words
body: Too many swear words. I read for 15 minutes and encountered 3 swear words. I stopped reading it and digitally returned it to Amazon Kindle for a refund due to "offensive content." If it woudn't have included the swear words, I'd have continued, even though I was very bored, just because I love the Harry Potter books and have faith in the author. I don't read books with swear words.

author: Hallie's Mom
title: Disappointed
body: I pre-ordered The Casual Vacancy, looking forward and curious to read a different genre written by Ms. Rowling. I could only get through about 12% of it before I quit reading it. It was depressing and it was hard to keep up with too many varied characters. I am a mature adult and loved the Harry Potter series. I supposed I anticipated a faster paced story. I would rate this book similar to many of the Oprah Book Club selections which I quit reading a long time ago. They also got to be too depressing. I don't mind a book with lots of interesting characters, but since I don't like reality shows, these characters were too much like unpleasant, conniving reality players to be part of an enjoyable read. And I do read for enjoyment because my life is real enough.

author: Amazon Buyer
title: Very glad I took a chance on this book...
body: Many of the reviews on Amazon do an excellent job of summarizing the plot, so I will not repeat that here.  Instead, let me summarize my reaction to this book and perhaps it will help others make up their own mind whether to read it or not.

author: Mark from Haifa
title: This book grew on me
body: It took me a while to get into this book, but once I did, it grew on me, and I read with increasing interest to the end. The characters are interesting, and the author successfully developed the story of their interaction in a small English town, where lives and plots are woven together.

author: Donald J. Richardson
title: Essentially Trash
body: While one should admire J. K. Rowling for trying to reach an adult audience, one must also retain relevant critical faculties; in this case A Casual Vacancy is embarrassingly awful. The characters are nearly interchangeable, the language is movie language (f*** with far too much regularity), and the characters are unsympathetic to distressingly negative. This appears to be naturalism to its NTH degree. Such wallowing in lower class society is not what this reader desires. He still believes literature ought to be enriching, elevating, and enlightening.

author: Diane B. Wilkes
title: THE CASUAL VACANCY Not A Dramatic Departure
body: When you've written a multi-million dollar book series that has spawned movies, merchandise up the wazoo, and miraculously magnetized boys back into the reading fold, as J.K. Rowling did with the Harry Potter books, much is expected. Loyal fans want to love the next book you write; snobby critics look forward to skewering it--"She can write children's novels, but..."

author: Chadwick Estrada
title: A dark look into a small town.
body: So I just finished reading The Casual Vacancy and I really enjoy it. I know people are having mixed feelings about the novel but for me it was great read. Rowling knows how to write great story about people who are connected one way or another. Its dark tale about struggle of drug abuse, bullying, and the feeling of being trap in a small town. Its not for everyone. For me this a is great stand alone novel and I can't wait for her next novel.

author: FW
title: Waste of time & money
body: I was not expecting Harry Potter but expected much better from Ms. Rowling. Are you sure she actually wrote this? This book is a complete boor and I am returning it immediately.

author: Wyomingwoman
title: dull
body: I had promised myself I would read at least 50 pages before I decided anything about this book because it took me that long to get into Harry Potter.  I didn't last that long.  I don't care for bad language and I didn't actually like most of the characters introduced at the first of the book.  Then I read the last chapter in case there was any redeeming qualities that would make me go back to read the rest.  There weren't.  I almost bought the book and am so glad I didn't. (sorry Amazon)

author: dpappas
title: Keep An Open Mind
body: This is a book that I really tried to start without any preconceived notions. I banned myself from reading any reviews of this book or any comments about it from other readers (the only thing I allowed myself to read was the book's summary). Basically what I tried to do was forget that J.K. Rowling was the author and to completely separate this book from the Harry Potter series.

author: F. M. Pepoon
title: Lack of Character Development Is the Fatal Flaw
body: I am a big fan of the Harry Potter series and have read the books again and again, wondering at JK Rowling's ability to create a world so real and appealing that readers want to live there, and to create stories that are so compelling they become a part of a reader. Sadly, this book did not come close to either of those experiences. As any Harry Potter reader knows, character development is not one of Rowling's strengths, and this is the fatal flaw of the book. The teenage characters are more finely wrought than the adults (as was true for the Harry Potter series) and there are a few of these teenagers who are engaging. I wish Rowling had either focused on the teenagers' stories more or developed the adult characters. The plot is mildly interesting and kept me reading through 2/3 of the book, but at that point, the fact that I did not care enough about the characters to continue reading overcame any vested interest I had in the story line. Finishing the book was a chore, and I found the ending to be wholly unsatisfactory. I hate when authors kill off characters because they cannot figure out what should happen next, it is an insult to the readers. If Rowling had spent some time developing some of the adult characters - there are two women in particular who could have carried the book - this might have been more successful. Alternately, instead of starting the book with the death of a man who appeared throughout the tale to be one of the few with any morals, Rowling could have started with his story and had him die later, which would have created an interesting pivotal point in the plot and tension in the story.

author: Proud Mom
title: AWFULL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
body: I read Harry Potter, but bought this with an open mind and not looking for an Adult Magical world, but what I go was garbage.  I rarely share my opinion of books, but wanted to warn readers to not waste their money on this book.  I was bored and the characters were flat and not written well.  Just save your money and buy something else.  I not only wish I could get my money back, but the time I wasted reading this.  Rowlings is good at writing Young Adult wizard novels and needs to find a new wizard to write about.

author: Debi Hernandez
title: Offensive
body: 40 pages in I found myself offended 3 times by language, alomst put it down twice before even getting that far.Boring,I am an avid reader 2 books a month,and if a book does not hold my attention 40 pages in ,I'm done...so sorry..Potter was her glory days,retirement looms...

author: C. F. Bush
title: Sorry Breakaway
body: I am very disappointed with this book.  I was not expecting anything like Harry Potter but I at least expected the story line to be readable and to keep my interest.  I am trying to find some redeeming qualities and cannot.  I will hope, if she writes another ADULT book it has a lot more to offer her readers.

title: The Casual Vacancy
body: This is the only review I have ever written.  I have never felt the need to tell people to save their money on a book before.  This book is painful to read.  I made it half way through the book, before I put it down for good.  I expected so much more from this author.

author: Travis
title: Thought-provoking. Cozy, even. Overall fully enjoyable.
body: The problem (some) people are having with this work of fiction is that they don't seem to be able to separate J.K. Rowling from Harry Potter. This book would be well-received by any other author but Mrs. Rowling's fame stemming from the very popular children's series has impeded many a critical thought. Think outside of the walls of Hogwarts, people.

author: abrenzikofer
title: very dark and depressing
body: I dont understand the point of this book. It was filled with characters who were miserable. I had a hard time keeping up with all the characters thrown at you in the beginning. Very depressing. I love to read and escape, but this was just so dark and dirty. No one seems to learn their lessons. Maybe I am not looking "deep" enough. Also would not let a child or teenager read this. Very strong language, sex, drugs, rape and abuse.

author: Pen Name
title: Very different from what you've come to know and expect from Rowling.
body: I have to start out by saying what a huge fan I am of J.K. Rowling, because I feel that may help some people understand my review better.  I'm a HUGE Potter fan, I re-read the series regularly and have been anticipating the release of any new book by Rowling for the past 5 years.  That being said, I didn't expect this book to be anything like Harry Potter plot-wise, or even in theme.  I was super-excited about something completely new from J.K. Rowling.  Regardless of what anyone says of her prose in her previous series I always found something sparkling and intoxicating in her writing style and characterizations.  So I eagerly purchased the Casual Vacancy on the first day of its release, and launched into it like a child greedily rips open presents on Christmas morning.  If anything asserts the distinction that this is not Harry Potter or any other book for young readers its the immediate and excessive usage of loose profanity, rampant drug and alcohol abuse and sexual depravity.  We are launched into the mind of every single character we encounter at some point, viewpoints shifting back and forth dizzyingly.  This allows us a unique access to their thoughts and backstories, and this third-person omniscent is very contrary to the third-person limited we experienced in her series.  Being a lover of minute details and normative everyday activities and thoughts, I was prepared to love this in every way.  You have to understand how much it pains me to say that I don't think I do, I feel the need to love it, to defend Jo Rowling and all her brilliance, but I think it would be "inauthentic" of me to claim it.  To me it feels like there's something missing.  This book is so dark and gloomy and heavy, and perhaps its meant to be after years of writing good-natured comedy and happy endings.  However the heaviness is wearing, and I found myself returning relentlessly back to the book, not as I have to all her others in avid anticipation of what would happen next, but with a sense of duty.  Though the characters are not wholly uninteresting, there're all seriously flawed in one way or another (which may be more true to life) but which makes it difficult to really find any of them likable and sympathetic, though it gets easier towards the end.  Something I missed here too was Jo Rowling's talent to easily weave seemingly small, but vastly important details into the story and keep them hidden there for later discovery and impact.  She does much less vivid a job creating a physical world for us under the assumption we can just see the small town without fresh and fruitful descriptors, and as a result the town seems flat, the homes nearly indistinguishable.  For me, the spark was missing, and throughout at least 90% of the novel I could scarcely believe it was authored by J.K. Rowling.  And though I'm sure she's intentionally moving away from and editting her writing so it doesn't match Potter, the attempt to redefine seems to rob some of the best qualities of Jo Rowling's writing.  Overall, it's okay, not completely unenjoyable, has some really poignant and heartfelt moments, but definitely isn't for everyone and won't inspire the cult following of her previous series; which may have been Jo's intentions all along.

author: Stone
title: Sad face...
body: What a huge disappointment coming from one of the best story tellers of her generation. I knew going into the book to put Harry Potter up on the shelf; this was NOT a wizarding experience. But what I wasn't expecting was boredom and run-of-the-mill story telling. Unfortunately this book is just like every other who dunnit out there! Ms. Rowlings, you have a unique talent for creating fantasy. Go back to your roots - I'm sure there's another Harry Potter in you somewhere!

author: Jaimie
title: Wonderful characters
body: I woke up at 2:30am, BING, and finished reading this book. I really enjoyed it, although it's not flawless and gets a little S.P.E.W. in places. This was exactly what I wanted to read, a kind of modern day Dickens/Austen thing. The characters were so engrossing, even the characters I have nothing in common with - Gavin, Samantha, Kay, Cubby. I'm going to miss them. Jo, you've done it again!

author: CJCACC 's mom
title: Not worth the trouble
body: Honestly, I am a huge J.K. Rowling fan, that is the only reason I finished the book.

author: Charlene
title: Thought-provoking, character-driven drama about real-life issues
body: This is nothing like Harry Potter.  Okay, I knew that, but deep down I was envisioning some of the ... magic in the world of Harry Potter would be evident here - but this is truly an adult book where honesty is more valuable than beauty.  It's real life, and it's harsh.  It was a little difficult to get into because of the vast array of characters who interact against the backdrop of the parish council election.  And J.K. Rowling takes her time masterfully shaping and delineating each character, creating a characteristically intricately plotted story which weaves the lives of at least twenty people into a varied, lively tale of the every day.  This novel is like a soap opera full of drama, petty jealousies, sex, drugs, abuse and adolescent rage.  Every private thought is revealed to the reader through the omniscient narrator making every failing of each character clear.

author: JJulieJ
title: Dull, Dismal and Disappointing!
body: The Casual Vacancy is a dull and dismal book, about dull and dismal people living in a dull and dismal village. I did read it right though to the bitter end, hoping and hoping for one tiny gleam of brilliance among the dross. I didn't find it and I didn't enjoy it.

author: D. N. Stone
title: Her Masterpiece
body: Another classic from J.K. Rowling.  I haven't been so consumed by a novel since The Help.  It's a sharp take on modern English village life and the need for compassion. Expect a lot of discussion of OCD in the coming months as more people read the book. It's not just about washing hands I learned, and JK says she suffered from it when

author: Elizabeth
title: Black but not magic
body: I gave into temptation and bought 'The Casual Vacancy' minutes before it was released on Kindle. It was not long before I regretted my impulsive buying. Some of the language I found to be rather contrived and forced. A minor detail. At times the writing lost its forward flow. Again, a minor detail. Certainly there was the promised humour but with a flippancy that seemed to remove reality from the characters. It was not long before the characters' lives exposed themselves for what they were or for what they were to become, humour being overtaken by the stark reality of gloom and doom. This was to be the focus of the much larger part of the book and  made the book as a whole seem out of balance. The endless, sordid and squalid misery in the lives of the over-ample sufficiency of characters presented me with nothing beyond my awareness of life for some people. A year of Coronation Street on paper. Here was an opportunity to offer our troubled society some possible solutions for consideration. But, alas, this did not happen.

author: Cody Rodgers
title: Adult per-se...
body: This is not an adult novel, this is just an adult trying to be crass, vile, and bring sex/exploits/etc. into a horrible plot and storyline. I never did like her writing style for the Harry Potter books, but I thought hey - she is only writing to kids (specifically) so do not get held up on the childish grammar and writing skills, but this continues to show that she really is not a good author. Period.

author: S. McKinney
title: A hot mess worth zero stars (spoiler alert)
body: I was interested in reading what JKR had to say as an adult novelist - my kids grew up along with Harry Potter, and although I loved those books, I thought that a writer of her prodigious talent would probably be able to pull off a non-Potter adult novel with ease.

author: Eric C Wilder
title: Not good
body: Too many characters. Not very compelling. Certainly not worth the price of admission. Check out the book from the library if you really must read it.

author: dpm
title: Love it, Love JK Rowling.
body: Amazing writer, amazing book.  She has such insight into human nature.  I am enjoying every minute.  Her character development, and the way she weaves the characters together, is truly remarkable.

author: slim
title: JK- Go back to writing children's books, please!
body: I wanted to like this book. I wanted the writing to be just as page-turning as the Harry Potter books. I figured JK Rowling's writing style wouldn't change a whole lot just because it changed age levels, but I was wrong.  DEAD wrong.

author: Beth Smith
title: Awful
body: I was excited to read an "adult" J.K. Rowling book and for the first time pre-ordered a Kindle book. I checked my Kindle the first thing in the morning on release day to get started. By the way, yes, I've read 6 of the 7 Harry Potter books (didn't read the 1st one.) I slogged through the 1st 1/3 of the book and then skipped to the last few chapters just to see how it all turned out. It wasn't that interesting or well-written and I hated all the foul language, the depressing characters and the topics in the book. I feel like I've been duped by J.K. Rowling and my respect for her as a writer has plummeted. If I ever read another of her books, it will only be after I've checked the reviews and the book has been out for awhile.

author: Rhino
title: Get the Audiobook - Well worth it!
body: I'm surprised the reaction to Rowling's first adult novel has been so tepid.  Yes, the book is nothing like "Harry Potter", but it is so impressive in its own right.  I'm actually a huge "Harry Potter" fan, but those were young adult books, and while they displayed JK Rowling's humor, memorable characters, excellent plotting, and fabulous imagination, they didn't give as much scope to her talent as a realist, satirist, and acute observer of human nature.

author: Terry Stagg
title: Read before you review!
body: I never write reviews, but I feel like I need to comment. All those that said " I read the sample, and this is what I thought...." I say "Sit down and shut up." Nothing sounds more stupid, oh except " I hate the price." If you are going to write a review  worth reading I would like to hear that you stuck with it until the end.

author: Wallaby
title: Like a PBS series about a small English village-  with complications
body: We were all warned that this is an adult novel,  and not a sequel to Harry Potter.  This is a very readable story about a beautiful village, Pagford and a large cast of flawed people.  You will find authentic British vocabulary here,  which I find delightful.  Other cranky Americans will gripe about minivans called  "people carriers"  and high school called  "fifth and sixth forms"  and the like.  Anyway the Council Head  (that's a city councilman for you testy Americans)  drops dead and the political wranglings and personal struggles of many residents makes for a British Miniseries novel.

author: Jo D.
title: A great novel for grown-ups.
body: So this is what real life is like after 'Dumbledore' dies -- or in this case, the excellent and upright councilman, Barry F. Without his empathy and intervention, everything goes from bad to worse in Pagford in this very grown-up novel from Rowling, who proves herself a very able writer indeed in this realistically depicted tragedy of modern-day politics and class antagonism. I found this book entirely engrossing, with well rounded characters with mostly believable obsessions and hang-ups [though for my taste Colin, or "Cubby", the deputy schoolmaster, was a little too Wing Biddlebaum for me to quite believe]. I was impressed that Rowling was so very in control here not just of her sentences [I only spotted one real clunker] but of her excellent imagery and tone. Her bleak view here is entirely intentional, as her last-minute leavening of an otherwise unremittingly tragic ending with a well told reminiscence shows us. And what is she trying to show? Well, when the little tike who fantasizes about the speed of real cars by saying, "Broom! Broom!" [in a quick nod to Harry's Nimbus 2000] meets such a sad final fate, Rowling is clearly letting us know that our magic-free world can only be improved incrementally and through the faltering efforts of rightminded individuals like the much missed Barry, so much do we depend on each other, despite all our flaws. Change is hard, so we need empathy to cut through our own vacancy and apathy and spur us to help, even when such help seems even less than pointless given the enormous weight of suffering on the one side and the forces of social injustice aligned to protect the status quo on the other.

author: Amazon Customer
title: The Casual Vacancy from start to finish-4 and1/2 stars
body: The Casual Vacancy is quite a departure from the author's previous books, of course, and is sure to irritate and anger some of her fans, but it should find its own audience quickly. The characters in this novel have nasty little secrets and the death which opens the story serves to reveal their many flaws. All of this makes Rowling appear more cynical and less humorous than in the Harry Potter series, and the book did start to feel very dreary about one third through. But I soldiered on, confident that the feeling of being in the hands of an excellent storyteller I had enjoyed during the opening pages would pay off. And it did. The resolution, while tragic, was satisfying and the changes that characters exhibited were believable and touching. I think her characters rang true and even though their lives were rather sordid, I didn't feel that the book itself was. It made for an engrossing, thought-provoking read. I would recommend it, but read the synopsis and don't expect anything magical other than Rowling's deft ability to expose a character's innermost secrets with precision and wit.

author: KennethHarmon
title: Even Legends Can Stumble
body: You can count the number of authors who successfully made the jump from children's fiction to adult fiction on one hand. The differences between the two are too vast and too hard to master. You can add J.K. Rowling to the ranks of authors who tried and failed. Her writing style is a perfect fit for children's fantasy, but does not work here. She tries too hard to make the jump and as a result has written a book that will soon be forgotten. I read this week that Rowling might write another Harry Potter book. I hope that is the direction she chooses, because adult fiction just isn't her cup of tea.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Who does she think she is $17.99 for an e-book!!!!!
body: I only gave her one star because my system would not take no stars!  Does she forget what it was like to be poor and homeless?  The book is horrible top!

author: jecb
title: in response to the one star reviews
body: i have to say, i was completely taken aback by the number of negative reviews of this book. when i read them, however, it was clear to see that many of the people doling out a single star did not even finish it, and many more were essentially disappointed they were not reading another harry potter book.

author: reading matters
title: Complex, gritty, thought-provoking book
body: The author is a keen observer of the human heart and human interactions.  JK brings us inside character's minds to hear the stories they tell themselves. The characters' inner fiction then drives the myriad of tragic-comedic events in the book.  This is fascinating and believable literature.

author: C. F. Crowe
title: Missing pages
body: The Kindle version of this book included 323 pages , the print copy contains 502 pages.  Comparing. page content shows that the Kindle version has fewer words per page.  Does this indicate two versions of this title?

author: Pendragon
title: Like banging your head against a brick wall.
body: Just like banging your head against a brick wall, it's wonderful when it's over.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Wonderful book
body: It did take me a bit of time to get into this book, mostly because of who the author is and how different the characters are  from the beloved Harry Potter.  But at some point, not sure when, I got so absorbed in the story  I forgot who wrote it. The characters are so finely drawn, so real, the story going towards an inevitable end, almost like watching an accident about to happen when you can do nothing about it. I couldn't put it down.

author: T. Nelson
title: If you're expecting an adult HP, you won't like it
body: I am a huge HP and JK Rowling fan.  But, I also read the previews and knew that this book would be completely different from HP. So, I went into it with an open mind.  If you are expecting typical JK Rowling fare, you will not like this book.  Most of the negative reviews appear to be from these type of people.  They also didn't give it enough of a chance.  It is impossible to accurately assess a story that you do not finish.  This is particularly true here.

author: delanolady
title: The Casual Vacancy is a winner for me!
body: I just finished reading this book. I couldn't put it down. The lives of the characters ring true to me, probably because I taught quite a few students who were "Krystal". I purposely did not look at some of the other reviews, but one reviewer seemed to be offended by some of the events taking place in the book. I hate to say this, but there are more "Krystals" than you probably know out there and they are quite desperate people. Ms. Rowling's characterization is true to me in all respects, but then I live in a small American town. We have all the same people here, we have "projects" and "welfare moms" nearby in a slightly larger town. Her description of political maneuvering in elections in small towns is exceptionally honest as is her portraiture of adults who cannot control computer sites as well as the teenagers involved. (But then I worked with teachers who did not know how to turn on their own computers, but I digress.)Throwaway children die every day and no one helps them, because they are dirty and smell bad. Teenagers commit suicide and cut themselves because of family problems. If you want fantasy, read the Harry Potter books. This book is very true to life and not just true to England. It could be set anywhere.

author: JCStreetSoldier
title: Don't jump on the bandwagon until you're informed
body: PRE-VACANCY:

author: J. Brandt
title: As much as I tried to enjoy this book....3 stars is generous at best
body: I bought this book the day it came out. I just finished it and I can honestly write that I struggled to finish it as I found myself

author: Macon_Mandy
title: Rowling does it again!!
body: I'm a huge HP fan and was terrified I wouldn't like this new book, but I absolutely loved it. It goes without saying that this is not a children's book. This is not Harry Potter. This book is just real.

author: Saga Ruby
title: Not my cuppa
body: So expensive. So eagerly awaited. So disappointed.

author: Linda Joy Singleton
title: Great Writing
body: I stayed up late to finish J.K. Rowling's newest book ... sound familiar?

author: invisiblgirl
title: If you're reading this review, you're smarter than me
body: I pre-ordered the book, even though the description didn't exactly tantalise, because it was written by an author who could make a grocery list interesting.  I should have waited for the reviews and saved myself $17.  The real JK Rowling is an author with wit and a love for wordplay.  Even her minor characters are so well-drawn, they could carry a book on their own.

author: S.Hocking
title: You should not compare it to HP
body: I will keep this short. I think Miss Rowling has done an excelent job with this book. The characters are down to earth as well as cleverly interlinked with each other. I am not even half way through but I am looking forward to finishing the book. The only reason why I haven't finished it is because I am studying a degree along side it.

author: Michael
title: Not so casual vacancy in J.K. Rowling's brain - shockingly arrogant, very angry leftist drivel...
body: The author is hell-bent on making you feel guilty and responsible for all the lowlife of this world. I am sure that you will learn nothing about the real British town from this book. What you will learn is that J.K. Rowling is a pathetic, dark, very angry, leftist demagogue. She could be a speech writer for the Obama White House.

author: mfch
title: real, raw, tragic, and nothing like Harry Potter
body: Another review here from someone who has actually read the whole book. And I do feel like I should offer some sort of disclaimer here- I am a huge Harry Potter fan and grew up with the books. However, Harry Potter has not blinkered my reading career, as much as I loved the books, I love other books more and am currently doing my literature degree at university. I feel like this is important to mention because whilst J.K Rowling's name drew me to the book in the first place, it is not what made me read it and not what made me enjoy it.

author: Dranea79
title: I wish we didn't have to enter in a star rating
body: If I had to go off my own enjoyment factor, I would rate it a one. If I am rating it based on the writing, I give it three stars. But seeing as I think I should write the review based on both, so I will give the star rating based on writing and my one star review in here.  :)  Seeing as there are numerous reviews already, I won't go into a synopsis of the book as I do in so many of my other reviews - so I'll just get to the meat of everything.

author: Scorpio Dragon
title: Kindle is Too Expensive
body: OK I realize this is a new release, but that does not excuse ripping off the customer for eBook version.  Maybe if the publishers were not so heavily invested into the printing press companies (Many own their presses and they are losing money big time) we would not have to pay for your losses.

author: Sho
title: Better than I anticipated
body: Does this sound about right? "Rowling's refusal to conform to happy endings demonstrates the fact that The Casual Vacancy is not meant to be entertainment. She wants to deal with real-life issues, not the fantasy world to which women writers are often confined. Her ambition is to create a portrait of the complexity of ordinary human life: quiet tragedies, petty character failings, small triumphs, and quiet moments of dignity. The complexity of her portrait of provincial society is reflected in the complexity of individual characters. The contradictions in the character of the individual person are evident in the shifting sympathies of the reader. One moment, we pity Stuart, the next we judge him critically."

author: Library Lady
title: Sad and Disgusted
body: I was so excited to read another J.K. Rowling. H.P. was a classic. But I was SEVERELY disappointed. so much foul language, SO much explicit filth. A good writer can use allusion without searing images of crass drivel being poured onto the page. I bought the kindle edition and could only make it to 13% before I had to put it away. I was sick to my stomache. I truly hope Rowling will return to something else next time, even if its not Harry. I feel like she was trying to move out of the pigeon-hole YA genre and went over the cliff in the opposite direction.

author: Rami Yoakum
title: Are you kidding me?
body: $17.99 for an electronic pulse? And people are paying that price? What's the old saying... a fool and his money are soon parted. Duh!

author: DarnGood
title: Masterpiece Theater 2012 or Mystery Science Theater 3000??
body: Well then, wasn't that interesting.  Love you JK and this is a well written book, as demonstrated by the revulsion along with the inability to stop reading.  But in Pagford you are either abusing or being abused by someone.  This is the predictable small town minutiae, with the gossip, waring factions, family disfunctionality, and tragic outcomes that pepper the news reports in the evening. Unfortunately in times like we are in where people need something uplifting, and inspiring us to the better angels of our nature, we are shellacked with a modern day dickensian david copperfield, in the most groveling human interactions.

author: M. Johnson
title: The Casual Vacancy
body: Well, I'll start with the obvious, in case anyone has yet to hear: this is definitely NOT Harry Potter for grown ups. It is proper English Literature. Oh, there are ghosts, though. The_Ghost_of_Barry_Fairbrother is all too flesh and blood, however. It is the study of a small town and what happens to that town when it loses its touchstone, in the form of the death of Barry Fairbrother. It is both a laugh track and a gut punch. Not something I probably would have picked up without JK Rowling's name attached, but I'm glad that I did.

author: Andrew
title: this book is just like harry potter!
body: a lot like harry poitter, especially the part about the snake!  and the magicless wands, can't wait for the next 6 books.  i even liked the swearing!

author: LLCox
title: What a waste!
body: This book was a great disappointment. The only reason I read the whole thing is because I paid so much for it. The whole book was full of miserable people doing bad things to each other. Really, she should not have written this!

author: *Caligirl_08*
title: I really don't understand why everyone is hating on this book so much???
body: I am only 1/3rd of the way through but I really felt like I had to come on here rush to this book's defense. Yes, IT IS NOT Harry Potter (but actually, the characters and personality from those books are still present in this book.) I love the humor and the unique way JKR has of depicting her characters and breathing them life. My favorite character so far is Fats. I would compare this book to Zadie Smith's

author: Brendan McGregor
title: Don't listen to haters.
body: Fantastic read. Just don't be one of these fools that pick it up expecting HP. Its an absolute page turner.

author: Bobbie
title: Amazing Author
body: I think J K Rowling is a brilliant writer and I would have bought this book if it were $117.99 and written in pencil on toilet paper. It is distressing that readers punish the author for the greed of the publishers. I had no idea what to expect and for some reason I was thinking Agatha Christie or PD James. Truth is, it was more like Salinger or Vonnegut, harsh realism and depressing insight into human weaknesses. The book is gritty, dark, humorous, and too believable. The characters are real, fragile, not likeable, and for the most part doomed. Rowling's writing is seamless and drags you in. Just like Harry Potter, you feel as if you know these people. You wish you could shake them, kill them, or help them. I couldn't put the book down. I can't say I enjoyed it, rather I experienced it and I am sure I will be thinking about it for a long time to come. As I mentioned before, I think Rowling is brilliant and this book solidifies my feelings. She is an amazing author, with an incredible mind. I would highly recommend the book. It is something you shouldn't miss.

author: corango
title: a waste of money
body: This book is so disappointing. i love thrillers and drama books. I had hoped that some of the magic that this author had produced in her harry potter series would spill over and produce something really special. This book is boring, uninteresting, slow and a waste of my 24 dollars. I suppose it wasnt a waste because i know now that i wont spend any more money on her next book.

author: Ben Shearon
title: The price is insane
body: Okay, I'm interested. Enjoyed the Harry Potter series. Like what I've seen of Ms Rowling in public. Book sounds interesting.

author: Astralwolf37
title: Apparently Wizards are Only Allowed to be Interesting and Likable
body: I read a good chunk of this at the bookstore to see if it would be something that is worth the $30+.  I never made it through the whole thing, so I'm not the best judge on the overall plot, but I can say unequivocally that the writing style is flat and the characters are dull and unimaginative.  Many people seem concerned that the book is being compared to Harry Potter too unfairly, but the author's previous work shows us what she is capable of, and she is falling short by miles and miles.

author: Happy reader
title: Dark, angry, ugly
body: An utter disappointment from JKR after her phenomenal success. Dark can be wonderful, but here it is merely pedantic and pointless.  An entirely uninspired book from start to finish.

author: A. Prentice
title: A Very British Novel; A True Heroine
body: This is a novel in a very English tradition; it has echoes of Dickens, of George Meredith, of Evelyn Waugh. Post-World War II, it has notes of John Mortimer's Paradise Postponed and more than a few hints of Martin Amis. Rowling sets her nominally political tale about a local concil election in a setting that contains both the beauty of a traditional English village - Pagford - and the grit of an industrial city - Yarvil - inextricably linked, as the history of England includes the green and pleasant lands and the dark Satanic mills. She people both towns and tells the interwoven tales of many families, contrasting the middle class and the poor. What is unique about this book are the combined voices of the teenagers who inhabit it: Krystal, Andrew, Sukhvinder, Fats, and Gaia. These are young people struggling to survive and find a way to successful adulthood - some will make it and some won't. While Rowling can be somewhat humorous in portraying the imperfect adults in this novel, she is serious about the children and depicts them with knowledge, empathy. The most poignant character is the most desperate, Krystal Weedon, who came to remind me in many ways of Bill Sykes' Nancy. She is a true English heroine for modern times. The conversations of flawed parents and their desperate children are gripping and memorable. I cried at the end of this book and I'm not sure at all why reviewers are calling it a black comedy.  The images of Krystal and her young brother Robbie at the end of the book will stay with you for a long time. HIghly recommended.

author: Mary Whipple
title: "You think reality is up for negotiation, that we think it's whatever you say it is...You must accept that you are not God."
body: (2.5 stars) Focusing on life in the very small community of Pagford, perhaps similar to the small communities Rowling herself knew as a child in Gloucestershire, Rowling emphasizes the pettiness, the rivalries, the back-biting, and the cruelties of "ordinary" life as people try to cope with the messiness of existence as it unfolds. There is no magic here to offer any hope of change, no wizard to sweep down and offer aid, either to the characters or to the reader, and as the action progresses, with its focus on the unpleasant and often violent aspects of many lives, the reader is forced to examine the elements of chance which can devastate everything that one might dream of.

author: granm
title: A No read
body: This book is depressing, rude, flat, and totally a waste of time.  Rowling should go back to what she does best...because it is NOT this book!

author: abcdefg
title: Life is too short to waste my mind on this dirty book...
body: This is so sad.  I can't finish reading this book.  I was so excited to read it but it is such a dirty book with sex, language and ugly people saying, thinking and doing ugly things that I know this isn't what I should be spending my time thinking or reading about.  As a Christian, I know I would be going against everything I believe in to be advocating this book by reading it. Why must such a talented writer waste her gift on something so trashy?  Is it not possible to write well AND cleanly?  i know it is...read CS Lewis, Mark Twain, Charles Dickens and countless other classic writers.  Sad.

author: Lori Wolf
title: Way to expensive
body: I would love to read this book. I am a J.K. Rowling fan. However,my rating of the book is due to the price. I think the price is way too high. Amazon is taking advantage of the J.K. Rowling name. I will read when it is as reasonably priced as other best selling books.

author: Vanilla Mango
title: trying to hard to be adult-ish
body: This book really feels to me like a child actress posing for playboy when she turns 18 just to prove she is a grown up now.  I'm only 26 or so pages into the book and really just contemplating not finishing it.  I don't mind "edgy" elements in a good plot and some hard reality to make a point in a story but this so far is like a string of the worst swears a kid can come up with to assert his adulthood. Maybe I'll update this if I read the rest of it, but from other reviews I guess I have rape, and child abuse to look forward to as the "plot?" thickens.....

author: Lisa Brandt
title: Not worth the Kindle price
body: This is the most expensive Kindle edition I've ever bought, and I did so only because I consider J K Rowling an awesome writer and story-crafter based on the HP books, and I just had to read her first novel for adults.

author: Kelsey Clair
title: The Casual Vacancy - worth a second read!
body: I had the same feeling while reading this book as I get while reading Potter - every page is pure entertainment. I couldn't put it down, but was devastated to reach the end. It was definitely an enjoyable reading experience for me, and I look forward to reading it the second time around to see what details went in one ear (eye?) and out the other the first time. I actually LIKED how none of the characters seem 'likable' in the beginning (and even when they were still that way at the end), and even though there are 15 or so "main" characters that the story revolves around, I found myself understanding and being able to relate to each one, and I think most people will too. With this book Rowling proves that she can be a master of reality as well as master of all things magical. A great work by a great author, it will not take long for my copy to become well-worn!

author: Delighted, Tunbridge Wells
title: A wonderful novel
body: Never having read an HP, I wasn't sure what to expect. What I found was a masterpiece, a huge panorama of a small village, peopled by the whole social spectrum. It's a wonderfully humane book with moments of great sadness and great humour.  It may be presumptuous to say about an author who has sold 450 million books, but she is truly an amazing writer.  So many people have described the sadness of leaving HP, but I'm sure that for many there will be no less sadness after leaving Pagford and its population of real (warts and all) characters.

author: Jessica
title: I really wanted to like it but....
body: I tried soooooo hard to read this book.  After 60 pages, I gave up.  I really wanted to like it, as I am a HUGE Harry Potter fan, but alas, I could not.  I knew it wasn't going to be Harry Potter, but I didn't know it was going to be so unlikable.  The characters were all horrible people who I didn't care about.  There were long passages that made no sense.  I read them several times but never understood.  You practically need a dictionary to figure out what J.K. Rowling is saying.  I am an adult, but the foul launguage and crude sexual references were too much for me.  I couldn't figure out where the plot was or where the book was possibly going to I stopped reading.  I'm sorry to say it, but I think fans of J.K. Rowling are going to be let down! :(

author: edel
title: JK Does It Again!!!!
body: When Barry fairbrother dies, his death affects almost each family in each house of the town of Pagford either directly or indirectly. One thing I quickly learned is that this wonderful author can still write characters we all care about. The book is told in a way that almost each chapter is given to a different family and we are almost flies on the wall watching and observing what is happening behind the closed doors of the town. Needless to say there is many secrets and scandals hidden in this ordinary town. There is sexually explicit parts in the book , and violence, and sexual violence towards children, drug abuse, self harm etc etc. The story is just about as different from Harry Potter as you can get, but saying that, for a lot of the adult Harry Potter fans I think they will enjoy it as a lot of care obviously went into the characters ,and their lives as I as a fan of the HP series was used to.

author: houstonbooklover
title: Terrible book!!
body: I was so looking forward to this book. I've read 100 pages and will not be finishing the book.  I don't like any of the characters so don't care what happens to them.  The story line is very dull and boring. It's very hard to believe that Rowling wrote such a disappointing book.  I found the language and sex to be offensive rather than adding anything positive or entertaining to the story.  Very depressing.

author: Silver Elm
title: Brilliant!
body: This book draws the reader in slowly. It's 500 pages, and plenty of time is given to get to know the various characters in the town and their stories and interconnections. Rowling creates a masterful web. After a certain point I couldn't put the book down--- the tension continues building and building all over the town, and I was desperate to find out what was going to happen to everyone, particularly with a couple of the characters that I cared about deeply, but also with a couple of characters I hoped to see fall!

author: Connie
title: Casual Vacancy
body: She should stick to Harry Potter type books

author: TK McEachin
title: J.K. Rowling Fails This Time Around, but I'm Still Rooting for Her
body: To start, this is my blog before I read a significant portion of the novel:

author: Dorfy
title: Huge Disappointment
body: I was so happy that J K Rowling was offering us another book to read. I fully expected it to be as good, and maybe even better than her Harry Potter books. I couldn't believe that this book was from the same author. I finished chapter 4 and decided to read the reviews on the book to see if I wanted to continue. Maybe it would get better. Well, looks like it doesn't. Unless you can identify with the low-lifes of the world, and only them. I wish there could have been a better mix of characters. I can't believe that J K Rowling's audience is made up of mostly low-lifes on drugs with totally hopeless lives. How's about us regular people? I hope she tries again and learns something from all the bad reviews she's getting on this one.

author: Connie J. Jasperson
title: An Adult book for adult readers
body: J. K. Rowling is an extremely strong writer, and is brilliant at crafting and peopling her tales. First off, you need to set aside Harry Potter and read this book as if it were the only work of hers you've ever read.  If you go into this expecting Hogwarts and all the gang reinvented, you will be disappointed. You'll love or hate this book on the strength of her work, not because it is part of a mega-phenomenon. It is a story of ordinary people, living rather mundane lives. Their politics are mundane and too important to them; their motives are the usual trifling things which motivate petty people. These are not always nice people.  That said, I would recommend this book to those who read literary fiction. This is an adult book, for adult readers.

author: Shelly A. Uner
title: "Adult" in every meaning of the word
body: Let me say first, I am a HUGE fan of the Harry Potter series, and I'm an adult with a literature degree currently teaching high school English.  I've read the Potter series four times all the way through and have gotten more out of it every time.  I was so excited to have a new J.K. book and pre-ordered a hard copy and a Kindle version.  I only made it through five and half chapters and am thoroughly disgusted and disappointed.  As a friend said after I told her about my experience, "It's like the child actor who grows up and goes into porn just to prove they are no longer a child."  Why, J.K., why?

author: Y. Scott
title: Gutsy effort, but not delivered well
body: First of all, I admire J. K. Rowling's courage to write a totally different novel after having written the most popular fantasy novels in the world. I also appreciate her effort to talk about difficult social issues we face today.

author: Zorra
title: "It's a Wonderful Life" on Privet Drive
body: FIVE STARS (Though Amazon is only allowing me to give it 4 for some reason).  I finished reading this book about eight hours ago, and I find myself still haunted by it.  A gritty version of "It's a Wonderful Life" set on a street much like Privet Drive, it is a challenging book.  Yes, it is a tragedy, foreshadowed from the beginning, but elaborate plot twists are not the point.  The point is the characters.  You won't like them at first, and you are not meant to.  Rowling unveils the way in which we are all cabined off from compassion by our own self-centered dramas.  She takes you on a journey of your own failings, and it's a cruel and unfortunately accurate journey.  But then she surprises you with compassion, even for some of her most unlikeable characters, even for you.  For example, this sentence:  "How awful it was ... the way tiny ghosts of your living children haunted your heart; they could never know, and would hate it if they did, how their growing was a constant bereavement."  All she asks is that you have the compassion for others that she has shown for you.  You finish the book with a series of "if onlys," because so many of the characters have the chance to avert tragedy, and fail.  If only, you can't help think, Hagrid was there, with his pink umbrella -ella -ella.  But this is the real world, and somebody like us has to rescue the boy under the stairs.  Rowling doesn't leave us without hope, however.  As in the original "It's a Wonderful Life," you also finish the book with an indelible sense of what one imperfect person CAN do.

author: Avid Reader
title: Absolutely Abysmal!
body: Absolutely pathetic attempt at adult fiction from J K Rowling. I purchased the book, read about 50 pages and trashed it (returned the book). Rowling has gone overboard with foul language to set herself apart from the kid's book style of the excellent Harry Potter series. The setting is horrible, characters boring and storyline will put you to sleep. The dialogues go on and on talking drivel about the same topic for 30 pages. Useless trash. I vow never to read another Rowling book just because of the way she has deviated from her strengths in this misguided attempt. Waste of time.

author: H. M. Knof
title: Too bored to finish
body: I, like so many others, looked forward to J.K. Rowling's first book after the Harry Potter series.  I ground through the first 25%, thinking that it had to get better, that there had to be a developed character somewhere.  It didn't; there wasn't.  'Nuff said.

author: Cotton Mather
title: I can't get through it
body: Oy vey--this book is a mess. It is dreadfully dull.  I will slog through it somehow this year, so all is not lost but--I will never believe that Ms. Rowling wrote it.  No way.

author: knotfixx
title: There's nothing wrong...
body: in writing a fabulous and entertaining series aimed at children, yet enjoyed by millions and millions of adults!!  And there's nothing wrong in selling 450 million copies of your wonderful series!

author: marina
body: 21$ the price of kindle edition????? Why??????

author: SDL
title: Enjoyed very much
body: Good for JK to branch out and do something different. While I still wish she would return to the Potter series at some point it is still great to have new stuff from her. The book had a real eerie feel to it. Small town secrets always make for a good story.

author: Kate
title: A Casual Vacancy Is now on my Bookshelf
body: I pre-ordered this with some trepidation.  When she first mentioned years ago that she was writing a "political fairy story for adults" I didn't think I would be fully on board without more details.  When word came earlier this year that the book would drop during the eight-week "sweet spot" before the Presidential Election in the United States I grew leery.  There are a lot of political issues about which Rowling and I seem to generally agree but I felt that the danger of this being a bleak polemic was high.

author: Tysha
title: A boring book
body: This book is boring. The plot is slow. I pushed  myslf to read it; but I could  only read it until page 17. Too boring. I am very dissapointed with Ms. Rowling.

author: Annette
title: Incredibly Disappointed
body: Would give a zero rating if poosible...downloaded book so I could not return it...deleted it from my library...not worth anyones time...crude

author: Anne Jordan
title: Ughhhhh!!!! What a WASTE!!!!
body: If I could give this 0 stars, I would.  I am so disgusted that an author, who possesses  such an enormous vocabulary and imagination would resort to f-bombs to convey her point.  Thank goodness I got a free sample for my kindle!!  I deleted it as soon as it was obvious that this book is garbage and that was way before I was even half way through the sample.  Try again, J.K. and next time make it a point to write without leaning on obscenities, as if that makes a book "adult".

author: Nick Brocketah
title: Much Too Expensive
body: Why are they charging so much for the Kindle version? Shame on them. Should definitely be more around ten dollars.

author: Love at First Book
title: Liked but not loved
body: When I heard that J.K. Rowling was going to be writing an adult fiction novel, my first thoughts were apprehensive.  As the deadline for the novel's release crept closer, I finally buckled down and decided I would read it (although I'm super annoyed at the ridiculously expensive Kindle price for the book).

author: Andrew Daubigny
title: Foul Ball
body: "... sliced through his brain like a demolition ball." If that's your idea of good prose, this book is for you.

author: Judy Shepherd
title: Today's world
body: Recommend late teen to adult.  great character development. small town life.   Examines bully,cyber crime, family structures an faith in human goodness.

author: Runa
title: Vacancy, Indeed
body: Reading this book felt so much more like an obligation than something done out of enjoyment. It was not a joy but a relief to finish it. I realize this wasn't supposed to be Harry Potter and comparisons are moot, but I didn't expect it to be the diametric opposite of HP. It is written for a totally different audience, an audience that does not consist of me. This thing can go sit on bookshelves with the likes of John Grisham and other rich people cranking out meaningless dramas. Where Harry Potter created a beautiful, rich, diverse cast of characters, The Casual Vacancy creates the same caricatured people I read to avoid. I found myself liking the characterizations of the teenaged characters (with the exception of social worker, Kay), and would be interested in seeing Jo create a realistic young adult novel, or even a more political novel, rather than the upper class gossipfest this was. There was some compelling themes that could have been explored further (the clinic, "the light of God shone from every soul") but ultimately went unresolved. It also would have worked better, in my opinion, as a linear novel, rather than one told from too many points of view, leading to a crowded, overwhelming read.

author: Christie
title: Adult maybe, grown-up not!
body: I was anticipating the release of The Casual Vacancy because it promised to be an interwoven tale of the residents of an English village.  Yesterday I eagerly went to my local bookstore where there they sat--big, thick copies of this wonderful sounding story.  I picked up my copy, bought it, and returned home to began to read.  What a disappointment it turned out to be!  Sure there were lots of characters but I didn't feel any sympathy toward them.  And the language!  No thanks, I don't need to read all that profanity and tasteless talk. Why couldn't this adult book be written for grown-ups?  Why is something considered "adult" because it is filled with tasteless profanity* just for the sake of it i.e. the F bomb ad nauseum?  We expect our children not to talk that way and read that stuff but as adults we accept it?  I guess I had hoped that Ms Rowling's story would be along the lines of other British writers such as Rosamunde Pilcher or Maeve Binchy.  Oh well, I'll have to just reread The Shell Seekers or Circle of Friends.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Rowling?  Really?
body: I am not only a big fan of Harry Potter but also a bibliophile in general.  Imagine my joy at having another offering to become obsessed with.  Unfortunately, the obsession for "The Casual Vacancy" borders on complete loathing.  I have to admit I did not and *could not* finish this literary abortion.  At about the quarter mark, I was compelled to delete it.  The run-on sentences, unfulfilled parenthesis and foul language do nothing at all to detract from the one-dimensional characters and rampant stereotypical behavior within a bleak setting.  If there's a storyline, I never found it.

author: Wild Swan
title: Alt Harry Potter
body: This book is about what would have happened to Harry Potter had there been no Hogwarts.  It's an "alt" version - what happens to a neglected child in the welfare state, what happens when there is no magic, what happens in a world composed of Durselys.  That makes it an adult book and a very unpleasant read. I could not bring myself to care what happened to any of the Durselys. I see that almost everyone gained self knowledge (and most did not put it to any use); I see that hacked Facebook pages as a means of knowledge is very clever (JKR lives); I see that a girl who was being destroyed is more confident because she is imitating someone (Kristen) whom she does not really see as she is - but I didn't care.  I was glad I'd reached the end alive myself, that was all.  However I did read the entire book so Rowling is still a page turner. I will also buy her next book but I hope someday she can integrate what is at present a double vision - magic childhood and adult rottenness.

author: SHELLEYBOND
title: It cost HOW MUCH for the Kindle edition?!!
body: Never having read the HP series, I was pleased when JK Rowling wrote this, a non-fantasy book.  I went to order it this morning and saw that the cost of the *Kindle Edition" is a whopping $17.99!!!!  I don't care WHO set the price -- that's outrageous for an ebook!  I've taken Rowling's book off my reading list and will be telling my book clubs why!

author: Beth
title: Grim, Crass, and Exceptionally Dull
body: You know that wholesome pop star who desperately wants to outgrow her good girl image? She leaks a sex tape, goes to rehab, and generally tries too hard to prove how bad she can be. That's what this book is. J.K. Rowling is proving that she's not just a writer for kids; she can write a grown-up book with sex, drugs, and a whole lot of foul language!

author: Evelyn
title: Why?  Why would anyone finish this book?
body: I wanted so much to like it, but page after page brought out new characters whom I would not like in real life, treating everyone around them badly, spewing venom,...every page full of bad feeling....who reads books populated with unlikeable people being despicacble? Worse,,  reviewers saying 'we all know people just like them?' I don't know people like them, thank God! And for all the times I have used language that would make my mother blanch (followed here by a comment which Amazom would not approve for publication,  though the book is riddled with far worse than what I said) after the first three chapters of this book, I had had enough of being splattered with a verbal buffet of offensiveness. If this were a hardcover edition, it would be thrown out the window with great force: being an eBook, however, I intend to smoosh my finger on that 'delete this piece of refuse' X with great satisfaction and move on to something with redeeming value.

author: Anna P.
title: Not HP... and that's ok!
body: This review has no spoilers!

author: fubar330
title: Fallen Hero
body: I have only read the sample, but that all it took for me to be disgusted.  Being a fan of Harry Potter I was happy to see that J.K. Rowling was publishing another book.  However, I didn't see this coming.  Yes, I looked past that boy wizard to read this book.  The language is valugar, I didn't care about the character at all when he died, and I felt embarrassed reading it. If this is what the future of books is becoming count me out.

author: B. Roberts
title: Good
body: Note: This review contains no spoilers about the plot.

author: Charles
title: Utter junk
body: First off, to avoid problems from the JKR is god crowd: I did read the book.

author: Her Dotness
title: R.B. Sheridan on downers
body: As a retired English teacher, I'm truly apologetic that I cannot finish this book. I know I should  read it and appreciate its merit since I'm certain based on the third of it that I did read that it will provide numerous thesis and dissertation writers with new grain for their scholastic mills.

author: M. Stark
title: A bleak view of humanity
body: I had to stop reading at around page 130. To say that this book is dysfunctional would be an understatement. It portrays humans in the worst light possible, and I saw absolutely no redeeming qualities in the characters (and there are many-- which is another thing, I couldn't even keep everyone straight!) I see this book as JK Rowling's experimentation with extremely upsetting subjects and multiple point of views. But I have to say, I don't think this experiment is a successful one and I hope she never writes something so depressing again.

author: Mudita
title: Erotic fiction for 16 year olds?!
body: Would you ask your grandmother to explain teenage sexuality? Would you read 500 pages of your grandmother explaining teenage sexuality? Well, it might read better than Rowling trying to do so...

author: Rory Marinich
title: The magic? Still there! But there's darkness, too, and plenty of sorrow...
body: At the start of Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone, we meet the Dursleys, stodgy and small-minded and "proud to say that they were perfectly normal, thank you very much." J. K. Rowling loves poking fun of the self-absorbed from within their own heads, then zooming out and showing us their victims, for whom the cruelty of idiots is considerably less fun.

author: Ballin
title: Call it the next "Fifty Shades of Gray"
body: Through the special argot Rowling utilizes, the reader can almost feel like sexual fluids are splashing all round them in this sexual thriller.  The passion is bifurcated into the categories of, hot and super hot.  The first 100/150 pages will be just "hot."  However, after that, you are in for a ride.

author: The Man on the Grassy Knoll
title: overpriced
body: You'd have to be out of your mind to pay $18 for an e-book! I think I'll wait for the discount.

author: S. Morton
title: $17.99..really????
body: The reason I chose to go to Kindle was to save money and space. (Stacks of books laying around get in the way) but come on publishers ...what makes you think the average workingman can or will pay that for a digital file?  Not Me. I work hard for my money. If I was going to pay that I would buy the hardback. I will just wait on the list at my local library. Seems strange to me that I can find some really good books for less than $5.00 by those who self publish but a large publisher wants a fortune because of a name. The book might be good but I somehow doubt it is $17.99 good.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Very Dissapointed
body: Purchased this book for my Nexas 7.  It's not anything I would normally choose to read.  Thought it being JK Rowling, it might be a just a good "Who Done It" Mystery.  WRONG!  No I didn't expect it to be Harry Potter.  A waste of money.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Updated after finishing: THIS BOOK COULD BE TRIGGERING FOR PEOPLE RECOVERING FROM BEING CUTTERS OR ABUSE
body: Update: finished the book.  Not really my kind of fiction, I read fiction to STOP thinking about the depressing inequalities and unhappy endings in real life. (Slight spolier) I knew there was going to be a suicide in the book from reading reviews. I found myself wondering which character it would be (there are over 20 characters whom we get point of view from, maybe over 30) but not particularly caring too much. It was one of the top 5 I suspected, tho the triggering event was a bit of a surprise it was predictable many pages before the triggering event happened. Folks DO need to go in prepared, one thing I didn't see mentioned in reviews was that one of the characters is a cutter. This, plus the POV portrayals of spousal and child physical abuse and rape could be very triggering for some folks. Being inside the mind of a character while they are slicing up their arm with a razor blade if you are a recovering cutter (or other self-mutilation behavior) could be a very bad thing is my concern. I finished the book feeling like I had just sat through a really rough time with a friend who was just really awakening to the horrible disparities in society and hadn't really found their footing & hope for the future yet. It is not an optimistic book, and there weren't any characters I really connected with - none of them felt at any point like people I would really want to sit & have a cuppa with if I knew even as much about them as the other characters did. Might be a really good book for folks thinking of going into social work or community activism to read though. Depressingly accurate portrayl of that from my experience. I suspect a lot of this was JKR trying to process & come to terms with her own kids being teens/young adults in the socioeconomic situations she's been in, etc, and her trying to understand why some of these horrible things happen in the world where she doesn't see any humans as pure saints or pure evil.

author: Instrument of the Blessed Virgin Mary
title: All about Obama and Romney
body: This book is basically about Obama v. Romney.  The facade of a city after its leader is gone.  So basically, our political system.

author: Patrick
title: More "Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" than "Harry Potter"
body: I'm only 1/4 of the way through the book but I just wanted to put forward a two thoughts that might influence your decision to get this book:

author: Nome de Plume
title: My 8 year old read this, I am disgusted by all the sex and drug use.
body: It was my 8 year old daughters birthday and I happened to be in my local book store.  I saw this in a display and thought "...Wow, she wrote the Harry Potter series, my daughter Ophelia would love this".

author: Ionia Froment
title: No Vacancy
body: The Casual Vacancy by J.K. Rowling is perhaps somewhat of enigma. I, just like countless thousands of other readers was so curious about what this author would come up with after so many hugely popular Harry Potter books. This book was in a way, refreshing, and in a way disappointing. Let me explain.

author: mary
title: lucked out and got it cheap
body: i actually only paid $10 for this book, because i got 15 dollars today for doing a survey at the mall, therefore i don't feel like i lost too much money. This book is weird, i would have rather seen Rowling do a book about Draco Malfoy and his family, that would have been much better

author: John Williamson
title: We're no longer in Hogwarts...
body: Don't let anyone kid you: there's magic in J.K. Rowling new novel

author: just another bookworm
title: Peyton Place meets PG Wodehouse. (Yes, I read it. No, I haven't read HP.)
body: Throwing in my two cents as one of the few people on the planet who hasn't read the HP series. (My kids were the perfect age as the books came out: young enough to love them, old enough to read for themselves.) I pre-ordered THE CASUAL VACANCY and inhaled it the minute it hit my Kindle mainly (I will admit) because it's a remarkable moment of publishing history, but I was quickly drawn into the story. The characters are people I already know, because they are the people we all already know. In the end, I liked this book on its own merits. And I liked it a lot.

author: potterfan19
title: Disappointed in this book:(
body: As a big Harry Potter fanatic I really looked forward to this book. I only tried the sample and what I read was not what I expected. I will not buy the full edition because this book does not interest me. Jo you have let me down. I hope that your next book will be another fantasy book then maybe I will be able to read it.

author: J. Nelson
title: Great book!
body: I received this book as a gift and I loved it.  Great writing.  Highly recommend. It is extremely ignorant for people to rate a book as a negative just because you are unhappy with the price.  Dumbest thing ever! It you don't like the price, keep it moving.

author: Henrik Ellegaard
title: A glimpse of the future?
body: With no competition from other book stores on the Kindle this is what happens: The Kindle book costs more than the hardback.

author: NBS
title: Combating stupidity...
body: I was interested in reading some reviews of this new book and was shocked to see it got only 3 stars.  As I read the negative reviews, I realized that the vast majority of the reviews are from people who haven't even read the book and who are basing their "review" solely on the price.

author: opinionated
title: Response
body: OK I didnt read this book.  I confess that along with others I find 18 too much for my reading budget.  I also have often found that a bit of patience can reward one with a substantially lowered price.  However, I am shocked by the moral judgements reflected in some of these reviews.  How much money an author already possesses has little to do with the value of her work.  Writing something people really want to read does require hard work.  This work does deserve monetary compensation.  So the kindle edition is not a simple download worth nothing because there is no paper.  Wake up you are paying for the WORDS.

author: legallyblonde
title: Greedy B---- Greedy Amazon
body: Well the book was so-so.  Ms. Rowling should stick to her original audience. I actually borrowed the book since I would never pay $17.99 for

author: Amazon Customer
title: READ THE SAMPLE BEFORE YOU SHELL OUT THE BIG BUCKS
body: Okay, so I haven't read the whole book.  Just like if I step in dog doodoo I don't need to get down and roll around in it, the first sample chapters of Rowlings' new book told me that it isn't something I'm eager to read.  You can decide for yourself whether it is an astounding step forward in her writing career or simply an astounding step.  For the price you will pay for this book, be sure you are going to enjoy it and there is doubt on that topic.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Boycotting because of price!!
body: Absolutely silly to pay $18 for a file download.  Greedy! Greedy! Greedy!  Shame on you... There is just one file, already produced (and not well based on other reviews).  Cost pennies to send.... I refuse to buy and so should others.  Send a message!

author: J. Friedman
title: I READ THIS BOOK!  Purchased at the bookstore. SPOILERS!
body: J.K. Rowling is best known for her Harry Potter Series. This book is an attempted shift at an adult novella. The book itself comes in an orange and red hardcover binding. The cover is a bit visually disappointing - a simple black "x" in a checkbox with vintage lettering indicating the title.

author: Martin Olvera
title: Way too expensive !!
body: I was very excited to buy this book for my Kindle Reader but...$17.99...are you kidding ? In this economy ??

author: Computer Geek
title: Was excited to buy until I saw the price for ebook.  Boycotting
body: After reading the news that this was released, I immediately went to Amazon to buy it.  At $17.99 for an e-book though, it simply isn't worth it, especially for a new, unproven series that isn't Harry Potter.  I will be waiting until the price falls or I can get it from the library as an ebook.  (Removed unhelpful comments about how much money JK needs)

author: Amazon Customer
title: gave it a chance and actually READ it
body: I purchased "The Casual Vacancy" last night on my Kindle Fire.  As a student, I don't have a lot of spare money for books and the price was slightly deterring, but I grew up with Harry Potter and absolutely love JK Rowling's writing, so I decided to go ahead and buy it.
